webTitle: G2: Joan Bakewell on early learning

fields.headline: Life's first lessons
fields.standfirst: Joan Bakewell on early learning
fields.trailText: Joan Bakewell on early learning.
fields.body:
The post-Christmas thank-you letters have been arriving and I'm impressed that, in these hectic times, children are still writing them. The spidery child's writing struggling to stay joined up, to stay in line and fill somewhere vaguely in the middle of the page, bear witness to real effort having been made.

Oh, how I myself hated having to write them. Receiving them now not only gives a warm glow of granny-pride, but reminds me of the agonies of my own childhood and how a wretchedness out of all proportion could spring from such a mild duty. The idea was always to have them written before New Year's Day, but I recall with shame how they lingered on to haunt me until the end of January. They are life's first lesson that "there's no such thing as a free lunch."

My youngest grandchild had her first "music lesson" recently. Maisie is just one year old. This, I know, may be enough to appal those currently worried that formal education is creeping ever earlier and stealing childhood from the very young. There are others - mostly parents - who believe a child's curiosity is such that early games with letters, in a mood of play, are an easy first step to reading. Maisie's music lesson falls into this category.

A young mother who is keen on music has round to her home some 10 children to share in musical play. She provides simple, small instruments - shakers, drums, a xylophone - and everyone sits round on the floor learning to listen. She teaches them to distinguish long sounds - a jug pouring water - from short sounds - something dropped into water.

And there is even a taste of classical music, too. Since just being alive is a learning process in itself, there is nothing but gain in young toddlers being given this kind of encouragement. The danger occurs when ambitious parents sign up their children for formal lessons with the glint of grades and exams in their eye.

Some of my grandchildren do Kumon, the system of maths-teaching in the home that instils by regular practise an easy familiarity with numbers and tables. In my schooldays, we chanted them until we could recite them in our sleep. Even today, faced with a tricky calculation, I still resort to a quick chant. But all that went out of fashion, condemned as rote learning with all its attendant ills (what were they exactly?).

Now Kumon is sneaking back into the same territory, though they perhaps wouldn't admit it. The daily paper - 10 minutes' worth of sums to fill in - teaches both an understanding of how numbers work and also, by regular repetition, a rapid recall of what they amount to. This makes children comfortable with maths at school. My grandchildren nominate maths as their favourite subject - probably because they get the sums right.

But there is another benefit of equal value. Ten minutes in a quiet room, with no distractions, no talk, no television, no moving around, teaches concentration - a skill worth having in almost any job, in any walk of life. Classrooms in today's schools, especially in primary schools, can't provide that utter quiet. Most homes probably can, and most mothers welcome it - not to mention grandmothers.

But there is an issue on which the generations differ in my family. The Commons select committee on education has just declared the idea of allowing childminders to smack as "totally unacceptable". I agree: I am totally against assaulting children - especially when they're so small! My own children don't share my hard line - yet I tell this story in their favour.

W e are 10 at table in a rather nice seaside restaurant, the sort that is modest enough but also gets into the food guides. One four-year-old grandchild is playing up in a thoroughly obnoxious way. We offer distractions, games, chatter . . . Nothing works. Other diners are eyeing us with loathing. Suddenly, her father has had enough, snatches her up in his arms and bundles her outside. They are gone some while.

They return all smiles, the child completely transformed, laughing and telling of how they have been to see the sheep in the field. What happened? On leaving the restaurant, she'd been given a short sharp smack on the legs and told why. There'd been tears, then cuddles, then their own special adventure together. Whatever had been griping her at the start was gone and she was now transformed into the adorable child we all love.

So was her father wrong? I couldn't find the argument that condemned him.

webTitle: Analysis: once children are settled, welfare considerations may ensure they stay

fields.headline: Once children are settled, welfare considerations may ensure they stay
fields.trailText: Alan and Judith Kilshaw's best hope of keeping the six-month-old twin girls they "bought" over the internet is to stave off any court hearing into their case for as long as possible.
fields.body:
Alan and Judith Kilshaw's best hope of keeping the six-month-old twin girls they "bought" over the internet is to stave off any court hearing into their case for as long as possible.

In a string of cases, the courts have allowed couples who brought foreign-born children into Britain in questionable circumstances to keep the children.

By law, the court's first consideration is the welfare of the child, and once a young child has become settled with a family the trauma of removal generally outweighs any other considerations.

So if Flintshire county council, which covers the north Wales area where the Kilshaws live, has doubts about the couple's fitness as parents, it will need to act quickly.

Keith McDonogh, director of education and children's services, said: "We are awaiting clarification from the Home Office, the Foreign Office and the national assembly on the international implications of this case.

"We have also requested from the family copies of the American adoption documentation and we would expect them to provide us with this as soon as possible. If it is not presented to us, we will be seeking legal advice on how to obtain it."

The council's most likely route if it decides to act is to take care proceedings, arguing that the children have suffered or are likely to suffer emotional damage.

They were looked after for two months by Richard and Vickie Allen of San Bernardino, California, who claim the babies' birth mother, Tranda Wecker, originally placed the twins with them before the Kilshaws agreed to pay more to the facilitator who advertised the children over the internet.

The Kilshaws have had the twins since December 1 and adopted them in Arkansas on December 22 after a journey from California to St Louis, Missouri, for their birth certificates and another drive to Little Rock, Arkansas.

Ms Wecker said yesterday that she had lied to get round the 30-day residence requirement for an Arkansas adoption by giving her aunt's Little Rock address as her own.

But even if fraud or irregularities were proved, the adoption would not necessarily be set aside.

In one case, a struck-off solicitor sentenced to four years in prison for mortgage fraud succeeded in adopting a child from El Salvador by concealing charges then pending. The couple supported their application with a private home study report, which did not include a police check on the applicants.

A high court judge approved the adoption although he held that the parents had contravened adoption law.

Allan Levy QC, an authority on child law, said that if he acted for the Allens, he would advise them to make the children wards of court in England as soon as possible. That would enable them to get a quick court hearing and get investigations started. If they had custody rights in California they could also take steps under the Hague convention to get the girls returned to them under reciprocal agreements between participating countries, he said.

webTitle: Blair demands law on internet baby trade

fields.headline: Blair demands law on internet baby trade
fields.trailText: Prime minister attacks 'deplorable' sale of babies to British couple and promises action to deny recognition of some adoptions.
fields.byline: John Carvel, Helen Carter  and Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles
fields.body:
Early legislation to prohibit the "deplorable" practice of trading children for adoption was promised by Tony Blair yesterday after the case of the British couple who bought American baby twins through an internet site run by a Californian child broker.

The prime minister said a bill in the current parliamentary session would remove bureaucratic obstacles that were hindering adoptions in this country and stop parents bringing in children adopted irregularly abroad.

"I think everyone feels it is absolutely deplorable that children are traded in this way. Adoption should always be about the interests of the child first," he told MPs after the issue was raised in the House of Commons by the Tory leader, William Hague.

Mr Blair also promised to implement the Adoption (Intercountry) Aspects Act. The act was passed in 1999, but was not brought into force. It could be used to refuse recognition to adoptions conducted abroad in countries that do not comply with the Hague convention which gives protection to children in these circumstances.

The prime minister's spokesman said: "He thinks the whole business is disgusting and shares people's horror that you can buy and sell children as a commodity and end up in a situation where you have got two sets of people who claim to be these children's parents."

Alan and Judith Kilshaw, the couple who paid thousands of pounds to adopt twin baby girls they found on the internet, said Mr Blair's criticism of their behaviour was unacceptable as they had not broken any laws.

Mrs Kilshaw stormed out of a television studio in the middle of a live interview for ITV at lunchtime.

She pulled out her earpiece leaving her husband Alan behind. When asked: "Where do you go from here?" she replied: "I go home and clean my house, clean my carpets, get a duster and give it a good Hoover and go through the place." She then stood up and said: "Last comment. I'm not doing any more for you," before walking away.

She is understood to have been responding to newspaper reports that her farmhouse in Buckley, north Wales, is dirty and unkempt.

Mrs Kilshaw already has four other children - two girls Louisa, 22, and Caley, 18, from her first marriage and James, seven, and Rupert, four, from her second marriage.

The prime minister's intervention caused a flurry in Whitehall among officials who did not expect adoption legislation until after the election and were still consulting on proposals in a white paper published in December.

Adoption charities were puzzled as to why Mr Blair thought legislation was needed so quickly. It is already an offence to trade children for adoption within the UK and the government can refuse recognition to adoptions conducted abroad in countries with slacker standards.

Felicity Collier, chief executive of the British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering, said the big political problem was whether to derecognise adoptions in the US. "The government has to decide: are we going to take the US off the designated list of countries whose adoptions we accept if they do not ratify the Hague convention," she said.

The FBI is carrying out what is described as a "preliminary inquiry" into the adoption, according to a spokeswoman. The inquiry, based at the bureau's Los Angeles office, is likely to focus on the exact circumstances in which the children were handed over and to examine who paid what and to whom.

An FBI spokeswoman said that the issue of internet adoption was not the subject of the inquiry as many firms now use the internet to advertise their services in this way.

The inquiry comes as concern is being voiced by children's organisations in the US about the growing practice of internet agencies offering babies for adoption.

The babies offered are usually from a small group of countries that still have loose adoption laws. They include Guatemala, China, Russia, India and Vietnam. Within the US, there are varying standards on how adoptions are undertaken with some states, such as California, enforcing strict policies of checking that children have not been sold while other states, such as Arkansas, have less stringent laws.

Social services in Flintshire, where the Kilshaws live, launched an investigation as soon as they heard of the adoption. On Tuesday, social workers unsuccessfully tried to contact the couple, who were holed up in a hotel near Cheshire giving interviews to journalists.

Yesterday, two social workers conducted a preliminary assessment of the children.

fields.headline: Phillips smashes Palace uprising
fields.trailText: Crystal Palace kept this tie alive into extra-time before bowing to their Premiership visitors.
fields.body:
Crystal Palace kept this tie alive into extra-time before bowing to their Premiership visitors.

Despite losing Daniele Dichio, sent off after picking up two yellow cards in his 14-minute cameo, Sunderland went through to a fourth-round tie at home to Ipswich with goals from Kevin Phillips and Kevin Kilbane.

Thomson's goal, struck from a Hayden Mullins cross, came after Thomas Sorensen had denied Dougie Freedman on a late one-on-one and was reward for Crystal Palace's refusal to accept defeat after being overrun for much of the second half.

Although Sunderland's rise to second place in the Premiership meant they began this replay as favourites, they must have arrived with some trepidation. They were beaten here by Palace in a Worthington Cup quarter-final last month and were relegated on this ground in 1997.

Yet they started promisingly, looking the more composed team, and could easily have taken the lead. When Alex Kolinko raced out of his area to hack clear of Kevin Phillips, Alex Rae had a chance to lob into an empty net from around 30 yards but missed the target.

Gradually, though, Palace found their range and began to dominate. Mixing some neat passing with plenty of long balls designed to exploit the pace of Clinton Morrison down the centre or the speed of the lively Latvian Andrejs Rubins on the left flank, they might have scored three times in quick succession.

After Morrison and Stephen Thomson had wasted chances, it needed a fine save from Thomas Sorensen to prevent Morrison converting a Rubins cross from close range. When Sunderland fell behind to Morrison's 17th goal of the season, it was scarely a surprise.

The visitors were responsible for their own misfortune, Rae misdirecting a header that sent Morrison through. The 21-year-old striker, wanted by Jamaica and Ireland and on this form perhaps soon by England, finished powerfully from just inside the area.

Palace continued to press, more than matching Sunderland's renowned strength and work-rate in midfield and looking particularly dangerous whenever they got the ball wide and crossed.

All the same, it needed two good saves by Kolinko to deny Sunderland an equaliser before half-time. Having first stopped a Phillips snap-shot after Niall Quinn had set up the chance, he impressively blocked another Phillips effort with his body.

The Quinn-Phillips combination should have brought Sunderland level inside two minutes of the restart, but the England striker clipped the ball wide from close range. That was the start of virtual one-way traffic from Sunderland as Palace, forced to reorganise when Fan Zhiyi went off injured, lost their zip.

Yet for all their dominance the Premiership side were struggling to find a way past Kolinko.

Having denied Gavin McCann, the Latvian saved well from Darren Williams and Don Hutchison. A moment of magic from Quinn, though, turned the tie on its head.

Chesting the ball down with his back to goal the Irishman spun and sent a brilliant volley into the corner. A minute later Phillips shook off Hayden Mullins and, unpeturbed by his earlier misses, sent a low shot in off the post.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Kiwomya strikes twice to resurrect Rangers
fields.trailText:
QPR 2 - 1 Luton
Kiwomya strikes twice to resurrect Rangers.
fields.body:
Chris Kiwomya scored two timely goals for Rangers, once to force extra-time when he scored the equaliser for Rangers in the 90th minute and then a killer goal to destroy Luton's dreams in the 112 minute.

Lee Mansell, making his debut for Luton, had given his team the lead after 59sec. Mansell, an 18-year-old YTS trainee, exchanged passes with Andrew Fotiadis on the edge of the QPR penalty area before striking a sweet volley in off the post, leaving Rangers goalkeeper Ludek Miklosko with no chance.

Rangers forced this replay with a penalty in the last minute of the first encounter. They could hardly have expected Luton's retaliation to be so rapid in this renewal of hostilities.

Luton's latest much-trained side surprisingly showed a much greater understanding throughout the first half, a feature evident from that first minute. As the home defenders hesitated, Mansell and Andrew Fotaidis exchanged passes before the youngster shot from 12 yards, the ball clipping Miklosko's righthand post on the way in.

Only two minutes later, however, Luton's injury jinx struck again, the 21-year-old defender Stuart Fraser being carried off after lengthy treatment following a shuddering collision with the QPR midfielder Matthew Rose. The victim was quickly replaced by Jude Stirling.

Luton were rarely threatened in this period, with the goalkeeper Mark Ovendale enthusiastically rubbing his hands to keep warm; by the interval he had still not been tested. All Rangers had to show in this barren period was an eighth-minute shot from Sammy Koejoe that was deflected for a fruitless corner and a highly ambitious overhead kick by Peter Crouch from the edge of the area that floated past the far post.

The home frustration was clear as the cat-calls rang out around the half-hour mark and shortly afterwards, as the Rangers management clearly felt the need to be more ambitious, they threw on another forward, Kiwomya , in place of the defender Chris Plummer, who had earlier almost presented Luton with a second goal as he slipped and let in the eager Fotaidis. But he wasted this inviting opportunity by blazing wide of the near post.

If Kiwomya was seen as an answer to Rangers' prayers, the home side were in for a long wait. Twice within six minutes just after the interval the former Arsenal forward wasted two opportunities. First he sent a tame shot straight towards Ovendale for the Luton goalkeeper's first save of the match. Then after Koejoe nodded forward, Kiwomya volleyed over from inviting range.

Luton were pushed back by Rangers belated initiative but so many home attacks petered out as they continued to loft the ball towards Luton defenders' heads. When the visitors managed to break free Clarke Carlisle ended one promising counterattack with a late challenge as Fotiadis sprang clear.

Kiwomya then made up for his earlier misses with his equaliser.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

All Rangers had to show in this barren period was an eighth-minute shot from Sammy Koejoe that was deflected for a fruitless corner and a highly ambitious overhead kick by Peter Crouch from the edge of the area that floated past the far post. The home frustration was clear as the cat-calls rang out around the half-hour mark and shortly afterwards, as the Rangers management clearly felt the need to be more ambitious, they threw on another forward, Kiwomya , in place of the defender Chris Plummer, who had earlier almost presented Luton with a second goal as he slipped and let in the eager Fotaidis. But he wasted this inviting opportunity by blazing wide of the near post. If Kiwomya was seen as an answer to Rangers' prayers, the home side were in for a long wait. Twice within six minutes just after the interval the former Arsenal forward wasted two opportunities. First he sent a tame shot straight towards Ovendale for the Luton goalkeeper's first save of the match. Then after Koejoe nodded forward, Kiwomya volleyed over from inviting range. Luton were pushed back by Rangers belated initiative but so many home attacks petered out as they continued to loft the ball towards Luton defenders' heads. When the visitors managed to break free Clarke Carlisle ended one promising counterattack with a late challenge as Fotiadis sprang clear. webTitle: Uefa to send in the big guns over transfers

fields.headline: Uefa to send in the big guns over transfers
fields.trailText: A top-level Uefa delegation will square up to Fifa's president Sepp Blatter as the row over the future of the transfer system rumbles on.
fields.body:
A top-level Uefa delegation will meet Fifa's president Sepp Blatter tomorrow to make clear in no uncertain terms its anger at Fifa's "unilateral" behaviour in the row over the future of the transfer system.

Uefa's president Lennart Johansson, chief executive Gerhard Aigner and vice-president Per Omdal will tell Blatter that Fifa must withdraw the document it submitted last week to the European Commission outlining a new transfer system and agree instead to a joint set of proposals.

Blatter will be warned that if Fifa fails to do so, Uefa will register an interest in the transfer issue, allowing it to open direct negotiations with the commission.

Anger towards Fifa, and Blatter in particular, was plain at a heated meeting of Uefa's executive committee which concluded in Nyon, Switzerland, yesterday. It was unanimously agreed to oppose Fifa's proposals, with Aigner adding that Uefa had offered to meet the relevant European commissioners to explain its concerns.

"We have told the commission Fifa's paper does not represent the view of European football and we will not accept it," he said. "We have written to the commission that this non-paper cannot be considered the basis for future negotiations."

In a blunt statement, the executive committee declared: "This document remains with the EC and as a result continues to undermine the negotiation process and the status of the original proposals.

"The new Fifa document creates a distinction between the European Union/European Economic Area and the rest of the world which is potentially damaging to European football.

"The Fifa document includes proposals which weaken two of the key principles for European football, namely contract stability and the development of an effective system of compensation."

Uefa is angry at Fifa's plans, which would allow players to terminate their contracts at three months' notice or with "just cause" such as not agreeing with the manager's tactics. It has a mandate from the top 13 leagues in Europe to go it alone unless Fifa agrees that the document presented jointly to the commission last year is taken as the basis for discussions.

"It is essential for the unity of the game that all future negotiations are based on the original Fifa-Uefa transfer task force proposals," Uefa insisted.

Arsenal's vice-chairman David Dein spelled out Uefa's opposition to the Fifa proposals. "If this were allowed to happen it would kill the game as we know it," he said. "It is totally impractical and unworkable. The sport would become unmanageable. I simply don't understand the rationale."

The commission insists it will go on examining the proposals put to it by Fifa, even though the world governing body insisted they were not concrete. Fifa will be under severe pressure tomorrow to withdraw them in favour of what Uefa calls "an agreed way forward".

Uefa's director of communications Mike Lee stressed: "We are looking for a constructive way forward, but Uefa must ensure that the overall interests of European football are being properly represented."

fields.headline: Scotland's paupers in breakaway bid
fields.trailText: Eight First Division clubs in Scotland are seeking to break away from the Scottish L:eague to form a second tier of Premier League.
fields.body:
The financial plight outside Scotland's top flight has prompted eight First Division clubs to seek a divorce from the 111-year-old Scottish League in order to form a second tier of the Premier League.

Representatives from the clubs, who met yesterday at Clyde's Broadwood stadium, say they are facing economic ruin under the current set-up. Two of the eight - Airdrie and Greenock Morton - are already run by administrators. The others are Livingston, Falkirk, Inverness Caledonian Thistle, Raith Rovers, Clyde and Ross County, and they are likely to be joined by Partick Thistle, who lead the Second Division and are expected to win promotion. The only First Division teams not represented were Ayr United and Alloa Athletic.

"If the First Division clubs are not around then I think Scottish football will be poorer for it," said the rebel group's spokesman Dominic Keane, the chairman of the First Division leaders Livingston. "But the way things are at the moment, I think there's a strong possibility of that happening. We need change.

"We're not out to destroy Scottish football; we're here to try and protect full-time professional football."

The Scottish Premier League was created in 1998 by the country's top clubs. The Scottish League continued to govern Scotland's three other senior divisions.

The SPL has been a huge commercial success, securing about £80m in sponsorship and television revenue for its 12 clubs. At the same time the lower divisions have suffered badly because of the meagre commercial income available under the Scottish League. Aside from Airdrie and Morton, several clubs are pruning their squads because of huge debts.

The SPL says it is aware of developments and will discuss the situation at its next meeting.

fields.headline: Celtic eye Gers fan Collymore
fields.trailText: Stan Collymore hopes to rejoin Celtic's manager Martin O'Neill in an deal that would see Tommy Johnson move to Valley Parade, despite having declared his love for Rangers.
fields.body:
Stan Collymore's remarkable talent for controversy could undermine his proposed move to Celtic even before he arrives in Scotland for talks.

The out-of-favour Bradford City striker, who turns 30 on Monday, hopes to rejoin Celtic's manager Martin O'Neill in an deal that would see Tommy Johnson move to Valley Parade. But Collymore has already guaranteed himself a feisty Glaswegian welcome by declaring his love for Rangers.

"Without wishing to be contentious, how could I ever sign for Celtic when my soft spot is, and always has been, for the blue half of Glasgow?" he told Rangers Monthly in October.

"Everyone down south is either a Celtic or Rangers fan and I am a Gers supporter. It stems from my mid-teens when I never seemed to have the Rangers shirt off my back. At the time guys like Terry Butcher were moving to Glasgow, and the Graeme Souness era really settled it for me.

"Even now I always look for Rangers' results every weekend, and if anyone asks me who I support it's definitely Rangers. I would love to play at Ibrox one day."

As only he can, Collymore appeared to have had a change of allegiance last night. "Celtic would definitely appeal to me," he said. "They are a massive club and obviously geared up for success."

Collymore has been surplus to Jim Jefferies' requirements at Bradford since the manager decided that, along with Benito Carbone and Dan Petrescu, the talented but troublesome striker would not be a part of the fight against relegation. Celtic are due to have further talks with Bradford today.

Monaco, meanwhile, have made discreet inquiries of Manchester United about Mark Bosnich's availability.

The French club want to increase the competition on their regular goalkeeper Stéphane Porato, and Bosnich's advisers confirmed last night they were aware of the interest. Bosnich has been ostracised by Sir Alex Ferguson after several fall-outs with the United manager and is now effectively the club's fourth-choice goalkeeper.

The United defender Ronny Johnsen is likely to miss the next three months after another operation yesterday on the injured knee that has troubled him for the past 18 months.

Roberto Mancini arrived in Leicester yesterday for talks with the manager Peter Taylor about spending the rest of the season on loan at Filbert Street. Mancini, 36, resigned from his coaching role at Lazio after Sven-Goran Eriksson's departure.

"If I get to play in the Premiership, I will try to do spying reports for Sven-Goran on the English stars who I'll face on the pitch," said Mancini.

Birmingham City have been told by the Football League to reschedule their Worthington Cup semi-final second-leg clash with Ipswich Town at St Andrews to January 30 because of police concerns over a clash with Aston Villa's home game against Leeds.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Vassell's volley gives Villa a leg up
fields.trailText:
Aston Villa 1 - 0 Newcastle
Vassell's volley gives Villa a leg up.
fields.body:
While Aston Villa await their Angel they might as well shine up a halo or two. Last night John Gregory's team earned themselves an FA Cup fourth-round tie at home to Leicester City with a fluent display of passing against a Newcastle side weakened by injuries and suspensions.

The winning goal came early in the second half when Darius Vassell, Villa's most impressive forward on the night, met a centre from Paul Merson to loop a shot beyond the reach of Steve Harper.

It was hard to judge how much the FA Cup meant to either side compared with what they might still hope to achieve in the Premiership. And after all, Villa and Newcastle had between them played patsies to the winners in the previous three finals.

Certainly on a bitter west midlands evening, and with Villa Park not two-thirds full, the thought of Cardiff in the spring seemed an even longer way off than Wembley in May. Newcastle, moreover, were without two of their brighter sparking plugs in Kieron Dyer and Nolberto Solano, both of whom were suspended.

The occasion, then, was hardly conducive to inspired football, and as both sides appeared intent on thumping the ball forward long and high the spectacle did not immediately capture the imagination. Yet with Vassell looking sharp up front and worrying Newcastle's defenders with his pace, Villa might well have taken an early lead.

In fact the striker had two chances inside nine minutes. Lee Hendrie's free-kick found him in space and in range but Vassell's first shot hit the near post and his second was headed off the line by Aaron Hughes.

Undaunted, the lively Vassell showed good control and vision in setting up opportunities for Dion Dublin and Hendrie, neither of whom could produce a shot to disturb Harper. Even so Villa, now getting the ball down and exposing Newcastle with adroit passing allied to astute movement, were starting to dictate the pattern and tempo of the match.

Without Dyer and Solano Newcastle could not help but look limited. The attacking combination of Shola Amoebi and Kevin Gallacher was not short of scoring potential but Bobby Robson's midfield was being forced too deep to give the pair meaningful support.

On the half-hour a neat first-time movement caught Newcastle bare on the left but when the ball was laid back to Merson he could only get a toe-end to it. From Villa's point of view the evening was acquiring a disturbingly familar look, with superior football let down by a chronic inability to score.

The loss of Gareth Southgate following a collision with Amoebi - the Villa captain was replaced in defence by Gareth Barry right on half-time - made little difference to the shape of the play. Villa continued to enjoy the bulk of the possession while Newcastle largely hung around hoping to catch them on the break.

Villa finally broke the deadlock five minutes into the second half when Barry swept the ball out to Merson on the right. His long centre brushed the head of the last Newcastle defender, Warren Barton, who had come on for Gary Speed, and Vassell, running in from the left, beat Harper with a looping shot off his thigh.

As he had not scored for 27 months, Vassell was presumably not overmuch concerned about which part of his anatomy was responsible. Nor were his team.

Newcastle now had to move forward in greater numbers which meant more space in their half for Villa to exploit. On the hour Hendrie and George Boateng did so to good effect, surging through with a double exchange of passes only for Hendrie to drag his shot wide. Almost at once, though, James had to dive at the feet of Gallacher near the edge of Villa's penalty area.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Home and Away
fields.standfirst: Milly settles in to life in Coogee, has a close encounter with an insect, meets the brat pack, and goes for an interview
fields.trailText: Milly settles in to life in Coogee, has a close encounter with an insect, meets the brat pack, and goes for an interview
fields.body:
Thursday was my first full day alone again now that Josh has gone back, and I though I'd be at a loss for what to do. As it happened, myself and two others from the hostel went to watch the Adidas International tennis at the Olympic park, Sydney so I didn't have time to feel sorry for myself! We arrived early and stayed 'til late so we could enjoy as much tennis as possible plus have a look round the park itself.

The whole place, like Sydney, is incredibly clean and has all the signs of having been recently done up for the Olympics - there was plenty going on throughout the day. As for the tennis, some of the highlight matches included Martinez winning, Lleyton Hewitt winning (backed by an extremely enthusiastic and biased Aussie crowd), and Anna Kournikova in a doubles match. I think it's safe to say a lot of the crowd weren't interested in her tennis ability, which I would imagine gets pretty frustrating (not that I'd complain if I was her!)

The next day myself and Brian, a fellow hosteller from LA, walked to Randwick just outside of Coogee to make use of the university's internet facilities. There are some advantages to looking like a student. We spent the afternoon on the beach - my first trip there since arriving in Coogee - which is pretty remarkable as it's only two minutes walk away. We played electronic chess and Brian wasn't too happy that I managed to beat him - still it entertained me!

That evening we went to Centennial Park to watch a 'Moonlight cinema' showing - films shown at night on a large outdoor screen. But the evening didn't run as planned. The film we thought we were going to see was Grease, so after a few minutes of watching a film about insects we were beginning to get concerned.. . it wasn't until I plucked up the courage to ask someone that we realised our mistake. Yes Grease was on, but in Adelaide. The film we'd been watching was Microcosmos - literally, a film about insects.

The next evening I went into Sydney to listen to a huge free jazz concert held in the domain (a large grassy area). It was brilliantly well attended, the bands were lively and funky, which made for an enjoyable evening drinking wine on the grass. Despite the fact I didn't get to bed until 4am, I was rudely awakened at 8am by the arrival of a new room-mate, Steve, who just would not stop chatting despite my monosyllabic replies. Deciding that now I was awake I may as well get up, myself, Steve and our Canadian room-mate Gabrielle headed out for a walk and a stop at the Clovelly hotel just along the coast. I got a lot of stick that day for insisting on drinking orange juice, but to be honest, drinking every day wears thin very quickly - although some people seem to manage it!

That evening a whole group of us stayed in to watch videos. It made a pleasant change, although the whole thing seems a far cry from the exhilaration of the blue mountains - I've promised to treat myself to do something special every so often so I don't start to feel like I could easily be in England.

Monday was incredibly hot - 40C. I headed into Sydney to try and avoid the heat by getting some jobs done such as open-ending my flight ticket - I no longer have any set dates on it - and to get a tax code for when I start work. Even the city was pretty sticky so I was quite glad for the cool of the evening and the chance to test out my improved cooking skills with spaghetti bolognese. Well, it's a start!

A group of us from the hostel took the bus to Palm Beach, the location for the filming of Home and Away. Besides seeing the beach itself, we were disappointed by how little there was there. I suppose we'd hoped to see some filming, even though I'm not a fan myself, but all we saw was the shooting of a deodorant advert for the UK - so when it comes out remember I saw it first!

In the evening Brian and I made another attempt to watch a film at Centennial Park. Over the last few days he's been insisting that The Breakfast Club was a classic film and was shocked that I hadn't heard of it (I think he put it down to me being English). I doubted his judgement, but I have to admit it was brilliant - an 80s brat-pack classic. We'd even brought a proper picnic this time so it definitely compensated for the last one - and hopefully put an end to the days of teasing we've had from the others at the hostel!

I'm looking forward more than anything to the time when I can move on again - and I've made the decision to go to New Zealand and the South Island, largely due to many people who've emailed me to tell me it's unmissable. But until then, I'm going to have to settle down a bit - but hopefully not too much!

Yesterday morning I had a job interview at a local hotel. I was fairly nervous, as the hotel is both incredibly posh and enormous, but the interview itself was surprisingly relaxing. In fact the interviewer was English and more keen to talk about how much better than Australian pubs English ones are! I felt pretty good about it, but I won't find out until next week if I got it - I'll let you know.

That afternoon I started making myself a proper temporary Australian resident - I got a phone and a bank account, which made me feel disturbingly like I was setting up a short-term life here - and a pretty good life all in all. Later there was a barbeque to celebrate a hosteller's last day. That's one good thing about hostel life - there constantly seems to be something to celebrate! Despite it raining heavily - see, it does rain here too - it was a fun afternoon and a great feed. Australians definitely have the right idea with barbeques, you can find public ones everywhere, so anybody at any time can get together and have a 'barbie'.

There is an incredibly strong backpacker presence in Coogee, and there have been plenty of local newspaper reports complaining about their behaviour and particularly that of the English. I think some people just see travelling as a way to party every night without restrictions and don't consider that other people actually live in these places too.

'Til next week (hopefully employed) milly

Despite the fact I didn't get to bed until 4am, I was rudely awakened at 8am by the arrival of a new room-mate, Steve, who just would not stop chatting despite my monosyllabic replies. Deciding that now I was awake I may as well get up, myself, Steve and our Canadian room-mate Gabrielle headed out for a walk and a stop at the Clovelly hotel just along the coast. I got a lot of stick that day for insisting on drinking orange juice, but to be honest, drinking every day wears thin very quickly - although some people seem to manage it! That evening a whole group of us stayed in to watch videos. It made a pleasant change, although the whole thing seems a far cry from the exhilaration of the blue mountains - I've promised to treat myself to do something special every so often so I don't start to feel like I could easily be in England. Monday was incredibly hot - 40C. I headed into Sydney to try and avoid the heat by getting some jobs done such as open-ending my flight ticket - I no longer have any set dates on it - and to get a tax code for when I start work. Even the city was pretty sticky so I was quite glad for the cool of the evening and the chance to test out my improved cooking skills with spaghetti bolognese. Well, it's a start! A group of us from the hostel took the bus to Palm Beach, the location for the filming of Home and Away. Besides seeing the beach itself, we were disappointed by how little there was there. I suppose we'd hoped to see some filming, even though I'm not a fan myself, but all we saw was the shooting of a deodorant advert for the UK - so when it comes out remember I saw it first! In the evening Brian and I made another attempt to watch a film at Centennial Park. Over the last few days he's been insisting that The Breakfast Club was a classic film and was shocked that I hadn't heard of it (I think he put it down to me being English). I doubted his judgement, but I have to admit it was brilliant - an 80s brat-pack classic. We'd even brought a proper picnic this time so it definitely compensated for the last one - and hopefully put an end to the days of teasing we've had from the others at the hostel! I'm looking forward more than anything to the time when I can move on again - and I've made the decision to go to New Zealand and the South Island, largely due to many people who've emailed me to tell me it's unmissable. But until then, I'm going to have to settle down a bit - but hopefully not too much! Yesterday morning I had a job interview at a local hotel. I was fairly nervous, as the hotel is both incredibly posh and enormous, but the interview itself was surprisingly relaxing. In fact the interviewer was English and more keen to talk about how much better than Australian pubs English ones are! I felt pretty good about it, but I won't find out until next week if I got it - I'll let you know. That afternoon I started making myself a proper temporary Australian resident - I got a phone and a bank account, which made me feel disturbingly like I was setting up a short-term life here - and a pretty good life all in all. Later there was a barbeque to celebrate a hosteller's last day. That's one good thing about hostel life - there constantly seems to be something to celebrate! Despite it raining heavily - see, it does rain here too - it was a fun afternoon and a great feed. Australians definitely have the right idea with barbeques, you can find public ones everywhere, so anybody at any time can get together and have a 'barbie'. There is an incredibly strong backpacker presence in Coogee, and there have been plenty of local newspaper reports complaining about their behaviour and particularly that of the English. I think some people just see travelling as a way to party every night without restrictions and don't consider that other people actually live in these places too. 'Til next week (hopefully employed) milly

fields.headline: Dot.coms and dot.gones
fields.standfirst:
High-profile UK internet ventures which have bitten the dust
Special report: dot.coms and dot.gones
fields.trailText:
January 18: High-profile UK internet ventures which have bitten the dust, by Amy Vickers.
Special report: dot.coms and dot.gones
fields.body:
Letsbuyit.com
Service
Founded by Swedes in 1999, Letsbuyit.com, like boo.com expanded at a rate of knots across Europe. Described as a "co-buying" network, the idea was that consumers would group together to secure bulk discounts on products. By the end of 2000, it was operating in 14 European countries, but sales were abysmal. Personalities
None, unless you count those annoying ants from the TV ads.
Pluses
In-yer-face advertising did lead to widespread awareness of the brand name, although no one actually knew what Letsbuyit.com did.
Minuses
The curse of the Swedish dot.coms. Letsbuyit's imminent failure can be put down to three factors: bad timing, over-ambition and a questionable business model. Letsbuyit worked on minuscule margins.
Life span
January 1999 (launched in April 1999) - January 2001
Money raised/spent
Raised £42m when it floated in July 2000, but was something of a spendthrift, burning through £5m each month and spending £62m on advertising.
Who lost out
BSkyB invested £10m, ProSieben £20m (16%), venture capitalist Speed Ventures (6.6%).
Reason given for closure
Nothing yet. Bankruptcy proceedings begin on Friday January 19.
Job Losses
350
Active subscribers
100,000

Breathe

Service
Started out as a free internet access provider. Followed Freeserve into unmetered access and moved heavily into mobile internet services
Personalities
Phone millionaire Martin Dawes
Situation now
Put into receivership in December. Saved by Great Universal Stores on January 8 which bought the technology and assets for £1.4m. Breathe will continue to provide internet access to its customers
Pluses
Provided a good service and had built up a good brand name
Minuses
Built its strategy around Wap, which has been slow to take off
Lifespan
Has been going since 1998
Money raised/spent
£40m (estimate)
Who lost out
Martin Dawes, Chase Capital Partners and 3i
Reason given for closure
Unable to secure fresh funding. Breathe had to pull out of a stock market flotation that would have valued it at about £100m, and raised the necessary cash
Potential job losses
Laid off 60, GUS saved 80
Registered subscribers
More than 500,000


Thestreet.co.uk

Service
Financial news website
Personalities
Martin Baker and Nils Pratley from Sunday Business
Pluses
Had lots of money and what seemed to be a successful US business behind it
Minuses
The needs of financial news community were already being catered for by other websites and publications
Lifespan
February-November 2000
Money raised/spent
£10.6m
Who lost out
TheStreet.com, Barclays, Chase Capital and 3i
Reason given for closure
Thestreet.com's falling valuation and a new strategy to save cash; getting the business to profitability
Job Losses
64
Registered subscribers
180,000

eVentures

Service
The incubator arm of venture capital firm ePartners
Personalities
Mark Booth, former boss of BSkyB - now CEO of ePartners
Pluses
Was backed by media giants News Corp and Softbank
Minuses
Business model was based on bringing successful US dot.coms to the UK. Only these businesses weren't not entirely successful
Lifespan
August 1999-December 2000
Money raised/spent
£70m
Who lost out
News Corp and Softbank
Reason given for closure
"The opportunity to bring US companies to the UK and find an exit for them is too tough right now"
Job Losses
12 at closure plus lay-offs in the summer
Registered subscribers
n/a

Switch2.net

Service
A streaming media portal for the youth market, or according to the PR, an internet-based entertainment network
Personalities
Former Loaded editor Tim Southwell was editorial director
Pluses
Saw the possibility of streaming cool video
Minuses
Was about a year too early for the expected broadband streaming boom
Lifespan
May-November 2000
Money raised/spent
£4m
Who lost out
Edison Interactive; Open, which was reported to own 10%
Reason given for closure
Southwell said he believed Switch2 was a year ahead of its time. EIB said it just restructuring but would now concentrate all its energies on its music operation Done & Dusted, investing £8m in it the next year
Job Losses
30
Registered subscribers
n/a


uTravel

Service
Travel website
Personalities
None
Pluses
None
Minuses
Operating in a crowded marketplace
Lifespan
August 1999-November 2000
Money raised/spent
£10m
Who lost out
United News & Media
Reason given for closure
Crowded marketplace. UN&M decided it should focus just on business-to-business
Job Losses
18
Registered subscribers
46,000


Easier.co.uk

Service
Online estate agent
Personalities
None
Pluses
Service was free, ie no commission
Minuses
Service was free, ie not much of a revenue stream. it soon became a very crowded marketplace
Lifespan
November 1999-November 2000
Money raised/spent
£11.2m on AIM in February
Who lost out
Founders Steve Rist and Steve Butcher are believed to have put money in. Shareholders who bought into the company when it floated in February
Reason given for closure
Currently up for sale but it is a very crowded marketplace and the outlook is not good
Job Losses
n/a
Registered subscribers
70,000 users

Ready2

Service
Online fashion style and beauty guide
Personalities
Society girls Susanna Constantine and Trinny Woodhall
Pluses
The founder were willing to do anything to make it work, including stripping off for an eye-catching ad campaign
Minuses
It lacked a revenue stream given that it didn't sell anything on the website
Lifespan
December 1999-November 2000
Money raised/spent
£5m
Who lost out
Atlas Venture, Whitney & Co
Reason given for closure
Couldn't persuade any VCs to give them any more money. The founders said the business was hibernating for the winter of dot.com discontent
Job Losses
28
Registered subscribers
33,000


Wowgo

Service
Teenage girls' website
Personalities
Former ad guru Michael Gold and former restaurateur David Peller
Pluses
Pulled in a seemingly strong management team
Minuses
No revenue stream. The worst thing about teenage girls is that they don't have credit cards and they do love to hang around shopping malls
Lifespan
June-November 2000
Money raised/spent
£6m
Who lost out
Unilever, Durlacher, incubator Eureka
Reason given for closure
Market conditions. Founders went into hiding
Job Losses
50
Registered subscribers
Unknown


Boxman

Service
Pan-European retailer of CDs
Personalities
Shareholders include Swedish pop band Roxette, Suggs and Ace of Base
Pluses
Was in the top three of European online CD retailers
Minuses
Had ambitious expansion and acquisition plans. Got too far ahead of itself assuming further fundraising would be easy
Lifespan
August 1997- October 2000
Money raised/spent
£55m
Who lost out
GE Equity, Bernhart Arnault, Roxette, Suggs, Ace of Base, Durlacher, ABN Amro and Viking Internet among others
Reason given for closure
Ran out of money, couldn't find any more
Job Losses
120
Registered subscribers
Unknown

UrbanFetch

Service
Ultra-fast delivery of anything from gourmet food to beauty products and electronics in cities
Personalities
None
Pluses
Everybody loved the service
Minuses
Spent far too much cash and undercut heavily on the premise that it would build up long-term brand loyalty
Lifespan
June-October 2000 (UK service)
Money raised/spent
£70m for international expansion
Who lost out
Vantage Point Venture Partners
Reason given for closure
Closed its UK operation and consumer division in the US after merger negotiations with competitor Kozmo fell apart and no rescue money was in sight
Job Losses
60 staff in London office. 100 in US
Registered subscribers
100,000 people on customer database


Worldsport

Service
Series of websites for a host of sports federations
Personalities
Alan Callan, a tax exile and one-time business manager for Led Zeppelin; former Daily Mirror deputy editor Brendon Parsons; Mike Miller from BBC Sport; and Adrian Metcalfe, former British athlete and event producer at the Atlanta Games
Pluses
Managed to sign up an estimated 150 deals with various sports organisations and federations
Minuses
Too esoteric. It turned out there were not enough badminton or water polo fans. The site also lacked support from a big-name federation such as Uefa
Lifespan
February-October 2000
Money raised/spent
Rumoured to be about £13m. Believed to have racked up debts of £7m
Who lost out
Alan Callan, unknown who main backer was
Reason given for closure
Too much debt, no one would invest
Job Losses
178
Registered subscribers
unknown


Learnfree.co.uk

Service
Times Educational Supplement website for parents
Personalities
None
Pluses
Had the backing of the Times Educational Supplement
Minuses
Was ultimately owned by internet sceptic Rupert Murdoch. Marketplace soon got very crowded Lifespan
March-October 2000
Money raised/spent
£5m
Who lost out
News International
Reason given for closure
market too crowded. News International changed its strategy
Job Losses
12
Registered subscribers
Unknown


Dressmart

Service
Pan-European online men's fashion retailer
Personalities
John Cleese was paid to appear at the Oslo launch party
Pluses
Very ambitious
Minuses
Investors lumped it together with boo.com. It had poor range of products that were very expensive
Lifespan
April 1998-August 2000
Money raised/spent
Raised £13m and ended with debts of £2m
Who lost out
Rumoured backers included the king of Sweden and a former Swedish prime minister. Funding came from AP-fund (a Swedish pension fund) and VC group Emerging Technologies
Reason given for closure
Market conditions
Job Losses
80
Registered subscribers
Unknown


ClickMango

Service
Health and beauty site
Personalities
Joanna Lumley. Tiny Rowland's son, Toby, was one of the founders
Pluses
Had Joanna Lumley as its public face. Founders were very frugal
Minuses
Run by two young inexperienced public schoolboys, trying to compete in a very small marketplace. Monthly turnover was only £4,000
Lifespan
October 1999-September 2000
Money raised/spent
£3m (allegedly in eight days)
Who lost out
Atlas Venture, Rothschild
Reason given for closure
The health e-retail market failed to take-off
Job Losses
25
Registered subscribers/users
Not many


Currantbun.com

Service
ISP and portal for the Sun newspaper. Rebranded as bun.com in October 1999 in an attempt to go upmarket. Failed
Personalities
Ellis Watson, Johnny Ball fronted the ad campaign
Pluses
Could cross-promote, and did, in the Sun and News of the World
Minuses
Johnny Ball fronted the ad campaign. Ultimately owned by internet sceptic Rupert Murdoch. ISP marketplace soon got very crowded
Lifespan
April 1999-March 2000
Money raised/spent
Upwards of £10m. 'Sold' the business to World Online in March
Who lost out
News International
Reason given for closure
Wasn't core business. ISP market got too crowded
Job Losses
Around 20. Some were moved across to News Network to work on the-sun.co.uk and FiredUp
Registered subscribers
Claimed 450,000 users, but more like 200,000


URwired

Service
Video games site
Personalities
Mattias Lamotte, a 29-year-old who still lived with his parents and used their money to set up the business
Pluses
Er, well, he tried
Minuses
Was too dependent on parents. Venture capitalists didn't take him seriously. Business model dependent on future distribution method of games
Lifespan
January 1999 - August 2000
Money raised/spent
£1.8m
Who lost out
His family
Reason given for closure
"Because Sony decided to delay the launch of Playstation 2"
Job losses
24
Registered subscribers
Unknown


Boo.com

Service
Clothing retailer. The Titanic of dot.com start-ups. Boo promised it all. Free shipping and free returns, a site in seven languages and 18 countries
Personalities
Swedish co-founders Ernst Malmsten and Kajsa Leander
Pluses
They looked good, well at least picture editors thought so
Minuses
Boo.com spent investors' money with zeal but generated little revenue. Got carried away by affluence - money was lavished on transatlantic flights and numerous other perks. Website launched six months late. Lots of technical problems
Lifespan
November 1999-May 2000. Relaunched early October 2000 albeit as a shadow of its former self
Money raised/spent
£115m in 18 months, leaving debts of £25m
Who lost out
Bernard Arnault, Goldman Sachs, JP Morgan and an investment arm of the Benetton Group
Reason given for closure
Burnt through all the money and needed more
Job Losses
220
Registered subscribers
Who knows?

webTitle: Charities driven to follow the collaboration road

fields.headline: Charities driven to follow the collaboration road
fields.trailText: Pressure from funders, financial problems and concern over duplication are all leading charities to consider partnerships and mergers. Patrick McCurry investigates
fields.body:
Partnerships and mergers within the voluntary sector have been moving steadily up the agenda of many charities. Drivers for closer links between organisations include pressure from funders and growing media and public concern about duplication of services.

Increased pressures on fundraising mean a growing number of charities face financial problems and are seeking to share infrastructure costs or, in some cases, merge with a larger organisation.

But despite these pressures, closer collaboration is proving to be a slow process thanks to the practical difficulties or pooling resources, and reluctance by many trustees and managers to give up their independence.

Des Palmer, a consultant who has studied mergers in the carers' sector, says: "Often, staff in charities find it difficult to move outside their set roles and many staff are keen to protect what they see as their domains."

He adds that he was involved in a joint application from two charities for lottery funding recently: "It took applications twice as long as usual because one of the problems was who would take overall responsibility for the project. There is always a danger in joint working that unless someone is put in overall charge, responsibilities fall between two stools."

Yet there are a growing number of joint working examples and of merger talks. One of the most important was the announcement by the Cancer Research Campaign and the Imperial Cancer Research Fund recently that they were considering a merger.

Another example is the partnership between the homeless charities Shelter and Crisis in the government-funded Millennium Plus homelessness project. In this, Shelter provides the advice to homeless people and Crisis the accommodation.

Rebecca Carpenter, project manager of Millennium Plus, said: "We set up the partnership because we both felt we had different expertise and it was important to focus on that rather than each try and do everything."

But the partnership has not been without its problems. "It's not been easy because different organisations have different ways of working."

She stresses the importance of being clear from the outset what the goals of the collaboration are and that there must be agreed protocols governing practical issues such as how often meetings will be held between the two organisations, what they will cover and who will chair them.

"We've both learned a lot from the experience and once you've built a relationship with another voluntary organisation it's much easier to repeat it in the future," says Ms Carpenter.

Sharon Norrish, director of consulting and development at Charities Aid Foundation, said the organisations have had more enquiries from charities about collaboration and merger in the past year than ever before.

She said: "One of the main drivers is that charities want to organise their resources more effectively and that often means a partnership of some form. Whether it leads to merger is another question."

Such partnerships range from sharing infrastructure costs, such as a finance manager or computer system, to delivering a charity's mission through an alliance with another voluntary organisation in a similar field.

"We've had enquires from a large variety of charities, ranging from healthcare and care of the elderly to recreational areas like caving clubs," said Ms Norrish.

She believes the increasing experience many charities have of working in partnerships with statutory organisations such as health authorities or councils is giving them the confidence to consider alliances with other voluntary groups.

Yes there is still a long way to go, argues Mr Palmer: "You can find examples of joint working and merger in the sector but they tend to be few and far between and there's a lot more potential for collaboration in campaigning, lobbying and service provision."

Drivers for closer links between organisations include pressure from funders and growing media and public concern about duplication of services. Increased pressures on fundraising mean a growing number of charities face financial problems and are seeking to share infrastructure costs or, in some cases, merge with a larger organisation. But despite these pressures, closer collaboration is proving to be a slow process thanks to the practical difficulties or pooling resources, and reluctance by many trustees and managers to give up their independence. Des Palmer, a consultant who has studied mergers in the carers' sector, says: "Often, staff in charities find it difficult to move outside their set roles and many staff are keen to protect what they see as their domains." He adds that he was involved in a joint application from two charities for lottery funding recently: "It took applications twice as long as usual because one of the problems was who would take overall responsibility for the project. There is always a danger in joint working that unless someone is put in overall charge, responsibilities fall between two stools." Yet there are a growing number of joint working examples and of merger talks. One of the most important was the announcement by the Cancer Research Campaign and the Imperial Cancer Research Fund recently that they were considering a merger. Another example is the partnership between the homeless charities Shelter and Crisis in the government-funded Millennium Plus homelessness project. In this, Shelter provides the advice to homeless people and Crisis the accommodation. Rebecca Carpenter, project manager of Millennium Plus, said: "We set up the partnership because we both felt we had different expertise and it was important to focus on that rather than each try and do everything." But the partnership has not been without its problems. "It's not been easy because different organisations have different ways of working." She stresses the importance of being clear from the outset what the goals of the collaboration are and that there must be agreed protocols governing practical issues such as how often meetings will be held between the two organisations, what they will cover and who will chair them. "We've both learned a lot from the experience and once you've built a relationship with another voluntary organisation it's much easier to repeat it in the future," says Ms Carpenter. Sharon Norrish, director of consulting and development at Charities Aid Foundation, said the organisations have had more enquiries from charities about collaboration and merger in the past year than ever before. She said: "One of the main drivers is that charities want to organise their resources more effectively and that often means a partnership of some form. Whether it leads to merger is another question." Such partnerships range from sharing infrastructure costs, such as a finance manager or computer system, to delivering a charity's mission through an alliance with another voluntary organisation in a similar field. "We've had enquires from a large variety of charities, ranging from healthcare and care of the elderly to recreational areas like caving clubs," said Ms Norrish. She believes the increasing experience many charities have of working in partnerships with statutory organisations such as health authorities or councils is giving them the confidence to consider alliances with other voluntary groups. Yes there is still a long way to go, argues Mr Palmer: "You can find examples of joint working and merger in the sector but they tend to be few and far between and there's a lot more potential for collaboration in campaigning, lobbying and service provision."

webTitle: Oxfam joins El Salvador earthquake rescue mission

fields.headline: Oxfam joins El Salvador earthquake rescue mission
fields.standfirst: Audio: Rachel Stabb of Oxfam reports on aid efforts in El Salvador
fields.trailText: A specialist Oxfam team has flown out to El Salvador to help the rescue operation after last week's earthquake. The charity has also sent out £100,000 worth of sanitation equipment and shelters. The team will be sending an exclusive diary to SocietyGuardian.co.uk during its stay.
fields.body:
A specialist Oxfam team has flown out to El Salvador to help the rescue operation after last week's earthquake. The charity has also sent out £100,000 worth of sanitation equipment and shelters. The team will be sending an exclusive diary to SocietyGuardian.co.uk during its stay.

"Clean water is the biggest need at the moment," said Joost Martens, Oxfam's representative in Latin America. The equipment, which includes tap stands, pipes and water tanks, can be set up quickly.

Communication and transport are very difficult at the moment and the team will be evaluating where its efforts can best be spent. Reports suggest that as well as the giant mudslide that affected Santa Tecla, five other areas in El Salvador have been severely hit by the earthquake.

Oxfam has been working in El Salvador for more than 30 years. It will be spending the next few days assessing the longer-term needs of the country to rebuild peoples' lives and communities.

 The flight was funded by the Department for International Development

webTitle: BBC1's celebrity cooks rustle up just 5m

fields.headline: BBC1's celebrity cooks rustle up just 5m
fields.trailText: TV overnights: Just one in five viewers tuned into BBC1's peaktime schedule with just one programme Celebrity Ready Steady Cook, starring Wayne Sleep and Nigel Benn, drawing more than 5m, reports Daniel Rogers
fields.body:
BBC1's peak-time schedule turned in a lacklustre performance last night with only Celebrity Ready Steady Cook creeping over the 5m viewer threshold.

The mid-week National Lottery draw, the series Escape to the Sun and Castaway failed to excite viewers receiving audiences of 4.3m, 4.5m and 4.7m respectively. On average the three programmes attracted a 19.3% audience share.

ITV performed considerably better with Holidays from Hell 3 - a new batch of dream trips that became nightmares - hitting 10m viewers (42% share).

Meanwhile the return of hard-hitting cop series The Vice attracted 8.4m viewers (38% share) and Coronation Street hit 13.9m viewers (57% share.)

ITV's relatively strong performance comes in the week it has promised advertisers to concentrate on maintaining an average peak-time lead of 7.4 percentage points over BBC1.

Elsewhere Channel 4's Embarrassing Illnesses series continued to haemorrhage viewers. Its revisit to breast conditions attracted 1.6m viewers (7% share), less than half the 3.4m viewers that its special on 'perfect breasts' attracted two weeks ago.

Channel 5's repeat introducing reality show The Mole received 0.9m viewers (8% share.)

webTitle: Grobbelaar loses court battle with The Sun

fields.headline: Grobbelaar suffers libel defeat
fields.trailText: Appeal court judges have thrown out a verdict that the ex-soccer star had been libelled by the paper, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Former Liverpool soccer star Bruce Grobbelaar suffered an embarrassing defeat in the appeals court today, when judges threw out a verdict that he had been libelled by The Sun newspaper.

Three appeal judges upheld a challenge by The Sun to a jury verdict that Mr Grobbelaar had been libelled by allegations of match fixing and threw out his £85,000 damages award.

One of the judges said the original verdict in August 1999 "represents a miscarriage of justice which this court can and must correct".

Former Sun editor Stuart Higgins said today: "I am absolutely delighted that I have been vindicated and, more importantly, that a brilliant team of Sun journalists has been vindicated.

"My only regret is that the great George Carman was not there to notch up another brilliant triumph on his bedpost of victory."

Not only will Mr Grobbelaar lose his damages, he also faces having to pay his own legal fees - estimated at more than £1 million.

But Mr Grobbelaar's solicitor David Hewitt insisted he would fight on to clear his client's name.

He said: "In our view, it is quite wrong for the Court of Appeal to substitute its findings for those of jurors who had the opportunity of hearing the evidence and evaluating the witnesses.

"This is not an end to the matter. We will be petitioning the House of Lords for leave to appeal."

The High Court libel action is the third time Mr Grobbelaar has declared his innocence of match-fixing to a jury after The Sun published a series of damning articles about him in November 1994.

The civil action follows two trials at Winchester Crown Court in 1997, the first of which ended in deadlock.

This resulted in Grobbelaar being cleared of conspiracy, along with ex-Wimbledon stars John Fashanu and Hans Segers and businessman Richard Lim.

fields.headline: Drivel at PMQs: no debate
fields.trailText: The latest excuse offered by the Labour party for its non-cooperation with pre-election televised            debates is that there's no need - we already have a sufficiency of illuminating debate in prime            minister's questions, staged each Wednesday for 30 minutes. But these are not reported in full by            parliamentary sketchwriters, and like so many other apathetic voters I have neglected either to turn            up at the House of Commons or to consult Hansard.
fields.body:
The latest excuse offered by the Labour party for its non-cooperation with pre-election televised debates is that there's no need - we already have a sufficiency of illuminating debate in prime minister's questions, staged each Wednesday for 30 minutes. But these are not reported in full by parliamentary sketchwriters, and like so many other apathetic voters I have neglected either to turn up at the House of Commons or to consult Hansard.

Perhaps it is true, and these regular sessions really do supply quite as much in the way of stimulating political ratiocination as anyone could reasonably expect. Certainly it is hard to believe that anyone could read some recent transcripts of these encounters and not be moved - to pity or contempt if nothing else.

I was particularly struck by a PMQs script from July 12, in which Blair and Hague's exchanges resembled the conversation of some hellish married couple determined to provoke or score a point with every rejoinder, whatever the cost to truth, good taste or personal dignity. Hague accused Blair of indecisiveness on the euro. "The prime minister goes on about his five economic tests on the euro. But the test that really matters is of leadership on the euro, and he has failed it . . ." "Oh," began Blair, with an intonation that may be readily imagined, "so the right honourable gentleman is going to keep the pound now. Tell me - is that a guarantee or just something he intends doing?"

The following week's tiff started with a Hague taunt about Blair's wish (stated in a leaked memo) for "eye-catching initiatives". "Can anyone think of anything more pathetic," he jeered. "Winston Churchill did not ask for blood, sweat and eye-catching initiatives." Oooh! Still, Blair usually gets his own back, with ethical knobs on. "I think we know what the right honourable gentleman is doing," he sniffed during a tussle over clause 28. "It is exactly the same as he did over the asylum issue - it is pandering to prejudice and it is not a pretty sight." Touche! "That was a nice lecture from Mr Eye-catching Initiative himself, wasn't it?" retorted Hague.

Of course, the pressures of political office mean the exchanges cannot always be this elevated. More recently the prime minister was content to label Hague "crazy" and, in a forced attempt at topicality, "the weakest link". Perhaps you had to be there.

fields.headline: I think it's all over, already
fields.trailText: The historian Macaulay once invented a public official called the Registrar of Foregone Conclusions. If such an office existed today, it would be busy recording Labour's triumphant re-election on May 3, and the subsequent execution at the hands of his stricken party of the Conservative leader.
fields.body:
The historian Macaulay once invented a public official called the Registrar of Foregone Conclusions. If such an office existed today, it would be busy recording Labour's triumphant re-election on May 3, and the subsequent execution at the hands of his stricken party of the Conservative leader.

But not everyone subscribes to this view. The most sceptical dissenter of all - how could it be otherwise? - is William Hague. The 2001 election, he cheerfully forecast last week, would be 1970 all over again.

Hague was nine at the time and still at his desk at Greasbrough Junior school, whereas I was slaving away on the Guardian news desk. So I thought it might be worth setting out for him the true nature of what happened then. He is certainly right in thinking that on June 18 Heath and his party rose miraculously from the coffin into which public opinion seemed to have bolted them. The Guardian had even published a feature exploring the likely processes by which Heath would be dumped as soon as the contest was over.

Almost all our reporters out in the sticks were confident that Wilson would win. When our man in the East Midlands submitted a survey suggesting a swing to the Tories, there were anguished arguments over whether such an obvious misjudgment ought to be printed. (It was). NOP on June 12, with Labour 12 points ahead, was a stake through Heath's heart; Marplan, with an 8.7 point lead on the morning before polling day, was another.

The weather was fine throughout the campaign. We tumbled in from the pub on the sweltering evening of June 18 ready and in most cases eager to write the story of Wilson making prime ministerial history: three terms in a row. The first result, from Guildford, was a bit of a turn-up: a 6% swing to the Tories. Poor old Guildford: out of step with the nation again. But then came the two Wolverhampton seats, with swings of 9% against Labour. Even allowing for the Enoch Powell effect, it was clear now that Heath was going to be the Lazarus of the night, leaving Wilson as its Queen Anne.

So, for Wilson read Blair; for Heath read Hague? Begins to sound plausible, doesn't it. But before William Hague starts believing himself, it is worth pointing out one or two little disparities. Until the run-up to polling day, Wilson's government had been foully unpopular. The Conservative lead over Labour on Gallup averaged 18 points through 1968 and 15 the following year. A year before the election, 76% of respondents expected the Tories to win; only 9% gave Labour a chance. Of 26 seats defended in byelections in 1966-70, Labour lost 15, 12 to the Tories. In February - no further from that election then we are from May - the Conservatives had a seven-point lead, and 54% thought they would win; only 25% fancied Labour. The fact that Labour was even in with a chance looks almost as remarkable now as its unexpected defeat.

The context this time is thoroughly different. Labour since 1997 has consistently been registering leads in the polls unprecedented since polling began. That pattern was only interrupted by the autumn of discontent, when the people backed the hauliers and farmers against the government, and the Tories nosed ahead for a moment; but only a moment. Where Wilson lost 15 byelections in just under five years, this government hasn't lost any, making it the first in 45 years (except for the short-lived outfit of February 1974) to keep a clean sheet. And though Heath's personal ratings were often not very bright, William Hague's have been even worse. People may not like or trust the Blair government much any more, but so far they like Hague and the Tories still less.

Why 1970 turned out as it did has never been clear. The most likely explanation is that people whose faith in Labour's competence to run the economy had begun to recover as the election approached became convinced in the course of the campaign that the Tories were still the more competent managers. Labour's complacency may also have turned off voters. "Wilson nauseating on TV" I noted on June 1. "Half smile, sickly softening of voice whenever he invokes 'the sick, the disabled', worthy of Uriah Heep." Some blamed an ungenerous, over-prudent budget. One minister attributed defeat to "the bug in Gordon Banks's tummy". England's ace goalkeeper missed the World Cup match against Germany on June 14 because he was ill; his deputy let in a soft goal which gave the Germans the match. That made rather a hole in the feel-good factor.

Are there any sporting disasters pending? Probably. But otherwise that comforter to which Hague is clinging looks to be made of straw. Sorry to be such a spoilsport.

fields.headline: Boycott angry at departure claims
fields.trailText: Express editor Rosie Boycott is furious about claims emanating from management sources that she is about to resign with a lucrative deal. By Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
Express editor Rosie Boycott is furious about claims emanating from management sources that she is about to resign with a lucrative deal.

Friends say that contrary to "management spin", she has not clinched a deal with Express owner Richard Desmond.

Rumours were rife today that Ms Boycott would resign today or tomorrow once a disagreement over a confidentiality clause had been resolved.

"There is no issue of a confidentiality. There has been no deal. All they are trying to do is paint Rosie as a greedy money grabber who is just holding out for more cash. She has not even had an offer from Desmond," said a source.

It is thought the first written offer of a pay-off was made to Ms Boycott's lawyers this afternoon.

It is also believed she is on one year's notice, not two as previously claimed.

"All this could be over in 10 minutes but Desmond is dragging it out," said a source.

"It is like crawling up a mountain and we are not even a base camp. It may have changed by tonight but there is no dialogue at the moment."

It is thought the Daily Star editor Peter Hill will take over as acting editor.

Ms Boycott's departure will end weeks of speculation about her future.

This follows the controversial takeover of the paper by OK! publisher and porn magazine magnate Richard Desmond

It was widely accepted that Ms Boycott, a liberal supporting feminist, would quit following Mr Desmond's arrival.

Her views are incompatible with those of a proprietor whose publishing empire includes 38 soft porn magazines, including Asian Babes and Big Ones.

However, sources say pornography is not the issue at stake.

Sources claim Boycott is quitting because, before Christmas, Desmond asked her and her deputy Chris Blackhurst to draw up plans to make up to 100 staff redundant.
