fields.headline: Blair rejects TV election debate
fields.standfirst: Decision provokes taunts of 'chicken'
fields.trailText: Tony Blair last night infuriated William Hague and Charles Kennedy by rejecting proposals by the BBC and ITV for a three-way televised election debate on the grounds that Britain's democratic combat is lively enough without one.
fields.body:
Tony Blair last night infuriated William Hague and Charles Kennedy by rejecting proposals by the BBC and ITV for a three-way televised election debate on the grounds that Britain's democratic combat is lively enough without one.

The prime minister's decision not to risk such a high-profile contest had been widely expected but prompted taunts that Mr Blair is what the Tory leader dubbed "a real chicken".

Mr Kennedy said the prime minister was unwilling to debate without the "400 cheerleaders" who sit behind him in the Commons.

Mr Hague even urged the broadcasters to go ahead with the two proposed debates anyway. "If Tony Blair still refuses to show, we'll just leave an empty chair with a big sign of 'coward' for where Tony Blair would have sat if he'd had the guts to turn up," he said.

The televising of prime minister's questions in the Common, and the robust traditions of parliamentary and media debate in Britain, were used to justify Labour's refusal to take part in the American-style debates.

"The UK is not electing a president and our constitutional positions are entirely different," Mr Blair's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, told reporters yesterday.

Mr Campbell had raised broadcasters' hopes in December, saying publicly that the idea was "perfectly good in principle" and that "my hunch is that at some stage it will happen".

But he and other senior advisers concluded this week that media obsession with election "process" - of which two TV debates would be an obsessive example - would only serve to detract from Labour's policy message.

"We want to concentrate on the issues which really matter to people," the Scottish secretary, John Reid, told Channel 4 News last night.

Peter Mandelson and Labour pollster Philip Gould are said to have backed the "withdrawal with dignity" strategy. Labour was determined to say yes or no before the campaign starts, probably in late March, to stop the issue being a distraction - as it was in 1997 when John Major made a desperate plea for a confrontation on TV.

Party officials and MPs engaged in campaign planning on all sides were therefore not surprised that Mr Blair would find an excuse. "There's not much in it for him," said one.

But the reasons given in a letter by Labour's communications director, ex-BBC journalist Lance Price, are those that have always existed.

"By comparison with other democracies, we have in the UK very lively political and media debate on a constant basis," he said.

Ministers will also be available to voters to discuss all the relevant issues outside "the Westminster village" in the election, he promised.

Blair aides denied that George W Bush's success in America - where he had been seen as the underdog but performed well in debates - was a factor.

The TV proposals had raised the prospect of legal challenges - demanding equal time or other restrictions - by smaller parties, notably the Scottish Nationalists.

When Mr Blair took part in a "meet the prime minister" session with voters in Leeds on ITV last month, the SNP successfully complained to the Independent Television Commission because a byelection was taking place in Falkirk at the time.

The BBC and ITV had buried their differences in favour of two debates - one chaired by David Dimbleby on the BBC, the other by his brother, Jonathan, on ITV. But despite Mr Kennedy and Mr Hague saying they would agree without condition, the January 31 deadline loomed without real negotiation taking place.

Mr Price explained: "Much is made of that fact that US presidential candidates hold TV debates. But we are not the US."

fields.bodyText: Tony Blair last night infuriated William Hague and Charles Kennedy by rejecting proposals by the BBC and ITV for a three-way televised election debate on the grounds that Britain's democratic combat is lively enough without one. The prime minister's decision not to risk such a high-profile contest had been widely expected but prompted taunts that Mr Blair is what the Tory leader dubbed "a real chicken". Mr Kennedy said the prime minister was unwilling to debate without the "400 cheerleaders" who sit behind him in the Commons. Mr Hague even urged the broadcasters to go ahead with the two proposed debates anyway. "If Tony Blair still refuses to show, we'll just leave an empty chair with a big sign of 'coward' for where Tony Blair would have sat if he'd had the guts to turn up," he said. The televising of prime minister's questions in the Common, and the robust traditions of parliamentary and media debate in Britain, were used to justify Labour's refusal to take part in the American-style debates. "The UK is not electing a president and our constitutional positions are entirely different," Mr Blair's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, told reporters yesterday. Mr Campbell had raised broadcasters' hopes in December, saying publicly that the idea was "perfectly good in principle" and that "my hunch is that at some stage it will happen". But he and other senior advisers concluded this week that media obsession with election "process" - of which two TV debates would be an obsessive example - would only serve to detract from Labour's policy message. "We want to concentrate on the issues which really matter to people," the Scottish secretary, John Reid, told Channel 4 News last night. Peter Mandelson and Labour pollster Philip Gould are said to have backed the "withdrawal with dignity" strategy. Labour was determined to say yes or no before the campaign starts, probably in late March, to stop the issue being a distraction - as it was in 1997 when John Major made a desperate plea for a confrontation on TV. Party officials and MPs engaged in campaign planning on all sides were therefore not surprised that Mr Blair would find an excuse. "There's not much in it for him," said one. But the reasons given in a letter by Labour's communications director, ex-BBC journalist Lance Price, are those that have always existed. "By comparison with other democracies, we have in the UK very lively political and media debate on a constant basis," he said. Ministers will also be available to voters to discuss all the relevant issues outside "the Westminster village" in the election, he promised. Blair aides denied that George W Bush's success in America - where he had been seen as the underdog but performed well in debates - was a factor. The TV proposals had raised the prospect of legal challenges - demanding equal time or other restrictions - by smaller parties, notably the Scottish Nationalists. When Mr Blair took part in a "meet the prime minister" session with voters in Leeds on ITV last month, the SNP successfully complained to the Independent Television Commission because a byelection was taking place in Falkirk at the time. The BBC and ITV had buried their differences in favour of two debates - one chaired by David Dimbleby on the BBC, the other by his brother, Jonathan, on ITV. But despite Mr Kennedy and Mr Hague saying they would agree without condition, the January 31 deadline loomed without real negotiation taking place. When a president is retiring, neither candidate is known until that time". Citing the regular exchanges at question time, Mr Price added: "Over the course of a parliament these exchanges span many hours and cover many issues ... nothing comparable exists in the USA. "Indeed, the recent Bush-Gore debate was the first substantive encounter between them. That cannot be said of the prime minister, William Hague and Charles Kennedy."

fields.headline: Your Christmas turkeys
fields.standfirst: We asked what was your worst Christmas present ever... here are some of your entries
fields.trailText: We asked what was your worst Christmas present ever... here are some of your entries
fields.body:
My worst present was my whole Xmas stocking. Two ties (one comedy/musical), one pair of fake Versace pants, and a jar of aubergine pickle. I know I'm a just-turned-30 new dad, but did my wife have to rub it in?
Joe Hallgarten

The worst Christmas present I ever had was a local history of Auchterarder - a place I've never been to.
James Andrew

My mother gives two kinds of presents: solid thoughtful ones and small worrying ones. Last year the small worrying presents included parsley-oil breath freshener pills. This year we got several pine-scented car deodorizers and little pillows of cedar shavings. I'm afraid she's trying to tell us something.
Martha Bridgegam, USA

Had a bit of a run recently... Christmas 1998... Q) What to get for grandad, the man with everything? A) As a last resort, a Body Shop shaving kit. Christmas 1999... the exact same shaving kit, re-wrapped in exactly the same paper is returned to me. Christmas 2000... a brand spanking new B-B-Q... excellent except it was from relatives who have visited my 4th floor, balcony-less, roof-terrace-less apartment... thanks!
Chris Raybould

Relatives - you've got to love them. No, you've GOT to love them, it's the law, even in the face of the most blatant "Don't love me" provocation. My darling auntie, as thoughtful as ever, asked me what I wanted for Xmas. Well, being a young go-ahead kind of a thing, I'd just got hold of a new dinky mobile to keep my cool and social life flowing nicely. "Something for my new moby, auntie" I foolishly hinted, forgetting that the devil's in the detail, and expecting a nice new fascia, hands free kit or some such.
Come Christmas Day and a nicely wrapped box dropped in my lap from auntie. Ripping open the wrapping with none-too-indecent haste, my eyes alighted on... a piece of plastic. With some blue liquid and two other bits of grey plastic trapped inside, and a gap.
Hmm... turning it over, I found the instructions: "Oil Dolphin Phone Holder", and next to them a sticker professing the true quality of my gift: "Made in China" (no offence to your chinese readers, but come on...). So, there's these two proto-dolphins trapped in blue oily stuff, and a gap for the phone... which is far too big for my new dinky phone, which just slips over every time I try to prop it up to show my new gift doing it's thing. Much as my smile kept slipping every time I tried to convince my aunt that I was pleased with her gift. This 'product' is a true challenge to the taste of the e-Bay audience. Roll on next year...
Shashi Desai

One of the worst and most soul destroying Christmas presents I ever received was a jar of pickled onions from my grandmother. This is after spending a year cleaning, organising and running the fairly large B&B she owns on the west coast of Scotland. She thought her present was genuinely generous as she thought I liked 'that kind of spicy food'.
Martin Lockhart

The worst Christmas present that I ever received was a few years ago when we were very short of money. I didn't expect very much for Christmas - a small box of chocolates maybe. But on Christmas Eve hubby said mysteriously that he had to go out for an hour or so. On his return he was smiling like the cat that had got the cream and eventually admitted that he had been out to get my present. I deduced from his manner that he had got me something I really wanted.
On Christmas morning everyone opened their presents - but there was nothing there for me. Hubby smiled mysteriously again and said it wasn't in the house and I'd have to find it. I wrapped up warmly and began a systematic search of the coal-shed, garage, garden and hut. An hour later, fingers becoming numb, I pleaded for a clue. He informed me it was in the car. Silly me! I searched the glove compartment, under the seats, in the boot - nothing! "Try under the bonnet" he hinted. Curiously I opened the bonnet - and there it was: a new battery, plumbed in. He still can't understand why I didn't say thank you!
Amanda Fergusson

My least favourite present this year was a pack of dishtowels, dusters and a can of polish. However, it didn't come from my husband as a heavy hint that I needed to brush up on my housekeeping skills, but from my eight year old daughter who had saved very very hard from her pocket money. I told her it was the nicest present I had ever received and in that moment I meant it too!
Irene Hunter

My worst Christmas present was an umbrella that wouldn't stay up - ever. On it's first outing it collapsed on me, knocking my glasses off,which subsequently broke on the pavement!
Robert Ridler

We were poor when I was a lad. And we were Northern. Poor And From Wigan is quite a different poor to Poor And From Kent. Now we have set the scene, cast back your mind to (about) 1980. BigTracks. I had spent an entire year dropping hints to my parents that I needed a BigTrack. BigTrack was the robot which could, using its catterpillar tracks, follow such simple commands as to go forward 5, turn right 90, and then forward 2. These simple joys would be lost on the children of today, but back then it was the very pinnacle of electronic advances. The advert on TV displayed BigTrack fetching an apple for Dad, and carrying drinks a la R2D2 in Star Wars - Return of the Jedi. It was not merely a toy, but a companion, and a highly desirable item. The rather indelicate hints I had landed had hit home, and my mother did no doubt, set out with all good intentions to buy me my prize. What I did in fact receive was a BigTrack trailer. Mum never really seemed to understand why a trailer without a BigTrack isa disappointment. She tried to sedate me with the half-promise that perhaps next Xmas I might get a BigTrack to pull my Trailer. In fact, in January she stood on my accessory and broke it. I never did receive the vehicle.
Christian Stretton

My auntie usually sends something rather strange (ballet books for my brother and tank books for me!) but this year was particularly special...she gave me a pepper pot but no salt to match! I wonder if I should ask around the rest of my family to see if someone else has been given the salt cellar, so we can re-unite the set!
Colette Healy

One year I was lucky enough to get this beautifully wrapped gift from a new(ish) boyfriend. What can it be I thought, chocolates , jewellery, cd player etc.? No. It was a plastic "can crusher"! The idea being if you crush your baked bean or soup cans before putting them into your dustbin you can fit more rubbish in the bin. Exciting git, I mean gift, or what? Needless to say our relationship did not blossom!
Elaine Henderson

My worst ever Christmas gift that I received was this year! Last year my husband walked away with a packet of Biro's from my sister and a book on trains. This year it was his family's turn to surprise me with some interesting gifts. The most notable of which I received with deep thanks from his Nan. The main gift came neatly wrapped in last years paper. As I gently unwrapped the package so as not to "spoil the paper for next year" I came across a glimpse of blue material peeping out from behind the offending scent.
As I delved further time stood still as I pulled out a blue 1950's half pinny - the sort that housewives with the white picket fences and perfect children might have used to make homebaked cookies. To add insult to injury was the detail on the pinny of a wonderful swirly red and black pattern, which could only be described as "Margaret Ledbetters' housecoat". I am a full-time working Mother, I teach, and I have a career. Somewhere here was the message that I should be staying at home. I smiled, said thank you and went upstairs to gently place it into a charity bag along with a collection of other items from Christmas.
Sarah Cooper

My worst Christmas present was a laced thong and bra set, being male did not help, but all was resolved when I found my brother had mixed up the gift tags. One good thing is that at least I know what my sister in law is wearing or is it?
Andy Davies

Year before last from work colleagues...the Gary Glitter story on video.
Martin Lampen

I received a nightie from my boyfriends mum for an age 12-13 girl when I am 24 years old.
Lucy Merrick

My worst ever Christmas present was a dusty roll-on deodorant from my mother-in-law. It turned out she'd forgotten to buy me a present, so she'd ransacked her bathroom cabinet for some unused bottle or jar. Either she was oblivious to the implied insult orshe just didn't care. The last two years she's given me a set of pink towels (for our blue bathroom) and a necklace that turns my neck green, so I'm beginning to suspect the latter.
The very same Christmas my sister-in-law gave me a cafetiere. It was actually quite nice, apart from the sticker indicating that it was a promotional freebie from the company she worked for! It must be some sort of family tradition.
Sue Plenty, Belgium

My nan hasn't got much money so when she asked me what I would like for Christmas I said that I would like some razors. Imagine my surprise when on Christmas day I opened up a giant packet of raisins. Mind you I didn't cut myself for a change.
Richard Francis

2 particularly bad presents: 1) from my gran a white cabbage accompanied by "Well you like coleslaw don't you?" 2) from my auntie a pair of men's ski gloves - I'm female, with very small hands and I've never been skiing in my life.
Lucy Batcup

Throughout December I had dropped hints to close friends and family that a camera would be an excellent present for me, especially because mine was stolen the previous Christmas. Excitement set in whilst opening presents as one present turned out to be a camera bag, and another a book on photography. The final present lay before me, the right shape and the right size and as I tore off the last shred of wrapping paper I held in my hands, with an ironic pride...a disposable camera !!!
Simon Powell

The worst gift I ever received was a box of truffles from my Aunt. The problem was, I gave them to her the previous Christmas. She'd kept them in a cupboard for a year, rewrapped it (using the same paper) and gave them back to me - they were past their sell by date!
Gerard Egan

My nomination is the three pairs of "Holy Socks" illustrative of the story of Jonah and the Whale given to me this year by my mother, a Church of Scotland elder. The whale looks more of a slug to me. She assures me that she has sufficient stores of the dratted things (on assorted biblical themes) to be able to make similar gifts, birthdays and Christmases, for the remainder of my natural life. The worst of it is that, through a temporary hiatus in my laundry arrangements, I've actually been forced to wear them.
Graeme Smillie

My mum's sister bought me a sack truck, yes... a sack truck for Christmas. What is a sack truck, well.... it allows for easy movement of sacks around the garden.... One problem, I have no garden, don't ever have the inclination to buy sacks. Have tried to find other uses for the amazing gift, works wellish as a TV stand, but not on BBC2, antenna causes lines, and have tried unsuccessfully to lend it to friends... Would you like it???
Mark Woods

This year I received £50 of clothes vouchers for my daughter - lovely, really useful prezzie you'd think - but they'd expired!
Dawn Quadling

My husband shot out of the house before having breakfast and was missing for one and a half hours. On his return he wished me happy Christmas, then proceeded to shove a small parcel in my hand. I opened my present and upon first glance threw it in the air shouting at the top of my voice "kill it".I thought it was some kind of spider but in fact it was something called an air plant, it was fluffy and kind of hairy and unfortunately the only thing my husband could could buy on Christmas morning from a garden shop. Every year I think how ugly a plucked turkey is but nothing could compare to the strange air plant that I had never seen before and with luck, hoped never to see again.
Leigh Addis

My worst Christmas present was a knitted scarf, glove and bobble hat set from my grandma. There was nothing wrong with them. Unfortunately I was serving in the infantry in Cyprus so the instruction to 'wrap up warm' was not helpful. The worst was to come - my sargeant thought it was amusing to make me wear the said articles on parade for an entire week and being nicknamed Private Pike.
Martin Woodhead

I had been dating my husband for about five years. One Christmas I went to his mother's house on Christmas eve and his mother asked me to drive her to the store to pick up some last minute gifts. When we got there she told me I needed to wait in the car because she was buying my gift too. The next morning I opened it up and there was a wallet-sized picture frame with the clearance sticker still on it for $1.77!!
Brandie Pettus

Woe is me! Being a newly married bloke this was the first Xmas my wife and I had spent together. I had expected a decent present to get over the disappointment of having tons of chinz as wedding presents (thats the trouble with Indian weddings - you get hundreds of guests remotely related to you who fob off their unwanted wedding presents to you by tippexing out their name on stuff like packs of argos student saucers and putting yours on etc.).
Anyway, my wife comes from Essex and unfortunately she must think that cuddly toys which stick to car windows are cool and therefore got me a girl and boy holding hands with "TRUE LOVE" emblazoned on each torso of the toy - sometimes there is not enough puke in the world. As a 26 year old Leicester lad with a degree of street cred i couldn't be doing with that and convinced her it would look so much better on our bedroom door.
Case closed.
Anonymous

webTitle: In brief: Sharon Stone edged out in favour of younger model

fields.headline: Sharon Stone edged out in favour of younger model
fields.standfirst: Plus: Documentary on Ozzy Osbourne tipped to take a prize at Sundance; Robin Williams and Edward Norton to co-star in comedy about kids' TV
fields.trailText: Plus: Documentary on Ozzy Osbourne tipped to take a prize at Sundance; Robin Williams and Edward Norton to co-star in comedy about kids' TV
fields.body:
 It looks as if Basic Instinct 2 has run into yet more trouble, with America's New York Post claiming today that the film's producers are now looking for a younger actress to replace Sharon Stone in the hope that this will help to attract a better leading man (see earlier story). Although the studio and Stone's spokesperson both deny the rumours, the newspaper reports that Stone may be preparing a lawsuit as her contract stipulates that she is paid a $15m (£10m) fee even if she doesn't star in the sequel to the blockbuster which brought her to fame.

webTitle: Analysis: There is still a serious shortage of teachers

fields.headline: Pretty vacant
fields.standfirst:
Whatever the latest figures say, there is still a serious shortage of teachers. Perhaps the solution is a proper pay deal - or a nasty recession

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Whatever the latest figures say, there is still a serious shortage of teachers. Perhaps the solution is a proper pay deal - or a nasty recession.
fields.body:
On January 4, the agency which monitors post-graduate applications for teacher training released figures showing a fall of 16.1% compared with the same time last year. Amid spiralling anxiety about teacher shortages, this looked disastrous.

Eleven days later, the same agency, the Graduate Teacher Training Registry, reported that having counted all the applications received by December 15, there had, in fact, been a 10% rise in post-graduate applications. The Liberal Democrats were sceptical of this "miracle" turnaround. The GTTR blamed the slow Christmas post and the early start to the holiday which meant staff finished processing applications on December 22, rather than December 24.

That small kerfuffle offers some illustration of the difficulties in assessing the scale of recruitment problems - a rather more perilous exercise than it should be. The most recent government figures show that teacher vacancies are running at an acceptable 0.8%, although with wide regional variation - in inner London vacancies ran at 2.6%. But those figures relate to a census on the third Thursday in January 2000, rather than this year. They also rely on a narrow definition of what a vacancy is; one which unions argue persistently underestimates the true figure.

The Department for Education and Employment is sticking to a definition introduced in the early 1990s, that a vacancy is a post which is not covered for less than a term. Which means that a post covered by a teacher on a year's contract cannot be defined as a vacancy, which may be right; less easy to accept that a post covered by a teacher taken on a rush for one term is not vacant.

In their report, Attracting Teachers, Alan Smithers and Pamela Robinson at the Centre for Employment Research at Liverpool University question why the DfEE has been able to report generally low levels of vacancies when the government has persistently missed its targets for recruitment to teacher training in secondary schools.

They attribute it to the ingenuity of head teachers in juggling timetables, teaching themselves, employing untrained teachers, and bringing in staff from Australasia, Canada and South Africa. There are clearly hundreds of foreign teachers working in the UK; how many exactly is apparently impossible to say. Smithers and Robinson reckon that about one in ten posts fall vacant each year. About half the full-time posts in primary schools and a quarter of those in secondary schools were filled by temporary contracts, mostly of a term or more. And around 50% of schools had difficulty filling posts, say Smithers and Robinson, not only in the south-east but also in places like Cornwall and the West Midlands.

Unions do believe the vacancy problem is worse than last year. The Local Government Association says it is not, and that in some parts of the country it may even be better. The government believes that primary schools are generally well covered, but accepts that recruitment may be more difficult this year than last in secondary schools in outer London and the home counties The two leading teacher unions, the NUT and the NASUWT, regard short weeks as a preferable alternative to stretching staff to the limit. And the combination of an imminent teachers' pay deal and the general election has given the row new zip.

There is general agreement that schools are being undermined by a long-term fault in teacher recruitment. In the 1970s, ministers cut the number of teacher training colleges for non-graduates as the birth rate fell. Post-graduate teacher training places were shaved too, hitting a low in 1983. The pruning went too far, and by the time places started going up again to deal with the rising birth rate, teacher training was competing for space in a much more crowded and confident graduate market. Starting salaries and conditions looked much more attractive in other professions. Since then, only in recession years have secondary school entries kept up with targets.

While targets for primary school teachers continued to be met, serious shortfalls in specific secondary subjects began to emerge. Last year, the secondary school trainees fell 13% short; 14,508 compared with a target of 16,615. Even then, there is huge wastage: about 40% of the 30,000 or so who enter teacher training do not enter the classroom.

Some 28,700 people have started teacher training this year, 2,250 (9%) more than at the same time last year. It is the first increase since 1992. Since 1997, the number of teachers in English state schools has increased by 5,400; and since 1998, by 7,000. All post-graduates teacher trainees now receive a £6,000 salary. Trainee teachers in the shortage subjects of maths, science, technology and modern languages have receive "golden hellos" of £4,000. But the candour shown by David Blunkett, the education secretary, in November, that without the introduction of training salaries recruitment would have been "very close to meltdown", betrayed how precarious the situation is.

Pupil numbers are projected to rise in secondary schools until 2005; the situation may get worse in the medium-term even if it then gets better. Teachers in England and Wales are looking enviously to Scotland, which last week agreed a pay deal worth 21.5% over three years, with an instant 10% rise and phased-in guarantees of a 35-hour week. Though it is not in the offing, a pay deal of that order would help. Or failing that, a really nasty recession.

 Will Woodward is the Guardian's education editor.

webTitle: Oxbridge 'may be violating rights act' on admissions

fields.headline: Oxbridge 'may be violating rights act' on admissions
fields.standfirst:
Education Unlimited
Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: Oxford and Cambridge universities could be violating the Human Rights Act by preventing students from applying to both, the head of the national admissions service will warn today.
fields.body:
Oxford and Cambridge universities could be violating the Human Rights Act by preventing students from applying to both, the head of the national admissions service will warn today.

Since 1985 candidates for undergraduate courses have been limited to choosing one on their university admission forms. But Tony Higgins, chief executive of the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service, will say today that most schools and higher education institutions want that to change.

In a speech in London, Mr Higgins will say: "It is accepted that the number of institutions to which an application can be made by any one individual must be limited so as to avoid chaos. But would it be lawful under the act to suggest that, if you applied to one institution, you were specifically barred from applying to another one?"

Mr Higgins will say that a consultation by Ucas revealed that most schools, colleges and universities wanted the restriction lifted.

From 2003 universities will not know from candidates' Ucas forms which other institutions the candidate has applied to. Candidates can apply to a maximum of six universities.

Susan Stobbs, director for admissions at Cambridge, said: "For many years candidates could apply to both universities. When you looked at it, very few people were offered one and not the other - they were either offered both or neither. This was an enormous strain on the students and on the tutors that were assessing them."

An Oxford University spokesman said that were the system to change, "the sharp increase in number of applications would be from individuals already applying to either Cambridge or Oxford, and would not represent any increase in the total number of applicants, which is a priority".

Article II of the first protocol of the act, which came into force in October last year, says: "No person shall be denied the right to education."

But Liberty, the human rights pressure group, cast doubt on Mr Higgins's claim. Spokesman Roger Bingham said: "We don't see that the Human Rights Act would extend that far. The right of access to education is protected but this is about a specific claim."

webTitle: Bosnich joins Blues to end United misery

fields.headline: Bosnich joins Blues to end United misery
fields.trailText: Mark Bosnich today joined Chelsea on a free transfer only hours after his contract was terminated by Manchester United.
fields.body:
Mark Bosnich today joined Chelsea on a free transfer only hours after his contract was terminated by Manchester United.

The 29-year-old Australian international's second stint at Old Trafford ended this lunchtime with a brief statement which read: "Manchester United can confirm that we have terminated Mark Bosnich's contract by mutual consent and, in doing so, we wish him well for the future."

Chelsea immediately signed the keeper on a three-and-a-half-year contract. "Mark is absolutely delighted to be joining Chelsea," said Bosnich's agent Steve Kutner. "They are a very successful club with ambitions that mirror Mark's own. At this time Mark does not wish to dwell on the past but only look towards a brighter future with Chelsea. "

However, Bosnich did not pass up the opportunity to have a dig at his former boss.

"Mark would like to thank the players, directors and supporters of Manchester United for the respect and friendship that they always showed him," he said through his agent, making no reference to Alex Ferguson - which will hardly quell speculation about the allegedly frosty personal relationship between the two men.

It is unlikely Bosnich will walk straight into the Chelsea first XI, with managing director Colin Hutchinson warning the player that "competition for the number one jersey will be tough".

Hutchinson said: "He will add to our squad and quality keepers. He is prepared to work hard to get into the team and does not expect to walk into the side immediately.

"Top teams need three quality keepers. We now have four in Mark, Ed de Goey, Carlo Cudicini and Kevin Hitchcock. We also have exciting young prospect Rhys Evans."

Hutchinson said he was delighted at landing Bosnich. "This is another in our list of quality free transfer signings.

"I was alerted that Mark was likely to become available on a free whilst having a break in Dubai. The whole operation was planned from there.

"Mark met with Claudio Ranieiri and our goalkeeping coach Giorgio Pellizarro. They know the player but not the person and were impressed. We are delighted he has chosen Chelsea.

"Minutes after I arrived back in the UK I met with him and finalising the deal took only a few minutes. He wants to play for Chelsea. He is hungry to win things and put the past behind him. He has a few points to prove."

Indeed he does. Bosnich was hailed as Peter Schmeichel's successor when he arrived on a free transfer from Aston Villa in May 1999.

But his fortunes soon dipped and after a couple of indifferent performances he injured his hamstring in United's third league game of the season against Leeds.

Sir Alex Ferguson clearly had doubts about his new goalkeeper and at the end of August he signed Massimo Taibi in a £4.5m deal from Venezia.

When Bosnich recovered he was unable to reclaim his place amid stories that Ferguson was unhappy with his weight and attitude.

But Taibi flopped spectacularly in his four games for United and in October Bosnich was recalled.

The Australian international's form improved and he produced arguably his finest performance for United in their Toyota Cup victory over Palmeiras in Tokyo in November.

However Bosnich found himself dropped again after Ferguson criticised his display in a 2-2 draw at Wimbledon last February.

Raimond van der Gouw took over in goal only for the Dutchman to drop a clanger against Bordeaux to gift Bosnich back the number one spot.

Bosnich started United's next nine games, including a great performance in the goalless draw against Real Madrid, before he was injured against Sunderland in April.

That proved to be his last match of the season and he ended the campaign claiming he had answered his critics.

But Ferguson was still not happy and at the end of May he bought Fabien Barthez in a £7.8m move from Monaco.

Barthez was installed as United's new number one and Bosnich slipped to third choice when he has left out of the team's mini pre-season tour of Germany and Malta.

Bosnich's departure means the United keeper's pecking order is now Barthez followed by 37-year-old van der Gouw, with American-born rookie keeper Paul Rachubka next in line. Youngster Nicky Caulkin is currently on loan at Bristol City

fields.headline: Jesse Jackson confesses to lovechild
fields.trailText: US civil right activist Jesse Jackson today admitted to having an extra-marital affair that resulted in the birth of a daughter.
fields.body:
US civil right activist Jesse Jackson today admitted to having an extra-marital affair that resulted in the birth of a daughter.

Baptist minister Jackson, 59, issued a statement about the 20-month-old child, saying that he had fathered her and had provided "emotional and financial support since her birth".

He continued: "I fully accept responsibility and I am truly sorry for my actions As her mother does, I love this child very much."

"I was born of these circumstances, and I know the importance of growing up in a nurturing, supportive and protected environment. So I am determined to give my daughter and her mother the privacy they both deserve."

While he refused to reveal their identity, Jackson did state that he would be stepping aside from his public duties for a time.

Jackson's New York-based spokesman John Scanlon later revealed that the minister had acted to pre-empt anticipated tabloid reports about the child.

Scanlon said the birth was the result of an affair Jackson had with one of his employees in the Washington office of his advocacy group, the Rainbow-PUSH Coalition.

The National Enquirer first reported the story. "This is no time for evasions, denials or alibis," Jackson's statement said. "No doubt, many close friends and supporters will be disappointed in me. I ask for their forgiveness, understanding and prayers."

Jackson is married with five children. He said wife Jackie and family were aware of the situation and were enduring "an extremely painful, trying and difficult time."

He stated he would be taking an indefinite break from activist activities, including opposing the confirmation of President-elect George W Bush's attorney general nominee John Ashcroft.

He was not available for further comment.

webTitle: Huge rise in race crime, reveals government

fields.headline: Huge rise in race crime, reveals government
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Racist incidents reported to the police rose by 107% last year, the Home Office disclosed today.
fields.body:
Racist incidents reported to the police rose by 107% last year, the Home Office disclosed today.

The total number of race crimes spiralled from 23,049 in 1998/99 to nearly 48,000 the following year in England and Wales, a new report shows.

In some police forces, the increases were huge - up 459% in West Mercia and 364% in Devon and Cornwall - and none of the 43 forces showed a reduction.

A separate report on how police are dealing with race and homophobic crime, and with recruiting ethnic minority staff, found most forces were doing well.

However, more effort was needed to end "complacency regarding this proportionality in the use of stop-and-search tactics" and in retaining and promoting ethnic minority staff.

North Yorkshire was found to be failing in six of the 10 areas examined in the study and City of London police was failing in five.

Gwent Police were failing in eight areas, but were rated good in two and satisfactory in one.

Meanwhile, the race statistics showed more than 818,000 stop and searches were recorded by police, down from more than 1m the previous year.

Police use of stop-and-search tactics - criticised in the Macpherson report into the racist murder of black teenager Stephen Lawrence for targeting ethnic minorities more frequently than whites - fell by 40% in the Metropolitan police area and 14% in the rest of England and Wales.

Black people were five times more likely to be stopped and searched than whites and four times more likely to be arrested.

Nearly 60% of the people arrested by the Met for robbery were black, said the report.

Home secretary Jack Straw said that the figures "reflected the different breakdown of who is committing robbery on the streets of London".

Figures show black people accounted for 57.2% of arrests for robbery in the Met's area compared to an average of 28.2% in the whole of England and Wales.

"In London, there's bound to be a higher proportion of black people stopped for street crime because a higher proportion of black people commit street crime - that is not because they are black but because of their social background, age group and educational attainment," said Mr Straw.

Commenting on the large rise in recorded race incidents, Home Office statistician Professor Paul Wiles said: "This increase most probably reflects better reporting and recording of incidents rather than an absolute increase in the numbers.

"The new simplified definition of a racist incident - any incident is racist if perceived to be so by the victim or any other person - may have assisted officers in better identifying such incidents."

Evidence from the British Crime Survey indicated that racist incidents were falling, he added. Mr Straw said that the sharp rise in the reporting of racial incidents was "good news" because it showed an increasing confidence on the part of minorities that their concerns would be dealt with by the police.

He told BBC Radio 4's World at One: "We know from the British Crime Survey that the total amount of racial crime seems to have gone down a bit.

"Why has the recording doubled? Because it shows an increased confidence by the black and Asian population to report these incidents and then have something done about them."

He dismissed as "utter nonsense" suggestions that the recent rise in violent offences was directly linked to a drop in the use of stop-and-search by police wary of being branded racist in the wake of the Macpherson Report.

Claims that police were being required to conform to the strictures of "political correctness" were a "smokescreen" put up by right-wingers who wanted to allege that the police had "gone soft on the black community", but did not have the guts to say so openly, he said.

He added: "Robbery has gone up in areas where there are no black people at all.

"It happens that the police division with the highest rate per thousand for robberies is Newcastle upon Tyne Central, where there are virtually no black people.

"There is a problem with robbery and it has got to be dealt with, and where the people committing the robberies happen to be black, the police have got to be able to deal with that as effectively and forcefully as if these people were white."

Stopping and searching of people about whom police had a reasonable suspicion was backed both by the Home Office and by the Macpherson Report, said Mr Straw.

The real change in the use of stop and search since Macpherson was that it was being targeted more accurately than before, he said.

"Although the numbers have come down, the arrest rate has gone up, and that's good news," said Mr Straw.

fields.bodyText: Racist incidents reported to the police rose by 107% last year, the Home Office disclosed today. The total number of race crimes spiralled from 23,049 in 1998/99 to nearly 48,000 the following year in England and Wales, a new report shows. In some police forces, the increases were huge - up 459% in West Mercia and 364% in Devon and Cornwall - and none of the 43 forces showed a reduction. A separate report on how police are dealing with race and homophobic crime, and with recruiting ethnic minority staff, found most forces were doing well. However, more effort was needed to end "complacency regarding this proportionality in the use of stop-and-search tactics" and in retaining and promoting ethnic minority staff. North Yorkshire was found to be failing in six of the 10 areas examined in the study and City of London police was failing in five. Gwent Police were failing in eight areas, but were rated good in two and satisfactory in one. Meanwhile, the race statistics showed more than 818,000 stop and searches were recorded by police, down from more than 1m the previous year. Police use of stop-and-search tactics - criticised in the Macpherson report into the racist murder of black teenager Stephen Lawrence for targeting ethnic minorities more frequently than whites - fell by 40% in the Metropolitan police area and 14% in the rest of England and Wales. Black people were five times more likely to be stopped and searched than whites and four times more likely to be arrested. Nearly 60% of the people arrested by the Met for robbery were black, said the report. Home secretary Jack Straw said that the figures "reflected the different breakdown of who is committing robbery on the streets of London". Figures show black people accounted for 57.2% of arrests for robbery in the Met's area compared to an average of 28.2% in the whole of England and Wales. "In London, there's bound to be a higher proportion of black people stopped for street crime because a higher proportion of black people commit street crime - that is not because they are black but because of their social background, age group and educational attainment," said Mr Straw. Commenting on the large rise in recorded race incidents, Home Office statistician Professor Paul Wiles said: "This increase most probably reflects better reporting and recording of incidents rather than an absolute increase in the numbers. "The new simplified definition of a racist incident - any incident is racist if perceived to be so by the victim or any other person - may have assisted officers in better identifying such incidents." Evidence from the British Crime Survey indicated that racist incidents were falling, he added. Mr Straw said that the sharp rise in the reporting of racial incidents was "good news" because it showed an increasing confidence on the part of minorities that their concerns would be dealt with by the police. He told BBC Radio 4's World at One: "We know from the British Crime Survey that the total amount of racial crime seems to have gone down a bit. "Why has the recording doubled? Because it shows an increased confidence by the black and Asian population to report these incidents and then have something done about them." He dismissed as "utter nonsense" suggestions that the recent rise in violent offences was directly linked to a drop in the use of stop-and-search by police wary of being branded racist in the wake of the Macpherson Report. Claims that police were being required to conform to the strictures of "political correctness" were a "smokescreen" put up by right-wingers who wanted to allege that the police had "gone soft on the black community", but did not have the guts to say so openly, he said. He added: "Robbery has gone up in areas where there are no black people at all. "It happens that the police division with the highest rate per thousand for robberies is Newcastle upon Tyne Central, where there are virtually no black people. "There is a problem with robbery and it has got to be dealt with, and where the people committing the robberies happen to be black, the police have got to be able to deal with that as effectively and forcefully as if these people were white." Stopping and searching of people about whom police had a reasonable suspicion was backed both by the Home Office and by the Macpherson Report, said Mr Straw. The real change in the use of stop and search since Macpherson was that it was being targeted more accurately than before, he said. "Although the numbers have come down, the arrest rate has gone up, and that's good news," said Mr Straw. "For example, in respect of black people in London, (the police) success rate has improved by a quarter. In the previous year, just 13% of those stopped and searched were then arrested. That has now gone up to 17%." Mr Straw conceded that improvements in police recruitment of ethnic minorities "could be faster", but said he remained confident the targets for recruitment would be met. webTitle: 'Racism by stealth' wins council engineer large pay-off

fields.headline: 'Racism by stealth' wins council engineer large pay-off
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: A former senior manager at Stockport council has been awarded £160,000 in an out of court settlement for what he claimed was racial discrimination and victimisation.
fields.body:
A former senior manager at Stockport council has been awarded £160,000 in an out of court settlement for what he claimed was racial discrimination and victimisation.

Justin Idehen said he was eventually forced out of his job as head of engineering services at the council, where he had worked for 15 years, through being subjected to racism. He said the council's management tried to move him to another job and accept a lower salary.

Mr Idehen, 38, a civil engineering graduate, had been in charge of 120 staff, with a £15m annual budget. He claimed managers used intimidation to make him accept the new deal. "I am not a paranoid person who cries race every time something happens," he said yesterday. "I'm not a whinger, I didn't go looking for this."

He added: "The more destructive form of racism is the subtle kind when you're patronised, when your bosses say they are doing something for your sake. When you complain about it you are further patronised."

When he complained, it was all swept under the carpet, he said.

"They attempted to change my job and my contract and terms of employment without consulting with me. The general trend is for people in my position to say nothing and get another job. That was part of my employer's strategy .. to force me out by harassing me.

"It was the kind of racism defined by the Macpherson report, all the attitudes and systems were prejudiced. In that respect I wouldn't hesitate to call it institutional racism, in that it wasn't just one incident. My treatment was unequal and that singled me out."

Mr Idehen, who had overall responsibility for highways maintenance, surveying and design, said that though the £160,000 pay-off appeared generous, he would probably be unable to find a job for several years.

"Employers have a very long memory," he said.

A spokesman for Stockport council said yesterday that the council abhorred racism and investigated allegations thoroughly and stressed that this complaint had not been upheld.

"Although we were confident of success in a tribunal, we agreed a settlement in the interests of everyone," he said.

webTitle: Funny goalkeeper, Amusing wobbly legs, and Humorous pair of plastic ears

fields.headline: Funny goalkeeper, Amusing wobbly legs, and Humorous pair of plastic ears
fields.trailText: BYE BYE, BOS BOS
fields.body:
BYE BYE, BOS BOS

As far as Mark Bosnich was concerned, today was just another day. Same as any other. And so, after crawling out of bed this morning and sitting down to a hearty breakfast of cake swilled down with Alka Seltzer, the lithe Manchester United goalkeeper went about his usual business: cruising slowly to Old Trafford, ambling out onto the pitch to shank a few balls into touch, and then settling down in the corner of the dressing room for a quick snooze under a large pile of warm burger wrappers.

But sadly, today was not just another day, and Bosnich would soon find his world crashing down around him faster than a 23-stone goalkeeper under a heavy challenge. Because, once Alex Ferguson had roused him from his post-lunch slumber by poking him from afar with a long pole - do you seriously expect a knight of the realm to touch an antipodean? - Mark realised his time at United was about to come to an abrupt end. And sure enough, one quick one-sided chat later saw the club terminate his contract "by mutual consent".

"In doing so, we wish him well for the future!" a United spokesman bellowed above the snorts and guffaws emanating from the manager's office. But exactly what "the future" holds for poor Bos Bos is unclear. It has been said that both Celtic and Monaco are looking for someone to fill their goal, and that's something certainly within the limits of Bosnich's abilities. But these are nothing more than rumours and, in the meantime, everyone's favourite Australian "athlete" is unwanted, resigned to a life bereft of hope and direction, where every empty day is as lonely as the next. Either that or he'll sign for Chelsea.

***STOP PRESS*** Mark Bosnich has just signed for Chelsea. Gah! There goes his lie-in with breakfast on a tray!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

GROB SMACKED

For a while there, Bruce Grobbelaar must have been pretty chuffed with his lot in life. Living in South Africa, probably with a big gun, he had been awarded £85,000 in libel damages by the High Court and had his name cleared of murky allegations of match-fixing. Indeed, so clear was his name that many people actually thought he had conceded loads of crap goals by accident.

Sadly, those same many people are likely to have changed their minds today after the Court of Appeal found in favour of the Sun "newspaper" and overturned the libel award. They told Grob he will also have to pay upwards of £500,000 in costs and told the world they were rectifying "a miscarriage of justice which this court can, and must, correct".

"All that had to be decided," said Lord Justice Simon Brown, "was whether Mr Grobbelaar took corrupt payments and, as to that, in my judgment only one rational view was possible, namely that the defendants' allegations were proved true."

All of which allowed the Sun to crow a bit this morning (we were just as surprised as you are). "The court has found unanimously and unambiguously in a devastating judgement that Bruce Grobbelaar corruptly accepted bribes to throw football matches," said their lawyer, Daniel Taylor. Grob, meanwhile, was "devastated" by the ruling and is set to take an appeal to the House of Lords. The Fiver suggests waggling his knees while he does it, it's worked before.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I know that there is no hope for me at Celtic and I don't even want to continue playing there. Perhaps I will manage to find another club, but in the meantime I am prepared to suffer. I'm not going to give up my chance to make as much money as possible, because in four or five years when my career is over that is all that I will have left. I will not forfeit a single shekel at Celtic" - Eyal Berkovic speaks frankly from his home in Israel. It'll be a waste of time sending Martin O'Neill a postcard.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

DISNEY DO WELL!

Disney have not become the multinational conglomerate that's so close to our hearts without being astute business brains. By changing the name of Eurodisney to Disneyland Paris, they transformed an ailing theme park into one that sounded like it was almost in Florida. By opening their own stores and offering punters across the world the chance to buy plastic Mickey Mouse hats, they changed the face of consumerism as we know it. Undoubtedly Disney are the Walt Disney of our age. So can someone tell the Fiver why they want to hire Celtic?

For some reason, it seems that Disneyland - the real, sunny one - want the bowler-hatted Bhoys as a regular attraction. Martin O'Neill's men are currently spending a week's break in the resort ("Help! Help! Ramon Vega's fallen into Thunder Canyon!") and the hyperactive Irishman has been using his time to broker deals with Disney's sports marketing executive. "We spoke about the possibility of some kind of tie-up," said O'Neill, jumping up and down on the spot. "The idea is that we would come out once or twice a season. Nothing has been agreed at this stage but the facilities here are certainly very good."

So good, in fact, that Ted Turner's Atlanta Braves baseball team has already agreed a 10-year-deal to perform and train in Disneyland's Wide World of Sports complex. Which makes you wonder why they've turned to a bunch of Aston Villa rejects as their next clients. Speaking of Alan Thompson, if a deal goes through it could be worth £3m for the Queen's Own Hoops, roughly the same as what O'Neill paid for the occasionally sharp-shooting midfielder. It's been said before, and it'll be said again, but God Bless Disney!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Bradford want Newcastle winger Stephen Glass. Bobby Robson may consider an offer from the Bantams as Glass will be available for nothing at the end of the season.

Bayern Munich are ready to offer Sol Campbell an £80,000-a-week tax-free package to join them next season.

Arsenal want to replace David Seaman with Boca Juniors goalkeeper Oscar Cordoba, according to Planet Football. Boca Juniors vice-president Roberto Digon claims Arsenal have been told they can have Cordoba for £2.7m. "The English club Arsenal are evaluating the options for the position, and one of those is Cordoba, who is available for $4m," Digon said.

Newcastle could move for Tottenham goalkeeper Ian Walker, according to the Mirror. Bobby Robson has privately accepted that Shay Given will move on and is now in the market for a replacement.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

David Beckham should seriously consider moving to Spain to further his career, according to Luis Figo. "I know that Beckham has reached the top in England and that Manchester is a great club, but there are also questions of personal ambition and desire to be considered," said Figo. "I was playing well at Sporting Lisbon, but since I have come to Spain I have improved as a player. I know that Beckham would be a great success in Spain."

Leicester have completed the signing of former Italian international striker Roberto Mancini on a short-term basis.

Christian Dailly this morning completed his £1.75m move from Blackburn to West Ham.

Brentford are to leave Griffin Park, their home of 97 years, and are looking for a possible ground-sharing option.

Ian Bishop will decide this weekend whether to leave Manchester City for Barnsley, Sheffield Wednesday or Miami Fusion.

Tommy Wright has been offered a one-year player-coaching role at Manchester City next season. The Northern Ireland goalkeeper, who has just joined Bolton for three months on loan, would have been out of contract this summer.

Fulham striker Paul Peschisolido has joined Sheffield United on a two-month loan deal.

A man arrested by Catalan police for behaving suspiciously today confessed that he was intending to kidnap a Barcelona player and demand a ransom. However, the man said he had no clear idea of which player he was going to target as he knew little about football. The club have been informed of the incident.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Channel 4: Football Italia (3.15am) "Does any one out there remember Doug Willis out of Neighbours?" asks Mark Campbell.

Channel 5: Jonathan Pearce's Football Night (12.20am) "He was the raisin-faced hoon who drove a ute and managed to father Jason Donovan."

Dutch Football (12.50am) "He was in pantomime at the Theatre Royal in Plymouth a few years ago when we saw him in a nearby pub."

Argentine Football (2.20am) "We were worse for wear we approached him,"

International Football (3.45am) "Upon quizzing him, we discovered that he was not crook,"

Footy Shorts (5.10am) "nor did he have rocks in his head."

Sky Sports 1: Football League Review (6.30pm, 12midnight) "After that we were asked to leave - which was just as well, as Widow Twanky looked a bit tasty."

Fifa TV (7pm, 12.30am) Conor McAuley has another bar tale. "I was in a hotel bar a few months ago on a Sunday afternoon trying to deal with a life-threatening hangover," he writes.

Spanish Football (8pm, 1am) "I spotted this moley-eyed guy in the corner of the bar letting a pint of Guinness fester. After doing a triple-take, I was sure it was the Nobel-prize winner Seamus Heaney."

You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 3am) "He was looking grumpy and was probably discussing how best to translate the Koran into Gaelic or something."

Australian Soccer League (11pm) "Anyway, I ordered a Bloody Mary for the head, and as I went to sit down, I heard him muttering 'poncey git'. Or something like that."

Sky Sports 3: Football Gold (10pm) Can you add anything to this, Mohan Rasanayagam? "Please stop this mindless rubbish about celebrities, b-list or otherwise. It's neither big or clever."

British Eurosport: Live Football (6.30pm) "Or indeed remotely entertaining. Or acceptable. In any way."

Talksport: Football First with John Kearns (7pm) Hmm. Well, there's only one day of it to go, and we want to go out with a bang. So come on, send your best story to the.boss@theguardian.com - and remember: this one's for Mohan!

webTitle: Councillor in call to stem the 'tidal wave' of English immigrants into Wales

fields.headline: Councillor in call to stem the 'tidal wave' of English immigrants into Wales
fields.trailText: A Welsh nationalist councillor has attacked what he claims are "tidal waves" of English immigration into the country, and called for the number of incomers to be strictly monitored.
fields.body:
A Welsh nationalist councillor has attacked what he claims are "tidal waves" of English immigration into the country, and called for the number of incomers to be strictly monitored.

Plaid Cymru's Simon Glyn, a Gwynedd councillor, could be disciplined by his party in the wake of the remarks.

He will meet tomorrow with Gwynedd's Plaid Cymru group leader Alun Ffred Jones to discuss what action might be taken. Mr Jones said: "We need to discuss what's meant by certain of his remarks before we go any further."

The group leader added that Plaid Cymru did not endorse Mr Glyn's statement, saying: "He's used some unfortunate language, to say the least."

Speaking on BBC Radio Wales, Mr Glyn called for incomers to be forced to learn Welsh, and referred to English as a foreign language in Wales. Less than 20% of Welsh people actually speak their native language.

The councillor also said retired people moving from England to Wales were "a drain on resources".

Welsh Labour MP Don Touhig (Islwyn) said Mr Glyn's comments revealed "the dark underbelly of Welsh nationalism".

"While nobody would dispute the problems facing many rural communities in Wales, these horrifying remarks betray the insularity and hostility to Britain which lays just beneath the surface of so much nationalist rhetoric," he said.

Mr Glyn told BBC interviewers: "We are faced with a situation now where we are getting tidal waves of migration, inward migration into our rural areas from England, and these people are coming here to live to establish themselves here, and to influence our communities and our culture with their own.

"They are obviously more dominant in one sense than we are, and we just can't cope with it.

Plaid Cymru's Simon Glyn, a Gwynedd councillor, could be disciplined by his party in the wake of the remarks. He will meet tomorrow with Gwynedd's Plaid Cymru group leader Alun Ffred Jones to discuss what action might be taken. Mr Jones said: "We need to discuss what's meant by certain of his remarks before we go any further." The group leader added that Plaid Cymru did not endorse Mr Glyn's statement, saying: "He's used some unfortunate language, to say the least." Speaking on BBC Radio Wales, Mr Glyn called for incomers to be forced to learn Welsh, and referred to English as a foreign language in Wales. Less than 20% of Welsh people actually speak their native language. The councillor also said retired people moving from England to Wales were "a drain on resources". fields.headline: Khamenei tries to keep control
fields.standfirst: Iran has just jailed a group of reformers. Simon Tisdall examines how the move will affect the country
fields.trailText: Iran has just jailed a group of reformers. Simon Tisdall examines how the move will affect the country.
fields.body:
The decision of a revolutionary court in Tehran to jail eight leading intellectuals and journalists has highlighted rising tensions within Iran as the country moves towards presidential elections this June.

Those imprisoned included Mehrangiz Kar, a leading lawyer and advocate of women's rights, and Akbar Ganji, an investigative reporter who embarrassed the regime by linking Islamic hardliners to the unexplained murders of dissidents.

The accused were charged with anti-state activities after attending a conference in Berlin last year sponsored by the Heinrich Böll Foundation.

The meeting's theme was "post-elections Iran", and involved a discussion of the implications of last spring's landslide Majlis (parliament) victory by reform parties.

But far from bringing an opening of Iranian society, the reformers' advances have since provoked a reactionary backlash by the clerical establishment that is guided by Iran's supreme spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.

Khamenei is the principal guardian of the legacy of the late Ayatollah Khomenei and the 1979 revolution that toppled the Shah. He and his supporters continue to wield the main levers of power, including control of the judiciary, the police and armed forces, and the media.

Ganji's newspaper, in which he published the allegations of an officially-sanctioned policy to silence the regime's critics, is one of more than 30 pro-reform publications that have been shut down since last year's elections.

Overseas reaction to the jail sentences has been sharp. Germany protested to Iran's ambassador and has indicated that a planned visit to Tehran this spring by Chancellor Gerhard Schröder may be postponed. The European Union has also condemned the court's action.

In Washington, the US state department put out a notably sharp statement yesterday, urging Iran "to remedy these unjust convictions and to carefully review other cases of unjust imprisonment".

The arrests and trials "represent a setback for human rights and a clear violation of the individual's right to freedom of expression and association," spokesman Richard Boucher said.

Within Iran itself, student groups - among the most vocal of the regime's critics - added their voices to the protests. In an open letter to Khamenei, the student-led Office for Fostering Unity claimed that the supreme leader was trampling the people's freedoms.

"Our main concern is freedom and justice. We don't want to taste oppression and remain silent," the group said.

Among Iran's fast growing population, the majority of people is too young to remember the revolution. As the ranks of these younger generations expand, pressure is growing - especially from women - for a relaxation of the strict Islamic social codes imposed by Khomenei, and for greater democracy and transparency in public affairs.

The symbol and leader of this movement for change is Iran's President, Mohammad Khatami, whose election in 1997 heralded the beginning of the present struggle for reform.

While upholding Islamic values and bowing to Khamenei's spiritual leadership, Khatami has sought to create a law-based civil society and to end Iran's self-imposed isolation from the outside world, in particular the West.

But Khatami's powers are severely circumscribed. He has been forced onto the defensive in recent months. Now he faces increasing discontent among his own youthful supporters at his perceived failure to deliver and at parliament's similar impotence.

This week's jail sentences have been seen as yet more evidence that Khatami cannot protect his own.

Khatami admits there is a problem. He has expressed his frustrations at the pace of reform and at interventions by Khamenei in the political sphere - such as his insistence on the dismissal of the popular, liberal culture minister, Ataollah Mohajerani.

Speculation has thus begun to grow that he may not run for a second term this June. Without the moderate and level-headed Khatami at the helm, however, there are fears that public frustration at the clerics' stranglehold on Iranian society could spill over into street violence and unrest (as has happened sporadically in the past two years).

Perhaps the most famous opponent of the mullahs is Ayatollah Hossein Ali Montazeri. He could provide a new rallying point for reformers if Khatami gives up the fight. Trouble is, he, too, is currently under arrest.

fields.headline: Grobbelaar's reputation takes drubbing
fields.standfirst:
Accused of illegally ensuring certainty on the football field, the future looks desperately uncertain for the former Liverpool and Southampton keeper after the court of appeal ruling, says sports correspondent Vivek Chaudhary
Grobbelaar loses match-fix damages appeal
fields.trailText: Accused of illegally ensuring certainty on the football field, the future looks desperately uncertain for the former Liverpool and Southampton keeper after the court of appeal ruling, says sports correspondent Vivek Chaudhary.
fields.body:
Over the past few years, it is the witness box and not the penalty box that has provided the main stage for former Liverpool goalkeeper Bruce Grobbelaar.

Today, as three appeal court judges announced their ruling and overturned the libel jury's verdict awarding Grobbelaar £85,000 in 1999, the man who became known as the clown prince of goalkeepers because of his zany antics was nowhere to be seen outside the high court.

Being absent at crucial times was always something of a hallmark of Grobbelaar's game, as some of his former Liverpool team mates found to their cost during matches.

For Grobbelaar, the judge's decision presents a mammoth financial and personal disaster. His reputation has been tarnished further and Grobbelaar will have to pay around £1million in costs. The judges; historic ruling not only represents the first time a libel jury's verdict has been overturned, but also upholds the Sun's allegation that Grobbelaar received money to fix matches.

For English football as a whole, today marked the first time when the highest authorities in the land confirmed that match-fixing has played a nefarious role the game, however small.

John Fashanu and Hans Segers, who is currently goalkeeping coach at Tottenham Hotspur and could be on the bench this Saturday for the match with Southampton, were also named by the Sun for their part in match-fixing activities. Like Grobbelaar, they too were cleared. But unlike him, they chose not to puruse any libel actions against the newspaper.

Since the Sun's allegations were first published in November 1994, Grobbelaar, then a Southampton player, has spent a good part of the past six years in court: two criminal trials, in which he was eventually cleared second time around of match-fixing, a 16-day libel trial against the Sun and the latest trial, which culminated in the disastrous ruling.

Grobbelaar has vowed to appeal against the judgment and still insists he has had no involvement in match fixing. Given the protracted legal wranglings of the last few years, few are willing to bet that the whole sordid affair has at last been laid to rest.

fields.headline: Cancer standards unveiled
fields.trailText: Inspection teams are to be sent into hospitals to ensure cancer services meet tough new quality standards aimed at driving up survival rates.
fields.body:
Inspection teams are to be sent into hospitals to ensure cancer services meet tough new quality standards aimed at driving up survival rates and cutting the time waited for diagnosis and treatment.

The national cancer standards - the first of their kind - were launched today by the health secretary, Alan Milburn, as part of the government's bid to improve the UK's record on treating the disease.

The UK has some of the worst five-year survival rates in Europe for cancer, and the NHS plan, published last summer, pledged to improve treatment to match other EU countries by 2010.

Mr Milburn also announced a national expansion from April of the cancer collaboratives scheme - currently being piloted in nine areas - which develops innovative ways of reducing waiting times for treatment.

The standards set out 10 categories with guidance on how care should be delivered. Cancer departments will have to show they are properly staffed, allow patients access to information, offer speedy treatment and palliative care.

From next April, teams of experts will visit hospitals throughout England to assess their services against the standards. Trusts which do not come up to scratch will have to draw up action plans to improve services. Mr Milburn said: "It will take time for the NHS to deliver world-beating cancer care, but this year patients will see substantial improvements in all parts of the country."

Sir Nicholas Young, chief executive of Macmillan Cancer Relief, said: "This is a great step forward. It is the first time that such standards have been set for cancer and this will give us a comprehensive picture of what is required in each local cancer network.

"A huge amount of work is required, however, to bring about improvements which must be resourced and it is essential that core cancer services do not suffer as a result."

fields.headline: Victims of global warming?
fields.standfirst:
Displaced penguins surf into Rio

Special report: the weather
Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Displaced penguins surf into Rio
fields.byline: Alex Bellos  in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
Tourists who are enjoying the glamour of Rio de Janeiro's beaches are being joined by some unexpected visitors - penguins from Patagonia.

Hundreds of half-starved penguins, many bearing the scars of shark bites, have been waddling ashore on some of the world's most famous tropical beaches - and experts suspect it could be the result of global warming.

When the birds arrive they are exhausted after the 2,000-mile swim from the penguin colonies on the Valdes Peninsula, near the Patagonian Welsh community of Trelew.

While most of the penguins are taken to the zoo to recover, some are being kept as pets by Brazilian fishermen, who feed them sardines and even walk them on a leash.

"You wouldn't believe how many people put these penguins in freezers when they rescue them," Valdir Ramos, chief mammal biologist at the Rio zoo, said. "Of course, they mostly die."

The occasional penguin paddling up to Brazil is nothing new. In a typical year about 40 stray Magellanic penguins used to arrive in the Rio area between June and August. But in 1999 the number rose, and last year about 300 arrived. "This is totally atypical," Mr Ramos added. "We can't talk about a 'penguin season' any more. It doesn't exist, they just keep coming."

While experts think the phenomenon may be a result of climatic changes, no one can agree on what kind of changes those are. Some believe it is because of unusually strong cold ocean currents, which improve the chances of a penguin surviving the journey.

They could also be following the migration of their staple food, anchovies. Another possibility is that, since almost all of those stranded are between six and eight months old, they were carried off by currents while learning to swim.

Rio's zoo collects many of the penguins and nurses them back to health; 16 are currently living in a refrigerated cabin and dozens more are in the zoo's infirmaries. In Sao Paulo three other zoos have created new penguin aquariums to receive the birds.

webTitle: Twins' birth mother wants her babies back

fields.headline: Twins' birth mother wants her babies back
fields.trailText: The controversy over American twin girls sold through an internet adoption agency has deepened today as the girls' natural mother claimed she wants her babies returned to her.
fields.body:
The controversy over American twin girls sold through an internet adoption agency has deepened today as the girls' natural mother claimed she wants her babies returned to her.

Tranda Wecker, a 28-year-old hotel receptionist from St. Louis, Missouri, told the Sun newspaper that she wants the babies back. Ms Wecker said she had received no money from either adoption and had no idea that the two couples involved had paid for the babies until police investigators in San Diego became involved.

Ms Wecker told an American television station that all the only person to receive any money was Tina Johnson, the agent who arranged both adoptions. Ms Johnson, who runs the Caring Hearts adoption agency in San Diego, California, has not commented publicly on the matter.

"I found out after all of this that they had wired money into Tina's account," Ms Wecker said in an interview on US television.

The British couple who are now caring for the twins, Alan and Judith Kilshaw, bought the babies for £8,200 and have refused to return them to a couple in California who claim the babies belong to them.

Richard and Vickie Allen paid £4,000 to Ms Johnson for the babies and were going through adoption procedures in California when the children were snatched from them and resold to the Kilshaws.

It also emerged today that the Kilshaws have had their home investigated for spirits. The couple called in paranormal investigators after they and their children thought they saw, heard or felt unexplained phenomena in their north Wales farmhouse.

In a video of the ghostbusters' investigation last year, handed to the BBC by the unidentified people who filmed it, Judith described the presence, saying: "I don't know... something evil. I don't know what it is." One of the couple's two young sons talked of 'The Milky Man', a ghostly apparition of an old man in a white milkman's coat.

Mr Kilshaw spoke of another spirit who had been troubling the family. "I've heard noises but I've never seen it. It's never bothered me," he said in the recording, made last year.

The new revelations came after the FBI confirmed it had begun a preliminary investigation, and British social services said the Kilshaws, of Buckley, north Wales, would be monitored.

Perhaps unsurprisingly, the story of the Kilshaws' adoption of the girls and their fight to smuggle them out of America could be made into a Hollywood movie.

Mr Kilshaw told the Express that he had begun talks with Hollywood film studios. He is quoted as saying: "I told the studio bosses, 'Let's get it on!' I really want to see this movie made.

"We were contacted on Tuesday night and they say they want to look at the possibility of turning our story into a movie. And they, like us, are very keen to make sure that happens. I think it would make a great film and I see no reason why that shouldn't happen." Mr Kilshaw also said he was taking legal advice about whether he could take court action to recover some of the £24,000 the couple spent getting the girls out of America.

He told the Express he and his wife incurred extra expenses because of the way Ms Johnson, of the Caring Heart Agency, had handled the adoption.

A third set of parents has also come forward to say they were offered the twin girls by Ms Johnson. Amy and Eddie White, from New York State, agreed to pay her £5,800, but the deal collapsed when they failed to produce the money quickly enough, the Sun reported.
