fields.headline: Star TV squares up to ITV over Indian 'Millionaire'
fields.trailText: 4pm: James Murdoch's Star TV hopes to bring the Indian Who Wants to be a Millionaire? to the UK but faces opposition from ITV, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Executives at Rupert Murdoch's Star TV station are still hoping to bring the Indian version of Who Wants to be a Millionaire? to the UK despite stiff opposition from ITV.

The Asian satellite TV broadcaster went live in the UK this week without Kaun Banega Crorepati? - or Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? - on its schedule, leaving the station's biggest hit on the sidelines.

"Certainly the issue is that we are a licensee of the format for parts of Asia, but it is not a blanket agreement. It is simply a question of not having the rights and we are talking to all the relevant parties about it," said James Murdoch, son of Rupert and chief executive of Star TV.

Celador, the UK production outfit that owns the rights to Millionaire, will not allow licensees to broadcast the programme outside the country it is made in.

So far ITV, holder of the UK licence, has resisted any change in the terms and today said there was little chance of Star TV getting its way.

"Star TV will not be able to show its version, as ITV needs to protect its contractual position," said an ITV spokeswoman.

However, she added that there was a small chance that ITV would broadcast Millionaire on its ITV2 channel if there was demand from the Asian community.

The success of the Indian Millionaire, which is hosted by Bollywood superstar Amitabh Bachchan, has been the key to Star TV's dominance of the ratings in India.

Mr Murdoch's BSkyB will carry the Star Plus Hindi entertainment channel and 24-hour Star News channel on its digital network, charging £16 per month for both channels. There are no plans as yet to offer the service on rival networks such as ONdigital and NTL.

Star will be seeking to repeat its performance in India and knock close rival Zee TV from the top of the UK market, which has a potential audience of around 1.5m Indian and South Asian viewers.

"Our product is of a much higher quality than Zee's. They will have to work much harder to respond to us, and they will find it increasingly difficult to keep up," said Mr Murdoch.

fields.headline: Party funding
fields.standfirst:
Both Labour and the Tories have benefitted from sizable donations from wealthy individuals. Simon Jeffery explains the fuss over big-money party donations

Special report: Labour in power
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Businessman Staurt Wheeler has poured £5m into the campaign to make William Hague the next prime minister. We explain the fuss over big-money party donations
fields.body:
Why do political parties need so much money?
British political parties are not funded by the state. Elected officials such as MPs are paid a salary and given an allowance to run their private offices - and, in some cases, cars - but the party they belong to has to find its own money for its offices, staff and election campaigns.

And how much does that cost?
Both Labour and the Tories are hoping to raise £15-20m this year. Election spending is capped at £20m to prevent US-style big money politics but, if they can find the money, the two main parties will actively spend it to win a majority in Westminster.

So who gives it?
Labour says that 40% of its funding now comes from individual members and small donations, 30% from trade unions, 20% from large single donations and 10% from commercial activities. Wealthy businessmen are a growing category since the trade unions are expected to cut their donation from £12m to £8m before the general election.

And what will they get in return?
Absolutely nothing. Giving to a political party is supposed to be an entirely altruistic pursuit.

So why all the fuss?
Because big-money donors make easy political targets. Labour made capital out of Asil Nadir's donations to the Tories (Nadir was, and is, a fugutive from British justice) and William Hague scored an early goal against new Labour just months after the 1997 general election with the revelation that Formula 1 boss Bernie Ecclestone had donated £1m to party coffers. Especially since it came only weeks before the government announced motor racing would be exempt from a newly-introduced ban on tobacco sponsorship.

Where do the Tories stand on party funding?
Unlike Labour, who revealed their big donors under pressure from the Economist magazine, the Tories have kept quiet. However, it is known the Conservatives have been reliant on party treasurer Lord Ashcroft's own donations of around £5m since the last election. Now Stuart Wheeler, the 65-year-old head of the IG betting index, has given the Tories a £5m gift to help them fund the general election campaign. The Tories need the money - the party is running a £9m overdraft.

Is there anything suspicious about Labour's current donors?
Lord Sainsbury, publisher Paul Hamlyn and financier Christopher Ondaatje have donated £2m each to the Labour party, but it is a far smaller donation of £33,000 from prospective Millennium Dome buyer Robert Bourne that has provoked the most interest in opposition circles. The Tories say they will question the donation in parliament, while Labour insists the money is simply the final installment of a £100,000 donation pledged before the dome was built.

What does the prime minister say about his party's donors?
Mr Blair has tried to turn Labour's big donors into a vote winner. He says he is "absolutely proud" that successful entrepreneurs and disaffected Conservatives support Labour.

Are party donations regulated?
The Neill/Nolan anti-sleaze reforms on party funding come into force on February 16. These will oblige parties to disclose donations of more than £5,000 and a place a bar on foreign donors. On presenting his report, Lord Neill said: "Many members of the public believe that the policies of the major political parties have been influenced by large donors, while ignorance about the sources of funding has fostered suspicion."

Is party funding a modern controversy?
No. In 1920, Liberal prime minister David Lloyd George was accused of selling political honours for between £10,000 and £40,000. Harold Wilson also gave out honours after he resigned as prime minister.

Should political donors be named?

fields.headline: Tory glee at record £5m gift
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The biggest ever single recorded donation to a British political party was revealed last night when the Conservatives announced they had received a £5m gift from a City betting entrepreneur.
fields.body:
The biggest ever single recorded donation to a British political party was revealed last night when the Conservatives announced they had received a £5m gift from a City betting entrepreneur.

The money, from Stuart Wheeler, the 65-year-old head of the IG betting index, is said to come without strings and was prompted by his "admiration" for the Tory leader, William Hague.

The move takes political parties another step away from funding by ordinary memberships and small-scale voluntary donations. Just after Christmas, Labour announced that it had received donations of £2m from millionaire publisher Lord Hamlyn and philanthropist Christopher Ondaatje. The party has also received a promise of £2m from the science minister, Lord Sainsbury.

The £5m donation will come as a relief to the Conservatives, who have been short of funds from business and consequently over-dependent on their party treasurer, Lord Ashcroft.

If, as expected, the Labour government imposes a £15m ceiling on election campaign spending, Mr Wheeler's largesse will cover a third of the Conservatives' election expenditure.

Mr Wheeler - who floated his betting firm for £145m in July - said last night: "I think William Hague would make a much better prime minister than Tony Blair. He is a man to get things done with the interests of the country at heart rather than by constant reference to opinion polls and focus groups.

"I have given £1m to the Conservative party today and I intend to give another £4m before the election with a view to giving the Tories the very best chance of winning the election and not just putting up a good show".

His donation gives a boost to the Conservatives following polls that showed them trailing Labour by as much as 15 points.

Mr Hague and Mr Wheeler have met but are not described as being close personal friends.

"Clearly this was a very friendly act, and they will become close friends," said a senior Tory MP involved in talks with Mr Wheeler.

IG, which makes spreads on the financial markets and sporting events, is predicting that the Tories will win 212 to 220 seats in the next election, giving Labour a clear winning majority with between 372 and 380 seats.

At the time of his company's flotation, Mr Wheeler took out £5m but retained a one-third stake in the firm valued at £41m.

Although the government is imposing a spending cap on election campaign expenditure, parties still badly need cash to run their day-to-day operations, as well as to fund pre-election campaigning such as the current poster campaign being undertaken by the Conservatives.

Up until the 1997 election, the Tories managed to massively outspend Labour in elections with a bombardment of posters and newspaper adverts. The sheer scale of the Tory operation demoralised Labour.

The size of Mr Wheeler's gift, coupled with the trio of £2m donations to Labour, is bound to sharpen calls for the state funding of political parties. Tony Blair has said he is personally opposed to state funding, largely because he believes it would be politically unpopular.

However, the Labour general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, has said that she thinks there is a case for state funding. The parliamentary Labour party chairman, Clive Soley, is also a supporter.

Mr Wheeler was educated at Eton and Oxford before joining the Welsh Guards and then qualifying as a barrister.

He started his firm with a £5,000 loan in 1974. The firm took tax-free bets on the price of gold, and since then the business has diversified into all the leading commodities, stock indices and sport.

The recent addition of betting on individual shares allowed the firm to treble annual profits to £10.1m. The company also takes bets on politics. When the company floated in July on the stock market shares were 240p. Since then the price has more than doubled.

In 1998 the company's internet division launched the first site to offer online spread betting and that has become one of its main arms. Last year turnover rose 58% to £15.8m.

Despite his faith in the Tories, Mr Wheeler is a shrewd gambler and in the last election put his money on the Labour party. He is also a former finalist in the world poker championships.

Mr Wheeler is also on the national council of Business for Sterling.

webTitle: The player who bet £5m on Hague

fields.headline: The player who bet £5m on Hague
fields.standfirst:
A fortune, a drive to gamble and a sure loser add up to a flutter of the heart rather than the head

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: A fortune, a drive to gamble and a sure loser add up to a flutter of the heart rather than the head.
fields.body:
It is a strange punt for a man who has made his millions from other people playing the odds and getting it wrong. Anyone phoning up IG Index, the spread betting firm founded by the Conservative party's latest financial saviour, Stuart Wheeler, to ask for a price on the forthcoming election, will be told in a blur of numbers the inevitable result: the Tories are not going to win.

Yet Mr Wheeler has reached an age, 65, and a level of financial security, where he can afford to take a flutter with his heart rather than his head - a £5m flutter at that.

This old fashioned City of London stalwart, who went to Eton College and Oxford University, was in the Welsh Guards and was called to the bar, has bagged an £80m fortune floating his business on the stock market in the summer. Most of that is still tied up in shares, but he cashed in £5m of his chips when IG became a quoted company, and has been squirrelling away profits ever since he introduced the arcane concept of spread betting to the compulsive gamblers of the Square Mile 27 years ago.

IG was started with a £5,000 loan; today the whole firm is worth £250m, and the business of spread betting, first conceived as a way of betting on the price of gold, has itself spread to cover every possible gambling opportunity, from cricket to the wholesale price of orange juice.

For the innumerate, the spread betting concept can be confusing. Punters either "buy" or "sell" at quoted prices on a particular event.

In the case of the election, the IG quote on the number of seats the Tories will win stood at a spread of 212 to 220 last night. Anyone gambling on a better showing by the opposition party would "buy" at 220, wagering a set amount for each seat.

If the Tories manage 250 seats on the night, for example, a punter betting £10-a-seat would win £300. If they only manage 150 seats, he or she would face a bill of £620.

The current spread on Labour's performance stands at 372 to 380 seats.

Mr Wheeler is himself a seasoned gambler - a poker player by choice rather than betting on the result at Highbury or on the progress of the FTSE 100 share index. He is a Las Vegas regular, once entering the poker world championships held annually at the gambling mecca, and on another occasion managing to get thrown out of Caesar's Palace for counting cards while playing blackjack and winning too much money.

He also drinks - lots of wine and sometimes pina coladas - and standing at a slightly bumbling 6ft 4in, a little deaf in one ear, and rather shabby in an expensively tailored sort of way he personifies the old amateur gentleman style of City players, where the lunches were long and money was made almost by accident. He looks suited to wood panelled dining rooms, rather than the brash, chrome-lined bars where today's up-and-coming City players relax.

Of course, Mr Wheeler did not build his fortune employing people in his own ilk. He is surrounded at IG by young male market traders, with calculator brains, who have given up the business of broking regular shares and bonds, preferring a world of unadulterated 24-hour speculation where "the winnings are tax free, and so are the losses," as the spread betters' chant goes.

William Hague's benefactor describes himself as a late starter. He was adopted by an American naval captain, Alexander, who died when Wheeler was seven, and his British wife, Betty. He did not excel at Eton and during national service, some of which was spent in Egypt, he managed to take a bullet in the lip during a training exercise.

He got through university unscathed, but his early career at the merchant bank Hill Samuel as a fund manager was something of a flop.

Even marriage came late at the age of 44 to Tessa Codrington, a freelance photographer and 10 years his junior. The couple have three daughters, the middle one Jacquette is a fledgling model, appearing as the face of Oil of Olay.

Mr Wheeler is on the national council of Business for sterling.

The next few months will tell whether Mr Wheeler's personal riches have matured a little too late for the Tory leadership.

Life behind the man

Born: 1935 in Enfield, Middlesex, and brought up by adoptive parents, Alexander and Betty. Father died when he was seven.

Educated: Eton, then Oxford University, where he gained a 2nd class honours degree in law.

Family: married to Tessa, 10 years his junior, a society photographer. Three daughters.

Employment: After serving in the Welsh Guards, qualified as a barrister, and later worked in the City as an investor at Hill Samuel and JH Vavasseur. Set up own company, IG Index, in 1974.

Business ethos: "Never be afraid to admit you're wrong. Take responsibility, apologise and move on."

Estimated fortune: £50m

Interests: poker, bridge, backgammon.

fields.headline: Granada shuts tourist attraction
fields.trailText: 4pm: Granada is closing the doors on its Coronation Street tourist attraction, reports Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Granada Media has pulled the plug on its Coronation Street tourist attraction and the rest of the Granada Studios tour in Manchester.

After a year-long consultation, Granada bosses have decided the once popular attraction has had its day and fails to fit into its core media business.

The attraction will close at the end of February with the loss of 38 full and part-time jobs.

"A number of ideas for its future were considered but in the end we believed it was no longer sufficiently attractive. It had to operate in an extremely competitive attraction market," said a spokeswoman.

Some 5.25m people have visited Granada Studios since it opened its doors in July 1988. Attractions included supping a pint in the Rovers Return, visiting the This Morning studio and taking a stroll down Sherlock Holmes' Baker Street.

Even five years ago the tour was attracting 780,000 visitors a year paying £11.99 each. At that time the BBC was considering creating its own theme park with the Tussauds Group.

But visitor numbers fell away rapidly and in December 1999, Granada closed the attraction to the public and concentrated on corporate hospitality events.

A radical rethink of the attraction was eventually shelved.

Coronation Street fans will still be able to see the outdoor sequences filmed during a number of open days, the dates of which will be announced by Granada in due course.

webTitle: Crowds turn out to mourn Damilola

fields.headline: Crowds turn out to mourn Damilola
fields.standfirst: More on the Damilola Taylor case
fields.trailText: Hundreds of mourners this afternoon attended the funeral of murdered schoolboy Damilola Taylor, who was stabbed to death in south-east London last November.
fields.body:
Hundreds of mourners this afternoon attended the funeral of murdered schoolboy Damilola Taylor, who was stabbed to death in south-east London last November.

The private ceremony took place at All Saints church in Plumstead, south-east London. Mourners wept outside as the small white coffin, topped with a white floral cross, was carried inside by six pallbearers.

Attending the ceremony were Damilola's parents, Richard and Gloria Taylor, who arrived at the church accompanied by senior investigating officer Deputy Assistant Commissioner Bill Griffiths.

The police officers who arrived first at the scene of Damilola's murder also attended, with a number of high-profile figures from Damilola's native Nigeria, including Arsenal striker Nwankwo Kanu, former Wimbledon footballer John Fashanu and Nigerian high commissioner, Prince Bola Ajibola.

Mr Fashanu, who was a friend of the Taylor family and had met Damilola's father in Nigeria, said before the service: "There's a lot of Nigerians here and all of them feel like they've lost a son."

Prince Bola Ajibola told the congregation: "I wish on this occasion to reiterate our profound and heartfelt condolences to the entire family The people of Nigeria have been deeply touched by the manner of Damilola's untimely death."

Addressing the congregation at the start of the service, the Rev Harry Owen said Damilola's death showed we live in a "fallen and imperfect world". He continued: "We dare to pray that the consciences of those responsible may be touched, filled with remorse and willing to admit the wrong that has been done."

He asked people who knew Damilola try to remember happy thoughts about the boy, "something particular you can thank God for as you remember his life".

He had arrived from Nigeria with his family just three months earlier. Days before his death, his mother Gloria had complained her son was being bullied.

Fifteen people have so far been arrested in connection with the youngster's death, but as yet no one has been charged.

fields.headline: What Tories have become
fields.standfirst: William Hague's Conservative party have turned into unpleasant Nixonian reactionaries
fields.trailText: William Hague's Conservative party have turned into unpleasant Nixonian reactionaries.
fields.body:
There'll always be an England - but it's not their kind of place any more. England, their England, has slipped away - irrecoverable as Lyonesse. Once it teemed with sturdy, self-reliant folk - provident, patriotic and positively brimming over with yeoman virtue. Families were the nurses of morality. Enterprise was balanced by public spirit and mutual obligation. Men were men in that Arcady - and they were always "sound". And the woman question, of course, had yet to be asked. Bliss was it in that England to be alive and Tory.

Bless. Psychological empathy is perhaps the most useful tool, as we crouch by the Tory on the couch babbling of green fields long ago. How did it come to this?

It is now a Tory axiom that England groans under an army of occupation. Mr Hague's excoriated "liberal elite" is in charge. Columnists spread their poison, broadcasters insert their not so subliminal messages. Teachers and lecturers went under a long time ago. But Tories have also distanced themselves from most other professional groups. The liberal chief constable has now been joined by the left-leaning general in that spacious pantheon which accommodates the Tory demons.

In the depth of its phobias the Tory party has now become at last an authentically European party - one of the reactionary right. It has cut loose from its roots in the English political tradition and is locatable somewhere in inter-war Europe. With its talk of "give us back our country" it recalls early Mussolini and the Spanish Falange of Primo de Rivera. The rhetoric fits easily into the fascistic Action Française tradition of invoking the nation and the forebears, "la terre et les morts". It is the party of offended virtue and angry patriots, of the misunderstood and permanently cross. Alienation is the daily rationed bread.

Tories hate "Europe" of course but, although they talk about it all the time, they don't really think in much detail about the institutional mechanisms of the European Union. "Europe" for them has symbolic value. By that term Tories mean the modern world with its anarchy of tastes and the individualism of minorities who threaten to become a majority. It means the alien in their midst, the refugee at the door and the deviant who threatens to jump into bed. It is the "threat to our way of life".

It is all pure reaction - and as such escapes conventional left/right distinctions. Much as fascism did. This new Tory league wants to represent the "petit peuple" and the resentful, those who just want to be up and at 'em. Conspiratorial and suspicious in temperament, they jeer at plotting liberals in high places.

Nostalgia is not a conservative prerogative - nor is it necessarily noxious. The left, after all, has had its own useful myths of trade union solidarity and pleas for "community values".

English conservatism has offered its own series of last ditches in which the fearful could recline. But the point is that they were always receding. The protests over two centuries against the emancipation of Roman Catholics, Dissenters and women faded away. The changes were accepted and then another lost cause could be embraced. No cause has been truly won in social reform until the Tory party secured its inevitable victory by rejecting it.

But this darkness is something new. This is Arcady turned nasty. It has always been an important function of the Conservative party that it should contain and control some very unpleasant people. A "liberal elite", from Harold Macmillan to Edward Heath, gave the local curs just enough red meat and conference rhetoric to stop them going somewhere else and becoming dangerous as well as nasty. Now, however, the curs are at the controls. The European continent supplies analogies but the explanation for the take-over lies further west.

Recently there died one of the eloquent giants of American political liberalism. John Lindsay, former mayor of New York, typified the liberal Republican tradition. He was a gracious tribune of the poor and dispossessed at a time when his party had been taken over by Nixonianism. The division between Lindsay and Nixon was not one of economic management. Lindsay was a classic welfarist. But then Nixon was also a big spender whose presidency was marked by the greatest extension of federal powers and government agencies since the days of FDR. The difference was rather one of temperament, between the open and the closed society. Nixon's was the paranoid style in American politics. And it is this which earns him his place in history as the most influential 20th century conservative.

Nixon's "silent majority" spoke with a "quiet voice in the middle of the shouting". They were "the forgotten Americans, the non-shouters, the non-demonstrators. They're good people. They're decent people. They work and they save and they care." The language had been around in American politics for a long time. As a vision of non-metropolitan virtue it had started at the end of the 19th century when it had been liberal and progressive rather than reactionary. Rural America was being displaced by the urban experience - hence the nostalgic appeal for a democratic order of the self-sufficient.

This American pastoralism opposed the huge European immigration whose political traditions were those of the peasantry - innocent of self-reliance and dependent on hierarchy. For these masses politics was a question of personal obligations - of mafia politics and family values. The Progressive movement had its own vicious kicks - but although so arcadian in tone it was well named. It opposed the new world of large corporations, the values of plutocracy and the city boss manipulation of immigrant votes.

Nixon perverted this language and turned it into something different - a cold-gospelling scream against the educated. His legacy split the Republican party and created the taste for Pat Buchanan. It was Nixonians who pursued Clinton for his eight years in office - and never accepted the legitimacy of a liberal presidency. Our own Conservative party is a Nixonian entity in its hatreds and cultivation of paranoia.

Here too there has been an earlier pastoralism of tone. Who among us can forget those Majorite maids cycling to early communion? And here too the tone has turned vicious, Thatcher's patronised C2 voters were Nixon's silent majority in English guise. Now the imitation is complete with William Jefferson Hague using liberal in its American sense of an upstart left.

The opposition leader is an enthusiast for American politics with a prodigious recollection of the occupants of state governorships and senatorial office. But this Anglo-American conversation goes beyond such feats of political obsession. His language is Nixonian and the recent case of Damilola Taylor showed the same readiness to manipulate. This is a very conservative Anglo-American relationship - special only in its darkness, its myths and its cruelty.

fields.standfirst: Publication date: January 19.
fields.trailText: January 19:The Boots Company has switched Citigate Dewe Rogerson for Tulchan Communications.
fields.body:
The Boots Company has dropped Citigate Dewe Rogerson after seven years and hired Tulchan Communications as the group's financial PR adviser.

Liverpool's Alder Hey hospital has cancelled an arrangement with Jonathan Street PR and handed the brief to the Central Office of Information.

Ferry operator Stena Line is axing its UK PR department in a bid to restore profitability.

The financial PR sector distanced itself further from the PR Consultants Association last week when three more City agencies quit the association.

Train operating company First Great Western has called in Barclay Stratton to boost its reputation with regard to safety.

Racecourse owner Arena Leisure has ditched Holborn PR and hired Bell Pottinger Financial to handle financial PR and investor relations.

MasterCard has handed its music sponsorship PR work to communications company the Big Group.

Samsung Electronics is seeking a UK PR agency following a decision by Complete Marketing Communications to resign the account to work for Philips Electronics.

The Weber Group Europe is to create a division, called Red Whistle, to focus on consumer technology and internet clients.

webTitle: What's on the BBC children's channels

fields.headline: What's on the new children's channels
fields.trailText: The BBC is promising to increase the money it spends annually on original UK children's programming by £30m, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The BBC is promising to increase the money it spends annually on original UK children's programming by £30m to supply output for its two new children's services.

The pre-school service has been allocated £20m in its first two years, while the channel for six to 13-year-olds will get £62m over the same period.

By comparison, the BBC spent £55m on children's programming in 1999-2000.

The BBC is promising to spend 75% of this money on UK-originated programming.

The pre-school channel is expected to be the first of the BBC's four proposed new digital TV services on-air, with a launch date pencilled in for the summer.

The pre-school service is targeted at children under six and will broadcast during the day on the same channel as BBC3 between 6am and 7pm.

The new Children's BBC pre-school offering will carry 90% British programming, a quarter of which will be new material.

The BBC is promising "selective" use of library shows such as Teletubbies and Tweenies, plus a "much greater proportion" of British programming and educational output than its commercial competitors.

It will "offer a range of new high quality UK-produced educative and entertaining programmes for young children" according to the BBC.

"The service will provide a consistently safe environment for the youngest audience, enhanced by the availability over time of an interactive television wrap around service."

The second CBBC service is aimed at six to 13-year-olds and is pencilled in for a launch in early 2002, with around 75% British programming.

A quarter of the schedule will be new programming, with a further 50% made up of repeated CBBC1 and 2 output and CBBC archive material.

This service will broadcast on BBC4's bandwidth, 7am-8pm, "with a broadly interactive agenda".

The BBC said the older children's service "will offer new UK-produced drama, comedy, entertainment and factual programmes with the best of current CBBC output".

Live Newsround bulletins will feature "at least three times a day" and a Newsround interactive service and children's rolling news website are also being developed.

The BBC said: "Connecting with children through the various means at their disposal - letter, phone, email, SMS messaging and web-based communities - will be at the heart of the channel's purpose and an interactive live 'core' to the channel will create a service that children can truly call their own."

fields.headline: Grobbelaar loses match-fix damages appeal
fields.standfirst:
 Ex-goalkeeper set to lose £85,000 and faces legal bill
 Judge calls original verdict 'an affront to justice'
fields.trailText: The court of appeal today overturned an £85,000 libel award made to former Liverpool goalkeeper Bruce Grobbelaar over newspaper allegations accusing him of match-fixing.
fields.body:
The court of appeal today overturned an £85,000 libel award made to former Liverpool goalkeeper Bruce Grobbelaar over newspaper allegations accusing him of match-fixing.

A panel of judges sitting at the appeal court in London ruled in favour of an appeal brought by the Sun newspaper.

The ruling means Mr Grobbelaar stands to lose the original £85,000 and also faces the prospect of a legal bill estimated to be well in excess of £1.5m.

Costs awarded against the Sun after the libel verdict last year were put at £900,000. Appeal costs will add several hundred thousand to that.

Mr Grobbelaar, a former Zimbabwe goalkeeper, won the libel damages after a high court jury held that a series of articles in 1994 accusing him of matchfixing was libellous.

But in December last year the Sun appealed, with its lawyer Richard Spearman accusing Mr Grobbelaar of lying over taped interviews which he said backed the paper's claims.

"The defendants say that sadly the badges of dishonesty and corruption belong to Bruce Grobbelaar because he is condemned out of his own mouth on the admissions made on the tapes," Mr Spearman told the appeal court.

Mr Grobbelaar, 43, brought his libel action against the Sun after he was acquitted of conspiracy to fix football matches in a criminal trial.

The goalkeeper, along with the ex-Wimbledon players Hans Segers and John Fashanu and the businessman Richard Lim, was cleared in a 1997 re-trial after the first court action ended in deadlock.

After reviewing in detail the evidence heard at the high court hearing, Lord Justice Simon Brown said: "I come at last to consider the probabilities of the case, and it is at this point that, to my mind, Mr Grobbelaar's story falls apart.

"He had, as it seems to me, just too much to explain away - his entire dealings with Mr Lim, his remarkable visits to Manchester and to London, his large cash transactions at around the time of the Liverpool-Newcastle match, his confessions on tape ..."

He added: "There are simply too many improbabilities piled one upon another inherent in Mr Grobbelaar's case for it to begin to be credible.

"His whole account of his relationship and dealings with Mr Lim beggars belief at every turn."

Daniel Taylor, company solicitor for The Sun's publishers News International, said later that the historic ruling was without precedent.

"For the first time in English legal history, a jury verdict in a libel action has been set aside on appeal on the grounds that it was perverse and unreasonable and, in the words of the judgment, an affront and a miscarriage of justice."

Mr Taylor added: "He stands today condemned by three of the nation's most senior judges as a man who betrayed his team mates, his fans and the national game.

"It has been over six years since the Sun first exposed his duplicity, but today that investigation has been fully vindicated."

Lord Justice Simon Brown said that he had "some misgiving" about allowing the appeal on the defence of justification.

"That, however, is not because I entertain the least doubt about Mr Grobbelaar's guilt, but rather because, as I earlier observed, the court must inevitably be reluctant to find a jury's verdict perverse and anxious not to usurp their function."

He said it would have been easy to reject the newspaper's challenge on the basis that the issue was one for the jury.

"Some, no doubt, will say that that is the decision we should have reached. I cannot agree. It is, I think, the experience of all of us that juries, from time to time, do arrive at perverse verdicts."

He said the verdict was "an affront to justice". The Sun's other ground for appeal, that the stories about a public figure should have been protected by qualified privilege, was rejected by the court.

Mr Grobbelaar's lawyers were refused permission to take the case to the Lords, but they can enter their own petition.

Zimbawean Mr Grobbelaar won a string of honours with Liverpool, including the league championship, FA Cup and European Cup in the 1980s and early 1990s before going on to play for Southampton.

fields.headline: Police suspend top black officer
fields.standfirst: Special report: Policing crime
fields.trailText: Scotland Yard have suspended one of their highest ranking ethnic minority officers over allegations of misconduct.
fields.body:
Scotland Yard have suspended one of their highest ranking ethnic minority officers over allegations of misconduct.

Superintendent Ali Dizaei faces a "significant number" of allegations that police say cover a range of internal disciplinary and criminal issues.

Mr Dizaei is legal advisor to the National Black Police Association and was based at Kensington and Chelsea station in London.

This morning's suspension is said by Scotland Yard sources to be one of the most challenging issues to face the force in the post-Macpherson era.

A spokesman said that the allegations cover matters of dishonesty, attempting to pervert the course of justice, personal misconduct and integrity.

Mr Dizaei was formally suspended this morning, following an eight-month internal investigation.

He joined the Met two years ago from the Thames Valley force and is a trained lawyer. Mr Dizaei was unavailable for comment.

The Met say that they have voluntarily referred the case to the Police Complaints Authority.

Mr Dizaei hit the headlines in 1999 when he accused the police service of "ethnic cleansing" black and Asian candidates.

Testing procedures used to pick senior ranks were "culturally biased", he said.

The Iranian-born law graduate recently criticised Home Secretary Jack Straw for reinstating a PC who called a teenager a "black bastard" during a struggle to arrest him.

fields.headline: Leicester sign teacher Mancini
fields.trailText: Peter Taylor is convinced that Italian veteran Roberto Mancini can help bring the best out of young strikers Ade Akinbiyi and Trevor Benjamin.
fields.body:
Peter Taylor is convinced that Italian veteran Roberto Mancini can help bring the best out of young strikers Ade Akinbiyi and Trevor Benjamin.

Mancini has signed for an initial month with the Foxes after quitting as player-coach of Lazio at the same time as new England boss Sven-Goran Eriksson.

He has not kicked a ball in anger for the Italian club this season, but Taylor has put him straight into the squad for Saturday's home Premiership encounter with Arsenal.

The Foxes chief is aware that Akinbiyi, Benjamin and Richard Cresswell have precious little experience of top-flight football and wants Mancini to groom them for the future.

The Leicester manager confirmed: "We will definitely be taking Roberto for a month and see how things go from there, but he has already made a good impression with me.

"He fitted in well with training on Wednesday and is already very knowledgeable about a lot of our players.

"After training, he took away a few videos of our games to get to know even more about how we play."

Taylor added: "Of course, Roberto knows that he is 36 and that I am looking for his football knowledge, not his legs.

"There will be enough young legs around him to do the running so that should be alright.

"He also understands that his role will be to help bring on the younger players and pass on experience to the strikers.

"I am optimistic that this move could work out very well and he will definitely be in the 16 for Saturday's match with Arsenal."

Mancini, who was initially tipped to replace Eriksson as coach at Lazio, won 36 caps for his country and played for Bologna before spending 15 years with Sampdoria and then joining Lazio in 1997.

fields.headline: Lack of investigative journalism on TV criticised
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: Panorama reporter John Ware has attacked the dearth of investigative journalism on UK TV, reports Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
The Panorama reporter responsible for exposing the Omagh bombing suspects has launched a scathing attack on the dearth of investigative journalism on British television.

John Ware, who made the acclaimed Who Bombed Omagh? documentary last autumn, berated programme controllers and TV audiences for neglecting truly penetrative investigations that reveal how the country is run.

"There are fewer and fewer truly tough-minded TV investigations - the kind that take significant amounts of time, money and tenacity," he said.

Mr Ware's attack will add to concern that even so-called "investigative" series, such as BBC's popular McIntyre Undercover, tend to favour style over substance.

Meanwhile, the BBC is launching another personality-led investigative series, fronted by Panorama reporter Paul Kenyon, while Sky recently announced it was forming an investigative news unit.

Mr Ware said: "A lot of TV journalism which calls itself investigative is now focused on consumer affairs - which is not that testing - or involves hidden cameras which occasionally produce programmes of some importance but also many which are of no importance.

"Some are very watchable but ultimately more sexy than significant," he added.

Mr Ware also criticised the media for failing to fight back against government spin and corporate PR.

"The leakage of reality - the political, commercial and administrative presentation of events as opposed to the way they really are - is the great sickness of the age," he said.

Who Bombed Omagh? was seen by over 4m people and was the last Panorama to be shown in its Monday peaktime slot before it move to late Sunday nights.

Mr Ware's naming of the four men who are suspected of the bombing was the conclusion of a gruelling and ambitious five-month investigation.

"If television invested more in investigations like these we might make audiences more enquiring and revive interest in current affairs," said Mr Ware.

fields.headline: BBC claims public backing for digital proposals
fields.trailText: The BBC found strong public support for its proposed new digital TV and radio services in its just completed consultation, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The BBC found strong public support for its proposed new digital TV and radio services in its just completed consultation.

Out of nearly 7,000 people who responded to the BBC on its proposals between October 3 and November 17 last year, 73% believed the new services would be a valuable addition to the BBC's offering.

On individual service proposals, 86% welcomed an advertising-free pre-school children's channel and 87% were in favour of a BBC service for children aged between six and 13.

BBC3 received a 65% approval rating, a figure that rose to 87% among the 16-25 demographic that will be the channel's core target audience; while 85% of respondents were in favour of BBC4.

The BBC's plans for four new digital radio services were welcomed by 70% of respondents.

Even stronger support was found for all proposals in a parallel survey of a nationally representative sample by independent researchers BMRB.

fields.standfirst:
BBC reveals digital plans

fields.trailText:
1.45pm update: The BBC claims its new proposals will persuade more analogue viewers to switch to digital TV, reports Jason Deans.

BBC reveals digital plans
BBC digital plans at a glance
What's on BBC3
What's on BBC4
Useful link: BBC website
fields.body:
The BBC is pitching its new service plans as an enticement for analogue viewers reluctant to switch to digital TV.

In its letter to the Department of Culture, Media & Sport seeking approval for the proposals, the BBC said its own research suggested "there will be real difficulty in reaching the government's target of analogue switch-off by 2006-10, as some 30-40% of the population are not interested in subscribing to extra digital channels".

The letter also stated: "The BBC believes that, by providing a limited number of high quality, free to view channels, it will greatly increase the attractions of digital TV for them."

But the BBC was also keen to stress that in launching four new digital TV services it would not be neglecting BBC1 and BBC2.

An extra £235m has been set aside for new programming for the two channels over the next two years.

In addition, shows made for the new digital services will be repeated on the main channels.

"The 70% of households who have not yet switched to digital receivers will therefore also benefit from the BBC's investment in new digital services," the corporation argued.

"Investment by the BBC in its digital services will remain a modest proportion of overall BBC spending - less than 15%."

The BBC has also set out how it believes each of the proposed new digital TV services will be distinct from what commercial broadcasters already offer.

Arts and culture channel BBC4 "will feature a far wider and more ambitious range of subject matter than either [commercial rivals] Artsworld or Performance Channel, including science, business, social issues, philosophy, politics and global affairs".

The BBC also emphasised that its proposed new children's services "are not designed to replace existing commercial channels for children", but to complement them in pay-TV homes and ensure "services for children are also available to those who cannot or do not wish to pay subscriptions".

These services will be distinctive, according to the BBC, because an extra £30m a year will be spent on UK children's programming, "opening up opportunities for both in-house and independent producers and helping to stimulate the children's production market".

webTitle: First flight for Concorde since crash

fields.headline: First flight for Concorde since crash
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: Concorde today made its first flight since last summer's Paris crash - but only for two weeks of rigorous testing at an aviation base.
fields.body:
Concorde today made its first flight since last summer's Paris crash - but only for two weeks of rigorous testing at an aviation base.

The crew-only Air France Concorde flight took off without incident from Paris's Charles de Gaulle airport, bound for a military aviation base at Istres, southern France. Half a dozen fire engines and at least one ambulance stood by as the plane took off, watched by Concorde enthusiasts lining the runway fence.

At the base, engineers will simulate fuel leaks on the underside of one of the aircraft's wings, as part of the work needed to bring Concorde back into passenger service and to better understand the chain of events that led to last year's crash.

A fuel-tank fire triggered by flying debris from a gashed tyre caused Air France Concorde flight AF4590 to crash near Paris on 25 July last year. All 109 people on board and four on the ground were killed.

The disaster prompted safety investigations into the ageing Concorde fleet. Until today, no Air France Concorde has flown since the accident and British Airways' seven-strong Concorde fleet has also been grounded since mid-August.

British Airways and Air France have joined forces to develop and test new safety measures for the planes. The ground work at Istres complements tests being carried out on BA Concordes at London's Heathrow airport.

This week, BA began outfitting one of its Concordes with liners made from material used in bullet-proof vests, designed to contain fuel if the plane's wing is ruptured.

Within eight to 10 weeks, it is hoped a BA Concorde will be ready to take a test flight. If successful, British Airways said this week that the supersonic jets might resume passenger services by the spring.

fields.headline: The best sports films and the 20th century flops
fields.trailText: As Derek Malcolm comes to the end of his century of film, Frank Keating recalls the best - and the worst - movies about sport
fields.body:
Mike Selvey's pithy little inswinger in yesterday's letters' page in the Guardian drew both a spot-on bead and a chuckle: "The lads at the White Hart are nervous that Derek Malcolm might slip in Titanic as the last of his top 100 films and so spoil a proud record of never having heard of any of the previous 99."

In G2 today, Derek opens his final envelope to announce his top of the tops. No sporting film made his list. Not surprising - there might have been, just about, 100 films devoted exclusively to sport but with the best will in the world they would not sustain 1,000-word mulling over for 100 weeks - that is, a fortnight under two years. Like, once you'd seen Rocky, you'd seen the lot.

For starters, you have strictly to categorise what you might call a "sporting" film. There are films about sport, films with snatches of sporting matters in them, and out and out sports documentary films per se, in which category the two Olympic films of 1936 and 1964, respectively Leni Riefenstahl's Olympia and Kon Ichikawa's Tokyo Olympiad remain still the apotheosis of the genre (good words for this particular sort of column).

Down the last century, I suppose most Hollywood feature films on sport have mostly concerned boxing ever since the first boxer-turned-actor Jimmy Clabby first bobbed and weaved across the flickering silver screen in The Kidnapped Pugilist in 1914. (Countless films about baseball have been churned out, but till recently they have been wary about their box-office appeal in uninitiated Europe).

Kirk Douglas was a great champ, so was Jack Palance, Spencer Tracey, Paul Newman, Liam Neeson and ringfuls more, including Charlie Chaplin and Danny Kaye, but the contest for the finest boxing film surely has to be a split-decision between Scorsese's ketchup-dripping Raging Bull and Huston's evocative small-town Fat City. My scorecard unreservedly ticks the latter, plus the all-time Oscar for Stacy Keach, the washed-out has-been attempting a comeback. But Fat City lost money as Huston despaired: "Fans want champs; people don't care for the spiritual processes of the defeated."

The cinema has seen few original screenplays on sport - most are adapted from short stories, novels, and plays. Which made Colin Welland's first-up screenplay for Chariots of Fire sock audiences even more delightedly between the eyes. The over-scholarly felt Welland took poetic licence too far over the facts of the 1924 Olympics but, heck, what's poetry for but licence?

The director Hugh Hudson has since not had remotely such a global success since, but Chariots will remain his resonantly substantial monument. Memorable still, and on my top three on the all-time podium.

Jostling with Chariots might have been The Hustler and Paul Newman's thrusting young pool player, and The Cincinnati Kid, Steve McQueen the likewise card sharp - but I disqualify them both; at their core was gambling, not sport or games playing.

Biopics of celebrated sportsmen have never quite come off, much as Hollywood has reeled them in and rolled them out. All I will say for sport is that William Bendix as Babe Ruth, Burt Lancaster as Jim Thorpe, James Earl Jones as Jack Johnson and Tommy Lee Jones (riveting) as Ty Cobb were streets ahead in terms of art imitating life than one-eared Kirk Douglas as Van Gogh, Charlton ("Athletic") Heston as Michelangelo or even, for heaven's sakes, Greer Garson as Madame ("Eureka! I guess") Curie.

Motor racing films such as Le Mans and Grand Prix I don't count either - good, but too noisy and over reliant on the hero's rival being cremated on the final bend. I liked baseball's Bull Durham a lot, and Field of Dreams, and ice hockey's swearword-a-minute Slap Shot: not so much golf's raved Tin Cup.

I'm afraid Brits were heavily implicated in last century's two worst sports films - Escape to Victory about soccer-playing POWs and The Final Test (old Jack Warner pretending to be Jack Hobbs) - but there were some good ones too. I adored Tony Richardson's Loneliness of the Long Distance Runner (Tom Courtney v-signing the reform school governor by not winning a race. But that wasn't so much sport as rebellion). So the bronze has to go to Lindsay Anderson's gritty (and Richard Harris's muddy) This Sporting Life.

I appreciate our Derek (our one-time racing correspondent, did you know?) could easily list two score bullfighting films, but here for the fun of it, in reverse order, is this corner's 100 weeks condensed into two or three hours: 3, This Sporting Life; 2, Chariots of Fire; 1, Fat City.

webTitle: Volunteering gives a new lease of life

fields.headline: Volunteering gives a new lease of life
fields.standfirst: Chancellor Gordon Brown has unveiled a £300m package to promote volunteering especially among older people. Nicola Hill talks to two older men to find out why they volunteer
fields.trailText: Chancellor Gordon Brown has unveiled a £300m package to promote volunteering especially among older people. Nicola Hill talks to two older men to find out why they volunteer
fields.body:
Bill Ibbotson

Mr Ibbotson is a volunteer regional organiser for RSVP in Barnet, a section of Community Service Volunteers especially aimed at older people. He coordinates volunteers who help out in schools across the borough as well as a group of volunteers befriending elderly patients at Finchley Memorial Hospital. The volunteers visit patients who do not have much support from family and friends, help them with any questions or queries they have and provide a friendly face and someone to talk to.

"I was made redundant at 58 with a heart problem and was virtually unemployable. But rather than sitting in a chair thinking the end had come, I decided to help out in a local school." This then developed into running a group of volunteers in Barnet.

Mr Ibbotson doesn't think money alone is the answer to recruiting more volunteers, he thinks the government should put pressure on local councils to help voluntary organisations by providing resources. "They have enormous assets - schools with spare rooms, photocopying facilities and massive purchasing power."

He also says the range of volunteering opportunities needs to be promoted. "People generally think of Oxfam shops but there are hundreds of things to do - helping disabled children swim, mentoring . . ." One 89-year-old woman he knows runs a group of 20 volunteers who knit "trauma teddies" for the police to give to children at the scene of accidents.

"I used to go on management courses and we would be told that people were motivated by a sense of belonging and I used to think that was rubbish, it was money that mattered. But when I stopped working it was the companionship that I missed. Volunteering provides me with that but I wouldn't do it unless I enjoyed it."

Geoff Moody

Geoff Moody is a 60-year-old retired policeman from Durham who volunteers with RSVP in Bishop Auckland. He runs a transport scheme, which chauffeurs housebound and disabled people to and from the local hospital and GP surgery. He recently made his 1,000th trip and is hoping to expand the scheme, even though he is recovering from prostate cancer.

"I was asked by the local surgery to form a support group of volunteers for the health centre. Although the head of the centre didn't think enough people would be interested, I recruited 25 people - retired doctors, taxi drivers, policemen and business people." The group provides transport for people who need lifts to the surgery or local hospitals. Volunteers are paid expenses and users of the service are asked to make a donation if they can afford it.

Mr Moody said: "It keeps me in touch with the public, I'm well known in the area, and it is nice to be thanked by youngsters for looking after their grandparents."

webTitle: MPs vote for ban on fox hunting

fields.headline: MPs vote for ban on fox hunting
fields.standfirst: Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: MPs last night endorsed overwhelmingly a total ban on fox hunting, paving the way for a confrontation with the Lords which will spill over into the general election campaign.
fields.body:
MPs last night endorsed overwhelmingly a total ban on fox hunting, paving the way for a confrontation with the Lords which will spill over into the general election campaign.

MPs voted by 399 to 155 to reject the option of keeping the status quo, a result that tallied closely with the 411 to 151 vote to ban fox hunting when MPs in November 1997 gave a second reading to Michael Foster's private member's bill.

A further proposal to have hunting regulated through a licensing system was rejected by 382 to 182 votes.

Tony Blair again told MPs he opposed fox hunting but signalled his uneasiness at the wider politics of a ban by missing the vote, flying instead to Belfast in a bid to revive the peace process.

But earlier Mr Blair gave a veiled warning to peers not to defy the Commons. He said: "We will wait and see what happens in the other house."

The MPs' decision last night came as hundreds of fox hunters held rallies around the country and vowed to defy the law if a ban is imposed.

The bill will go into committee for detailed scrutiny and then pass to the Lords by the end of February. Peers are expected to vote for a middle way option of state licensed hunts backed by a legally enforceable code of conduct.

It is unlikely that MPs would then have time to overturn the Lords before March 29, the last date on which parliament can sit prior to the expected May 3 election.

The Tory leader in the Lords, Lord Strathclyde, confirmed that the bill had little chance of reaching the statute book before the election.

He promised: "When the bill reaches the House of Lords, it will be subjected to the same scrutiny as any other government bill. No bill, not even the shortest and least controversial one, can normally pass the Lords in less than six to seven weeks from when it leaves the Commons," he said.

"That means that if there is an election called for April or May this bill has no chance of becoming law, for timing reasons alone."

Jockeying has already started in the Labour high command over the wording of the manifesto commitment on a ban. Labour faces a choice between offering another free vote backed by government time, or promising to invoke the Parliament Act and so short-circuit further opposition from peers.

In the Commons the Tories attacked Labour for showing a warped set of priorities. David Lidington, the shadow home affairs spokesman, said: "In my view a ban would criminalise thousands of law-abiding citizens and do nothing to improve animal welfare."

fields.headline: Son of Star Wars
fields.standfirst:
William Hague has backed George W Bush's plans for a national missile defence system. Here's our guide to the best sites on Dubya's pet project

More NetNotes
fields.trailText:
NetNotes:William Hague has backed George W Bush's plans for a national missile defence system. Here's our guide to the best sites on Dubya's pet project
More NetNotes
fields.body:
1. It all began with Ronald Reagan and his ambitious (some would say fantastic) 1983 plan for a space-borne missile defence system, known as the strategic defence initative, but quickly dubbed Star Wars.

2. The idea was immediately rubbished by many. Russia, fearing a nuclear attack, was particularly unhappy about it.

3. There was also concern that the lasers Star Wars would employ to shoot down incoming nuclear missiles could themselves be used as weapons.

4. Star Wars transformed into a missile-to-missile system, theatre high altitude area defence (THAAD), rather than Reagan's space laser fantasy. The system relied heavily on America's bases in the UK, Fylingdales and Menwith Hill in the Yorkshire Dales.

5. The problem was, after an obscene amount of money was spent on the project, Star Wars still didn't work. To prove otherwise, the Pentagon allegedly rigged some tests.

6. But some companies, such as Lockheed Martin, weren't worried, as Star Wars was very good for business.

7. Enthusiasm for the whole project slowly waned throughout the 90s, until President Clinton decided to revive the idea. Predictably, his decision was also ridiculed.

8. Although some people still thought it was a good idea.

9. With the ascent of George W Bush, Star Wars - or the Son Of - is back on the agenda, now known as national missile defence.

10. William Hague is behind the plan all the way. But is Tony Blair?

fields.headline: What's on BBC4
fields.trailText: BBC4 will offer an ambitious range of programming on science, business, politics and the arts, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
The key purpose of BBC4, says the corporation, is to underline the BBC's public service commitment.

According to the BBC it will offer "a far wider and more ambitious range of subject-matter than either Artsworld or Performance Channel, including science, business, social issues, philosophy, politics and global affairs".

There will be extended coverage of the BBC Proms, Young Musicians and Cardiff Singer of the World competitions and programmes deriving from the BBC partnership with the Royal Opera House.

The BBC says the channel will be "an extension of BBC TV's cultural programming, not a substitute for it".

It says that BBC1 and BBC2's commitment to broadcast around 230 hours a year of music and arts programming will not be affected by the launch of the channel.

BBC4 will broadcast from 7pm to 1am daily and is aimed at anyone with an interest in highbrow culture.

It is expected to rely heavily on deals already struck by BBC1 and BBC2 to cover events with a paltry budget of £26m in year one.

Today's outline schedule for the channel includes world cinema, weekly cultural debates and interviews in the style of BBC Radio's In Our Time.

fields.headline: BBC splashes out £300m on new digital services
fields.standfirst:
BBC digital plans at a glance
What's on BBC3
What's on BBC4
Useful link: BBC website
fields.trailText:
12pm: The BBC has unveiled plans to spend more than £300m on new digital TV and radio services in the next two years, reports Jason Deans.

BBC digital plans at a glance
What's on BBC3
What's on BBC4
Useful link: BBC website
fields.body:
The BBC has revealed plans to spend more than £300m on new digital TV and radio services in the next two years.

Its proposals were submitted to the government today for approval as part of a statutory consultation process.

In total, BBC director general Greg Dyke is proposing a £313m investment in four new digital TV services and five digital radio services between April 2001 and March 2003, subject to the approval of culture secretary Chris Smith.

Nearly half the money - £152m - will go to BBC3, the youth-oriented TV channel due to relaunch from the ashes of BBC Choice towards the end of this year.

BBC4, the highbrow arts and culture channel that has been described as the Radio 3 and Radio 4 of TV, will get £57m over the next two years.

This is a fraction of the current £89m annual budget of Radio 4 and the £64m Radio 3 gets.

The new service is due to replace BBC Knowledge on digital cable, satellite and terrestrial networks before the end of 2001.

The lengthy proposals also reveal that the BBC is planning to launch one of its planned children's services as early as this summer.

This is despite howls of protest from the commercial sector, which claims that the BBC should not be allowed use licence-payers money on services already provided by channels such as Nickelodeon and Disney.

The BBC has set aside £82m for two new children's TV channels.

One is a pre-school service for children under six and is slated to go on air in mid 2001, with a second service for six to 13-year-olds due to launch early next year.

In addition, the BBC is proposing to invest £22m over the next two years in five new digital radio services, including a music service aimed at a young black audience, a new best of BBC speech radio station, an Asian network and Five Live Sports Plus.

A BBC spokesman said: "We believe that our new television and radio service proposals will provide a distinctive but complementary alternative to commercial services.

"The proposals will add substantially to viewers' and listeners' choice, with a wide range of high quality British-made programmes, universally available and free to people with digital equipment," he added.

The BBC's commercial broadcasting rivals and other interested parties have just over a month, until February 28, to submit comments to the Department of Culture Media & Sport as part of the culture secretary's consultation on the corporation's digital proposals.

fields.headline: What's on BBC3
fields.trailText: BBC3 , the corporation says, will be "firmly rooted in the BBC's core objectives" and will be the only channel in the corporation's line-up to "focus exclusively on the young and young at heart".
fields.body:
BBC3 , the corporation says, will be "firmly rooted in the BBC's core objectives" and will be the only channel in the corporation's line-up to "focus exclusively on the young and young at heart".

It will launch end of this year or the beginning of next, with insiders predicting a February start date.

The channel's £57m budget in its first year is similar to that of Channel 4's new station, E4, but is paltry compared with that of BBC1, which mops up a massive £823m a year on everything from costume drama, soaps such as EastEnders and news.

According to today's proposals, it will, however, have access to BBC1 and BBC2's high-profile talent.

BBC3 will broadcast from 8pm to 2am seven days a week and is aimed at 16 to 34-year-olds.

The proposed schedule includes an on-the-hour news service, contemporary drama such as This Life and light entertainment such as Never Mind the Buzzcocks.

BBC3 boss Stuart Murphy is also promising new talent comedy shows such as the League of Gentlemen and sports entertainment such as They Think It's All Over.

Around 90% of the schedule will be British with new content, including repeats of new content, accounting for 80% of the schedule.

fields.body:
Enodis, the engineering and machinery group formerly known as Berisford, paid the price for disappointing an increasingly sceptical market yesterday as its shares fell 17% to a new year low of 179.5p.

Senior executives at the company warned first-half profits from its core catering division would fall "some way short" of the strong performance recorded last year.

The outlook, they admitted, was uncertain with the continuing impact of a store closure programme by one of its top US clients, coupled with a general weakening of the marketplace.

The comments, made at the annual meeting, had a swift and brutal impact on the stock price which rapidly sunk to a two-year low of 168p before recovering slightly.

But it is not all gloom for Enodis, which principally operates in the commercial food equipment, domestic kitchen furniture, bathroom and joinery products.

Opinion is still mixed in the City, where many analysts are split between "buy" and "hold" ratings, and the company still has its supporters.

Investment bank CSFB, for example, cut its price target from 360p to 320p because of the earnings downgrade, but maintained its buy rating as the value of Enodis still makes the emergence of a buyer for the food equipment side a possibility.

There is also the hope of a soft landing in north America, while the declining trend in the beverage market, according to the company, appears to be flattening.

On top of this the management has pledged to vigorously attack costs, although the benefits are unlikely to be seen until the second half.

They key for Enodis will be how well it performs over the coming months and whether it decides on any corporate activity.

Serious questions are already being asked about the future of Magnet, its kitchen and bathroom manufacturing business, which analysts don't believe fits in with the company's focus. Hold.

fields.headline: New Media Age
fields.standfirst: Publication date: January 18
fields.trailText: January 18: The Direct Marketing Association wants to include SMS in its opt-out marketing regulations.
fields.body:
The Direct Marketing Association's bid to become the industry body of choice for e-business has kicked off with a recommendation for an opt-out SMS preference service.

AOL plans to drop Internet Explorer as its default browser and replace it with Netscape Navigator when the contract comes up for review next year.

Vodafone is to launch the UK's first full voice-browsing service as an alternative to WAP.

Interactive TV agency Smashed Atom is setting up a cross-industry body to combat bad design in interactive TV.

Premium-rate telephone service watchdog ICSTIS is cracking down on unscrupulous ISPs and content providers who deliberately mislead consumers about call charges.

SohoLondon founder Nick Henry has quit the agency to launch dedicated mobile marketing company Wireless Ventures.

Channel 4 has linked up with interactive agency KPE to produce a cross-platform broadband destination for digital entertainment channel E4.

Site of the week www.roalddahl.com scored 63 out of 75 and is described as "more than just a site for Dahl lovers".

fields.headline: Micra production still in doubt
fields.standfirst: £40m government aid package may not safeguard future of the new model in Britain
fields.trailText: Britain's battered motor industry may see the loss of more jobs to mainland Europe even though the European commission yesterday cleared a £40m government aid package to help Nissan's Sunderland plant in its campaign to make the new Micra model.
fields.body:
Britain's battered motor industry may see the loss of more jobs to mainland Europe even though the European commission yesterday cleared a £40m government aid package to help Nissan's Sunderland plant in its campaign to make the new Micra model.

Nissan's executive board is to decide later this month whether to build the new car at Sunderland or at a Renault plant at Flins, near Paris.

A spokesman for the Japanese car company, which is 37% owned by Renault, said the EC's decision slightly improved Sunderland's chances, but stressed that many other uncertainties remained.

If the French plant wins, more than a third of Nissan's 5,000-strong workforce at Sunderland could lose their jobs. It would be another body blow for the British motor industry which is already facing the loss of thousands of jobs.

Ford and Vauxhall have both decided to close plants in Britain and move work to other plants in mainland Europe, where costs are lower due to the weak euro.

Nissan's Sunderland plant currently makes the Primera, Almera and old Micra models. Nissan would have to invest £315m to build the new Micra at Sunderland. Production is due to start in 2003.

Under the cost-cutting plans implemented by Carlos Ghosn, the former Renault executive now running Nissan, the new Micra will share many common components with Renault's Clio and Twingo models made at Flins.

Mr Ghosn put pressure on the EC by saying that a choice between Sunderland and Flins would be made by the end of the month even if the aid issue had not been resolved.

The British government had gone out of its way to get a quick decision from Brussels.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, said he was grateful that the aid application had been cleared in record time. "We are continuing to press the case for Sunderland and today's news is helpful. But Nissan has made it clear that this is just one of a number of issues that will influence its decision."

The EC was not initially convinced that Flins was a serious alternative to Sunderland, even though it had a considerable cost advantage. It launched a formal investigation into the deal in September last year.

However, Mario Monti, the competition commissioner, said yesterday he was now satisfied that the proposed aid was in line with EU rules.

General Motors, which is closing its Vauxhall plant at Luton with the loss of 2,000 jobs, yesterday reported a $5bn (£3.4bn) profit for last year. Sales rose 4.4% to a record $183.3bn.

However, fourth-quarter earnings were almost halved, mainly as a result of poor performance in Europe and losses at Isuzu, its Japanese affiliate.

webTitle: Jodie Foster takes on Cannes jury duty

fields.headline: Jodie Foster takes on Cannes jury duty
fields.trailText: The double Academy Award-winning actress, who speaks fluent French, will head the jury at this year's Cannes International Film Festival
fields.body:
Jodie Foster has been named as the head of the jury at this year's Cannes International Film Festival. But the choice of a major Hollywood player to front the festival has been seen in some quarters as a political exercise on the part of Cannes president Gilles Jacob, who was criticised last year for allegedly keeping American product at the festival to a minimum. The appointment of Foster, insiders say, is part of a deliberate effort to smooth ruffled Hollywood feathers.

Yesterday Jacob moved swiftly to counter such speculation. "We didn't choose Jodie to please America, but to please the whole world," he said. "Jodie promised me years ago that she would do it. She has won the highest awards. It was high time she came to Cannes to award some herself."

In addition to scooping Oscars for her performances in The Accused and The Silence of the Lambs, Foster's earlier film Taxi Driver won the Palme D'Or at Cannes in 1976. The daughter of a Parisian mother, the actress speaks fluent French and yesterday admitted that she was delighted with the appointment. "I've dreamed of the honour of being president of the jury at Cannes since I was a child," she said. The 54th Cannes International Film Festival runs from May 9-20.

webTitle: BBC digital plans at a glance

fields.headline: BBC digital plans at a glance
fields.trailText: However modest the budgets and however much director-general Greg Dyke argues that the BBC is limiting its expansion, the corporation's blueprint is far from modest.
fields.body:
However modest the budgets and however much director-general Greg Dyke argues that the BBC is limiting its expansion, the corporation's blueprint is far from modest.

If the BBC gets the go ahead for its plans, viewers will be able to watch or listen to a total of 18 channels, not including the BBC's World Service, in just two years' time.

Today's consultation outlines the budgets, timetable and schedules for the services for the first time.

TELEVISION

 BBC1 and BBC 2: The BBC insists it is not turning its back on its core services, with an extra £95m in 2001/2 and an extra £140m a year from 2002/3 being ploughed into BBC1 and BBC2.

 The BBC's UK news channel, BBC News 24 , will also continue, as will BBC Parliament, which will develop its commitment to covering the devolved Scottish Parliament and Welsh and Northern Ireland Assemblies as well as Westminster.

 BBC3 will rise from the ashes of BBC Choice in late 2001 and early 2002. It will be an alternative channel to woo back younger viewers who have deserted to Channel 4, E4 and satellite television.

 BBC4 will be created out of BBC Knowledge, offering increased coverage of the arts, sciences, history, philosophy and current affairs.

 BBC Children A: A service for children under six promising a range of "new, high-quality, UK-produced educative and entertaining programmes for young children, alongside the BBC's highly valued existing pre-school strands". To launch this year.

 BBC Children B: A service for children between six to 13-year- old: The BBC promises "exciting drama, comedy, entertainment, news and factual programmes with the best of current CBBC output and the very best of world children's television for children.

RADIO

 The BBC also proposes to offer five new radio networks in addition to the existing Radios 1-5 Live and World Service. Radios 1-5 will remain much as they are, but there will be five new national digital radio services:

 Network X (working title): black music, news and factual programmes for a primarily young audience.

 Network Y (working title): will offer popular music from the BBC's extensive archive from the 1970s to the 1990s.

 Network Z (working title): the best of current and archive radio programmes of comedy, drama, stories and features, with programmes aimed at both adults and children.

 BBC Five Live Sports Plus: a new outlet for live sport.

 BBC Asian Network: a range of programmes focused on Asian audiences currently available only regionally.

 In addition, for some time as an experiment BBC World Service has been available in the UK on the BBC's digital radio multiplex (alongside its overnight availability on BBC Radio 4).

webTitle: Bill will lead to 'scramble' for GPs

fields.headline: Bill will lead to 'scramble' for GPs
fields.trailText: Health minister Alan Milburn faces another challenge to his health and social care bill today after a Department of Health committee attacked his proposals to reform the provision of family doctor services as "flawed" and "outdated". Patrick Butler reports
fields.body:
Health minister Alan Milburn faces another challenge to his health and social care bill today after a Department of Health committee attacked his proposals to reform the provision of family doctor services as "flawed" and "outdated".

The medical practices committee (MPC), which ensures the fair distribution of GPs across the NHS, has warned Mr Milburn that its proposed abolition will pitch health authorities into a chaotic scramble to recruit scarce doctors.

The MPC, whose abolition is likely to be debated by MPs in the Commons today, said the removal of national controls over GP distribution will lead to "an open market for a scarce commodity".

The row over the abolition of the MPC - which both the British Medical Association and the Royal College of GPs oppose - follows widespread criticism last week of the government's plans to replace community health councils.

MPC chairwoman Ro Day has written to Mr Milburn saying his justification for abolishing the committee is outdated and that latest data gives the lie to his claim that the current system has led to a shortage of GPs in deprived areas in the north of England.

Mrs Day claims that Mr Milburn misled MPs last week when he claimed there were "50% more GPs in Kingston and Richmond or Oxfordshire than there are in Barnsley and Sunderland".

She says: "Using up-to-date figures there will now be proportionally more GPs in both Sunderland and Barnsley than in either Kingston and Richmond or Oxfordshire."

She adds: "I am writing to express my serious concern that incorrect and misleading information is being presented as justification for the proposed abolition of the medical practices committee."

The government is determined to correct what it sees as a historical bias in GP distribution that has led what it has claimed is an over-provision of family doctor provision in the shires at the expense of Labour's northern and inner-city heartlands.

It wants to hand local health authorities and primary care trusts the power to organise their own GP provision through a financial allocations formula.

But the MPC argues this will create an inequitable internal market in which health authorities "battle" each other to hire doctors - a battle that the wealthiest authorities will win.

It says: "The MPC feels strongly that there should continue to be an over-arching national body empowered to undertake an active role in the management in the equitable national distribution of GPs.

"Over its 52-year stewardship of the distribution of general medical practitioners, the MPC has made a valuable and important contribution towards achieving equity in the distribution of doctors Distributing GPs according to a financial allocations formula can only create an open market for a scarce commodity.

"Health authorities may well be able to attract GPs to their under-doctored areas through the offer of enhanced financial packages, but with a finite number of GPs available, this can only be at the expense of other areas."
