webTitle: Why do ministers really want to abolish MPC?

fields.headline: Why do ministers really want to abolish MPC?
fields.standfirst: The medical practices committee - which ensures the fair distribution of GPs across the NHS - is set to be scrapped under the NHS plan. But committee member Dr Sarah Jarvis fears it is an attempt by ministers to control doctors
fields.trailText: The medical practices committee - which ensures the fair distribution of GPs across the NHS - is set to be scrapped under the NHS plan. But committee member Dr Sarah Jarvis fears it is an attempt by ministers to control doctors
fields.body:
For more than 50 years, the medical practices committee (MPC) - which ministers wish to abolish - has been charged with the task of ensuring that patients have equitable access to GPs.

In recent years, the increasing shortage of GPs has meant that in order to maintain relative national equity, the committee has been forced to make some unpalatable and unpopular decisions, turning down applications for practice or locality vacancies on the basis that other areas needed the GPs more.

At the same time, GP workload - both in terms of consultation rate and bureaucracy - has continued to increase, and some GPs have been understandably upset at being refused the medical workforce they felt they needed to provide a high quality service.

Despite its best efforts, there is still not complete equity of distribution of GP workforce - and in its quest for a scapegoat, the government has picked upon the MPC. The health and social care bill will bring into statute the abolition of the MPC, announced by the secretary of state for health in the NHS plan of June 2000.

But what is the real reason for consigning the MPC to sacrificial bonfire of equity? Has it really failed in its purpose? The general practices committee (GPC) and the royal college of general practitioners (RCGP) think not.

These two bodies might be expected to be among those most likely to gloat at its demise - the former because it represents so many GPs whose requests for new partners have been ignored by the committee; the latter because the MPC has found itself bound by statute to ignore the workforce implications of really high quality practices.

Yet in their joint response to the NHS plan, the bodies state that they "find the proposed abolition of the MPC perplexing and profoundly worrying, not because we seek to preserve an expert body which has served the country well, but because we believe that this proposal will achieve the opposite effect on equitable distribution to that envisaged

"The MPC has never had the ability to influence the socio-economic forces which determine where people, in this case GPs, choose to settle. Despite this, the MPC has succeeded in ensuring all patients across the country have good access to reasonable numbers of GPs. Indeed, matters might have been far worse were it not for the expertise of the MPC over the years."

So what is the government's rationale? At first glance, cost might seem to be the reason. The MPC costs £500,000 per annum to run, and the explanatory notes on the bill state that there is a "potential saving to the government".

Yet the vast majority of the MPC's work centres on workforce planning, and the government proposes instead to set up a series of workforce development confederations, at a cost of many millions of pounds, to address workforce and training issues for GPs and other primary care staff.

The MPC's success has been limited by its powers of negative direction, which allow it to declare vacancies in needy areas but not to direct GPs to work there - issues largely centred on socio-economic forces.

As the GPC/RCGP response states: "Successive governments could have created the necessary financial inducements to counter these forces but have failed to do so."

The government has thrown itself wholeheartedly into the quest for more efficient and innovative working in general practice, via the NHS primary care pilots, but has, as with fundholding, failed to commission any robust research into its effectiveness before rolling out the programme.

Can it be coincidence that a desirable side-effect of the pilots, from the government's point of view, is the change for involved GPs from self-employed (independent) to employed (far more easily controlled) contractor status?

Further, can it be coincidence that abolishing the MPC and incorporating GP workforce planning into general primary care workforce planning makes GPs just one more layer in the health workforce? Could it be that the MPC made them too special, and therefore more difficult to control?

 Dr Sarah Jarvis is a west London GP

webTitle: Letters: War Child writes to clear name

fields.headline: War Child mounts an offensive to clear its name
fields.trailText: We would like to set the record straight in response to allegations against War Child UK (January 10), write patrons and trustees of War Child.
fields.body:
We would like to set the record straight in response to allegations against War Child UK (January 10). Firstly, the impression given is that patrons left recently - but Luciano Pavarotti, Brian Eno, Juliet Stevenson, Brent Hansen, David Bowie and Tom Stoppard resigned between February and June 2000. Neil Morrissey has been a patron of War Child UK since 1998 and Hugo Speer has been a patron since 1999.

Bill Leeson left on October 29 1999 and Mike Terry has not been involved since March 1999.

When the then trustees were made aware of the payment to Bill Leeson, they ordered its immediate return. The decision to retain Bill Leeson as an employee rests with that board.

War Child UK's administrative costs are not excessive. Over the past four years, our average administrative costs have been 5.5%. These are shown in our audited accounts. We disagree with the figure stated by the charity commission and have requested clarification as to how they calculated it.

No money that has already been raised for the Pavarotti Music Centre has gone astray. Additional funding has recently been received which will be disbursed in full to the project. The only other element that has not gone to the project is the contractually agreed 8% administration charge. War Child Netherlands continues to support the Pavarotti Music Centre.

All money raised by War Child UK for the Liberian Children's Village was directed to that project. The initial expenditure, which was paid from London, related to development costs in starting up the project. These costs included the assessment, looking for suitable land and other legitimate expenses. All remaining monies were transferred to War Child Italy, together with all the relevant paperwork.

Eleven employees did attend the Modena concert in 1998 but at minimum cost. Six people drove and the rest flew economy. All of them were engaged throughout the concert on War Child UK work. It was a prime opportunity to raise the profile of the charity and promote its work.

Lynne Kuschel states that she has never taken a business class flight on War Child UK business. She did attend the garden party in Sarejevo to celebrate the Queen's birthday in summer 1998 at the invitation of Charles Crawford, the British ambassador to Bosnia, because she had been awarded the MBE for War Child's diabetic programme.

All the allegations predate the involvement of the current board of trustees. War Child "started as a daring and innovative charity" and the current board, staff and patrons are determined that the ideals at the heart of the charity will remain.

fields.headline: Win A Century of Films
fields.standfirst: Every Thursday for two years, Guardian film critic Derek Malcolm wrote about his top 100 movies - now the basis of his new book, Derek Malcolm's Personal Best: A Century of Films (ID Tauris, £9.95). Tackle our quiz on the Century of Films for a chance to win one of five copies of the book
fields.trailText: Tackle our quiz on the Century of Films for a chance to win one of five copies of Derek Malcolm's Personal Best: A Century of Films
fields.body:
1. Which versatile figure makes two appearances on Malcolm's list, as the director of The Wind and the star of Wild Strawberries?
A. DW Griffith
B. Victor Sjostrom
C. Carl Dreyer

2. What was the title of the fictitious film-within-a-film in Preston Sturges's Sullivan's Travels that was recently appropriated by a bona fide movie?
A. O Brother, Where Art Thou?
B. Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon
C. The Wind Will Carry Us

3. Who is the youngest director included on the Century of Films?
A. Jean Vigo (for L'Atalante)
B. Paul Morrissey (for Trash)
C. Michael Reeves (for Witchfinder General)

4. How did the French director of the classic hitman thriller Le Samourai affect an all-American style?
A. He changed his surname to Pollock (after visiting the Musee d'Orsay) and had his Paris home redecorated as a Western saloon
B. He changed his surname to Presley (after first hearing the Sun Sessions) and cultivated an Elvis quiff and sideboards
C. He changed his surname to Melville (after reading Moby Dick) and wore a Stetson hat on the movie set

5. Which of these artists is NOT featured on the soundtrack of Pasolini's The Gospel According to St. Matthew?
A. Prokoviev
B. Beethoven
C. Billie Holliday

6. What did critics claim was Japanese film-maker Kenji Mizoguchi's prime reason for making movies?
A. To settle scores with his estranged family
B. To earn enough money to entertain geishas
C. To fund a hefty opium habit

7. Which novel was Erich von Stroheim's silent-screen classic Greed adapted from?
A. Frank Norris's McTeague
B. Willa Cather's O Pioneers!
C. Mark Twain's Pudd'n'head Wilson

8. In his introduction to film number 55, Malcolm writes: "Those celebrating the success of Sam Mendes's American Beauty as a scorching exposure of American suburbia might benefit from taking another look at [this] much more radical fable on the same subject." What film is he referring to?
A. David Lynch's Blue Velvet
B. Bob Rafelson's The King of Marvin Gardens
C. John Cassavetes's The Killing of a Chinese Bookie

9. Which featured director, once interviewed by Malcolm on the toilet, commanded the writer to "come on in. I can deal with two shits at once."
A. John Huston
B. John Ford
C. Ingmar Bergman

10. The plot concerns the wife of a political prisoner who tells the man's sick mother that her son is away pursuing a Hollywood career. Malcolm judges it "one of the most moving commentaries of life under political tyranny that I have ever seen." It's one of the lesser known choices on the Century of Film. But which one?
A. Ousmane Sembene's Xala
B. Ermanno Olmi's The Tree of Wooden Clogs
C. Karoly Makk's Love

webTitle: Casting news: Sandra Bullock to star in Ya-Ya Sisterhood

fields.headline: Sandra Bullock to star in Ya-Ya Sisterhood
fields.standfirst: Plus: Ray Liotta and Jason Patric to co-star in cop thriller
fields.trailText: Plus: Ray Liotta and Jason Patric to co-star in cop thriller
fields.body:
 Sandra Bullock (pictured) looks set to take the lead role in the film version of Rebecca Wells' bestseller The Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood, playing the wired theatre director daughter of a soulful mother (to be played by Requiem for a Dream star Ellen Burstyn). The film's backers, Warner Bros, are hoping to secure Ashley Judd to play Burstyn's younger incarnation in the lengthy flashback portions.

 Ray Liotta and Jason Patric will hook up in the streetwise cop thriller Narc for Cutting Edge Entertainment, reports Variety. The film tells the tale of a narcotics officer (Patric) who, while probing a cop's murder in tandem with a police lieutenant (Liotta), gradually realises that he be being set up. Writer-director Joe Carnahan has scant time to prep his actors. The film is due to start shooting on Monday.

webTitle: MP accuses Tories of 'sinister' religious drive

fields.headline: MP accuses Tories of 'sinister' religious drive
fields.standfirst:
Special report: religion in the UK
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Conservative central office is accused today of trying to influence the Church of England general synod as part of a campaign to win the votes of thousands of churchgoers.
fields.body:
Conservative central office is accused today of trying to influence the Church of England general synod as part of a campaign to win the votes of thousands of churchgoers.

A leaked letter reveals close links between the party's HQ and a group of traditionalists on the church's ruling body pushing for a stricter line over issues such as the family and divorce.

Published in tomorrow's Church of England Newspaper, synod member Irene Riding said in a note to the Conservative Christian Forum based in central office that "we have gained some good people and I think the new synod should be able to push through the necessary reforms".

The document is to be made public as William Hague steps up his drive for the Christian vote which Tory strategists believe could be crucial in marginal seats if the turnout is low.

More than 300 meetings in churches have been organised and 500,000 free newspapers outlining Tory policies are to be handed out after services as the Conservatives claim their stand on issues is closer to Christian doctrines than Labour. Today the Tories launch two documents, Compassionate Conservatism in Britain and America and Values in the 21st Century, in a direct appeal to churchgoers.

Critics of the "1990 Group" within the Church of England of which Dr Riding is a member have criticised it as "exclusive" and "closed-minded".

Ben Bradshaw, a Labour MP and member of the Commons ecclesiastical committee, labelled it a "sinister" body and said: "It also seems to be more evidence of growing activity in this country of those trying to imitate the religious right in the US." But Tim Montgomerie, director of the Conservative Christian Fellowship, said: "I have enormous respect for Irene Riding and other traditionalists who were selected when going for synod. As a member of the CCF, Irene Riding has a right to ask for materials to be circulated to other members."

webTitle: Once children are settled, welfare considerations may ensure they stay

fields.headline: Once children are settled, welfare considerations may ensure they stay
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Alan and Judith Kilshaw's best hope of keeping the six-month-old twin girls they "bought" over the internet is to stave off any court hearing into their case for as long as possible.
fields.body:
Alan and Judith Kilshaw's best hope of keeping the six-month-old twin girls they "bought" over the internet is to stave off any court hearing into their case for as long as possible.

In a string of cases, the courts have allowed couples who brought foreign-born children into Britain in questionable circumstances to keep the children.

By law, the court's first consideration is the welfare of the child, and once a young child has become settled with a family the trauma of removal generally outweighs any other considerations.

So if Flintshire county council, which covers the north Wales area where the Kilshaws live, has doubts about the couple's fitness as parents, it will need to act quickly.

Keith McDonogh, director of education and children's services, said: "We are awaiting clarification from the Home Office, the Foreign Office and the national assembly on the international implications of this case.

"We have also requested from the family copies of the American adoption documentation and we would expect them to provide us with this as soon as possible. If it is not presented to us, we will be seeking legal advice on how to obtain it."

The council's most likely route if it decides to act is to take care proceedings, arguing that the children have suffered or are likely to suffer emotional damage.

They were looked after for two months by Richard and Vickie Allen of San Bernardino, California, who claim the babies' birth mother, Tranda Wecker, originally placed the twins with them before the Kilshaws agreed to pay more to the facilitator who advertised the children over the internet.

The Kilshaws have had the twins since December 1 and adopted them in Arkansas on December 22 after a journey from California to St Louis, Missouri, for their birth certificates and another drive to Little Rock, Arkansas.

Ms Wecker said yesterday that she had lied to get round the 30-day residence requirement for an Arkansas adoption by giving her aunt's Little Rock address as her own.

But even if fraud or irregularities were proved, the adoption would not necessarily be set aside.

In one case, a struck-off solicitor sentenced to four years in prison for mortgage fraud succeeded in adopting a child from El Salvador by concealing charges then pending. The couple supported their application with a private home study report, which did not include a police check on the applicants.

A high court judge approved the adoption although he held that the parents had contravened adoption law.

Allan Levy QC, an authority on child law, said that if he acted for the Allens, he would advise them to make the children wards of court in England as soon as possible. That would enable them to get a quick court hearing and get investigations started. If they had custody rights in California they could also take steps under the Hague convention to get the girls returned to them under reciprocal agreements between participating countries, he said.

webTitle: Blair demands law on internet baby trade

fields.headline: Blair demands law on internet baby trade
fields.standfirst:
Prime minister attacks 'deplorable' sale of babies to British couple and promises action to deny recognition of some adoptions

More net news
fields.trailText: Prime minister attacks 'deplorable' sale of babies to British couple and promises action to deny recognition of some adoptions.
fields.byline: John Carvel, Helen Carter  and Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles
fields.body:
Early legislation to prohibit the "deplorable" practice of trading children for adoption was promised by Tony Blair yesterday after the case of the British couple who bought American baby twins through an internet site run by a Californian child broker.

The prime minister said a bill in the current parliamentary session would remove bureaucratic obstacles that were hindering adoptions in this country and stop parents bringing in children adopted irregularly abroad.

"I think everyone feels it is absolutely deplorable that children are traded in this way. Adoption should always be about the interests of the child first," he told MPs after the issue was raised in the House of Commons by the Tory leader, William Hague.

Mr Blair also promised to implement the Adoption (Intercountry) Aspects Act. The act was passed in 1999, but was not brought into force. It could be used to refuse recognition to adoptions conducted abroad in countries that do not comply with the Hague convention which gives protection to children in these circumstances.

The prime minister's spokesman said: "He thinks the whole business is disgusting and shares people's horror that you can buy and sell children as a commodity and end up in a situation where you have got two sets of people who claim to be these children's parents."

Alan and Judith Kilshaw, the couple who paid thousands of pounds to adopt twin baby girls they found on the internet, said Mr Blair's criticism of their behaviour was unacceptable as they had not broken any laws.

Mrs Kilshaw stormed out of a television studio in the middle of a live interview for ITV at lunchtime.

She pulled out her earpiece leaving her husband Alan behind. When asked: "Where do you go from here?" she replied: "I go home and clean my house, clean my carpets, get a duster and give it a good Hoover and go through the place." She then stood up and said: "Last comment. I'm not doing any more for you," before walking away.

She is understood to have been responding to newspaper reports that her farmhouse in Buckley, north Wales, is dirty and unkempt.

Mrs Kilshaw already has four other children - two girls Louisa, 22, and Caley, 18, from her first marriage and James, seven, and Rupert, four, from her second marriage.

The prime minister's intervention caused a flurry in Whitehall among officials who did not expect adoption legislation until after the election and were still consulting on proposals in a white paper published in December.

Adoption charities were puzzled as to why Mr Blair thought legislation was needed so quickly. It is already an offence to trade children for adoption within the UK and the government can refuse recognition to adoptions conducted abroad in countries with slacker standards.

Felicity Collier, chief executive of the British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering, said the big political problem was whether to derecognise adoptions in the US. "The government has to decide: are we going to take the US off the designated list of countries whose adoptions we accept if they do not ratify the Hague convention," she said.

The FBI is carrying out what is described as a "preliminary inquiry" into the adoption, according to a spokeswoman. The inquiry, based at the bureau's Los Angeles office, is likely to focus on the exact circumstances in which the children were handed over and to examine who paid what and to whom.

An FBI spokeswoman said that the issue of internet adoption was not the subject of the inquiry as many firms now use the internet to advertise their services in this way.

The inquiry comes as concern is being voiced by children's organisations in the US about the growing practice of internet agencies offering babies for adoption.

The babies offered are usually from a small group of countries which still have loose adoption laws. They include Guatemala, China, Russia, India and Vietnam. Within the US, there are varying standards on how adoptions are undertaken with some states, such as California, enforcing strict policies of checking that children have not been sold while other states, such as Arkansas, have less stringent laws.

Social services in Flintshire, where the Kilshaws live, launched an investigation as soon as they heard of the adoption. On Tuesday, social workers unsuccessfully tried to contact the couple, who were holed up in a hotel near Cheshire giving interviews to journalists.

Yesterday, two social workers conducted a preliminary assessment of the children.

fields.trailText: Plus: Blair Witch 3 goes ahead despite the failure of Book of Shadows; screenwriter claims that he came up with the original idea for Notting Hill
fields.body:
 Anthony Hopkins (pictured) has ruled himself out of a third instalment in the adventures of Hannibal Lecter, reportedly saying that enough is enough. Producer Dino de Laurentis is keen to adapt Thomas Harris's first Lecter novel, Red Dragon (already filmed as Manhunter back in 1986), as a prequel to both The Silence of the Lambs and Ridley Scott's recently completed Hannibal, which opens next month. "Everyone wants to know what happened before Lecter was caught," says Dino. "There is room for more than Harris put in his first novel." What there isn't room for, it appears, is Hopkins, who is rumoured to have turned down a $20m (£13.5m) offer to play the role again. If Red Dragon goes ahead, De Laurentis now looks set to seek out a younger actor.

 Undeterred by signs that their franchise may already be flagging, Artisan Entertainment are pressing ahead with a third Blair Witch production and have again secured the services of Daniel Myrick and Eduardo Sanchez, creators of the hit first movie. But the Blair business took a knock with last year's Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2, directed by Joe Berlinger, which opened to duff reviews and poor box office - $26m (£17.6m) in the US compared to the $140m (£94.89m) made by the original film. But chapter three looks like it could be a long time coming, since Myrick and Sanchez currently have their schedules full to bursting. The film - a prequel to the original tale - is tentatively set for a release in autumn 2002.

 Blood and Wine screenwriter Nick Villiers is suing Universal Pictures and producer Eric Fellner for £15m, claiming that he came up with the original concept for the film Notting Hill. Villiers's suit, filed last month in LA, claims that he passed a script for a film called Cheek to Fellner, who later cribbed heavily from it for his tale of a star-crossed bookseller and a Hollywood icon. Also named in the suit are co-producer Duncan Kenworthy and writer Richard Curtis.

fields.headline: HateWatch calls it a day
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Online civil rights watchdog, HateWatch, has closed down, saying that the organisation has achieved its goal of focusing public attention on the activities of hate groups on the internet
fields.body:
Online civil rights watchdog, HateWatch, has closed down, saying that the organisation has achieved its goal of focusing public attention on the activities of hate groups on the internet.

The founder of Boston-based HateWatch, David Goldman, said that hate groups have failed to use the internet to increase their numbers or advance their causes. When the organisation launched in 1995, Mr Goldman feared that the internet would give hate groups a powerful new tool, but he said the opposite has happened.

He explained: "The internet put these groups in the spotlight, and put them under a scrutiny they have not had to deal with before. The internet takes away the mystery and the fear that the unknown generates."

Mr Goldman's assessment contrasts sharply with the findings of the European Union's racism monitoring unit, which found that hate sites on the internet are proliferating.

In their November report, EU researchers said that more than 2,100 racist and anti-semitic websites had sprung up, mainly in the US. In Germany alone, the internal security service recorded the existence of 300 registered hate websites in 1999, up from 200 in 1998.

"Movements which were in decline in both Europe and the US have received a new lease of life thanks to the sites they have created," the report said.

Mr Goldman disagrees: "There has not been a proliferation of hate groups on the net. If you look at the types of groups listed in the EU report, they are not hate groups. There may be more ultra-conservative groups or pro-gun, 2nd amendment groups, and those may be troubling, but they are not hate groups."

Even so, he does not think all is rosy with civil rights on the internet. With HateWatch dissolved, Mr Goldman will now focus his energies on changing civil rights legislation in the US and Europe.

This week he launched a new civil rights organisation, Paragraph175. It takes its name from a section of the German penal code - no longer in force - which made lesbian and gay sex an imprisonable offence and was the legal basis for the deaths of thousands of homosexuals in Nazi concentration camps.

Through Paragraph175, Mr Goldman hopes to make legislators take issues like cyber terrorism more seriously.

"The increase of racist cyber terrorists is the most troubling thing happening on the internet," he said. "There are individuals who would not normally go out into the real world to commit hate crimes but are emboldened in front of a computer."

Goldman wants to see governments actively combatting cyber terrorist activities such as denial-of-service attacks on the websites of civil liberties groups or the stalking of individuals online due to their race, sex or sexual preference.

Paragraph175 will also be tackling burgeoning moves in Europe to ban hate groups from the internet, such as the recent case in which a French court forced Yahoo! to block French citizens from accessing a Nazi memorabilia auction site.

"If my experience at HateWatch has taught me anything, it is that banning these groups will only exacerbate the problem," Mr Goldman said. "It is better to have their activities out in the open where civil rights groups and law enforcement can scrutinise their activities."

Related articles

21.05.2000: Fear and loathing on the internet

Paragraph175.org

fields.headline: West Ham: a review of 2000
fields.standfirst: It wasn't a bad year all in all for the Hammers. Join KUMB as they take a look back at the highlights of the Millennium year
fields.trailText: January 2000 - Villa Killer
fields.body:
January 2000 - Villa Killer

The new Millennium started off in pretty good fashion with two goals in the last five minutes at Newcastle to snatch a point. But that was as good as it got for a while, as the next two games saw us face Aston Villa twice - once in the Worthington Cup quarter-final replay (which we lost 3-1), and then in the league (Paolo Di Canio snatching a point with a late equaliser).

Still, spirits were lifted with a comprehensive win at Leicester thanks to a brace from Paolo Wanchope - his first league goals since November.

February - It's Frank v Paolo!

There were only three games in February - which brought a total of sixteen goals. Unfortunately 10 of those were in our end!

Gary Charles got his Hammers career off to a flyer with a last-gasp oggie at Southampton to gift Hoddle's disciples all three points. But the Hammers came back to win an extraordinary match at Upton Park against Bradford 5-4 - a game which saw Frank Lampard and Paolo Di Canio literally fighting over the ball for the right to take a penalty. Needless to say Di Canio won.

The month ended with a 4-0 defeat at home to Everton - most notable for the worst goalkeeping debut ever witnessed at Upton Park, thanks to Sasa Ilic who had joined on loan from Charlton as injury cover.

March - Goal of the Season

With the Hammers Euro hopes faltering, the team put on a spirited burst during March which saw us gain 10 points from a possible 15. Consecutive wins against Watford and Southampton were followed by a disappointing defeat at doomed Sheffield Wednesday and a bore draw at home to Chelsea. March probably summed up the season - good in patches but too inconsistent to mount a serious challenge for a European spot.

However, the month ended in spectacular fashion. Not the result - a fairly reasonable 2-1 win over Wimbledon - but Paolo Di Canio's stunning volley which rightly earned him the award for Goal of the Season.

April - April Fools

When the 99/00 fixture list was announced everybody groaned when they saw us pitted against Man.Utd at Old Trafford on April Fools Day. And despite Paolo Wanchope giving us all a glimmer of hope with a 10th minute opener we ended up losing 7-1 - our heaviest defeat for many a year. Pity poor Craig Forrest who four years earlier had conceded 9 whilst playing there for former club Ipswich.

Typical of our season we followed that disaster by winning three on the trot; against Newcastle (2-1), Derby (2-1) and Coventry (5-0). Almost as typical we lost to 'Boro at the Riverside again thanks to a goal from our arch nemesis, Brian Deane.

May - Foe Goes

The last three games of the 99/00 season saw us gain just one point. First a sickening 2-1 defeat at Arsenal; after we had led for so long and against one of the most biased performances you will ever see by a referee - thank you Mr.Durkin. A 1-0 defeat at Sunderland swiftly followed, which left the home game with Leeds.

And what a disappointing way to end the season. 0-0 was enough to secure a 'Champions' League place for Leeds, whilst the Upton Park faithful were treated to the outgoing Marc-Vivien Foe receiving his marching orders for a well placed kick at a prone Leeds defender. We finished ninth - out third top ten finish in a row, but only a C- at best for Harry's men after we had seemed destined for European football again. One piece of good news - Freddy Kanoute signed a four-year contract.

June - Video Nasties

With no domestic football to look forward to until August heads turned to the Euro Championships. But whilst a nation was yet again experiencing the disappointment of another poor England show Rio and Frank were living it up in Ayia Napa turning heads of their own, and 'shocking' a nation with their antics according to the tabloids.

The latest arrivals from our second academy at Highbury arrived in the shape of Nigel Winterburn and Davor Suker. Neither cost us a penny in transfers but at nearly £50k a week in wages for the pair they didn't come cheap.

July - MD Talks

West Ham made their biggest signing of pre-season in July - Bobby Moore's collection of medals and other memorabilia came home for a little under £2m.

Hammers MD Paul Aldridge gave it up to complete an extensive Q&A with KUMB (read it here). The transfer rumour mill was in full flow - Rio Ferdinand was apparently about to sign for Leeds, and we were said to be hot on the trail of little known defender Hayden Foxe.

The football started again with a 2-1 friendly defeat at Celtic. The South Coast tour began well with comprehensive wins at Bournemouth and Plymouth.

August - Goodbye Julian

Exeter and Swindon were duly disposed of in the latest legs of the pre-season programme, which continued later in the month with wins at Barnet and Rushden & Diamonds. The transfer market went haywire before the season began - Paulo Wanchope went to Man.City, Gary Alexander to Swindon. Hayden Foxe arrived - and saw his permit application knocked back. Christian Basilla also arrived on a season long loan.

Julian Dicks says goodbye to West Ham with an emotional farewell at Upton Park. The season started with a 4-2 defeat at Chelsea - which was swiftly followed by a 1-0 defeat at home to Leicester, and also saw the club up for misconduct under the new FA rules. The first point of the season came in a thrilling 2-2 draw with Man.Utd at Upton Park.

September - Goodbye to a legend

A 1-1 draw at Sunderland started the month off. That was swiftly followed by a 1-0 defeat at Spurs - a result which left the Hammers in the bottom three. The fuel crisis briefly threatened to disrupt the game with Liverpool which eventually finished 1-1 and left the Hammers bottom of the league still looking for a win.

That duly arrived with the 1-0 win at Walsall in the Worthington Cup, thanks to a debut goal from late sub Jermain Defoe. The second leg finished 1-1 - and could have been much worse. The first league win came at Coventry - a 3-0 demolition which quelled the mounting calls for Redknapp's head. The month ended in disappointment with a 1-1 draw at home to Bradford thanks to a last minute Petrescu equaliser. Meanwhile, the reserves recorded their last win of 2000 at Notts.Forest.

Paul Kitson went to Palace on a months loan, Gary Charles went to Birmingham and Marc Keller to Portsmouth for the same period. Kaba Diawara came in from PSG for the season.

The month ended with the sad news of the death of Hammers legend John Dick (read our tribute here).

October - Light at the end of the tunnel?

The Hammers started life in October still bottom of the league - and were lucky to escape with a point at Ipswich. A footballing lesson duly followed from Arsenal before we finally climbed out of the bottom three with back to back wins against Newcastle (1-0) and Blackburn (2-0) in the Worthington Cup.

Jon Vinton launched the 'Retire the 6' campaign which continues today. We talked to Daniel Sjolund (read it here) and Paolo Di Canio (here). KUMB launched on Teletext (Page 520).

November - Bye bye Rio

The fans were stunned by the news that the club had finally agreed to sell Rio Ferdinand to Leeds following months of speculation. The £18m received for the Peckham born lad constituted a world record for a defender. Predictably the fans were up in arms until an impeccably-timed good run of form softened opinion somewhat.

Our best month of the year (football wise) by far. Ten points from four league games including stunning wins at Southampton and Leeds - traditionally bogey grounds for us. Man.City were taught a footballing lesson in a four goal second half blitz at Upton Park. The form was only marred by a dreadful 0-0 draw at Derby.

In typical West Ham fashion we followed up the impressive league form with defeat at home to first division Sheffield Wednesday in the Worthington Cup.

KUMB talked to Tony Cottee (read that here) and Frank Lampard joined us for an excellent Q&A (read here). We won an award for best Hammers site on the web. Which was nice.

Transfer-wise Rigobert Song came in from Liverpool, and Daniel Sjolund went the other way in a £1m deal.

December - Hell freezes over ...

The Hammers stretched their unbeaten run in the league to nine games with a win over Middlesbrough and draws against Villa and Everton, before Leicester ended the run with a 2-1 defeat at Filbert Street. Christmas was a day late at Upton Park as Charlton were thrashed 5-0 on Boxing Day; the Hammers biggest win for 8 months.

Just as last year had ended in farce with the Manny Omoyinmi scandal so this year saw the last league game of the year cancelled just two hours from kick-off after the club had made Titanic-like boasts about it's £1m undersoil heating system - which duly packed up at the first sign of ice.

Hannu Tihinen joined the club on a three month loan deal. Titi Camara became the second Liverpool player to join inside a month as he signs for £1.5m. Harry Redknapp's audacious £10m bid for Inter's Robbie Keane fails. Paolo Di Canio wins plaudits worldwide for his amazing act of sportsmanship in the game against Everton. Harry Redknapp doesn't know whether to laugh or cry.

The first KUMB Christmas jolly took place at the Hamilton Hall - hopefully you'll all be back next year! We chat with Frank McAvennie (read that here).

Hayden Foxe goes on loan to Belgium before ever playing a first team game. Jermain Defoe equals a 73-year-old scoring record whilst on loan at Bournemouth.

This article first appeared on Knees Up Mother Brown

fields.headline: Memo to BBC news staff
fields.standfirst: In a memo issued to TV news staff, BBC news chiefs say they have 'no problem' with the return of ITV's News at Ten despite the clear ratings threat to its own Ten O'Clock News.
fields.trailText: Re: Ten O'Clock News
fields.body:
Re: Ten O'Clock News

There is less than a week to go before ITV launch their spasmodic return of News at Ten and we just wanted to separate newspaper fiction from fact.

First, a reminder of why we moved our news to 10pm.

 It's a better time for news. More has happened by 2200 and having a news hour running until 1900 with the main news only two hours later at 2100 was never the most rational scheduling.

 It's better for BBC1: next autumn and winter we will be seeing the benefits of the BBC's investment in its main channel. And new drama and comedy will be launched more effectively at 2100 than at 2130.

How do we judge success?

 The most important thing is that we continue to provide a top quality service to our audience. We want to be more ambitious, we want to make more use of specialist correspondents, we want to have a broader agenda and more intelligent coverage.

 We also aiming to stem the decline in audiences which has been affecting terrestrial news.

The Nine was declining at the rate of about 8% per year not because it was doing anything wrong but because it was at the heart of a peak-time battleground in which all the terrestrial channels were experiencing competition from satellite and cable.

In these circumstances the prime piece of twaddle was a newspaper report last week which said that "ominously the audience for the ten had risen by only 100,000 since its launch".

This is actually a major achievement: the fact that we are doing better than we were a year ago is unalloyed good news and means we can claim to have made an encouraging start.

And we've always made it clear that we are in this for the long haul. We will judge the success in audience terms over a couple of years, not over a couple of weeks. Ratings fluctuate depending on the odd hit programme here on the odd clinker there. And it is daft to look at this in a short-term way.

So we have no problems with ITV's move of the news not least because they don't seem wholehearted about it. ITV moved their news in the first place because it didn't want it at 10pm - and it's now News At Ten but not on Fridays and not across the whole weekend, and next week not on Wednesday either. It's also less than 20 minutes long which artificially boosts its average audience but inevitably means fewer stories and less analysis than the BBC news.

We therefore want to put on record our thank to everybody who works on the Ten for what they have achieved so far and our confidence that bbc news will remain the undisputed market leader across the television day.

Richard Sambrook
Deputy director of news

Roger Mosey
Head of television news

More has happened by 2200 and having a news hour running until 1900 with the main news only two hours later at 2100 was never the most rational scheduling.  It's better for BBC1: next autumn and winter we will be seeing the benefits of the BBC's investment in its main channel. And new drama and comedy will be launched more effectively at 2100 than at 2130. How do we judge success?  The most important thing is that we continue to provide a top quality service to our audience. We want to be more ambitious, we want to make more use of specialist correspondents, we want to have a broader agenda and more intelligent coverage.  We also aiming to stem the decline in audiences which has been affecting terrestrial news. The Nine was declining at the rate of about 8% per year not because it was doing anything wrong but because it was at the heart of a peak-time battleground in which all the terrestrial channels were experiencing competition from satellite and cable. In these circumstances the prime piece of twaddle was a newspaper report last week which said that "ominously the audience for the ten had risen by only 100,000 since its launch". This is actually a major achievement: the fact that we are doing better than we were a year ago is unalloyed good news and means we can claim to have made an encouraging start. And we've always made it clear that we are in this for the long haul. We will judge the success in audience terms over a couple of years, not over a couple of weeks. Ratings fluctuate depending on the odd hit programme here on the odd clinker there. And it is daft to look at this in a short-term way. So we have no problems with ITV's move of the news not least because they don't seem wholehearted about it. ITV moved their news in the first place because it didn't want it at 10pm - and it's now News At Ten but not on Fridays and not across the whole weekend, and next week not on Wednesday either. It's also less than 20 minutes long which artificially boosts its average audience but inevitably means fewer stories and less analysis than the BBC news. We therefore want to put on record our thank to everybody who works on the Ten for what they have achieved so far and our confidence that bbc news will remain the undisputed market leader across the television day. Richard Sambrook Deputy director of news Roger Mosey Head of television news

webTitle: G2: What critics think of Derek Malcolm's selection

fields.headline: What the critics say - it's a question of taste
fields.standfirst:
Other critics give their opinion

Derek Malcolm's century of films
fields.trailText: Other critics give their opinion.
fields.body:
Alexander Walker, London Evening Standard

Bravo, Derek! Someone had to be the first to drop Citizen Kane. How well travelled the list shows him: proof of diligence on critics' juries the world over. Refreshing, too: how assiduously he prefers the secondary work to the certified masterpiece, thus giving us all more oxygen to argue with.

My own quibbles: surely Kubrick's Dr Strangelove, Antonioni's L'Avventura and Huston's The Dead (over Paths of Glory, The Passenger and Fat City). Weak on the comic - if Will Hay, why not George Formby? - and unexpectedly strong on the erotic: glad that Capra's Bitter Tea of General Yen, a tauntingly pre-Morality Code cockteaser, has beaten out It's a Wonderful Life. I hope some day, on Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?, I am asked who directed Pakeezah. Now I know.

Nick Fisher, the Sun

This is a buff's list, not a punter's list. Where's Erin Brockovich and Men In Black? Where's American Beauty or American Pie or American Movie, come to that? Long films with dense subtitles are not my cup of rosie. I think Derek and me would be hard pushed to ever pick a Saturday night out at the flicks together. Does he even eat popcorn?

I think I read down to Kes before I even recognised any of these names as movies. Kinda smells of pretension to me. But hey, without buffs there would be no poncey foreign film festivals. And we know how important they are. Not. Kes, Apocalypse Now, Raging Bull and Night At The Opera ... yep, I go along with all of these as firm candidates for any Top 100. But, as for the other 96 titles, you're on your own Del.

Jean Roy - L'Humanité (France)

As any "favourite" list, as opposed to "best", Derek's one is very revealing. It proves his extensive knowledge of world cinema, whatever the country or the period, his preference for style over stars, and for films which deserve to be reminded over crowd-pleasers (no Gone With The Wind).

It also shows his resistance to cliches (Strike, and not Potemkin, Touch of Evil and not Citizen Kane, Young Mr Lincoln and not Stagecoach, Beyond a Reasonable Doubt and not M, Boudu and not Rules of the Game), and his openness to everything from Fantasia to Behind the Green Door. He is a brave man.

Geoff Andrew - Time Out

A solid, admirably open-minded selection, albeit mostly somewhat classical. Putting aside personal taste (I detest Brief Encounter), I was surprised by the inclusion of the Reeves, Morrissey, Mitchell Brothers(!) and Blank films, and by the kitschiest Disney. Most glaring omissions: no Davies, Demy, Dovzhenko, Kiarostami, Leone, Malick, Yang - and no Lumières or Méliès.

Nick James - Sight and Sound

Personal canons are always the best, and Malcolm's astute choice of one film per great auteur is rich with surprise and understanding of the quality of world cinema, but I regret the generational bias which excludes any current auteur or film made since 1985.

Peter Keough - The Phoenix (USA)

You've got to admire a 100 best movie list that omits Citizen Kane but includes Behind the Green Door. Derek Malcolm's favourites include many of the obvious auteurs, but not the obvious films - Ford's Young Mr. Lincoln rather than The Searchers, Renoir's Boudu Saved from Drowning rather than Rules of the Game, Capra's Bitter Tea of General Yen rather than anything else (but why Coppola's bloated Apocalypse Now, rather than The Conversation?)

Also, a plus is the emphasis on non-Hollywood movies and developing countries (though where is Abbas Kiarostami?). In short, I disagree with about half, which is what a list like this should accomplish - provoke discussion and challenge preconceptions.

Klause Eder - German critic

I tried desperately to find favourite films which Derek might have missed. No chance: they're all in. I'm time and again surprised at the variety and openness of his film taste - avoiding the common-sense film history and engaging himself for outsiders as well as "exotic" directors, in particular from Asian cinematographers. See his favourites, and you know how exciting cinema can be.

David Thomson - Independent on Sunday

Glaring errors? Films that don't deserve to be there? What is the point of inventing such silly games and then reporting them to some Supreme Court? DM has every right to play top l00 films if it amuses you, but why should anyone else be dragged in, and why should a mere list be given such Schindlerian gravity?

Philip French - The Observer

Critics put their reputations on the line every week judging the new films, and every December, by picking the year's 10 best. To publish a book on the "100 best films of the century" is really putting your head on the block, even if that "best" is qualified as "personal". Derek Malcolm's choice strikes me as sound and stimulating, a mixture of the conservative and the adventurous. The usual suspects are there, but often represented by unexpected films (eg a Touch of Evil instead of Citizen Kane, The Bitter Tea of General Yen rather than Mr Deeds Goes to Town), and all the movies are of value.

Personally, I regret the absence of Sirk, Boetticher, Donen, Vertov, Tourneur, Whale, Kazan, Boorman, Malle and Roeg, but recognise that Malcolm is making a statement by omitting Spielberg. There are no Australian directors represented, and no SF flicks. All lists reveal something about the compiler, and there's a lot of sex and socialism here.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours have taken a course in marketing and would like to point you towards our superb new fanzine section
fields.trailText: Roberto Mancini is likely to be unveiled as a Leicester player later today.
fields.body:
Roberto Mancini is likely to be unveiled as a Leicester player later today.

Bayern Munich are prepared to dangle an £80,000-a-week tax-free package under the nose of Sol Campbell. Club president Franz Beckenbauer is known to be a huge fan of the Spurs defender, who is out of contract at the end of the season and can leave White Hart Lane on a Bosman free. However, the Express claim Fulham want Campbell to lead their inevitable Premiership campaign next season.

The Express also repeat the Fulham for Teddy Sheringham rumour. Meanwhile, Jean Tigana has made a £2m bid for Tranmere's Jason Koumas. The highly-rated midfielder could go if Everton knock the Wirral club out of the FA Cup later this month.

Arsenal want to replace David Seaman with Boca Juniors goalkeeper Oscar Cordoba, according to Planet Football. Boca Juniors vice-president Roberto Digon claims Arsenal have been told they can have Cordoba for £2.7m. "The English club Arsenal are evaluating the options for the position, and one of those is Cordoba, who is available for $4m," Digon said.

Newcastle could move for Tottenham goalkeeper Ian Walker, according to the Mirror. Bobby Robson has privately accepted that Shay Given will move on and is now in the market for a replacement.

New Barnsley boss Nigel Spackman hopes to sign Isiah Rankin in a £350,000 deal from Bradford.

Barnsley, Sheffield Wednesday and Burnley are locked in a race for Manchester City midfielder Ian Bishop.

fields.headline: Kabila and the Congo
fields.standfirst: The shooting of the president has thrown the Democratic Republic of Congo into turmoil. Sarah Left explains why
fields.trailText: The shooting of the president has thrown the Democratic Republic of Congo into turmoil. We explain why.
fields.body:
Is Laurent Kabila dead or alive?
Officials in the Democratic Republic of Congo admit that Kabila was shot but say he is now receiving medical treatment in Zimbabwe. Reports from Zimbabwe - including a source within the Zimbabwean government - say he died in a plane on route to receive medical treatment. The British and Belgian foreign ministries believe Kabila is dead. What is certain is that Kabila has not appeared in public since the shooting, but neither has his body been produced. His son, army leader Joseph Kabila, has been appointed interim leader by his father's officials.

Who wants Laurent Kabila dead?
Kabila has not been short of enemies during his nearly four years in power. The Democratic Republic of Congo has been embroiled in a bloody civil war for two and a half years and any of the competing factions could have been behind his death. Millions have died in the war; in June last year the International Rescue Committee, a US-based humanitarian organisation, estimated that 2,600 people were dying every day.

Who would take over the country if Kabila is dead?
The attack on Kabila seems to have been an assassination attempt rather than part of a coup, so his government is still in charge. But Congo has never recovered from the vacuum of power left when the country's long-term dictator, Mobutu Sese Seko, fled the country in 1997. The intimate involvement of numerous and competing foreign interests makes the Congo difficult to govern effectively, and Kabila has no obvious successor. Much of the country's infrastructure has been destroyed in the civil war, particularly in the eastern part of the country nearest Rwanda and Uganda.

Who are the main players in the civil war?
There are two main factions in the war, neither of which have popular support among the people of the Congo. The first are the anti-Kabila rebels backed by the governments and armies of Uganda and Rwanda. They are opposed by pro-Kabila troops backed by Zimbabwe, Namibia and Angola. There are also numerous internal rebel armies, mostly backed by foreign powers.

What is the war about?
The Democratic Republic of the Congo - known as Zaire before Kabila changed the name in 1997 - was ruled for over 30 years by Mobutu, a brutal dictator. Mobutu's grip on power was slipping seven years ago when a civil war in neighbouring Rwanda broke out. The Hutu, who make up the majority of the Rwandan population, began slaughtering the minority Tutsi. The genocidal murder of 800,000 Tutsis came to an end when Tutsi forces gained control of the country. The now outlawed Hutus fled to Zaire where they were sheltered by Mobutu.

How did the Rwandan war spill over into Zaire?
Rwanda - along with another neighbouring country, Uganda - wanted to round up the Hutu rebels and bring them back, but the government felt it could not simply invade Zaire without a better excuse. To cover up its actions, Rwanda and Uganda recruited Kabila to lead an indigenous revolt within Zaire to bring down Mobutu. The Rwandans and Ugandans felt that if Kabila won power, he would protect their countries by stamping out the Hutu rebels.

So is Kabila popular within the Congo?
Kabila was hailed as a conquering hero when he marched into Congo's capital, Kinshasa, in May 1997 to oust Mobutu. The people of Congo needed a change of leadership and hoped he would turn around the legacy of terror and corruption left behind by Mobutu. And Kabila's backers in Rwanda and Uganda felt they could now wage war on the Hutu rebels with his blessing.

What went wrong?
One year later, Kabila changed his mind about the Hutus and refused to force them back into Rwanda. The Rwandans and Ugandans abruptly switched sides and began to support rebels seeking to overthrow Kabila. For his part, Kabila courted support from Angola, Namibia and Zimbabwe, all of which had interests in using the vast nation of Congo for its own purposes. Angola wanted to fight the rebels from its own civil war who sheltered in Congo, and Zimbabwe was hoping to get rich off the mineral rights Kabila signed over.

What is the future for Congo if Kabila is dead?
Congo sits at the centre of Africa and is the third largest nation on the continent. It has a vast wealth of minerals and plenty of land which can be used either for lucrative agriculture, mineral exploitation, or as has happened more recently, to shelter the rebels from other nations' wars. So many powerbrokers in the region want a hand in controlling Congo. Kabila's death would probably not end the civil war. The United Nations has long toyed with the idea of a peacekeeping mission there, but so far nothing has materialised.

fields.headline: A life up in smoke
fields.trailText: Some smokers, though not many, I suspect, have chosen this activity as their method of suicide. It does not sound as if Sage meant to do so
fields.body:
Lorna Sage's autobiography, Bad Blood, was mentioned time after time in the celebrity Christmas lists. For once, the recommendations were right. Bad Blood is as compelling as its critics said, a wonderfully worthy winner of the Whitbread biography prize. Finishing it last week, I rejoiced at the discovery of Lorna Sage, envied her students, resolved to read her other books, maybe even the appreciation of Angela Carter. What a fine thing it seemed that Lorna Sage's own literary talent had been recognised while she was still young enough to relish it: 57.

The next morning's newspapers announced her death, of emphysema. It is a smoker's illness. Gore Vidal mentioned her "ominous smoker's cough". Snoo Wilson, a former student of Sage's, observed that "memories of those who die with emphysema are generally wreathed in the ambiguous seductions of cigarette smoke". Long ago he had taken her photograph: "I persuaded Lorna to light a fresh cigarette with a match - swoosh! - for each take. This she did, with evident pleasure, saying she had never known photography to be such fun before."

Some smokers, though not many, I suspect, have chosen this activity as their method of suicide. It does not sound as if Sage meant to do so. Her agent, writing about her illness, said: "She had the most intense will to live of anyone I have ever known." Anyone who has read Bad Blood will find that easy to believe.

It is Sage's astonishing will, as much as her intelligence, that makes Bad Blood so inspiring: she overcomes all obstacles, whether emotional, educational, financial; ignores doubters; defies her enemies - most memorably in the hospital where, as a schoolgirl, she gave birth to a daughter.

Sage, who had exams coming up, wanted to go home and revise. The matron said she couldn't. "Yes I could, I said, I was married. Then I needed my husband's permission, she said. That's not true, I replied. In any case, she said, I wasn't well enough to leave, I had an infection. And where did I get it? I said nastily, in this foul hospital. I'll be better off if I leave. 'If you leave,' she shouted, losing her temper, 'you'll die!' But if she was in rage, I was in a bigger one. 'I'd rather!' I shouted back, and she spun on her heel and retreated."

What had she written about smoking? The only references I could find in Bad Blood related to her grandfather, always surrounded "with a cloud of smoke", whom Sage would accusingly be said to resemble. She recalled his pipe smelling like a bonfire: "This was after his first stroke, when I was seven or eight years old, and he was supposed to cut down on smoking but instead extended his meagre ration and fed his habit with more or less anything combustible." He died soon after from a second stroke.

The next thing I read about cigarettes was contained in a late Christmas card from "Smokers' Pressure group Forest". Forest announced that it would be holding: "The Big Smoke 2, an annual party for smokers and tolerant non-smokers." What, I wonder, does Forest want to celebrate? The news that the number of women with chronic lung disease has doubled?

The director of Forest, Simon Clark, says: "The Big Smoke recreates an era when most people at parties were happily smoking, and the ones who weren't didn't give a damn. To smoke in public is still a great pleasure and people who like to smoke or drink and listen to Cuban music are a damn sight more fun to be around than those who don't."

People like myself, who abandoned the habit after a shamingly long struggle, must accept that we shall never again be so interesting or glamorous as when we were surrounded - like Grandpa! - by clouds of sexy smoke. It remains an axiom, among smokers, that "all the most amusing people" are the ones bravely courting bronchitis, emphysema, heart disease and cancer out in the garden.

In the Faber Book of Smoking, a recent contribution to the smoker-hero myth, gratefully reviewed by smoker-critics, the late Jeffrey Bernard puts this line persuasively: "Women who are healthily promiscuous, not to the extent of being whores or something, nearly always are smokers ... Non-smokers tend to be more judgmental."

Today, on the contrary, the pro-active, pro-death Forest members tend to be the ones who sound judgmental, or actively offensive. In fact given the obscene numbers who die of lung cancer each year the indulgence of smoking - as opposed to say, the outrage over under-age sex, or breast-beating over eating disorders - is striking. Actors still flourish cigarettes as coolness-indicators. Models, usually keen smokers, prefer to campaign for breast cancer awareness. No wonder the percentage of young female smokers is actually rising. Would anything stop them? They might start looking at the obituaries.

fields.headline: Marketing
fields.standfirst: Publication date: January 18.
fields.trailText: January 18: One2One has hired former Virgin.com marketing director Robert Pepper to head its CRM activity.
fields.body:
One2One has hired former Virgin.com marketing director Robert Pepper to head its CRM activity.

Coca-Cola GB has appointed Mother to handle advertising for Alive, the non-carbonated fruit drink it will launch in April.

Sainsbury will this week launch its biggest ever cause-related marketing initiative in a tie-up with the British Heart Foundation that will see the supermarket position itself as the sector's healthy-eating option.

The Marketing Society Awards 2001 is open to entries until the end of this week.

Advertisers and agencies have reacted positively to ITV's five-point action plan.

Bird's Eye is set to unveil a high-quality frozen food range called enjoy!, which it will back with a £20m support package, its biggest launch budget ever.

Sonera Zed has appointed Claydon Heeley Jones Mason to work on the launch of its UK mobile internet service.

Express Newspapers has parted company with its Glasgow-based creative advertising agency, The Bridge, and is understood to be taking the £7m creative task in-house.

Barclays is relaunching its retail marketing services division under a new brand, The Circle.

fields.headline: Sundance 2001 reflects "world in transition"
fields.trailText: This year's showcase of the best of independent cinema emphasises the development of digital techniques and features a number of films with gender-bending themes
fields.body:
The Sundance Film Festival kicks off today with its annual showcase of the best and brightest from the independent movie scene. Critics are already commenting on the overall character of this year's line-up which, they feel, demonstrates a special emphasis on both gender-bending themes and digital techniques. Clearly these are wild times for the American movie.

Observers point, in particular, to the inclusion of Richard Kelly's digital time-travel yarn Donnie Darko, starring Drew Barrymore, and Daniel Minahan's hotly-tipped Series 7, a digital spoof on Big Brother-style reality shows.

On the sexual side, they single out John Cameron Mitchell's adaptation of the provocative stage play Hedwig and the Angry Inch (pictured), the Brazilian transgender saga Princesa and the sex-change documentary Southern Comfort. Contemplating Sundance's eclectic and exotic line-up, festival co-director Geoff Gilmore admitted to Variety that: "We haven't had a festival that is more difficult to typify than this year. It's an independent world in transition."

On a more trusty level, Sundance kicks off with My First Mister, the directoral debut of Chicago Hope star Christine Lahti, while the more high-profile movies on show include Allison Anders's rock-and-roll caper Things Behind the Sun, Tom DiCillo's Double Whammy, the white-collar satire The Business of Strangers, starring Julia Stiles, and The Caveman's Valentine, starring Samuel L Jackson as a homeless man implicated in a murder. The festivities wrap up on January 27.

webTitle: Henry Porter on journalist Auberon Waugh

fields.headline: Waugh at peace
fields.standfirst: Offensive, yes. A bully, sometimes. But he was not the racist, sexist snob some claimed him to be.  Henry Porter remembers a man of contradictions
fields.trailText: Offensive, yes. A bully, sometimes. But he was not the racist, sexist snob some claimed him to be. Henry Porter remembers a man of contradictions.
fields.body:
Auberon Waugh is a difficult person to defend against the people who loathed him, or, more accurately, the people who had made up their minds about him many years ago and refused to read him. To them, he was the "racist, sexist snob" evoked by the BBC reporter Nick Higham in yesterday's instant radio obituary. More particularly, they saw him as a reduced version of Evelyn Waugh's renowned spite and conservatism; yet without the talent.

The truth is that Bron didn't much care what people thought of him and in fact he used this as one of the longest-running jokes of his career, conjuring up in his numerous columns a blimpish figure who was all the things that Higham so automatically trotted out. It was a tease which worked from early in his career at the Daily Mirror through his work for the Spectator, Private Eye and the Telegraph. But, as with his father, it was often a problem to see where the tease ended and the real Waugh began.

I first met Bron at a Private Eye lunch in the late 70s when he was doing his best to annoy everyone with an extravagantly funny and offensive diary that ran every fortnight in the Eye. Also at the lunch were Peter McKay, Richard Ingrams, Peter Cook, Willie Rushton and John Wells, the last three of whom are all sadly dead. It was an unforgettable day for a young journalist - a lot of laughter and very good jokes.

Bron seemed to me to be a rather frightening figure, party because he said exactly what came to his mind but also because he was very shrewd and funny. Later, when I got to know him slightly better, he came round for supper and I made the mistake of asking him what he thought of a book I had just written about the failings of Fleet Street. "I didn't like it much," he said. There was a pause while he searched for the word he wanted. "Rather priggish, I thought."

He was utterly fearless and possessed one of the most independent minds of his generation of journalists. He would not tolerate cant from either side of the political divide. Just as the Conservative press had decided that Princess Diana was thoroughly mad and bad, Bron became her champion, claiming that she had been ill-treated by the royal family. And of course he was absolutely right.

Just as his colleagues, such as Christopher Booker, became convinced of the unwavering evil represented by the institutions of the European Union, Bron decided that our only hope was to become ever more integrated. He liked Europe and believed in its superior civilisation, whereas he nurtured a lifelong mistrust of American culture.

He took such causes rather seriously - he could not have been so devastatingly funny if he hadn't been essentially earnest about them. But the one thing he never took seriously was himself. He could be teased and, while the most vicious attack would certainly provoke reprisal, he never once appeared to take it to heart. It was all part of the game.

I once played a disastrous joke on him that ended in a long-running legal dispute between the then literary editor of the Sunday Times, Claire Tomalin, and Private Eye. The hoax involved a little volume called Recent Gay and Lesbian Fiction that I sent to Bron with a note purporting to come from Tomalin that asked him to review the book favourably. I seem to remember the phrase "knowing your sympathy for the gay movement" appeared fairly high up in the letter. I also advised him to make a phone call to the literary department of the Sunday Times before setting off on his review.

This, unfortunately, he failed to do. If he had called Tomalin he would have discovered the hoax. Instead he rushed into print with a vituperative item in his diary that, needless to say, resulted in a writ from the Sunday Times. The point was that Bron didn't object to gays or gay fiction; he simply hated being told what to think and write. The letter seemed to confirm his suspicions about the then liberal Sunday Times.

The case dragged on and became more and more bitter. Meanwhile nobody at Private Eye or the Sunday Times had the slightest idea who had written the letter. I kept my head down for two years while Bron fought it out with the paper's lawyers. Huge bundles of letters accumulated as he argued that he had not accused Tomalin of being a left winger or a lesbian, but that even if he had, it would have been insulting rather than damaging.

At length Bron guessed I was the author and confronted me in the mildest possible terms at another Private Eye lunch. When I confessed he just laughed, a reaction that contrasted to the eruption that took place at the Sunday Times, where I was required to make a shaming public apology to Tomalin, the other victim of my idiotic hoax.

When the case was over and the settlement agreed upon, I took Bron out to lunch by way of an apology. The whole affair had left him rather weary and cross about the libel laws, but he didn't take it out on me. Instead, he gave me a long lecture about effective lying. "The thing is," he said, "you should tell the truth as often as you can, but in such a way as people don't believe you or think that you're being funny."

I learned quite a lot about him at that lunch. He appeared much more the melancholic than I would have ever guessed and was evidently prone to romantic yearnings. Except for male friends of long standing such as Richard Ingrams and the Guardian columnist Alexander Chancellor, he seemed to prefer women's company. And they liked him for his beady cleverness and the quality that many people will never credit - his sympathetic ear. In person he was also astoundingly polite.

These traits never came over on TV and it was quite hard to spot the mildness and tolerance of his nature in his writing. But it was there and the irony is that he was more liberal in his attitudes than many self-proclaimed liberals. He simply couldn't stand the bossiness of modern society - one group of self- appointed nannies deciding what the rest of us can and can't do. Hence his long campaign against the MPs who voted against fox hunting.

The other regular target of his astonishingly versatile pen (he wrote four very good novels) was the thuggery of the popular press and its degrading influence on national life. He hated the jeering of the tabloids and the way they descend on celebrities who fall from grace. Perhaps we have come to accept this as part of the British character, a congenial indulgence of the mob, but latterly it seemed he could never take much satisfaction from the downfall of people such as Jonathan Aitken, even though Aitken had resorted to the hated libel laws and very nearly won his case against the Guardian.

But let me not get too carried away. Bron was exceptionally tough on his enemies. When he suspected that the leftwing columnist and campaigner John Pilger had been misled when he was exposing the exploitation of child labour in Cambodia, he never let go. Pilger had arranged to buy a young girl called Sunee in Bangkok as proof of his allegations. He movingly wrote an account of returning the child to her parents, only to discover that she had been legitimately studying in Bangkok. He could be forgiven for being hoaxed, but Bron never did and pursued him remorselessly in the Spectator, even coining the verb "to pilger".

Bron wrote quickly and wittily, which enabled him to appear in a lot of publications over the course of a week. The tone of these articles varied enormously. In one publication you might find a cruel dismissal of some benighted minister's efforts; then in another an endearing account of how he had been looked after in one of his numerous stays in hospital. If he had formed one of his curious obsessions about you, you certainly felt it, as Jeremy Thorpe, the disgraced Liberal leader, will testify. On other occasions his campaigns, for instance against Harry Evans and Lord Gowrie, seemed frankly mystifying, and that was because there were private scores being settled, chiefly over women, one gathers.

I often wondered about this part of Bron's character. It seemed so odd that a man who hated bullies and vindictiveness was capable of being both. Perhaps it was because he had so little self-pity and assumed that people were as robust as he was. It's difficult to know, but he was certainly aware that he had caused a great deal of offence over the years. "Looking back over my career to date," he said in his 1991 autobiography Will This Do?, "and at all the people I have insulted, I am mildly surprised that I am still allowed to exist."

Now he no longer does, I shall miss reading him. He really was a cut above the rest, despite - and perhaps because of - his obvious failings. But surprisingly these did not actually include snobbery, racism and sexism.

webTitle: Unintelligible in pursuit of the debatable

fields.headline: Unintelligible in pursuit of the debatable
fields.trailText: The hunting bill had arrived. It was a glorious sunny day. Outside the House of Commons the horns of Countryside Alliance protesters pierced the eggshell sky. The chase was on!
fields.body:
The hunting bill had arrived. It was a glorious sunny day. Outside the House of Commons the horns of Countryside Alliance protesters pierced the eggshell sky. The chase was on!

Inside, MPs decided to start with a little hunting of their own. Andrew Robathan, a Tory, tackled Mr Blair for the 289th time over John Prescott's cheap union flat.

"Your unpleasant and nasty obsession reflects much worse on you than on the deputy prime minister, whose integrity I prefer any day of the week," Mr Blair replied. The rest of the hunt dipped their hands into Mr Robathan's still-warm blood.

Nicholas Soames somehow managed to mount his steed. Why had the prime minister misled us all by claiming on TV that he had voted against hunting in 1997 when he hadn't, and that the bill had been lost in the House of Lords, when it wasn't?

"As for what I said on Question Time," Mr Blair replied, "we will wait and see what happens in the other House!"

Gone to earth! The pack (I think of Mr Soames as a half a dozen hounds in one sack) spotted another quarry and swerved to attack the Speaker, Michael Martin. The prime minister had been less than honest, he said. The Speaker replied that no member of the House was less than honest, which, to be fair, caused as much merry chortling among MPs as it did in the galleries.

"No honourable member would mislead. Perhaps misinform," said Mr Martin firmly, if nonsensically. "That certainly is an original ruling," said Mr Soames, with the de haut en bas splendour of a master of foxhounds scoffing at a tenant farmer. This time it was the Speaker's twisted, bleeding corpse which will be on an animal rights shock poster.

Finally the debate. Tally-ho! The deputy speaker, Sir Alan Haselhurst, sounded the horn: "We must now deal with the question that clause 1 stand part, with which it will be convenient to debate whether clause 2 stand part, and clause 3 stand part ... new clause 1 with amendments (a) to (c) ... first four clauses and three new clauses..."

On and on he went. I have attended whole debates which were shorter than Sir Alan's briefing. Yet there are people who understand this gobbledygook. Luckily, none of them are members of parliament.

The debate thundered over the much-loved old ground. Had members seen a video made by Lord (Melvyn) Bragg about the problems a hunting ban would cause farmers in the Lake District? "Shoot Lord Bragg," yelled Tony Banks.

No one was safe. Mr Banks later admitted tipping a live rat into his neighbour's backyard. What had it to do with the debate? Nothing, but the House was in the grip of a collective bloodlust.

Labour's Ian Cawsey was asked if he would adopt a hound which will otherwise be put down when a ban comes in. Panic in his eyes! Then he got it: "A dog is for life, not just a debate!" he exclaimed. A masterful escape.

Mike Foster, who brought in the original bill, scorned the idea of self-regulation. Ann Widdecombe sat on the Tory frontbench nodding energetically at everything he said.
