fields.headline: Auberon Waugh
fields.standfirst: A writer with a talent for vituperation and a taste for vendettas, his columns showed a hatred of authoritarianism of both left and right
fields.trailText: A writer with a talent for vituperation and a taste for vendettas, his columns showed a hatred of authoritarianism of both left and right.
fields.body:
Auberon Waugh's death at the age of 61 is more sad than surprising. His immediate heredity wasn't promising - his father died at 62, his mother at 57 - and he suffered from ill-health all his life, partly resulting from severe wounds sustained during National Service at the age of 18.

That may, in part, have accounted for the acidic personality which made him the most verbally brutal journalist of his age. Everyone who met him remarked on the contrast between his ferocity in print and his personal geniality, but this was hard to explain to those who didn't know him, especially if they had been on the rough end of his pen.

Apart from health, his background shaped his career in one other respect. He spent much of his life trying to escape from the shadow of his father, the greatest English novelist of his age. This provided an obvious weapon for Auberon's enemies. Philip Larkin joked about "my projected series, Talentless Sons of Famous Fathers - Waugh, Amis, Fuller...", and for Polly Toynbee, "Poor Bron is but a Randolph to a Winston." In fact, Auberon Waugh could be called many things, but not talentless, as he showed once he shook off that shadow.

He was the second child and first son of Evelyn and Laura Waugh. Auberon Alexander - always Bron to those who knew him and to many who didn't - was born just as the war broke out, and just as his father was setting off on his quixotic and in the end bitterly thwarted search for military redemption. Bron barely saw his father until he was five, and even thereafter Evelyn boasted with chilling jocosity that he saw his children "once a day for 10, I hope awe-inspiring, minutes".

After his father's death in 1966, Bron became his champion and continued many of his feuds. But his distinctly bleak autobiography Will This Do? (1991) casts a cold light on those early years, epitomised by the moment when father removed son's banana - a rare delicacy at the end of the war - from his plate and ate it. Coming clean, Bron would now admit that he had barely begun to like his father by the time of his death.

For his part, Evelyn never concealed the boredom and vexation Bron caused him. Father wrote to 16-year-old son with considerable insight, "You have a sense of humour and a gift of self- expression. On the other hand you are singularly imprudent and you have a defective sense of honour. These bad qualities can lead to disaster."

Although Bron Waugh was often described as reactionary or rightwing, this missed the point about him personally as well as ideologically. If he was a Tory, he was a Tory anarchist, whose upbringing was a series of rebellions. He detested Downside, the Benedictine public school, quaintly claiming that the headmaster had "set himself up in opposition to me".

He then loathed his National Service training, and never ceased to rail at the stupidity and brutality he had encountered at the Guards depot at Pirbright. Waugh was nevertheless commissioned into the Royal Horse Guards (The Blues), and sent to Cyprus. There one day he became annoyed by a fault in the Browning machine-gun of his armoured car, seized it by the muzzle and shook it, until it had fired several rounds through his chest at pointblank range. He was very lucky to survive.

This later inspired one of his best columns, in the New Statesman. He had heard it said, Waugh wrote, that he had been shot by his own men, or that he had lost a testicle. In reality, the injury had been self-inflicted, and he had lost a lung, his spleen, several ribs, and a finger, "but nothing else (my italics)".

While recuperating in Italy, he began his first novel. The Foxglove Saga (1960) was undoubtedly promising, and was undoubtedly helped by the name Waugh. It sold 14,000 in hardback, setting a mark for later disappointment. Waugh then went up briefly to Christ Church, Oxford, to which he had won an exhibition in English, to read PPE, but left after a year having failed to pass an exam, and taken a dislike to the academic authorities. After an unsuccessful attempt to join the Foreign Office - yet another part of the establishment which earned his undying enmity - he turned the obvious way.

His early career in Fleet Street was chequered, working briefly for the Peterborough column on the Daily Telegraph, then joining the Daily Mirror. The highlight of his career as a Mirrorman was in 1967. During the Six Day war he flew to Israel, where Mandy Rice-Davies was said to have gone to the front as a nurse. In fact, she was pursuing her usual honest trade as a Tel Aviv night-club hostess but, in the best Scoop tradition, Waugh had her don a nurse's uniform for a photograph. He saw this as one of his proudest journalistic achievements, along with another some years later when a column of his in the Times, which included a flippant joke about the prophet Mohammed, led an enraged mob to burn down the British Council building in Rawalpindi.

In 1967, he was made political columnist of the Spectator, an enterprising choice on the part of the then editor, Nigel Lawson. Waugh took his duties seriously enough, though attendance at Westminster only increased his aversion to politics and politicians. His time at the Spectator coincided with the Biafra war, when the Ibo-speaking, and largely Catholic, province seceded from Nigeria. This was the first serious cause to engage Waugh, who poured savage indignation on the Wilson government and Michael Stewart, the foreign secretary, for colluding at the conduct of the war, in which millions of Africans were starved into submission.

In 1970, Waugh abruptly left the Spectator. He had been seeing the week's issue through the press, and on a whim changed George Gale's name to "Lunchtime O'Gale" in the contributors' list. When Lawson sacked him, Waugh sued for wrongful dismissal. After a court case worthy of Beachcomber, when Bernard Levin and Alan Watkins testified on his behalf, he surprisingly won damages of £600.

Despite this, Lawson magnanimously re-employed Waugh as a novel reviewer, where he honed his talent for vituperation, which he later and even more brilliantly practised in the obscure magazine Books & Bookmen. Like other "slashing" reviewers, he would point out that he often lavished praise on the writers he liked. These were far from predictable. One favourite was the Californian hippy novelist Richard Brautigan, another Angela Carter. And Martin Amis never forgot how "very generous" Waugh had been.

In 1970 he found a natural billet at Private Eye. The "Diary" he wrote for the Eye over the next 16 years was unique, a combination of polemic, causerie, parody and fantasy. Those who liked it thought it very funny indeed, though its technique was partly pure abuse.

Harold Wilson was an "old crook" (and a Soviet agent, Waugh sometimes suggested), with his "revoltingly ugly" colleague Barbara Castle. Not that Waugh was politically partisan. Heath was a buffoonish ninny, and Churchill a "war criminal, mass murderer and persecutor of PG Wodehouse".

This taste for the calculatedly distasteful even extended to his wine columns: he compared one wine to "a bunch of dead chrysanthemums on the grave of a still-born West Indian baby". He ruthlessly used these columns, and the Spectator Wine Club, to stock his own cellar. Waugh was never squeamish about journalistic ethics. Once he discovered the delights of the "freebie", he gave breathless accounts of his trips to the Orient, and the wonderful "Thai two-girl massage".

Sometimes his abuse was random. Watching television of an evening, Waugh caught the Tchaikovsky bio-pic, The Music Lovers. "Hideous woman, dreadful film. One can't really blame Tchaikovsky for preferring boys. Anyone might become a homosexual who had once seen Glenda Jackson naked."

But other diatribes were deliberate. Waugh had a truly Sicilian taste for vendetta, pursuing Lord Gowrie for decades because they had once competed, Gowrie successfully, for the same girl at Oxford. His tendresse for Tina Brown helped explain another long feud, with Harold Evans. His diatribes against Jimmy Goldsmith (on the possible size of whose "organ" he once dilated in print), or Shirley Williams, at any rate had no personal basis.

If that sounded childish, Waugh's writing was valued by good judges. Anthony Howard took on Waugh for the New Statesman, where he wrote some of his best columns for what he imagined was his typical reader, a bad-tempered leftwing woman teacher in the Midlands.

By now Waugh had finally given up fiction, after publishing five novels in all. He said that his novels were not selling any more and were not getting any better, though at least one, Consider the Lilies (1968) is still very funny and readable (the others are Path of Dalliance, 1963, Who Are the Violets Now, 1966, and A Bed of Flowers, 1971). Maybe the truth was that abandoning fiction was another way of escaping his father's shadow.

Another was his increasingly detached attitude to Catholicism. Gradually he stopped going to church, later ceasing to be a practising or even believing Catholic.

In 1976, the new editor of the Spectator, Alexander Chancellor, hired Waugh to write a weekly column. This decade, his own thirties, was perhaps the best of Waugh's writing life. His political as well as literary opinions were unpredictable. If he went on repetitiously about the "foul-mouthed, dirty and drunk" working classes, he disliked them not least because of their taste for punishment, especially capital punishment, which he abhorred. He also loathed war, and later opposed the Falklands, Gulf and Kosovo campaigns. In his idiosyncratic way, he was part of an authentic mood of revulsion against the bossy authoritarianism of left and right.

Then he found another obsession. Jeremy Thorpe, the Liberal leader, had been caught up in a seamy scandal concerning a youth called Norman Scott, which led finally to Thorpe's departure as party leader and then his prosecution and acquittal. At the 1979 general election, Waugh stood against Thorpe in his North Devon constituency on behalf of the Dog Lovers' Party, an allusion to the strange episode when a hitman trying to frighten Scott, or worse, shot his pet dog. Waugh lost his deposit, but had the gratification of hearing Lord Denning say that his election address, which Thorpe had tried to suppress, could be published, and of seeing Thorpe lose his seat.

Then Waugh published a book about the case, The Last Word. It showed his inability (shared by all the Eye gang) to understand the basic principles of justice, but it also supplied an appropriate note of black farce: as the journalist David Leigh said, Waugh gave a version of the affair in the style of Joe Orton.

That North Devon constituency was near home for Waugh. He had married very young, in 1961, Lady Teresa Onslow, daughter of the Earl of Onslow, and lived with his family in the country, first in Berkshire and then at his father's old house, Combe Florey, in Somerset. After raising her family of two sons and two daughters, Teresa took a degree and made her own notable career as translator and novelist.

By the 1980s, Waugh showed signs of restlessness, and looked for excuses to spend more time in London. When Ian Hislop became editor of Private Eye in 1986, Waugh left haughtily and abusively to take up the editorship of the Literary Review, a monthly owned, and heavily subsidised, by Naim Attallah. These later years were puzzling. Waugh devoted much energy to his beloved magazine, bullying all his friends to write for tiny fees, and he established an annual party for the magazine's Bad Sex Award, a back-handed prize for novels with excruciating sexual descriptions.

And yet the truth was that the Literary Review was not so much bad as pointless. Equally, though Waugh was more prolific than ever, the columns he wrote for the Sunday Telegraph from 1980 and the Daily Telegraph from 1990 never quite matched the dash and bite of his best work for the Spectator or Private Eye.

Part of the answer may have been that he was never quite at his best in national papers. But part was exhaustion. He kept working at a manic pace. Although he was earning more than most English journalists, Waugh seemed obsessed by the prospect of poverty, or at least by the need to provide for his family. Apart from the Thorpe book and his memoirs, the only books he published in his later years were collections from his various columns. He twice won the What the Papers Say Award for Columnist of the Year.

To say that not everyone loved Bron Waugh would be an understatement. A certain kind of politician and journalist, often though not always female, found him repugnant, and his success incomprehensible. Such foes were baffled by the boyish camaraderie of old Fleet Street, not to say its tradition of ecumenical friendship: before he had a London flat of his own, Waugh used to stay with his great friend Paul Foot.

In fact, apart from his vague dislike of male institutions, Waugh himself had many women friends. And he enjoyed holding court to pretty girls and jolly lads at the Academy Club, a bohemian joint he founded next to his office.

Some of the more impassioned attacks on Waugh over the years appeared in the Guardian. Alexander Chancellor responded to one. He wasn't a disinterested witness: he had been a friend and colleague of Bron's for many years before their children Alexander Waugh and Liza Chancellor married. Nevertheless, when he wrote that Waugh was "brave, generous, funny and an extremely skilful writer," it may not have been the whole story, but it was a large and true part of it.

 Auberon Alexander Waugh, editor and writer, born November 17 1939; died January 16 2001

fields.headline: 'Better to go than sit around being a terrible old bore'
fields.standfirst: Tributes to master of satire who lived in the shadow of his father
fields.trailText: Auberon Waugh lived in the shadow of his father, the comic novelist Evelyn Waugh, and of his father's disapproval. But, when his premature death was announced yesterday, he was recognised as having more than a spark of the same keen gifts
fields.body:
Auberon Waugh lived in the shadow of his father, the comic novelist Evelyn Waugh, and of his father's disapproval. But, when his premature death was announced yesterday, he was recognised as having more than a spark of the same keen gifts.

In tributes of a warmth he rarely received in his lifetime of journalism and satirical columns, he was said by the editor of the Daily Telegraph, Charles Moore, to have brought "the vision of an artist" to his work. "He was a very original, real genius in journalism", Mr Moore added.

Alan Coren, another leading comic writer of his generation, said he shared some of the qualities of a tradition of writing which stretched back to the 18th century essayist William Cobbett and included GK Chesterton, Hilaire Belloc and Evelyn Waugh.

News of his death, at the age of 61 from heart trouble, produced raw grief among colleagues. Mr Coren said it was another blow after the loss of three others from the satire generation, Peter Cook, William Rushton and John Wells.

It reminded him of the words of the American writer SJ Perelman: "When a humorist dies, you should go somewhere where there's a good band and drink till they throw you out".

Waugh, editor since 1986 of the Literary Review, died on Tuesday at Combe Florey, Somerset, his father's old home which he had proudly maintained from his earnings as a freelance journalist. His wife, Lady Teresa Waugh, said yesterday: "He had been unwell for quite a long time, with a bad heart. It's hard to sum up someone so wonderful - but I've been hanging around for 40 years so that says something."

Like his father, Auberon Waugh, who smoked despite having lost a lung in a youthful military accident and relished wine for much of his life, appeared to age prematurely. But when he mentioned it in his dry manner, his friends and readers could rarely tell whether he was joking.

In September, 1999, he wrote, "Like many of my friends, I have been suffering from most of the symptoms of senile deterioration for at least five years, including general forgetfulness, nominal aphasia, an inability to recognise anyone.

"I think there is much more of it around than anyone realises - possibly something to do with global warming, or petrol fumes, or hamburger gases.".

His decline emerged clearly in his last interview, given in November to publicise the cherished Bad Sex Awards given by the Literary Review for clumsy explicit writing in new novels.

He had lost weight, admitted to a loss of concentration and spoke of a recent faint. "No-one knows what caused it", he told an interviewer from The Independent newspaper, "The heart probably. I don't think I'll survive long. I can feel I'm on my way out".

"Bleeding hell", the interviewer replied, in a moment reminiscent of his father's novel Scoop, about the iniquities of journalists, "Hang on for the next hour at least, or I'm well stuffed for this Monday's interview".

Waugh laughed, but kept asking, "Have you got enough? Can I go now?". He also said, "I'll be sorry to leave my wife and various friends. But better to go than sit around being a terrible old bore."

Comic vision

In an interview with MediaGuardian.co.uk, Mr Moore, for whose paper Waugh had written a column since 1990, recalled, "He was the only person in the whole of Britain, apart from the IRA, who said he wished Mrs Thatcher had been killed in the Brighton bombing.

"It is an extreme example and I am not saying he really meant it and as always with him it was done in a comical way but it was something nobody else would have dared say. He greatly disliked morality wherever it came from and he was a great inspiration as a writer.

"One often speaks of people as being irreplaceable," said Mr Moore, "but in this case it is true. He was a very original, real genius in journalism who brought a comic vision of the world to his writing. It was like the vision of an artist.

Alan Coren said Waugh was always in pain after his accident as a national serviceman, when he mishandled a machine gun which went off, injuring his lungs, spleen and ribs. Attempting to unblock the jammed Browning machine gun, he made the mistake of standing in front of the weapon and shaking the muzzle, causing six bullets to be fired at point-blank range into his chest.

As he lay on the ground waiting for an ambulance, he remarked to his platoon sergeant: "Kiss me, Chudleigh." But "Chudleigh did not recognise the allusion and from then on treated me with extreme caution," he recalled. Coren recalled yesterday: "Bron always had that sort of English stoicism which did not allow him to bang on about his illness.

"He was very much in a line of dissident, subversive counter-culture which expresses itself humorously. In another country, he would have been a serious dissident. But English dissidents are not like that. He was in essence a very serious man, very humorous, not reactionary.

"He cared deeply about the decline of things he believed in. He was never a fascist. He was a decent, personally very kind and professionally savage man. I love it when those things go together.

"He had a vision which was often expressed in a curmudgeonly way but he himself was not a curmudgeon".

Ian Hislop, editor of Private Eye, said Waugh was the "master of surreal comic vitriol. He was terrifically proud of the Private Eye diaries he wrote. I think he once said some of them were his finest work. He had a rather black view on life. It was sometimes difficult to separate the comic persona of misanthropy from the real man. I think he had difficulty separating it himself."

Simon Clark, director the smokers' lobby, Forest, said: "Bron was an inspiration to us. He was a great example of tolerance and commonsense. We will greatly miss his friendship and support."

When I was 15 and going through a mildly rebellious phase, I held the school record at Downside for 14 canings in one term. I am not claiming they did me no harm, merely that I found them quite disagreeable and they certainly never developed any taste for flagellantism

(Undated)

Among the 256 MPs who trooped through the division lobby to continue our arms supply to Nigeria and to help kill the next generation of Biafrans, many were known to me as humane, reasonably intelligent people. They had allowed themselves to become machines

Michael Caine has described himself as "every bourgeois's nightmare, a cockney with intelligence and a million dollars" but there is nothing paradoxical or even unusual in the son of a Billingsgate fish porter being knighted. Most of those chosen for knighthood nowadays seem to come from that sort of background

(November 1991)

Peter Cook 1937 -1995

Founded ground-breaking comedy club the Establishment in 1960 and agreed to invest money in Private Eye in 1961. He remained a major shareholder throughout his life, giving editors a free rein. His main contribution, aside from numerous one-off jokes, was the introduction of the famous speech-bubble covers. Probably best remembered as an entertainer, appearing in Not Only But Also (1961-75) with Dudley Moore as the infamous Dud and Pete.

Willie Rushton 1937-1996

With Christopher Booker was a founder member of Private Eye in 1961.

He was part of the team that launched satirical show That Was The Week That Was, appearing between 1962-63 on BBC TV. He was an actor, author, cartoonist and broadcaster and illustrated the book A Turbulent Decade 1976-85, by Auberon Waugh.

Richard Ingrams Born 1937

Educated at Shrewsbury school, where he edited The Salopian, and later Oxford university.

Joined Private Eye in 1962 and became editor the next year, staying in the chair until 1986.

He has written many books including Mrs Wilson's Diary (1965) and, with John Wells, the collected works of Denis Thatcher (1980). He was made chairman of the magazine in 1974 and remains a columnist for the Observer.

Christopher Booker Born 1937

One of the founder members of Private Eye, he was the magazine's first editor from 1961-63 and has been regular contributor since. He was the resident scriptwriter on That Was The Week That Was and has written several books including The Secret Diary of John Major 1992-95 and St Albion Parish News (1998).

Has also been a contributor to the Telegraph, Spectator and has a column in the Sunday Telegraph. Campaigning Journalist of the Year in 1973.

John Wells 1936-1998

Co-editor of Private Eye between 1964-67 and a performer on That Was The Week That Was. A writer, director and accomplished actor, he will be best remembered for his caricature of Sir Denis Thatcher in Anyone for Denis? with himself in the lead.

fields.headline: Lily Savage becomes a brand
fields.trailText: 8am: Comedian Paul O'Grady has registered his drag-queen character as a trademark, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Lily Savage - the acid-tongued, cross-dressing host of ITV's Blankety Blank - is now officially a brand.

Comedian Paul O'Grady, Lily's creator and alter ego, has registered the Lily Savage trade mark in 12 classes of product.

These include cosmetics and beauty products, jewellery, leather - including imitation leather - alcoholic drinks, and even wigs.

Lily joins a long line of entertainers and sport stars who have seen the value in registering their well-known names as brands.

Linda McCartney trade-marked her vegetarian food recipes, Paul Newman his salad dressing, Rolf Harris his Stylophone, Bjorn Borg his underwear and Denise Van Outen her bikinis.

Manchester United legend Eric Cantona even applied to the patent office to register the crowd chant "Oooh, aaahh, Cantona!" for use on boxer shorts, stationery and teaching materials.

Twenty-first century icons to more recently jump on the bandwagon include England rugby captain Lawrence Dallaglio and footballer Alan Shearer.

But while Alan Shearer duvets are all the rage in the north-east, it appears unlikely that a garish range of Lily Savage lipsticks is about to be launched in her native Liverpool.

A spokeswoman for Mr O'Grady said the main reason for the registration was to protect the character against counterfeiters and rogue products.

Ian Buchan of the Institute of Trade Mark Attorneys said: "Paul O'Grady is doing the sensible thing in seeking trade mark protection for the remarkable character that he has developed. It is a valuable asset.

"While I can't actually see myself in a Lily Savage wig, I'm sure there are many people out there who would gladly buy such merchandise," he said.

fields.headline: Welsh football team sues BBC in race row
fields.trailText: 10.45am: A Welsh soccer team is taking the BBC to court over alleged racial discrimination, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
A Welsh football team is suing the BBC for alleged racial discrimination because the broadcaster will not carry its results on Final Score.

Welsh League champions Total Network Solutions are making their move after three years of lobbying BBC executives came to nothing.

Final Score carries the results of the major UK football leagues every Saturday at 4.45pm on BBC1, and is a staple of the long-running Grandstand show.

TNS claims its league is as important as the lower Scottish and Conference leagues.

However, the BBC argues that its Saturday results only include teams featured in Littlewoods Pools coupons.

However, the BBC will have to state its case in court after the frustrated club issued a writ with the backing of the Commission for Racial Equality's Cardiff branch.

webTitle: Analysts predict tough year for UK media

fields.headline: Tough year ahead for UK media say analysts
fields.trailText: 8.30am: UK media companies face a tough 2001 as dot.com advertising goes into freefall, according to analysts. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
UK media companies face a tough 2001 as dot.com advertising goes into freefall, according to analysts.

The European media team at ABN Amro have cut their stance on the sector to "reduce", due to the dramatic downturn in the US economy and a fall in advertising revenues from cash-strapped start-ups.

"The economic environment appears to be rapidly deteriorating in the US in particular, and the troubled hi-tech and automotive sector will contribute to lower advertising growth," said the note.

However, UK firms will bear the brunt of the slump in advertising growth, with ITV giants Granada Media and Carlton Communications set for negative advertising revenue growth in the first half of the year.

The ABN note added that the UK TV market should "just about" hold its share of the advertising market in 2001.

"The slowest of the major European markets is set to be the UK, where GDP growth is likely to be the slowest and the dot.com boom had most effect in 2000," the note said.

ABN predicted that UK dot.com advertising will show negative growth of -0.5% for 2001, contributing to a drop in advertising growth from 8.5% in 2000 to 5% for the next 12 months.

The media sector's exposure to the advertising market is dangerously high, with ABN calculating that 50% of its revenues were advertising-related.

Such is the media team's concern for the sector, its one remaining company on the "buy" list is Luxembourg-based satellite operator Societe Europeene des Satellites.

fields.headline: MTV accuses Bectu as dispute escalates
fields.standfirst: Jan 16:MTV in strike threat
fields.trailText:
10.30am: MTV has hit back in its dispute with the union, which is ballotting its members on industrial action. By Jason Deans.
Jan 16:MTV in strike threat
fields.body:
MTV has hit back in its industrial dispute with Bectu, accusing the union of perpetuating "inaccuracies".

Bectu will be balloting its MTV members on industrial action from next Monday over plans to cut holiday entitlement and reduce overtime payments.

MTV Networks Europe said it did not want staff to "subsidise development", as claimed by Bectu official Sharon Elliott.

"MTV Networks Europe is concerned to note that several inaccuracies appear to have been perpetuated in the media by Bectu in respect of contractual negotiations within the Broadcast Services division," the company said.

"The new terms and conditions are designed to make the Broadcast Services division competitive enough to compete for third-party work and also bring Broadcast Services staff's terms and conditions in line with those of other UK-based MTV employees," it added.

The new contractual arrangements "adhere fully to both the spirit and practice of current industry standards on terms and conditions for shift workers in this industry, while the terms remain more advantageous than those offered by comparative organisations in the UK television sector", MTV said.

MTV added that it was in discussion with "a small number of shift workers" in its Broadcast Services division, not the entire staff of the department.

The Viacom subsidiary said it was negotiating directly with the staff concerned "in the interests of protecting the confidentiality of the individuals concerned" and saw "no benefit in the involvement of a third party such as Bectu".

MTV added it was "confident it had followed all the correct, appropriate and legal processes in the conduct of this negotiation".

fields.headline: 13 arrested in child porn raids
fields.trailText: Police yesterday arrested 13 suspected paedophiles in the largest ever UK operation against child pornography on the internet.
fields.body:
Police yesterday arrested 13 suspected paedophiles in the largest-ever UK operation against child pornography on the internet.

Officers from 13 forces made the arrests in dawn raids across the country, recovering 27 computers along with thousands of photographs, videos and magazines.

Most of the material features scenes of children being raped and sexually abused, and those arrested are thought to be linked.

"Images like these are evidence of the sexual assault and rape of children, and anyone who buys or downloads them perpetuates the cycle of abuse," said Detective Chief Inspector Bob McLachlan, head of the Metropolitan police unit which coordinated the operation.

"We know that the internet is increasingly used as a conduit for the exchange of pornographic pictures of children.

"Those responsible believe that the internet affords anonymity, but police technology in this area is increasingly sophisticated."

Other forces involved in the operation were Grampian, Humberside, Merseyside, Lancashire, West Yorkshire, Derbyshire, Hertfordshire, Avon and Somerset, Bedfordshire, Devon and Cornwall, Thames Valley and Sussex.

fields.headline: No 1. West Ham United
fields.standfirst: Graeme Howlett, editor of Knees Up Mother Brown, introduces us to the club he loves
fields.trailText:
What makes West Ham so special
Since time immemorial, West Ham have had to fight against the "bigger" clubs in London, such as Arsenal and Chelsea (and once upon a time, Tottenham) - which is why success, when it comes, is even more special. We are not and have never pretended to be one of the glory clubs - just a good, honest, hard-working, attractive team who try to play football the way it should be played.

We are not and have never pretended to be one of the glory clubs - just a good, honest, hard-working, attractive team who try to play football the way it should be played.

The high points
Minds inevitably go back to the World Cup of '66. England might have had their name on the trophy, but everyone knows that it was West Ham that won it! Then there's the Cup Winners' Cup win in '65, the FA Cup win over Arsenal in '80 and the Intertoto Final 2nd Leg in Metz.

Mind you, as a West Ham fan you also enjoy stuffing the big boys from time to time - which is why the two occasions that we denied Manchester United the title in the mid '90s (a 1-1 draw in 1995 and a 1-0 win in 1992) are also pretty memorable.

The low points
Too many to mention. The long series of Cup defeats against lower-division opposition rankle still, but for the worst you have to go back less than 12 months, when 'Mannygate' meant we had to replay the Worthington Cup quarter-final against Aston Villa after we had won the game - which we subsequently lost.

How we're doing at the moment
After a terrible start followed by a good recovery, our season seems to have slumped again. Three defeats in the last four games have seen us fall outside the top ten - and worse still, behind Tottenham and Chelsea. Elsewhere, young Jermaine Defoe is doing the business on loan at Bournemouth - he's scored in every one of his nine league appearances there, and only needs to score in his next three to match Dixie Dean's 70-year-old record.

The next match
Our next game takes us across the water to Charlton. Having stuffed them 5-0 less than a month ago we should be optimistic, but Alan Curbishley's boys are no mugs at The Valley, and will prove a far tougher proposition this time round.

This is irritating
Since the sale of Rio Ferdinand to Leeds for £18m in November the club has so far invested in two Liverpool reserves in return - Rigobert Song and Titi Camara. And we've just been told that the club wouldn't sanction the transfer of Lorenzo Amoruso from Rangers because of his financial demands.

The chairman
Terry Brown, although unpopular with the fans, has brought the club forward greatly in recent years. It could be a lot worse - Doug Ellis anyone?

Our traditional rivals
Traditionally it's Millwall, but since they fell away into the darker depths of the football league, Tottenham have taken over as the root of all evil. With good reason you could argue - how many Spurs fans are there who still think they're a big club? I've got news for you lot

The crowd's favourite
Paolo Di Canio is the Boleyn's current golden boy, with Joey Cole - "always believe in your soul" - a close second. Most popular player ever? The greatest English footballer ever - Bobby Moore (closely followed by the likes of Billy Bonds, Trevor Brooking and Geoff Hurst). I don't think any opposing player is ever accepted by Upton Park, but on a personal level I'd say Ryan Giggs - a truly talented footballer. Not Paul Ince. No, definitely not.

Figure of hate
Now where do you start? This season I would say it's between "Fat Dave" Ginola and the Afghan hound from Leicester - what's his name, Lily Savage or something? Paul Ince will always be the most hated player at Upton Park. Hammers fans have never forgotten how he posed in the red shirt of Manchester United whilst still on our books. Ince aside, Paul Allen was an instant villain when he left us for Tottenham back in the early '80s. He thanked us by scoring against us soon after and celebrating in front of our fans.

How we're turned out
You can't knock the current Fila shirt. And with good old Dr Martens emblazoned across the chest for good measure, the club are definitely on a winner. The best kit of all time is split evenly, in my opinion, between the classic '60s claret-and-blue shirt and the early '80s Adidas shirt, which was so cool it was untrue. The worst? Has to be the Pony (in all senses of the word) effort with the big collars from the late '90s.

Ridiculous merchandise
No contest this one. Has to be the knickers with "I've scored at Upton Park" written on them. Nice.

Mascots
We've got two of the buggers - Herbie Hammer (a grotesque figure with a Hammer where his head should be) and Bubbles the Bear (far more infant-friendly). They cuddle each other a lot.

The ground
The Boleyn Ground is a tight, compact arena where players can literally feel the crowd upon them - just ask anyone who has had to work the flank alongside the Chicken Run!

The crowd
Top songs are (obviously) Bubbles, plus newer "compositions" such as La Donna E Mobile (for Paolo Di Canio) and Spandau Ballet's Gold (For Jo-ey Cole). They're usually a much quieter lot down there these days, but not without the odd eccentric. One supporter was seen standing in the Bobby Moore stand against Sunderland last weekend naked for a full 10 minutes. Honest!

Local knowledge
If you're an away fan - get in the ground! Green Street, the approach you use from Upton Park tube, contains the Boleyn and the Queens pubs - both West Ham only unless you're very brave (or, if you wear colours, stupid). Food-wise there are the usual fast-food vendors, although good old pie, mash and liquor is still easy to get hold of - essential on a match day.

Links
Good for a read if you're around the ground are the fanzines OTT (On the Terraces), OLAS (Over Land And Sea) and the Ironworks Gazette. On the web - after you've visited KUMB (www.westhamunited-fc.com) - why not say hello to the boys at Mangler (www.mangler.co.uk)? The message board there is as lively as they come.

Hopes for the future
We're all still hopeful of a place in Europe come May. Despite the recent slip, we're still going forward, and with one or two new faces we could really be in with a shout. And why have I got a funny feeling about our visit to Old Trafford for the fourth round of the FA Cup? Must be the eternal optimist in me ...

fields.headline: Palestinian TV chief murdered
fields.standfirst:
Tel Aviv throws doubt on claims that Israeli collaborators shot dead Arafat protege

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Tel Aviv throws doubt on claims that Israeli collaborators shot dead Arafat protege, writes Suzanne Goldenberg .
fields.body:
The head of the official Palestinian television network was shot dead in a seafront restaurant in Gaza yesterday, an audacious daylight killing which the network blamed on collaborators with Israel.

There was no independent confirmation of the official Palestinian claim that Hisham Mikki, 54, was felled by the "bullets of treason and betrayal", fired by two masked men using pistols equipped with silencers.

But the speed with which the official media accused Israel, and those who serve its interests, is telling of the atmosphere of suspicion that has engulfed the Palestinian areas in the wake of the officially sanctioned Israeli policy of assassinating their key leaders.

Israel said yesterday that the army and intelligence services had no hand in Mikki's death. Officials in Gaza said privately that the television chief, a protege of the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, could have been killed because of political or personal grudges.

Mikki's driver, who also served as a bodyguard, was detained for questioning.

The Israeli government has repeatedly accused the official Palestinian media of "inciting" violent protests in the West Bank and Gaza. But the style of yesterday's killing, and the target, were very different from the assassinations Israel has carried out on commanders of Mr Arafat's Fatah militias.

Mikki was killed at a time when the West Bank and Gaza are in the throes of a hunt for suspected collaborators, as the Palestinian Authority and vigilante squads turn on the enemy within.

Its war on collaborators opened on Saturday when two men wereshot by firing squad and four others were convicted of treason at short military trials. Unofficially, it began in November, when vigilantes executed their first suspected collaborator.

Since the weekend, the Palestinian police have arrested more than 100 West Bank men suspected of providing information to Israel on the movements of Fatah leaders who are believed targets of assassination.

To the Palestinians, the assassinations are a terrifying reminder that although they no longer live under Israel's direct control they remain at its mercy, and that even their nerve centre, the Fatah movement, is compromised by Israel's network of informers.

The arrests come despite an amnesty issued on Monday allowing collaborators to escape trial - and the prospect of execution by firing squad - by turning themselves in and making full confessions.

The consequences of being accused of collaboration, or being related to a collaborator, are dire. In the Bethlehem area one man was held for 44 days after police traced phone calls he had made to Hussein Abayat, a Fatah commander killed by missiles fired from Israeli combat helicopters.

Ibrahim Atiyat was tortured in detention. His nipples were torn off, and he was beaten so severely that he had to be treated in hospital three times before his innocence was proved and he was released on January 6.

The families of collaborators are also vulnerable - which is why to date only a handful of collaborators have come out in the open to seek amnesty.

Yesterday relatives of Majdi Mikkawi, who was executed in Gaza, took out a newspaper advertisement washing their hands of him. "We announce that we no longer have any relationship with or responsibility for the above mentioned person," the advertisement read. "We also condemn... the ugly deed that he committed."

The main force behind the hunt for collaborators is the Fatah militia, the very target of Israel's assassination campaign. "We are the ones that start the investigation, and after that we hand the information to the authorities," said Abdullah Abu Hadid, who leads the militia in the Bethlehem area.

He said his men were behind the vigilante killing of a collaborator in November, Kassam Khlef, the first of at least six men summarily executed.

Khlef was known to have worked with the Israelis during the first intifada, but Mr Hadid's men had no recent evidence against him. "He was killed just to serve as an example to other collaborators that this is what can happen," Mr Hadid said.

The readiness of Fatah militias to dispense rough justice belies the pitiful circumstances which lead some Palestinians to treason. Palestinian officials admit there are thousands in their ranks who provide low-grade intelligence to Israel. There is a list of 350 in the Bethlehem area alone.

Many of the collaborators are barely out of their teens and poorly educated, coerced into providing information in return for Israeli work and travel permits, or to escape criminal prosecution or blackmail for sexual improprieties.

Others turned traitor during the last intifada. Though the Palestinian authorities have compiled lists of informers of that era, peace agreements prohibit their prosecution.

Some Palestinians believe that the amnesty and the threat of vigilante killings are being used to press collaborators to break their connections with Israel.

"I think it is a message to the collaborators to lay down and do nothing," said Khalil Shikaki, a Palestinian analyst in Ramallah. "I do not think the Palestinian Authority really expects people to give themselves up."

webTitle: University admissions should be less 'culturally biased'

fields.headline: University admissions should be less 'culturally biased'
fields.trailText: Universities should treat working in a family cornershop or business as just as valuable an extra curricular experience as captaining a rugby team when selecting students, the chief academic quality watchdog told MPs yesterday.
fields.body:
Universities should treat working in a family cornershop or business as just as valuable an extra curricular experience as captaining a rugby team when selecting students, the chief academic quality watchdog told MPs yesterday.

Academic institutions might attract more students from ethnic minority groups, if they were less culturally biased when considering applicants with similar academic grades suggested John Randall, the head of the quality assurance agency for higher education.

The comments came during the second hearing of the House of Commons education committee's inquiry into student drop outs. UK universities boast one of the lowest drop out rates by international standards - with 17% of students not completing degrees. But the MPs are investigating why the numbers of students bailing out of courses varies so much for similar academic institutions. They are also considering whether the drive to reduce drop out rates conflicts with the government's efforts to attract more students from poorer backgrounds and ethnic minority groups , who are more likely not to complete their degrees.

"In discriminating between candidates with broadly equivalent academic grades, institutions may consider evidence of personal initiative, or team-working ability," said Randall. "Such evidence comes from a range of sporting, artistic or voluntary activities. But institutions need to be sensitive to which applicants have had opportunities to participate in such activities, and to remember that in a culturally diverse society, there are many ways in which leadership may be demonstrated."

Randall told the MPs that admissions tutors should "not just go for the leader of the rugby club" and consider for example the entrepreneurial initiative shown by those who helped to run a family business. The negative experiences of those turned down by universities could have an adverse affect on others from similar backgrounds he argued. The recommendation will be part of advice on university admissions published by the quality assurance agency this year.

The latest university admissions figures show that degree applicants from ethnic minority groups are less likely to get into university than white applicants. Just under 70% of black applicants secured university places last year, compared with 80% of white applicants. Students from ethnic minorities made up 3% of the 300,000 new degree students in 2000.

Randall said that universities could improve drop out rates by providing better information for prospective students, making that they enrolled on suitable degree courses, and increasing the feedback given to them during courses.

"A common complaint from students is that not enough feedback is received on work submitted for assessment," said Randall. He said that there was also a temptation for universities "to get bums on seats" and not assess whether students had the appropriate skills to enrol on courses.

Student drop outs cost the taxpayer about £200m a year MPs were told last week.

webTitle: Leader: we need international rules on adoption

fields.headline: Shopping for babies
fields.standfirst: We need international rules on adoption
fields.trailText: We need international rules on adoption.
fields.body:
The story of Kimberley and Belinda's first few months of life cannot but horrify. Adopted at the cost of £4,000 by one couple, the Allens, they are removed by their birth mother after she changes her mind and driven 2,000 miles to be adopted under Arkansas' fast-track procedures by another couple, the Kilshaws, at a cost of £8,200. The long journey leads to the babies developing coughs and dehydration.

Two aspects of this are equally repugnant: the bidding for babies in a globalised trade and the desperate, selfish behaviour of the Kilshaws.

UK politicians chorus their disapproval, but in truth, there is very little they can do about this particular case. There may be doubts over the Kilshaws' suitability to adopt, but unless there is evidence of real harm, the local authority cannot remove the children, since the UK recognises US adoption orders.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, has announced an inquiry into how the Kilshaws brought the babies in on visitors' visas, but the immigration authorities are not to blame; many children involved in inter-country adoptions come into the UK on such visas. The battle will be in the US, where the Kilshaws and the Allens will slug it out through the courts. The case could run and run. The birth mother lied about her address in Arkansas, which could invalidate the Kilshaws' adoption; but under Californian law, she is entitled to change her mind in the choice of adoptive parents.

The bigger picture is that this mess underlines the urgency of ratifying the Hague Convention on inter-country adoption - also the subject of the Liberal Democrat MP Mark Oaten's bill passed in July 1999. But it will not be until 2002 that we have the regulations in place; the delay is partly due to the prime minister's intervention to give priority to other aspects of adoption reform. But Kimberley and Belinda have dramatically illustrated that the internet has globalised the baby trade. We cannot afford to wait.

Related stories
Blair demands law on internet baby trade

Once children are settled, welfare considerations may ensure they stay

webTitle: Serious commitment to deprived areas needs serious funding

fields.headline: Serious commitment to deprived areas needs serious funding
fields.standfirst: While Labour's new strategy for neighbourhood renewal is welcome, it is seriously lacking in many areas, writes Bob Holman
fields.trailText: Comment: While Labour's new strategy for neighbourhood renewal is welcome, it is seriously lacking in many areas, writes Bob Holman
fields.body:
Soon after taking office, New Labour established a social exclusion unit charged with transforming Britain's poorest neighbourhoods. It has now published its strategy in A new commitment to neighbourhood renewal (Cabinet Office, January 2000)

Having lived in deprived areas for 25 years, I welcome any improvements. But the proposed financial input is small. The documment states: "Communities in the 88 most deprived districts will get around £400,000 each over three years." £400,000 is peanuts compared with the £250m of public money lavished on Portcullis House to provide luxury offices for MPs.

Policy contradiction
Just as serious, the new strategy contains a fundamental contradiction. It talks about the "grassroots empowerment of people". Empowerment entails low-incomed residents of disadvantaged areas deciding on policies and then allocating the money to local groups to implement them.

Yet, for all the radical words, the government strategy is mainly the old top-down approach. The government has already set the targets for neighbourhoods. Few would disagree with ministers when they call for a reduction in crime and poor health. But residents might have given priority to a youth club in every patch, to dealing with loan sharks, to providing a holiday for every child. Too bad - the targets are already set.

Next, the government has decided that the main vehicles for change will be local strategic partnerships consisting of local authorities, national voluntary societies, housing associations, private companies etc plus a few community reps. They appear little different from the elitist urban development corporations so dear to Mrs Thatcher. Often the experience of residents is that, within partnerships, they are the small boys who get consulted while the big boys make the decisions and get the goodies.

Not least, New Labour has decreed that it will appoint neighbourhood managers to coordinate services and to ensure that targets are met. Coordination often means meetings with no action. And what if local people don't see the point of a neighbourhood manager? Too bad, you're getting one.

The missing link
The missing link in the strategy is any recognition that the lead role should be given to neighbourhood projects. These projects are controlled by local committees who engage residents as staff and volunteers.

They run the services which people want such as credit unions, food co-ops, cafes, debt counselling or sports teams. They support vulnerable families and divert youngsters from delinquency. They succeed because they are rooted long-term in the community rather than being three-year initiatives under outsiders. Their problem is shortage of funds.

The project with which I am associated in Easterhouse, Glasgow, receives not a penny from the government and nothing from the city council towards the salaries of its five staff.

What is required

The government should finance a national neighbourhood fund to provide around a million pounds a year to every deprived area. The money would be administered by local trusts consisting of residents elected from their community. The trusts should set targets and then allocate grants to neighbourhood projects which are genuinely locally controlled.

Empowermment
The cost might run into billions but so do the public subsidies to privately run rail companies.

The minister responsible for the neighbourhood renewal is Hilary Armstrong. Years ago, I was her tutor at university and was pleased when she took jobs in community work before turning to politics. She has focused more attention on needy communities than any government since the second world war and has done so without attaching any blame on poor residents. Full marks so far.

However, her policies may benefit disadvantaged communities but they will not empower local people. I award her a pass but not a distinction - yet.

It has now published its strategy in A new commitment to neighbourhood renewal (Cabinet Office, January 2000) Having lived in deprived areas for 25 years, I welcome any improvements. But the proposed financial input is small. The documment states: "Communities in the 88 most deprived districts will get around £400,000 each over three years." £400,000 is peanuts compared with the £250m of public money lavished on Portcullis House to provide luxury offices for MPs. fields.headline: ONdigital numbers in dispute
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText:
The number of ONdigital customers who gave up subscriptions could be far higher than the one in five who cancel annually, new figures suggest. By John Cassy.
Jan 17: City not impressed
Jan 17: ONdigital reaches 1m target
fields.body:
The number of customers who gave up subscriptions to ONdigital during the last quarter could be far higher than the one in five who cancel annually, new figures suggest.

Some industry sources believe that the broadcaster could be losing almost every other new customer.

The digital terrestrial TV operator yesterday announced that it hit the target of signing a million customers by the end of 2000 but concerns about its "churn" - the rate at which customers cancel - depressed the shares of joint owners Carlton Communications and Granada Media.

ONdigital says its annual churn rate is 15-20% but figures from GFK, a source of data for the electrical retail trade, suggest that churn in the 12 weeks to Christmas could have been well in excess of the previous periods, industry sources said.

Research from GFK shows that during the quarter ONdigital sold 134,000 boxes through the shops - the same number by which it said its new subscriber base grew.

But ONdigital has said in the past that GFK consistently underestimates actual sales. Industry sources suggest the broadcaster is likely to have sold up to 170,000 boxes through retailers during the period. In addition, there would be direct telephone sales which analysts at Merrill Lynch estimate account for "around half" of annual sales.

"Churn is fundamental to the profitability of a pay-TV business and it looks like [ONdigital's] rate in the run-up to Christmas was higher than it has ever been before," said one industry source.

An ONdigital spokesman said the company did not give churn figures for the fourth quarter but dismissed the concerns. He said annual churn rates remained at around the 15-20% and would be reduced to 10-12% in time.

He also emphasised that the proportion of telephone sign-ups trails off during Christmas because gift hunters are out on the high street and boostset-top box sales in shops.

ONdigital staff were last night at a party thrown to cel ebrate reaching the 1m subscriber mark, toasting what chief executive Stuart Prebble described as a great British success story. "We've achieved it faster than Sky, faster than any cable company, faster than Vodafone, or Orange or Cellnet," he said.

Analysts were more sober, pointing out that ONdigital has a long way to go to overtake BSkyB, which has 4m installed digital homes, and faces competition from cable firms.

"ONdigital will be a modest but a not that impressive success," said Mathew Horsman, analyst at Investec Henderson Crosthwaite. "There is room for it but it's never going to be a 5m home pay-TV platform. They will be lucky to get 3.5m."

Initiatives to meet ONdigital's targets include new interactive football coverage and a planned campaign with ITV to persuade viewers to buy interactive digital TVs when they replace their sets.

fields.headline: Hollick set to ditch C5 stake
fields.standfirst: Channel 5 owners at war
fields.trailText:
9.45am update: Lord Hollick is close to dumping its Channel 5 stake after losing a court battle with key shareholder RTL, writes Dan Milmo.
Channel 5 owners at war
fields.body:
Lord Hollick's United Business Media is close to dumping its stake in Channel 5 after losing a courtroom clash with key shareholder RTL.

Industry sources said RTL has pushed United into a corner after it successfully appealed against an injunction brought by Lord Hollick's company over a £10m film deal.

"It clarifies the situation in RTL's favour. It means that if United want to block any expenditure in the future, they will have to think about it very clearly," said a senior industry source.

United has yet to rubberstamp a £180m increase in the Channel 5 budget, which is likely to bring matters to a head.

The source said that RTL, which owns 65% of Channel 5, took legal action because United gave "no particular" reason for blocking the acquisition of a film rights package from Warner Brothers in December last year.

"It is a strange situation. Clearly United do not want to be in it for the long term, but they want the best price for their holding. Even if both parties are not negotiating face-to-face, it is clearly a negotiation process of some kind," added the source.

United recently changed its name from United News & Media following the sale of its ITV interests to Granada Media and its controversial offloading of the Express newspaper group to OK! tycoon Richard Desmond.

Its 35% stake in Channel 5 is expected to fetch £350m, which would be invested in United's ongoing reinvention as a business information group.

The source added that the effect of the recent dispute on negotiations "remains uncertain".

fields.headline: Unintelligible in pursuit of the debatable
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Parliament
Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: The hunting bill had arrived. It was a glorious sunny day. Outside the House of Commons the horns of Countryside Alliance protesters pierced the eggshell sky. The chase was on!
fields.body:
The hunting bill had arrived. It was a glorious sunny day. Outside the House of Commons the horns of Countryside Alliance protesters pierced the eggshell sky. The chase was on!

Inside, MPs decided to start with a little hunting of their own. Andrew Robathan, a Tory, tackled Mr Blair for the 289th time over John Prescott's cheap union flat.

"Your unpleasant and nasty obsession reflects much worse on you than on the deputy prime minister, whose integrity I prefer any day of the week," Mr Blair replied. The rest of the hunt dipped their hands into Mr Robathan's still-warm blood.

Nicholas Soames somehow managed to mount his steed. Why had the prime minister misled us all by claiming on TV that he had voted against hunting in 1997 when he hadn't, and that the bill had been lost in the House of Lords, when it wasn't?

"As for what I said on Question Time," Mr Blair replied, "we will wait and see what happens in the other House!"

Gone to earth! The pack (I think of Mr Soames as a half a dozen hounds in one sack) spotted another quarry and swerved to attack the Speaker, Michael Martin. The prime minister had been less than honest, he said. The Speaker replied that no member of the House was less than honest, which, to be fair, caused as much merry chortling among MPs as it did in the galleries.

"No honourable member would mislead. Perhaps misinform," said Mr Martin firmly, if nonsensically. "That certainly is an original ruling," said Mr Soames, with the de haut en bas splendour of a master of foxhounds scoffing at a tenant farmer. This time it was the Speaker's twisted, bleeding corpse which will be on an animal rights shock poster.

Finally the debate. Tally-ho! The deputy speaker, Sir Alan Haselhurst, sounded the horn: "We must now deal with the question that clause 1 stand part, with which it will be convenient to debate whether clause 2 stand part, and clause 3 stand part ... new clause 1 with amendments (a) to (c) ... first four clauses and three new clauses..."

On and on he went. I have attended whole debates which were shorter than Sir Alan's briefing. Yet there are people who understand this gobbledygook. Luckily, none of them are members of parliament.

The debate thundered over the much-loved old ground. Had members seen a video made by Lord (Melvyn) Bragg about the problems a hunting ban would cause farmers in the Lake District? "Shoot Lord Bragg," yelled Tony Banks.

No one was safe. Mr Banks later admitted tipping a live rat into his neighbour's backyard. What had it to do with the debate? Nothing, but the House was in the grip of a collective bloodlust.

Labour's Ian Cawsey was asked if he would adopt a hound which will otherwise be put down when a ban comes in. Panic in his eyes! Then he got it: "A dog is for life, not just a debate!" he exclaimed. A masterful escape.

Mike Foster, who brought in the original bill, scorned the idea of self-regulation. Ann Widdecombe sat on the Tory frontbench nodding energetically at everything he said. John Bercow, Mini-Me to her Dr Evil, for once disagreed with her. Did Mr Foster also object to that other self-regulating body, the Advertising Standards Authority?

Yoiks! Whose blood could fail to be stirred by attending a meet of the historic Groucho Hunt, perched on their steeds outside an old coaching inn, their traditional black Armani suits glinting in the winter sunshine, their stirrup cups charged with margaritas. And they're off in a cloud of white dust! Sorry, clods of black earth.

Emotions runs high
Weary, defiant riders find the going hard
Talk about it

webTitle: Political emotions run high over foxes

fields.headline: Little room for compromise as emotions run high over foxes
fields.standfirst:
Government accused of wrong priorities

Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: Labour MPs were last night accused of losing all sense of priorities by voting for an outright ban on fox hunting.
fields.body:
Labour MPs were last night accused of losing all sense of priorities by voting for an outright ban on fox hunting.

The accusation from the shadow home affairs spokesman, David Lidington, came as MPs accused each other of using illegitimate and often intimidatory tactics to get their way.

Taking the key clauses of the fox hunting bill in comittee on the floor of the house, MPs were given three options; the status quo, a continuance of hunting but under a licence, and an outright ban. The Home Office minister, Mike O'Brien, a suporter of a ban, asserted the right of parliament to determine the issue, saying the future of fox hunting was a matter of controversy up and down the country. "The idea that this parliament should abstain from a decision is a nonsense," he said.

He rejected Tory claims that Scottish MPs had no right to vote on the bill when it would not be enforced in Scotland. The British parliament had decreed Scottish MPs had a constitutional right to debate the matter, he said.

For the Tories, Mr Lidington said his first preference was for self regulation. He described the middle way alternative as both "cumbersome and bureaucratic".

He also doubted that the compromise option would satisfy opponents of fox hunting. He said: "We are dealing with people who are prepared to use intimidation, threats and violence".

The proposed hunting authority, he said, was supposed to operate by consensus, but there was little likelihood it will be able to reach agreement on licences and a code of conduct. A ban was objectionable in principle and would not improve animal welfare. The alternative to hunting - shooting and snaring foxes - was not selective and had no close season.

He added the police powers required for the ban were draconian. Accusing the government of losing all sense of priority Mr Lidington concluded: "We shall be voting for the liberty of our constituents, the livelihoods of our constituents and for common sense."

The former Tory home secretary, Michael Howard, criticised ministers for bringing the issue forward at a time of rising violent crime. It was another example of a "trivial, frivolous and irresponsible" government.

"It beggars belief that any serious government, faced with an explosion of violent crime, would even contemplate distracting the police from tackling that problem, by imposing on them these large, uncertain and impractical burdens," Mr Howard said.

Labour's Michael Foster (Worcester), who tried unsuccessfully four years ago to ban fox hunting through a private member's bill, insisted this was the only "consistent and principled" option.

He urged MPs seeking a compromise to "get real. When a mammal is chased to the point of exhaustion... is that something we can really compromise on?"

The Tory former minister John Maples (Stratford on Avon), said hunting was not just a hobby or a pastime but a way of life. It was the most efficient way of controlling the fox population and the alternatives were very probably worse. He attacked the "largely misplaced and cuddly" image of foxes. They would gratutitiously kill lambs, chickens, piglets and ducks. "For that reason, they're judged to be vermin", he added.

Labour's Dale Campbell-Savours (Workington), while stating he would vote for a ban, urged MPs to consider what would happen if shooters were allowed to roam the dales as a means of culling foxes. "There's a problem which isn't being addressed in this debate and that's what's going to happen in the Lake District, in parts of Scotland, and I'm told in parts of Wales if there's a total ban ... shooters will be allowed into the Lake District and they will frighten a lot of people on the fells," he warned.

Lembit Opik, one of the founding members of the middle way group, said none of the options were perfect. But the compromise formula was the most workable opportunity for keeping landowners on side "and not criminalising those who believe they're doing nothing wrong".

The Lib Dem MP for Montgomeryshire said his group proposed strict rules for the granting of licences. Hunt premises could be inspected at any time, members of hunts would have to undergo training - and pay for it - and activities such as unlicensed hunts, would incur steep penalties. "We have a very powerful and robust set of proposals," he said.

fields.bodyText: THE GUARDIAN Tony Blair has rejected proposals for a televised election debate. P2 Better to go than sit around being a terrible bore: Auberon Waugh has died. P3 Ribena has lost its appeal against the Advertising Standards Authority. P11 The BBC is planning to overhaul its 10pm news amid fears of falling ratings. P14 The two shareholders in Channel 5, United Business Media and RTL, have become embroiled in a court battle over future investment in the broadcaster. P27 CNN is to cut 400 jobs nearly 10% of its workforce. P27 ONdigital is losing customers. P28 Letsbuyit.com is just one day from collapse. P28 THE DAILY TELEGRAPH Auberon Waugh dies at 61. P1 BBC drops Vanessa Feltz. P6 The return of ITV's News at Ten. P22 An interview with Elizabeth Clough, Channel 4's head of religious output. P23 DOTCOM TELEGRAPH Ad cuts hammer struggling websites. P1 RedHotAnt drops unmetered access. P1 Media firms rein in internet ambitions. P5 THE INDEPENDENT Blair won't join rivals in TV debate. P1 Judge rules Ribena tooth claim "misleading". P11 THE TIMES Tony Blair has rejected the opportunity for a live pre-election TV debate. P1 Auberon Waugh dies in his sleep. P7 The BBC has axed Vanessa Feltz. P13 The Cancer Research Campaign is to feature serial killers in its forthcoming anti-smoking campaign. P15 THE FINANCIAL TIMES Ministers are considering launching an inquiry into the BBC's internet arm. P4 The battle between RTL and United Business Media over Channel 5 has spilled into the courts. P24 ONdigital has lodged a new complaint against rival BSkyB with the Office of Fair Trading. P26 Radio First is expected to announce a deal with Derby County Football Club to launch a digital radio station. P26 THE WALL STREET JOURNAL Letsbuyit.com faces bankruptcy. P1 NBC is considering extending its half-hour hit comedy Friends by 10 minutes per episode to compete against CBS's hit programme Survivor. P25 DAILY MAIL The BBC has bid £400m for the rights to live FA Cup matches. P2 Amanda Holden's new raunchy look. P3 Dale Winton to pick up £90,000 for presenting show linked to Comic Relief. P16 Popular US shows to be screened months in advance on E4. P23 DAILY EXPRESS The new-look National Lottery is to start six months late, in February 2002. P17 THE SUN Sky Sports presenter Kirsty Gallacher has been voted football's No 1 babe. P3 THE MIRROR Taggart actor Raymond Robertson has died after collapsing on stage. P11 DAILY STAR Two singers have been axed from TV show Popstars for lying about their age. P7 Vanessa Feltz labelled Weakest Link presenter Anne Robinson "horrendous" after appearing on a celebrity edition of the show. P13 AND FINALLY... A British version of the raunchy US TV show Temptation Island is under threat because producers fear contestants here may not be up to it. The show features couples who are split up and sent to a Caribbean island to be introduced to beautiful "tempters". "Perhaps we could shoot it on Canvey Island," said Sky's James Baker. fields.headline: Mal content
fields.standfirst: The BBC's Mr Soap, Mal Young, is a leftwing Scouser with a chip on both shoulders, so what is he doing at the BBC, asks Maggie Hyde
fields.trailText: January 18: The BBC's Mr Soap, Mal Young, is a leftwing Scouser with a chip on both shoulders, so what is he doing at the BBC, asks Maggie Hyde.
fields.body:
Mal Young, head of continuing drama at the BBC, hits all the fours, 44, and celebrates three years in the job this month. As a revolutionary Aquarian (January 26 1957), with outsider Uranus strongly placed, it is surprising to find him at home in a bureaucracy, especially as "Uranus-ruled executives are as rare as albino pandas" (Linda Goodman). Young is a Scouser, reputed to have Leftist views and a chip on both shoulders, so what is he doing at the BBC, building a reputation as Mr Soap with Holby City, Doctors and now EastEnders four times a week?

Some Aquarians do have a conventional streak from Saturn's influence, but Mal Young's horoscope emphasises the bohemian end of this sign, big on idealism, brotherhood and friendship. It would be inconceivable for him not to have a guiding philosophy behind his work, especially since the inventive Aquarian Water Carrier is usually ahead of his time, carrying ideas from the future to illuminate the present. The community and the group spirit mean a lot: "the Aquarian is involved with people, humanity is his thing!" (Alan Oken).

But Aquarians sometimes lock on to unconventional ideas which they refuse to give up on principle, whatever the opposition or the evidence. Starting with his 1999 Royal Television Society Lecture, Young has come out fighting for the cause of soaps in the betterment of society. He reckons that they are educational and "can unify the nation", and that if Dickens was alive today he "would be writing popular drama for telly." Dickens, hot on social truths, was also an Aquarian (February 7 1812) and their horoscopes have some striking similarities, but Young's belief that soap counts as great drama with a social conscience has been met with derision. It does not fulfil the demand that television drama should give a voice to sections of society that do not already have one (Kamel Ahmed, Guardian 27/11/99), and even Young's own staff are said to have named his work 'Malodrama'.

The never-ending, teasing world of the soap only gives us an imagined intimacy that seldom runs parallel to our own lives. Most of us don't paralyse the local dope dealer by pushing him off a railway bridge (the current EastEnders plot), or bury troublesome people under the patio (Brookside). Here we hit a peculiarity common to Aquarians. Despite all their humanitarianism, an Aquarian is "the most lovable robot in the world, but there's a bolt missing. This tragic bolt is the capacity for intimacy" (Debbi Kempton-Smith). This is especially so in Mal Young's horoscope because he lacks water, the emotional element which engenders empathy and hooks the viewer, so despite all his clever Mr Soap ideas, he sometimes seriously loses the plot.

He could be in danger of doing so again this year. Boundless Neptune is conjunct the Sun on his birthday, dominating the year. Its self-deceptive downside could give him confusing and unattainable goals, although strong Capricorn influences - bonnet soaps and historical dramas? - bring him benefits through tried and tested formulas. But if his Aquarian social conscience is really serious, this year Neptune calls his bluff as a redeemer. Phil Mitchell handing out hot soup to the homeless? Somehow, we don't think so.

webTitle: Hunting supporters' fighting talk betrays sense of defeat

fields.headline: Weary, defiant riders find the going hard
fields.standfirst:
Fighting talk betrays sense of defeat

Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: Around 500 riders and thousands of unmounted supporters rallied to the call of the Countryside Alliance, staging a meet to coincide with mass hunts in Cornwall and Wales. Their presence was a gesture of defiance and the last ditch attempt to dissuade MPs from voting for a ban.
fields.body:
As the sound of a horn cut through the winter air, dogs streamed through the gates with riders close behind. The black and scarlet coats were a striking contrast to the icy fields, while the horses' breath froze into clouds. The scene could have been taken from a painting, the title: The Hunters' Last Stand.

Around 500 riders and thousands of unmounted supporters had rallied to the call of the Countryside Alliance, staging a meet to coincide with mass hunts in Cornwall and Wales. The narrow lanes around Higham, a village near Colchester in Essex, were lined with Land Rovers and horseboxes.

With so many riders and such hard going over the frozen ground, the Essex and Suffolk hunt had little hope of catching a fox. The real quarry yesterday was the government. Their presence was a gesture of defiance and the last ditch attempt to dissuade MPs from voting for a ban.

It was an impressive show, complete with celebrity supporter Robin Page, presenter of One Man and His Dog.

But despite the smooth organisation and fighting mood, you sensed that many of those present had already abandoned hope. The world they spoke of preserving yesterday has already gone; hunting is one of its last vestiges. The values they cherish -stability, tradition, conservatism in all its senses - have been eroded by the forces of modern life.

Age is a virtue here. Foxhunting is a 300-year-old sport, they tell you; there are hounds with pedigrees which can be traced back for 250 years. "We welcome you all to this little part of God's acre where we all have three things in common," Ian Finch, secretary of the Essex and Suffolk hunt, told the crowd. "We are all countrymen, we are all sportsmen and we all have absolute resolve to remain on the rural map forever and a day.

"We have a terrific inheritance from our forefathers which we have a duty to hand on to our children. If we do not pull our weight now we will be guilty of a serious crime."

Speaker after speaker pledged their willingness to break the law and go to jail if necessary. "Mr Blair cannot lock us all up," said David Trotman, a huntsman for 32 years. "We shall be here next year and the year after and the year after that."

But their own rhetoric gave them away. Once they believed they spoke for England. Now they cast themselves as members of an oppressed minority denied their basic liberties.

"When the House of Commons debates and votes on the hunting bill we will almost certainly see prejudice and bigotry prevail over tolerance and good governance," read a message of support from Sam Butler, chairman of the Countryside Alliance's campaign for hunting.

"The public see this assault as anti-democratic, unnecessary and unfair. These events illustrate quite clearly that you cannot take on a minority and expect to get away with it."

Despite the scorn poured on "political malcontents" and "the damn stupid yahoos of the League [Against Cruel Sports] and RSPCA", the hunters faced no opposition yesterday.

The hunt saboteurs had not bothered to turn up, hinting privately that there was no point because they had already won their battle.

For all the passion shown yesterday, the hunters seemed to agree. As the tired riders marked the end of an unsuccessful day in the saddle with a quiet pint at the nearby pub, the talk was of when, not if, hunting was banned, whatever the result of last night's vote.

webTitle: Carphone Warehouse posts 81% rise in sales

fields.headline: Carphone Warehouse posts 81% rise in sales
fields.trailText: 9.15am: The mobile phone retailer has reported a massive surge in handset sales but is remaining cautious, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Mobile phone retailer Carphone Warehouse has reported a massive surge in handset sales, but is remaining cautious about the year ahead.

Despite reporting that Christmas sales soared by 81% to £124m, the UK's largest mobile phone retailer said it was "confident" its full-year results will meet expectations.

One analyst described the retailer's caution as a "mystery", given that the notoriously fragile retail margins had not been affected by increased competition.

"People might be wondering if this is as good as it gets," said the analyst.

Carphone's shares fell 2.5% to 211.5p in early trading.

Today's sales figures come as no surprise, following record yuletide sales for UK mobile phone operators Vodafone, BT Cellnet and Orange.

However, it has been a mixed start to the year for the industry, as handset makers Motorola and Nokia reported dissappointing results.

Their sales figures increased speculation that the mobile phone market may be reaching saturation point, with over 405m handsets sold last year.

fields.bodyText: Mobile phone retailer Carphone Warehouse has reported a massive surge in handset sales, but is remaining cautious about the year ahead. Despite reporting that Christmas sales soared by 81% to £124m, the UK's largest mobile phone retailer said it was "confident" its full-year results will meet expectations. One analyst described the retailer's caution as a "mystery", given that the notoriously fragile retail margins had not been affected by increased competition. "People might be wondering if this is as good as it gets," said the analyst. Carphone's shares fell 2.5% to 211.5p in early trading. Today's sales figures come as no surprise, following record yuletide sales for UK mobile phone operators Vodafone, BT Cellnet and Orange.
