fields.headline: Travelocity.com unveils ad campaign
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The holiday site's TV, press and ambient ads are capitalising on Britons' tendency to overwork, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Online travel company travelocity.com is taking advantage of the collective post-Christmas gloom with a advertising campaign focusing on a stressed-out worker.

The ad opens with a young bloke being woken by the bleep of his alarm clock.

Taking a comic look at the daily grind, the office worker is shown squeezing onto the train on his way to work, sitting in his office and finally getting home and collapsing into bed in his suit - before the whole routine starts again.

The spot ends with a shot of an idyllic beach and the line, "You work too hard, you need a holiday."

Ad agency St Luke's came up with the idea after seeing the statistic that 60% of UK workers don't take their full yearly holiday entitlement.

"Britain is a nation in the grip of overwork - something we feel particularly strongly at this time of year," said account director Tom Lucas.

"We've focused on this social trend to create a campaign people will identify with,"he added.

The campaign, which breaks today, will appear in the morning papers and on sandwich wrappers - as well as on TV - in a bid to catch potential customers at their most susceptible.

webTitle: U>direct closes in on pay-per-view rights

fields.headline: U>direct closes in on pay-per-view rights
fields.trailText: U>direct has emerged as a front runner to win the pay-per-view rights to live Premiership football, write John Cassy and Dominic Fifield.
fields.body:
The broadcaster u>direct has emerged as a front runner to win the pay-per-view rights to live Premiership football at a meeting of Premier League chairmen today.

U>direct was heavily criticised for its transmission problems during England's World Cup qualifier with Finland in October but is understood to be the preferred choice of the League's advisers.

The cable giant NTL, which pulled out of an agreed £326m deal in October, and BSkyB, which won the rights for the main live package, have also submitted bids.

Several chairmen fear that the bids will not match the original agreement because of scepticism about whether supporters are prepared to pay to watch individual matches.

"U>direct screwed up on the England game and will have to pass a quality threshold before we accept any bid," said one chairman last night.

Middlesbrough hope to persuade Terry Venables to remain on Teesside next season, despite ITV insisting his role as chief pundit on its new-look football coverage will restrict him to the studio rather than the training pitch.

Since joining Boro as first-team coach last month, Venables has overseen an unbeaten seven-match run to hoist the club into the relative security of 15th place.

Boro's chairman Steve Gibson is keen to keep the 57-year-old next season, with a consultancy role the likeliest arrangement, allowing him to coach the side for three days a week and ease the manager Bryan Robson back in.

"I really do believe that if things keep going well and Terry's really got the bug for it and he's enjoying it, then he'd do everything he can to stay with the club," said Robson.

Venables has almost three years of his television deal to run and is seen as integral to the network's coverage next season. ITV is believed to be reluctant to release him from his contractual obligations.

Newcastle hope to bring the Russian international midfielder Igor Yanovski to St James' Park from Paris St-Germain in part exchange for their left-back Didier Domi.

webTitle: Students conform to sundry types, Mori survey says

fields.headline: Students conform to sundry types
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: To most of the population, they are simply identified as students. But it takes a keener eye to establish the differences between a home bird, academic green fiend, carefree, techno-careerist and wrong choice Charlie.
fields.body:
To most of the population, they are simply identified as students. But it takes a keener eye to establish the differences between a home bird, academic green fiend, carefree, techno-careerist and wrong choice Charlie.

The polling group Mori has produced classifications of students with similar views in a survey on university experience being published today.

The classifications will be used and updated in annual surveys for Unite, a student accommodation company, which commissioned the poll.

The survey showed that home birds are mostly female, over 26 and living at home.

Academic green fiends study arts and sciences at an old university and are in higher education mainly because they want to learn more about a chosen subject.

Wrong choice Charlies are at a new university that is not their first choice.

Techno-careerists are privately educated and make greatest use of IT and see money spent on university as a good investment.

Carefrees are younger, middle class and studying at an old university.

The survey revealed that before starting university, more than a fifth of male students could not cook, use a washing machine or iron. Most of those still did know how to do these tasks when the poll was being conducted.

Some 30% of students worked part time while at university and 19% during holidays. Students from state schools were far more likely to be worried about debt than those from private schools - 39% compared to 23%.

Just under half, 47%, lived in private rented accommodation, 21% lived in halls of residence, 21% with their parents and 11% in their own homes.

For 63%, the course had met their expectations and 70% felt university had prepared them well for work.

Some 59% had their own computer, 4% had a Wap (wireless application protocol) phone, and 2% had a motorcycle.

About 15% said that with hindsight they would have chosen a different course, and 14% a different university.

9% of students admitted to being homesick. Asked why they had gone to university, most said it was either "to gain qualifications", or "improve chances of getting a good job".

Just 21% said it was "to learn more about the subjects in which I am interested".

Mori polled 1,103 full time undergraduate and postgraduate students at 22 universities in October and November.

The classes of 2001:

Home Birds

 Most likely to be female, over 26 years, not AB social class and studying at a new university. Chose university as can live at home, and are happy with this arrangement

 Most likely to be working part time, less likely to owe money and have least help from parents/partner

 Course is most likely to have fallen short of expectations

 Least likely to have gained confidence while at university

Academic Green Fiends

 More likely to study arts and sciences at an old university

 More likely to have gone to university to learn more about chosen subject, to mix and to gain independence

 Most likely to be happy with quality of teaching and expectations of course

 Most likely to go travelling after university

 Most likely to be interested in world issues and least likely to be concerned with money

Wrong Choice Charlies

 Most likely to be at a new university, which was not their first choice

 More likely to have problems with course, people they live with and accommodation

 Most likely to be worried about debts

Techno-Careerists

 More likely to have private education

 More likely to be studying at an old university

 Went to university to gain qualifications for chosen career

 Most likely to measure success in financial terms, but hold more traditional values about religion and marriage

 Make greatest use of IT and the internet

Carefree

 More likely to be younger, middle class and studying at an old university

 University seen as a natural progression from school

 Social life and getting away from home are best aspects. Positive view of university

 Greater debts than other groups

 Most likely to receive help from parents

 Least interested in world issues and the environment

fields.headline: Channel 5 owners at war
fields.standfirst:
United and RTL go to law in dispute over increase in programming budget

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Channel 5 shareholders United Business Media and RTL have become embroiled in a court battle over investment in the broadcaster, write David Teather and Rob Griffin .
fields.body:
The two shareholders in Channel 5 - Lord Hollick's United Business Media and RTL - have become embroiled in a court battle over future investment in the broadcaster.

The two sides ended up in court before Christmas after attempts by United to prevent Channel 5 from buying rights to a package of Warner Brothers movies, the Guardian has learned. There is tension between the two sides over plans to increase Channel 5's annual programming budget from £120m to £180m this year.

The face-off in court followed a board meeting at which Channel 5 executives put forward plans for the Warner deal which was on top of the existing programming budget. The Warner Brothers library purchase gives Channel 5 access to more than 80 films and is worth £10m.

United refused to back the investment but Channel 5 chairman Remy Sautter argued that the objection was against the interests of the company. He carried the motion and told Channel 5 executives to proceed with the Warner deal.

In response United gained an injunction against Channel 5 which was subsequently overturned in an appeal by RTL.

Insiders describe the relationship between United and RTL as uneasy. The judgment against United is likely to increase pressure on Lord Hollick to sell his company's 35% stake in Channel 5.

Last year United spelled out its intention to quit the TV market and refocus on business-to-business media. The strategy was forced upon Lord Hollick after plans to merge United with Carlton Communications were blocked leaving him with little option but to sell his three ITV franchises to Granada Media.

Since then it has been a game between United and RTL to see which side would blink first. RTL, which owns the other 65% of Channel 5, has a pre-emption right over United's stake and has made it clear that it would be a willing buyer.

Analysts have valued the stake at around £350m and it is understood that both sides asked their banks before Christmas to work on valuations.

United aides say the company is happy to sit on the stake and is in no rush to sell. But the lack of commitment has begun to frustrate Channel 5 executives.

Last year RTL backed the proposed 50% increase in Channel 5's annual budget to around £180m for this year. It is understood, however, that United is reluctant to rubberstamp the increase and is approving any added investments on a case-by-case basis.

RTL, a pan-European media group formed by the merger of Pearson Television and CLT-Ufa last year, is keen to build Channel 5 into a more mainstream broadcaster. The increased investment is in part an attempt to move the channel away from its reliance on cheap imports and late-night soft porn. The hoped-for change was illustrated by the ousting last year of chief executive David Elstein, who was replaced by Dawn Airey.

The broadcaster, which launched 3 ago, is at a critical stage in its life. According to industry sources, Channel 5's peak-time audience share fell from 5.4% in the fourth quarter of 1999 to 5.2% last year. Its annual figures have also shown a sharp slowing in growth, averaging less than 6% for 2000.

RTL has predicted that audience share could reach 10% within a few years.

webTitle: G2: Derek Malcolm concludes his Century of Film

fields.headline: 'Cinema didn't actually start with Star Wars'
fields.standfirst:
Every Thursday for two years Derek Malcolm has been writing about his top 100 movies. He explains how he made his choice

Derek Malcolm's century of films
fields.trailText: Every Thursday for two years Derek Malcolm has been writing about his top 100 movies. He explains how he made his choice.
fields.body:
If I had £1 for every time someone has asked me, "what is your favourite film of all time?", I wouldn't be writing this. I would be relaxing somewhere hot, under my favourite palm tree. Film critics will probably have the same question fired at them by St Peter at the entrance to the Pearly Gates. Woe betide anyone who nominates Monty Python's Life of Brian.

The question is, of course, unanswerable, since the reply depends on mood, date, time and the questioner. It is no use telling an Alien-lover some obscure Japanese film he or she has never heard of (though that does stop the conversation in its tracks, which might be a good thing). But 100 favourites? Now that is a different matter.

But I am not so sure, now, that I have completed my list. I have come to the conclusion that I need another 100. Don't worry, I won't do it. But my guilt at leaving particular film-makers and films out gets stronger by the day. I asked one director's agent whether he would like to come to the launch of my book, based on the Guardian 100. "Is one of his films included?" came the wary answer. "Er - no," I replied. I don't think the film-maker even got the message. That is embarrassing, particularly as I had set myself only two rules, designed to include as many directors as possible.

The first rule was to restrict my choices to one film by each director. I feared that otherwise I would slap half a dozen John Ford or Luis Buñuel movies on to the list, to the exclusion of even more film-makers than are already missed out. So I am constantly apologising, particularly to British directors. John Boorman, Mike Leigh, Terence Davies - you were nearly in, and probably should have been for, respectively, Point Blank, Naked, and Distant Voices, Still Lives. Mea culpa thrice over.

The second rule was to consider the whole history of the cinema and as many countries as possible - because so much has been largely forgotten nowadays, at least in this country, where film is not generally regarded as an art with much of a history at all. I wanted to remind people, especially the multiplex generation, who have more than doubled cinema attendances in Britain over the past 20 years, that the cinema didn't actually start with Star Wars (though it did help to start the revival.)

If you don't think that is necessary, consider the letter that the Guardian received from a reader who complained that I had reached 80 films and he still hadn't heard of a single one of them. He even went so far as to say that he would bet a friend that the same would apply by the time the list was completed. What? Never heard of Hitchcock's Vertigo, Scorsese's Raging Bull, Coppola's Apocalypse Now or Carol Reed's The Third Man?

And consider a recent talk I gave to 30 teenage media students. "Why did you choose so many old films?", I was asked at question time. "Because there were rather more great directors then than there are now, like John Ford and Orson Welles. Hands up who has heard of either?" No hand went up for Ford, and only one for Welles. Their teacher then hurriedly borrowed the book.

There are, I'll admit, some names among the 100 films that are obscure even to those who are familiar with most of the great names. But it is a critic's privilege to remember and remind. I think those films - like Santiago Alvarez's amazing shorts, shot when the Cuban revolution was at its height, or the Filipino director Lino Brocka's Manila: In The Claws of Darkness, about a country boy immersed within the corruption of the big city - shouldn't be forgotten, because they each had something important to say, and said it amazingly well.

Another obscure work, Karoly Makk's Love, made in Hungary in 1971 and about a political prisoner returning home to his wife and mother after years of incarceration, was recently rescued from the legion of the lost at a major European festival, and hailed by everyone there as a masterpiece. That was after I had included it in the Guardian list, and I felt doubly justified.

The point is that so much of the cinema's past has been lost or forgotten, and since the cinema has only been going for 100 years or so, it shouldn't have been. No other art form is so sketchily remembered.

Ask Martin Scorsese, America's most important director, and he will tell you the same. He has been running campaigns to save this heritage for over 20 years, and has had some notable successes. But deep in the vaults of Hollywood, and elsewhere around the world, movies of considerable importance still lie mouldering in untended graves. Thanks to Scorsese and others - such as the cash-strapped British Film Archive - many of them have been saved. The coming of DVD, which is cheap for transfers, should help considerably too.

And if the letter writer who had heard of none of my choices would even care to know, I recently met a distinguished European critic who also happened to be writing a 100 best list for his newspaper. To my astonishment, we had agreed on 68 of the choices - and he, too, hadn't got many of his 100 from the last 15 years or so.

The age of my choices, I must agree, may be a valid criticism of my list. But I can only say that one needs a bit of time to go by before deciding whether a more or less contemporary film or film-maker can be measured among the greats. Things look different from afar, and you suddenly realise how good a movie is that was totally disregarded in its time, such as Stroheim's slaughtered Greed, cut down to a fifth of its original length, or Tod Browning's famous horror show, Freaks. You also discover that films you thought were wonderful don't stand up to a second or third viewing, and I can't tell you how many contemporary films fit that bill.

This is not a golden age in which great film-makers can be nurtured and can thrive. It is now too expensive to make movies, and thus there is too much dependence on the big corporations, which approve most projects and try to make them pay. In America, your average "big" film costs around $60m. It costs the same amount to put it out and hype it up. That's well over $100m to be made before you can even think of breaking even. And how many movies achieve that without making a few compromises?

Scorsese, for instance, has had only two outright successes at the box office: Taxi Driver and Goodfellas. The rest, like Raging Bull, one of my 100, barely make their money back. Or only do so after years, through video, television and cinema revivals. Hollywood, for so long the exemplar of great popular entertainment, now has to cater largely for the under-25s, who make up around 70% of its audiences.

It does so with enormous skill, and sometimes widens the age of that audience considerably. But the situation usually doesn't make for great films - just movies which hopefully catch the transient mood of the times. "Don't call me a Hollywood director," Scorsese once said. "I'm an in-spite-of-Hollywood director." A lot of other film-makers would say Amen to that.

And where are the European masters now? Most have gone to those Pearly Gates, and haven't been replaced. When I started out as Guardian film critic, there was Bergman, Buñuel, Rossellini, Visconti, Fellini, Antonioni, Truffaut, Bresson, Godard, Tarkovsky and all, working at the height of their powers. At every London film festival it was possible to see two or three films which have now become classics. Now you are relieved to see a few goodish films.

This isn't the view of a cynical old codger, but an unfortunate fact.

We can all make mistakes, and 20 years hence will probably accord the films of some now comparatively unregarded directors a status we could not now imagine.

But my list is not the 100 best. It is 100 of the best, which is a slightly different thing - personal favourites, which I hope I have good reasons to celebrate. I couldn't go, for instance, without Laurel and Hardy, at whom some perfectly reasonable people scarcely smile, let alone laugh.

But I can't actually say any of their films, including Sons of the Desert, my choice, should be accorded the title of masterpiece - whatever that means - with the exception of The Music Box, a short film in which they attempt to deliver a piano to a customer up a steep stone stairway. That got them their only Oscar, and certainly is a masterpiece.

Some have suggested that mine is an anti-American, or rather anti-Hollywood, list. And I suppose it could be thought so, were it not for the fact that the principal task in my own mind was to try to persuade film-goers who don't already know that there really is such a thing as world cinema, and that great films have come from all parts, not just America. But having said all that, there are 31 American films in the 100 - a larger number than from any other country, although not all the Hollywood choices were actually directed by Americans.

There is considerable truth in the theory, once put to me by the American director and writer, Paul Schrader, that Hollywood is world cinema, since so many talents from all over the world have made films there. It is certainly by far the greatest source of popular entertainment in the film business.

But there are others things than Hollywood movies, and many of the best from elsewhere are only labelled "arthouse fare" here because they aren't in the English language. It would be a brave exhibitor, for instance, who placed Les Enfants Du Paradis in a multiplex now, or even in a commercial British cinema at the time it was made. But though directed and written by great artists (Marcel Carné and Jacques Prévert), it was to ordinary people in France what Gone With The Wind was to those in America - a popular film that could be seen again and again, along with the buffs.

But then the division between art and commerce in the cinema has always been a bugbear of mine. It stops many people seeing the films that are made by great directors, who just happen to work in a foreign language, and it also stops others from even trying to appreciate popular culture.

All I can do is to repeat the old, old adage: Let all the flowers in the garden bloom. A good many of them, I think, are in my 100 favourites.

It is no use telling an Alien-lover some obscure Japanese film he or she has never heard of (though that does stop the conversation in its tracks, which might be a good thing). But 100 favourites? Now that is a different matter. But I am not so sure, now, that I have completed my list. I have come to the conclusion that I need another 100. Don't worry, I won't do it. But my guilt at leaving particular film-makers and films out gets stronger by the day. I asked one director's agent whether he would like to come to the launch of my book, based on the Guardian 100. "Is one of his films included?" came the wary answer. "Er - no," I replied. I don't think the film-maker even got the message. That is embarrassing, particularly as I had set myself only two rules, designed to include as many directors as possible. The first rule was to restrict my choices to one film by each director. I feared that otherwise I would slap half a dozen John Ford or Luis Buñuel movies on to the list, to the exclusion of even more film-makers than are already missed out. So I am constantly apologising, particularly to British directors. John Boorman, Mike Leigh, Terence Davies - you were nearly in, and probably should have been for, respectively, Point Blank, Naked, and Distant Voices, Still Lives. Mea culpa thrice over. The second rule was to consider the whole history of the cinema and as many countries as possible - because so much has been largely forgotten nowadays, at least in this country, where film is not generally regarded as an art with much of a history at all. I wanted to remind people, especially the multiplex generation, who have more than doubled cinema attendances in Britain over the past 20 years, that the cinema didn't actually start with Star Wars (though it did help to start the revival.) If you don't think that is necessary, consider the letter that the Guardian received from a reader who complained that I had reached 80 films and he still hadn't heard of a single one of them. He even went so far as to say that he would bet a friend that the same would apply by the time the list was completed. What? Never heard of Hitchcock's Vertigo, Scorsese's Raging Bull, Coppola's Apocalypse Now or Carol Reed's The Third Man? And consider a recent talk I gave to 30 teenage media students. "Why did you choose so many old films?", I was asked at question time. "Because there were rather more great directors then than there are now, like John Ford and Orson Welles. Hands up who has heard of either?" No hand went up for Ford, and only one for Welles. Their teacher then hurriedly borrowed the book. There are, I'll admit, some names among the 100 films that are obscure even to those who are familiar with most of the great names. But it is a critic's privilege to remember and remind. I think those films - like Santiago Alvarez's amazing shorts, shot when the Cuban revolution was at its height, or the Filipino director Lino Brocka's Manila: In The Claws of Darkness, about a country boy immersed within the corruption of the big city - shouldn't be forgotten, because they each had something important to say, and said it amazingly well. Another obscure work, Karoly Makk's Love, made in Hungary in 1971 and about a political prisoner returning home to his wife and mother after years of incarceration, was recently rescued from the legion of the lost at a major European festival, and hailed by everyone there as a masterpiece. That was after I had included it in the Guardian list, and I felt doubly justified. The point is that so much of the cinema's past has been lost or forgotten, and since the cinema has only been going for 100 years or so, it shouldn't have been. No other art form is so sketchily remembered. Ask Martin Scorsese, America's most important director, and he will tell you the same. He has been running campaigns to save this heritage for over 20 years, and has had some notable successes. But deep in the vaults of Hollywood, and elsewhere around the world, movies of considerable importance still lie mouldering in untended graves. Thanks to Scorsese and others - such as the cash-strapped British Film Archive - many of them have been saved. The coming of DVD, which is cheap for transfers, should help considerably too. And if the letter writer who had heard of none of my choices would even care to know, I recently met a distinguished European critic who also happened to be writing a 100 best list for his newspaper. To my astonishment, we had agreed on 68 of the choices - and he, too, hadn't got many of his 100 from the last 15 years or so. The age of my choices, I must agree, may be a valid criticism of my list. But I can only say that one needs a bit of time to go by before deciding whether a more or less contemporary film or film-maker can be measured among the greats. Things look different from afar, and you suddenly realise how good a movie is that was totally disregarded in its time, such as Stroheim's slaughtered Greed, cut down to a fifth of its original length, or Tod Browning's famous horror show, Freaks. You also discover that films you thought were wonderful don't stand up to a second or third viewing, and I can't tell you how many contemporary films fit that bill. This is not a golden age in which great film-makers can be nurtured and can thrive. It is now too expensive to make movies, and thus there is too much dependence on the big corporations, which approve most projects and try to make them pay. In America, your average "big" film costs around $60m. It costs the same amount to put it out and hype it up. That's well over $100m to be made before you can even think of breaking even. And how many movies achieve that without making a few compromises? Scorsese, for instance, has had only two outright successes at the box office: Taxi Driver and Goodfellas. The rest, like Raging Bull, one of my 100, barely make their money back. Or only do so after years, through video, television and cinema revivals. Hollywood, for so long the exemplar of great popular entertainment, now has to cater largely for the under-25s, who make up around 70% of its audiences. It does so with enormous skill, and sometimes widens the age of that audience considerably. But the situation usually doesn't make for great films - just movies which hopefully catch the transient mood of the times. "Don't call me a Hollywood director," Scorsese once said. "I'm an in-spite-of-Hollywood director." A lot of other film-makers would say Amen to that. And where are the European masters now? Most have gone to those Pearly Gates, and haven't been replaced. When I started out as Guardian film critic, there was Bergman, Buñuel, Rossellini, Visconti, Fellini, Antonioni, Truffaut, Bresson, Godard, Tarkovsky and all, working at the height of their powers. At every London film festival it was possible to see two or three films which have now become classics. Now you are relieved to see a few goodish films. This isn't the view of a cynical old codger, but an unfortunate fact. We can all make mistakes, and 20 years hence will probably accord the films of some now comparatively unregarded directors a status we could not now imagine. But my list is not the 100 best. It is 100 of the best, which is a slightly different thing - personal favourites, which I hope I have good reasons to celebrate. I couldn't go, for instance, without Laurel and Hardy, at whom some perfectly reasonable people scarcely smile, let alone laugh. But I can't actually say any of their films, including Sons of the Desert, my choice, should be accorded the title of masterpiece - whatever that means - with the exception of The Music Box, a short film in which they attempt to deliver a piano to a customer up a steep stone stairway. That got them their only Oscar, and certainly is a masterpiece. Some have suggested that mine is an anti-American, or rather anti-Hollywood, list. And I suppose it could be thought so, were it not for the fact that the principal task in my own mind was to try to persuade film-goers who don't already know that there really is such a thing as world cinema, and that great films have come from all parts, not just America. But having said all that, there are 31 American films in the 100 - a larger number than from any other country, although not all the Hollywood choices were actually directed by Americans. There is considerable truth in the theory, once put to me by the American director and writer, Paul Schrader, that Hollywood is world cinema, since so many talents from all over the world have made films there. It is certainly by far the greatest source of popular entertainment in the film business. But there are others things than Hollywood movies, and many of the best from elsewhere are only labelled "arthouse fare" here because they aren't in the English language. It would be a brave exhibitor, for instance, who placed Les Enfants Du Paradis in a multiplex now, or even in a commercial British cinema at the time it was made. But though directed and written by great artists (Marcel Carné and Jacques Prévert), it was to ordinary people in France what Gone With The Wind was to those in America - a popular film that could be seen again and again, along with the buffs. But then the division between art and commerce in the cinema has always been a bugbear of mine. It stops many people seeing the films that are made by great directors, who just happen to work in a foreign language, and it also stops others from even trying to appreciate popular culture. All I can do is to repeat the old, old adage: Let all the flowers in the garden bloom. A good many of them, I think, are in my 100 favourites.

webTitle: Appleton to host BBC3 travel show

fields.headline: All Saints star to host BBC3 travel show
fields.trailText: 8.30am: All Saints' Nicole Appleton has been signed by BBC Choice to spearhead its transformation into BBC3, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
All Saints star Nicole Appleton has been signed up by BBC Choice to spearhead the transformation of the channel into BBC3.

She and TV presenter Kate Thornton will star in a new travel series set in Canada.

The show has been billed as a cross between road movies Thelma and Louise and Priscilla, Queen of the Desert.

Appleton, who is poised to leave the band with her sister Natalie, made the approach to the BBC personally.

The deal with such a big star comes at a crucial period for BBC Choice, which from tonight will face direct competion from Channel 4's entertainment channel E4.

Channel 4's new station features a series of heavy-hitting stars including Ali G, cult magician David Blain and all of Warner Brothers's hit series including ER, Friends and Ally McBeal.

The travel series will be one of the linchpins of the first winter schedule for BBC3, which is expected to start at the end of this year or early 2002.

In the series, Appleton and Thornton will travel from Toronto to Vancouver in silver Winnebagos.

She has promised that her boyfriend, Oasis badboy Liam Gallagher, will also appear in the series, which will be filmed in September.

Samantha Janus and Donna Air will also feature in the £1m series.

webTitle: Granada to cash in on Popstars success

fields.headline: Granada to cash in on Popstars success
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Granada TV will take a slice of the profits generated by the show's manufactured band, reports Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
Granada TV stands to make a windfall from its Popstars series if the band it creates turns out to be the next big thing.

Under its contract with Polydor and the band, Granada Media will take a slice of the profits generated during the lifespan of the band.

But Nigel Lythgoe, LWT head of entertainment, who has become the star of the new ITV series, will not be be taking a cut - even though he is directly responsible for the discovering the talent.

A spokesman for Granada said: "Most of the research has been paid for by Granada - the auditioning has cost hundreds of thousands of pounds - so Granada will have a stake in the band.

"But the band is on a very good deal. Many artists get completely stitched up and turn out to be virtual employees of record companies. This will not be the case with Popstars.

"If they are the new Spice Girls, we will do very nicely. Equally, if they turn out to be the new 911, the cost will go down as part of the budget," he added.

Granada and Polydor are confident the band they will form at the end of the 13-week series will be a massive success.

They have already signed a three-album deal and a single will be released to coincide with the final episode of the series.

However, if the band is successful, Granada will have to tread carefully when it comes to promotion.

There will be follow-up documentaries but ITV will have to ensure these do not give the band unwarranted plugs.

"There are very strict rules regarding undue prominence," said the Granada spokesman.

"If, for example, the first single is a huge hit but the second is a flop and the band suddenly turns up in an ITV show, questions will be asked.

"We have been through all of this with the Independent Television Commission and what we can and cannot do is clear at every level," he added.

fields.headline: Media lose net value
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Amid yesterday's stock market euphoria, there was one sector that failed to join in the fun - media. Dealers traced the problems to a research note from analysts at Dutch investment bank ABN Amro.
fields.body:
Amid yesterday's stock market euphoria, there was one sector that failed to join in the fun - media. Dealers traced the problems to a research note from analysts at Dutch investment bank ABN Amro.

Warning of tough times ahead for the sector in 2001, ABN lowered its recommended investment weighting for the media to "underweight " (Europe-wide) and downgraded 22 stocks.

ABN said the recent underperformance of the sector was related to the evaporation of the convergence and internet value applied to media companies at the height of the dot.com boom rather than a wholesale de-rating of their underlying businesses.

With the outlook for advertising deteriorating and earnings downgrades starting to roll in, the note reckons the share prices of media groups face a fundamental de-rating.

fields.headline: Utilities become power play
fields.trailText: After seeing three sessions of hard-won gains almost wiped out on Tuesday, the London market managed to rally yesterday - if only in relief.
fields.body:
After seeing three sessions of hard-won gains almost wiped out on Tuesday, the London market managed to rally yesterday - if only in relief.

To be precise, relief that fourth-quarter figures from Intel had sneaked past (lowered) expectations and that the US consumer price index was weaker than expected, raising hopes that the Federal Reserve will cut rates again at the end of the month.

The ever-volatile FTSE 100 index ended ahead 114.1 points at 6,197.4 and the Techmark 100 up 108.63 to 2,655.87.

In fact, for technology stocks it looked like the return of dot.com boom, with half a dozen posting double-digit percentage gains after the Nasdaq stormed higher in reaction to the CPI data. Among the best were IQE, up 40p to 255p, Bookham Technology, 192p higher at £12.70, Computacenter, 62.5p better at 452.5p and Baltimore, up 32p at 350p, among the best.

However, it was rising telecom and banking issues that led the market higher. BT, 15p better at 702p, and Vodafone, up 7.5p to 230.5p, moved in line with their counterparts on Wall Street, while Barclays and Royal Bank of Scotland responded to recommendations from Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein. Shares in the former finished 55p higher at £22 and the latter 77p better at £17.02.

Nonetheless, most of the day's action was in the utility sector. Shares in Powergen shot up 92p to 700p after it confirmed takeover talks with German group E.ON, bringing the rest of the sector with it as punters tried to find the next takeover target. The shrewd money settled on International Power, up 22p to 232p, and Innogy, 16.5p higher at 201.5p.

In a market so strong, the performance of British Airways, down 20p to 425p, raised a few eyebrows. Analysts tried to pass off the fall as nothing more than profit-taking. After all, BA shares reached an 18-month high earlier this week. But traders were not convinced, citing dark talk that BA is planning a rights issue.

Elsewhere on the downside, speciality chemicals group ICI lost 3p to 500.5p unsettled by a downgrade from Schroder Salomon Smith Barney. Reducing its rating to "underperform" (City speak for sell), Schroder said it was concerned about the impact a slowdown in the US will have on ICI's profits.

The broker also reminded investors that ICI still faces litigation in the US. Rhode Island is trying to sue 10 companies, including two ICI subsidiaries, for around $1bn to cover the medical costs of people suffering from lead poisoning. A judgment on whether the suit should proceed is expected soon.

Consumer goods group Unilever slipped 14.5p to 503p amid chatter that CSFB was trying to place a large block of Unilever shares at a discount to Tuesday's closing price.

On a brighter note, buyers were queuing for Airtours, 10p higher at 242p, on talk that a bid of around 350p is on the way. However, many rejected the tale, pointing out that there was a large institution in the market yesterday trying to pick up 10m Airtours shares.

Those of a more sceptical disposition were more interested in whispers that the property company British Land, unchanged at 473p, is considering going private in much the same way that rival MEPC did last year. Sector watchers reckon British Land boss John Ritblat would have to offer at 600p to have any chance of success.

Elsewhere, it was not exactly a new tale but Glynwed, maker of Aga kitchenware, rose 9.5p to 221p on talk of a 265p bid from Swiss group Georg Fischer.

At the small cap end of the market, Turbo Genset slipped 287.5p to £21 after HSBC Securities started coverage with an outright "sell" recommendation. Although a fan of its technology, HSBC thinks the shares are overvalued.

webTitle: Arts: Polly Toynbee on painter Sarah Raphael

fields.headline: Melancholy masterpiece
fields.standfirst: Sarah Raphael, who died this week, was commissioned by the National Portrait Gallery to paint a group of women from the Guardian. One of them, Polly Toynbee, recalls their delight in the artist's company during a series of intense sittings
fields.trailText: How sad to learn of the death of the very talented painter Sarah Raphael, says Polly Toynbee. We came to know her when she was commissioned by the National Portrait Gallery to paint a group of us who worked on the Guardian women's page in the 1970s and 80s.
fields.body:
How sad to learn of the death of the very talented painter Sarah Raphael. We came to know her when she was commissioned by the National Portrait Gallery to paint a group of us who worked on the Guardian women's page in the 1970s and 80s. It was an extraordinary and unexpected commission - both for her and for us, though she had already won distinguished prizes by then.

We were, of course, astonished and flattered by the idea, which came about when Claire Tomalin, the feminist writer and biographer, joined the NPG board. Pacing the galleries, Claire had noted wryly how many contemporary men and how few women hung on its walls, and she set about commissioning more women.

She proposed that a portrait of Guardian women should be painted by a leading young woman artist. So there it now hangs. On the right hand side sits Mary Stott, the founder of the first and only serious and feminist women's page in the days when "women" used to mean woollies, jellies and sillies. Now 93, all her gleaming marbles as bright as ever, she is still the resolutely unvain, unvarnished editor who was sometimes mistaken for a bag lady.

Liz Forgan, whose legs we always thought were unjustly prominent in the picture, was women's editor from 1978 to 1981 and our convert: she arrived regarding the job as a temporary irritation on the way to more serious things, but underwent a Damascene conversion to feminist ideas and stayed to become one of the best editors ever.

Posy Simmonds, on the far left, is the cartoonist who made the page compulsive reading with her long-running strip: her recent Emma Bovary is every bit as clever and perceptive. I am the one leaning over the back of the sofa where Jill Tweedie - the doyenne - was slowly dying of motor neurone disease. Jill was the centre of the painting, the centre of our thoughts then and the fount of energy, wit and wisdom that made the pages remarkable.

It was not going to be easy for Sarah to ease herself into our group. The sittings were intense; Jill was weak, but full of passion, indignation and jokes. Sarah sat on the floor cross-legged in one corner and was a delightful extra presence, warm and sympathetic, as we reminisced, drank much wine and enjoyed the last chance to spend long hours with Jill.

Sarah fell quickly under Jill's magnetic influence and loved the commission, spending far longer on the sittings than she had planned. For those months we came to know her well too, through those long conversations that went on into the dusk in Jill's sitting room.

The painting hanging in the gallery has always been imbued with the melancholy of Jill's death. Now there will be the added pall of sadness that not only Jill but Sarah too is dead, shocking since she was the youngest of us by far, with such a brilliant career still ahead of her.

webTitle: Employment falls for the first time in seven years

fields.headline: Employment falls for the first time in seven years
fields.trailText: Britain's booming jobs market has stalled, according to official figures published yesterday. The number of people in work fell between September and November for the first time in more than seven years.
fields.body:
Britain's booming jobs market has stalled, according to official figures published yesterday. The number of people in work fell between September and November for the first time in more than seven years while the government's preferred measure of unemployment rose for the second consecutive quarter.

However, with the number of vacancies still the highest for 40 years, it was unclear whether the jobs market was suffering from slowing demand for labour or a shortage of skilled workers.

Michael Saunders, an economist at Schroder Salomon SmithBarney, said a pick up in average earnings in November to 4.4% suggested the market could be constrained by a lack of qualified staff.

But Jonathan Loynes, of Capital Economics, said that with much of the increase concentrated in manufacturing, the earnings figures could easily go into reverse as the sector bore the brunt of an expected slowdown in global growth.

With last year's millennium-related bonus payments falling out of the index over the next few months, Mr Loynes said: "Don't be surprised to see earnings growth fall well below 4% by February."

The figures, published by the office for national statistics, showed that the number of people out of work and claiming benefit fell by 2,600 in December to a total of 1,044,300, reducing the average decline over the last three months to just 700. The fall left the claimant count rate at 3.6% of the workforce for the fifth month in a row.

The more comprehensive International Labour Organisation unemployment level, which includes people looking for work but not necessarily on benefits, increased by 11,000 in the latest quarter to 1.58m but the jobless rate remained 5.3%.

Employment fell 25,000 in the quarter to 27.9m, the first fall in the level since spring 1993 when the economy was only just shaking off the effects of the last recession. It reduced the employment rate to 74.5% from 74.7%. Job losses were concentrated in the manufacturing sector, which has shed 100,000 workers over the past year.

An ONS official said the job market was levelling off rather than at a turning point .

webTitle: BP faces environmental grilling from shareholders

fields.headline: BP faces green test
fields.trailText: BP faces four critical shareholder resolutions on environmental and social issues at its annual meeting in April.
fields.body:
BP faces four critical shareholder resolutions on environmental and social issues at its annual meeting in April.

The resolutions question a $580m (£415m) investment in PetroChina, call for a transition strategy beyond oil to renewable energy and demand a full risk assessment of drilling in the Arctic wildlife refuge in Alaska.

They aim to build on last year's call for an end to Arctic exploration, which won 13% of shareholder votes. They will also capitalise on the group's new strategy, Beyond Petroleum, warning shareholders of the risk to BP's reputation if this is seen as a shallow marketing stunt.

Stephanie Tunmore of Greenpeace UK said yesterday that it is in shareholders' interests for the new strategy to be accelerated. "The investment strategy for renewables is nowhere near adequate. For the rebranding to work they need to tell us how and tell us when, otherwise we are looking at weasel words."

She predicted that conventional fund managers would be more receptive to this year's resolution because of last July's legal change which requires pension funds to address ethical issues.

Supporting shareholders are being organised so that the resolutions can be filed by the end of the month. They include several US social investment funds, together with British pressure groups including Greenpeace, WWF and the Free Tibet campaign.

The US funds have been instrumental in meeting the British requirement for resolutions to be backed by £10,000 worth of shares across 100 investors. They include Trillium Asset Management, whose senior analyst Simon Billenness proposed last year's resolution.

He said BP was an environmental leader in the oil industry but it was in investors' interests to seek improvements. BP declined to comment.

fields.headline: Company that fell from grace
fields.trailText: Ten years ago investors rushed to buy shares in Huntingdon Life Sciences, which once traded at more than 300p. Now, it is a pariah to big institutional investors. Earlier this week the shares were worth 1p.
fields.body:
Ten years ago investors rushed to buy shares in Huntingdon Life Sciences, which once traded at more than 300p. Now, it is a pariah to big institutional investors. Earlier this week the shares were worth 1p.

The fall from grace began in 1997 when abuse of animals at the laboratories was uncovered. Despite the introduction of new management and the shake-up in testing procedures, the company never recovered the confidence of investors.

The Labour party's pension fund was one of the first to pull out when it told investment firm Phillips & Drew to sell its shares in the company. Other big investors followed and Huntingdon's brokers, representing the company in the City, pulled out.

Now the Royal Bank of Scotland has to decide whether to continue throwing a lifeline to the laboratory which has not made a profit under the new management. The publicity has reawakened interest in the shares, which have hit 4p in recent days.

Related stories

fields.headline: CGNU snubs Rover workers
fields.trailText: Growing confidence among MG Rover workers was undermined yesterday after the country's largest insurance company cast doubts on the group's future.
fields.body:
Growing confidence among MG Rover workers was undermined yesterday after the country's largest insurance company cast doubts on the group's future.

CGNU, the result of last year's £19bn merger between CGU and Norwich Union, is refusing mortgage insurance for workers at the group's Longbridge plant.

A spokesman said: "The future of MG Rover has not been absolutely determined. From our point of view there is very much an issue around job security. It is the situation at the moment where our underwriter's view is that there is sufficient uncertainty to keep this [ban] in force."

John Towers, the former Rover chief executive who now chairs MG Rover, said: "It's ironic. Ford is closing its plant at Dagenham, Vauxhall wants to close Luton and there is even a question mark over Nissan at Sunderland, yet Longbridge is prospering.

"It indicates that Norwich Union haven't really done their homework."

This month MG Rover said it had exceeded last year's sales target of 200,000 vehicles and chief executive, Kevin Howe, said it was on course for a return to profit next year. The workforce has been issued with free shares in the company.

Tracey O'Meara raised the mortgage insurance issue after being refused a quote by CGNU's Norwich Union Direct because her husband worked for MG Rover.

webTitle: German rival opens bid talks with Powergen

fields.headline: German rival opens bid talks with Powergen
fields.trailText: Powergen, the energy group, could be the latest British utility to fall into foreign hands after confirming yesterday that it is in talks with German rival E.ON.
fields.body:
Powergen, the energy group, could be the latest British utility to fall into foreign hands after confirming yesterday that it is in talks with German rival E.ON.

Amid confusion about the outcome of the talks, both companies insisted that it was too early to consider an immediate bid. Powergen has also been approached by other groups. That uncertainty strengthened when it emerged that Ed Wallis, Powergen's chairman and chief executive and architect of its expansion strategy, only returns to his desk today after a four-week holiday in the Virgin Islands.

As shares in the group surged 95p to close at 703p, analysts suggested that any successful bid would have to be pitched at 750p-800p - valuing Powergen at up to £5.2bn or £10.4bn including debt. Another German utility, RWE, last year paid £6bn, a pre mium of 43%, for Thames Water.

Andrew Stone at BNP Parisbas said an 800p offer would represent a 32% premium over yesterday's opening price of 608p but cautioned that the deal could fall through because Powergen is set on US expansion and E.ON on European growth over the next five years.

"In addition, Powergen has an aggressive management style and if there is a clash of cultures we doubt if E.ON would go hostile," he said in a note which suggested that either Scottish and Southern Electric or United Utilities could enter the fray.

Under Mr Wallis's stewardship the group, originally an electricity generator, has moved into energy supply and distribution and paid $5.4bn (£3.8bn) for Kentucky-based LG&E, a US utility.

That deal has been partly financed by disposals of British power stations which are due to net more than £1bn but has, analysts at Schroder Salomon Smith Barney say, "severely stretched" Powergen's finances. E.ON, formed from the merger of Veba and Viag, is cash-rich and has said it would raise €7.25bn (£4.4bn) from the enforced sale of its 45% stake in Viag Interkom, the mobile phones operator, to partner BT.

Innogy, the demerged British arm of what was National Power, said it would sell its Fawley oil-fired power station near Southampton to Independent Power UK for over £42m - booking a net £48m profit on disposal.

webTitle: Gillian Sandford on why Serbs are disillusioned

fields.headline: Almost the same old Serbia
fields.standfirst:
The October uprising was something to celebrate, but war criminals are still unpunished

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The October uprising was something to celebrate, but war criminals are still unpunished.
fields.body:
Yugoslavia is entering a new dawn, it seems. The federal parliament - burnt in the October 5 uprising - is repaired and recently hosted an assembly of the new government of President Vojislav Kostunica. The country, already in the United Nations and the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe, is signalling its desire to join the European Union.

But several Serbs could not bear to stand in the street celebrating this coming new year. Why? Because they are voicing disillusioned fears that both everything and nothing has changed.

Everything has changed because Slobodan Milosevic is facing the end. "He is finished" - as the slogan of the student-based resistance movement, Otpor, says. The best he can get is a trial in Belgrade for electoral fraud and corruption. The worst is one that lays at his feet secret service assassinations and war crimes, followed - or preceded - by answering to war crimes' indictments at the UN tribunal in the Hague.

And what of October 5 itself? Was the revolution really a popular civilian uprising, or was it closer to a police and military coup? It will take many years before we finally know. But what is already clear is that the muscle that stormed the parliament and state television station came from men who learned the trade of war in Croatia, Bosnia and Kosovo - and had past or current links with Yugoslavia's police, army and paramilitary groups. They wanted rid of Milosevic, not because of his international crimes, but because he had become Serbia's albatross.

In all informed accounts of the revolution the role of the special units is paramount, particularly that played by the commander of the elite special police unit, the Red Berets. Mihajlo Ulemek is a veteran of Serbia's wars and former member of the notorious paramilitary group, the Tigers, commanded by assassinated war crimes indictee Arkan. The Red Berets' decision to dump Milosevic and ignore orders when called to retake state television, secured power for the new government. But it opens up the suspicion that Serbia's new leaders, like the old, are in deep debt to men who are - or could well be - UN war crimes indictees themselves.

That is why some believe that nothing has changed. One of the most powerful images of east Germany's revolution was the ransacking of the Stasi building. Yet here, no one ransacked secret police premises, and the head of that organisation, Rade Markovic, still retains power. Ulemek is now a national pin-up.

The free press that receives generous western money has not reported in detail the evidence of General Radislav Krstic, on trial in the Hague for the massacre in Srebrenica of an estimated 6,000 plus Muslims, slaughtered by Serbs. The recent discovery of a Muslim mass grave near the eastern Bosnian town of Visegrad - now totally Serb controlled - goes unmentioned. Would it have been ignored, if under the garbage, lay the bones of slaughtered Serbs?

A new party, the party of Serbian Unity, led by another former member of the Tigers, gained enough votes for its MPs to sit in parliament. Taken with the vote of the rightwing Radical party, this shows that more than one in ten Serbs still buys into Milosevic's doomed greater Serbia project that fired the nationalist wars.

An examination of the recent past is needed. Federal foreign minister Goran Svilanovic might seem to have started the process when he spoke of the formation of a so-called truth commission, composed of international and domestic experts who are to review the facts about the war crimes committed in the past decade in Kosovo, Croatia and Bosnia. But the proposal won't wash. How can you examine war crimes across the federation without direct participation of authorities in Bosnia, Croatia and Kosovo? Have they been asked? Why duplicate the work already being done by the tribunal? And most of all, is Svilanovic suggesting that no extraditions from Belgrade will take place until after this commission's work is finished? Milosevic and the rest of us will probably be dead by then.

There is a tribunal and everyone has signed up to it. Its chief prosecutor, Carla Del Ponte wants Milosevic, Bosnian Serb army General Ratko Mladic and Bosnian Serb political leader Radovan Karadzic extradited. These indictees' trials could take place partly in Yugoslavia because they might help to clarify events for Serbs, a spokeswoman says, but they also have to be carried out in the Hague because of the international nature of the war - and witnesses' desire for a trial on neutral ground.

Now western policy is focusing on creating a stable Serbia. It is now subject to the influences and pressures that western government and donor organisations decide to apply. Doubtless some concessions will be sought - something beyond the trial of Milosevic. But how much will again be swept aside by Serbia - and its new global partners - as the demands of a new real politik once again become paramount?

 Gillian Sandford is the Guardian's correspondent in Yugoslavia.

webTitle: Grandparents: Penelope Farmer on elderly role models

fields.headline: 'I didn't have a clue'
fields.standfirst: With no memories of her own grandmothers, author  Penelope Farmer  found that she had no role models to turn to when she became one herself. So she had to learn fast
fields.trailText: With no memories of her own grandmothers, author Penelope Farmer found that she had no role models to turn to when she became one herself. So she had to learn fast.
fields.body:
At around 9am on May 22 1996, I stood at the door of a Bristol maternity unit, gazing through a locked glass door at Eleanor Ruth Penelope Roser, my first grandchild. The door was an uncomfortable symbol of the fact that, in reproductive terms, things had moved on. I was now firmly in the back seat.

This I had to work out, painfully, over the coming days of cooking and cleaning at my daughter's house. But at that moment I was simply moved - and bemused - by the sight of the crumple-faced scrap lying in the arms of the woman whom I'd held as an equally frail scrap in my arms such a short time before. Oh, the heartbreaking brevity of it. I imagine most women feel this, in some way, at first sight of their first grandchild.

In my case, there was the added poignancy of the early demise of all previous grandmothers in my mother's family. I was the first woman in four generations to know the pleasure of belonging to three generations of women. When I decided to make a book about grandmothers, it was largely in order to find myself a role model. My paternal grandmother, 88 when I was born, hardly figured. I didn't have a clue.

It surprised me during my research to find how bemused many women now are - even those who've grown up with grandmothers. Things have changed for everyone; not least through the simple fact that, with increased longevity, we grandmothers have lost our rarity value. In 1900, only one in four people would have had four living grandparents. By 1976, two out of three did. One of my two granddaughters has all four; the other has three. Both have a living great-grandfather. Emily, the younger, has a great-grandmother besides.

On top of that, any special knowledge we grandmothers might have had has been superseded by technology - who uses terry-towel nappies and safety-pins now? Our role as a daughter's helpmeet has equally been superseded by their ever more involved partners. It is not just our daughters and daughters-in-law (or out-law) we have to tread carefully with now in matters of child-rearing. It's our sons, also.

One lasting memory of the first few days of Ellie's life was hearing my daughter and her partner in animated discussion with the health visitor about the colour of her shit. I, of course, belonged - choking with laughter - on the other side of the door. As Phyllida Law, one of my informants, said, succinctly, you have to edit yourself. Indeed. And fast.

Nor do many of us fit the old stereotypes - if we ever did. Even in the 19th century I discovered some far-from-staid grandmothers. But now nobody expects us to look and dress like "the older woman". We work. We run. We go to the gym. We travel, often singly, to unlikely places - I, this Christmas, went by fairly rough means to Timbuktu. We take lovers and even the partnerless are nowadays urged in manuals aimed at the over-60s to enjoy themselves via masturbation.

Above all, we think about where we're at, and write about it. In her autobiography, the anthropologist Margaret Mead commiserated with us on never being able to take ourselves, as grandmothers, for granted. It is hard work. On the other hand, we the generation that came of age with feminism have, throughout our lives, articulated areas of women's lives previously unarticulated, considered unseemly on the one hand, and too commonplace to be interesting, on the other. These range from menstruation to loss of virginity, to the more intimate and emotional sides of sexual partnerships - heterosexual and homosexual - to childbirth, divorce, and, as we've grown older, to the menopause and, now, grandmotherhood.

Ironically enough, however particular our take on it, this place we've reached now leads us back to a much less particular, more fundamental matter: biology. Some of us are ill already. Even those who've managed to stay fit and well cannot deny the fact that though we may not feel old, we are ageing. Our sense of mortality is augmented by a not new, but fuller recognition that our adult lives contain completely the lives of the new parents, our children. We realise, seeing their children begin their lives, that we are that much nearer the ends of ours.

For our grandchildren, that is our importance. We provide a sense of generations, the lack of which impoverished me. My granddaughters' gain from seeing their mother's or father's relationships with us, their mothers. Margaret Mead quoted the idea that a unit of human time is the space between the memory of grandparent and grandchild. I never saw my mother with her mother or knew what was held deep in my grandmother's memory.

But I make sure that Ellie begins to know what mine holds. For her, at four, the childhood of her mother, let alone mine, is unimaginably long ago. But I can help shift her perception a little. When she's playing me up and wails: "I want my mummy," I wail back: "And I want my little girl." And I watch her stop, think and realise - with all the implications - that her mother and my little girl are one and the same person.

As to how to be a grandmother, I sigh wearily at manuals suggesting I turn myself into an alternative kindergarten. We are all different. What I am is a storyteller, so I tell my grandchildren stories. Just as another grandmother I met the other day - a landscape historian - takes her granddaughter round Birmingham canals and discovers with her the different kinds of drain covers and bridges. Ellie's other grandmother is more patient than I am and cooks with her. I have a picture of Ellie whisking up egg whites for meringues, not something she's ever likely to do around me.

I am equally aware of what my grandchildren give me. Precisely because I know how brief babyhood and childhood are and precisely because I am (thankfully) not bound up with the day-to-day routine of childcare, I appreciate, as I did not with my own children, where each child is now, at this moment. To be around small children again at a time in my life when I feel myself swept towards its ending comes with the welcome recognition that life renews itself endlessly, with or without me.

It is also a wonderful excuse to be silly. Ellie and I play at bears in the bed, growling at each other. We skip wildly together along the pavement. We go down slides, side by side. We pretend we're both clockwork and have to be wound up before we start walking. Her smaller cousin, Emily, even insisted on climbing into the bath with me the other day and playing fishes. Despite the endless ailments they pass on to me, a much less touted aspect of grandparent hood - poor George Sand caught whooping cough from her grandchildren - it feels like pure privilege.

It feels the more so because I know that grandparenthood can be no fun in other families, other parts of the world. Not all grandmas are fit, let alone carefree. Some are crippled by arthritis. Some become demented. For my book, I found accounts of heroic grandparents struggling to bring up the children of their Aids-stricken young, and distressing reports of granny abuse at home and in hospital.

Too many grandparents, I discovered, never see their grandchildren after family break-up. Others have poverty-stricken children who don't acknowledge the aged parents they can't afford to support. A recent newsletter about the grandmother I sponsor in southern India announced that she is happy because, now she is provided for, her children dare visit her again. That leaves me very sober. And feeling still luckier.

Last time I visited my younger granddaughter, she rushed to the door shouting, "My Pennepy." Last time I saw the older one, we walked down to the local city farm together and she said: "I was absolutely dying to see you, actually." They seem like the greatest compliments in the world.

fields.bodyText: At around 9am on May 22 1996, I stood at the door of a Bristol maternity unit, gazing through a locked glass door at Eleanor Ruth Penelope Roser, my first grandchild. The door was an uncomfortable symbol of the fact that, in reproductive terms, things had moved on. I was now firmly in the back seat. This I had to work out, painfully, over the coming days of cooking and cleaning at my daughter's house. But at that moment I was simply moved - and bemused - by the sight of the crumple-faced scrap lying in the arms of the woman whom I'd held as an equally frail scrap in my arms such a short time before. Oh, the heartbreaking brevity of it. I imagine most women feel this, in some way, at first sight of their first grandchild. In my case, there was the added poignancy of the early demise of all previous grandmothers in my mother's family. I was the first woman in four generations to know the pleasure of belonging to three generations of women. Our role as a daughter's helpmeet has equally been superseded by their ever more involved partners. In her autobiography, the anthropologist Margaret Mead commiserated with us on never being able to take ourselves, as grandmothers, for granted. It is hard work. On the other hand, we the generation that came of age with feminism have, throughout our lives, articulated areas of women's lives previously unarticulated, considered unseemly on the one hand, and too commonplace to be interesting, on the other. Ironically enough, however particular our take on it, this place we've reached now leads us back to a much less particular, more fundamental matter: biology. Some of us are ill already. Even those who've managed to stay fit and well cannot deny the fact that though we may not feel old, we are ageing. Our sense of mortality is augmented by a not new, but fuller recognition that our adult lives contain completely the lives of the new parents, our children. We realise, seeing their children begin their lives, that we are that much nearer the ends of ours. For our grandchildren, that is our importance. We provide a sense of generations, the lack of which impoverished me. My granddaughters' gain from seeing their mother's or father's relationships with us, their mothers. Margaret Mead quoted the idea that a unit of human time is the space between the memory of grandparent and grandchild. I never saw my mother with her mother or knew what was held deep in my grandmother's memory. But I make sure that Ellie begins to know what mine holds. For her, at four, the childhood of her mother, let alone mine, is unimaginably long ago. But I can help shift her perception a little. When she's playing me up and wails: "I want my mummy," I wail back: "And I want my little girl." And I watch her stop, think and realise - with all the implications - that her mother and my little girl are one and the same person. As to how to be a grandmother, I sigh wearily at manuals suggesting I turn myself into an alternative kindergarten. We are all different. What I am is a storyteller, so I tell my grandchildren stories. Just as another grandmother I met the other day - a landscape historian - takes her granddaughter round Birmingham canals and discovers with her the different kinds of drain covers and bridges. Ellie's other grandmother is more patient than I am and cooks with her. I have a picture of Ellie whisking up egg whites for meringues, not something she's ever likely to do around me. I am equally aware of what my grandchildren give me. Precisely because I know how brief babyhood and childhood are and precisely because I am (thankfully) not bound up with the day-to-day routine of childcare, I appreciate, as I did not with my own children, where each child is now, at this moment. To be around small children again at a time in my life when I feel myself swept towards its ending comes with the welcome recognition that life renews itself endlessly, with or without me. It is also a wonderful excuse to be silly. Ellie and I play at bears in the bed, growling at each other. We skip wildly together along the pavement. We go down slides, side by side. We pretend we're both clockwork and have to be wound up before we start walking. Her smaller cousin, Emily, even insisted on climbing into the bath with me the other day and playing fishes. fields.headline: Home help
fields.standfirst: Michael Young  and  Jean Stogdon  explain why they have launched a new group for grandparents
fields.trailText: Michael Young and Jean Stogdon explain why they have launched a new group for grandparents.
fields.body:
The growing pressures on family life mean that grandparents are in demand - perhaps even "in fashion". Who cares for young children when both parents are in paid work? It is as likely to be the grandparents as the gamut of childminders, creches and nurseries. Who takes the children to and from school? Often the grandparents. Who comes to the rescue when parental families break down? Grandparents again.

Grandparents have mattered to families for hundreds of thousands of years in every known society the world over. But they have gained a new importance in a modern society like ours, not because of governments but because of demography. Family size has fallen, so the lateral family of uncles and aunts and cousins is less prominent. People are living longer, so the "vertical extended" family, including grandparents, has been growing steadily. When a child is in need, it is now less often auntie who comes to the rescue and more often nan.

This transformation has not yet been recognised by the welfare state. A form of social blindness prevents us seeing the importance for the health of our society of what is happening in front of our eyes. Which is why today sees the launch of Grandparents Plus, a new organisation to serve grandparents and their families across Britain. "Plus" refers to other kin. The aim of the new body is to achieve fuller recognition of the social and psychological value of what grandparents do.

Grandparents Plus will:

 be a lobbying group for grandparents.

 press for more grandparents to be recruited by social services as foster carers.

 campaign to develop greater use of grandparent and kinship care before fostering is considered.

 launch local groups for grandparents who, in cases where parents have mental health or other problems, are in loco parentis .

 set up pilot projects towards a new mediation service for parents and grandparents experiencing difficulties.

 establish a national network of learning groups on grandparenting issues (backed by a discussion booklet).

Grandparents Plus hopes to stimulate the formation of learning groups, both within the new body and in cooperation with oth ers. Its first partner will be the University of the Third Age (U3A), the adult education organisation where members teach each other. There are now 110,000 members in over 420 local groups; many are, of course, grandparents. As well as learning, they often work as volunteers in schools and colleges or as helpers on a one-to-one basis for pupils with learning difficulties.

U3A is a model for Grandparents Plus. Let us hope we, too, have 100,000 members within 10 years. To achieve this, we plan to collaborate with many other organisations for older people, for parents and for children, including Age Concern and the Grandparents Federation. We believe Grandparents Plus will prove an idea whose time has come.

 For details, write to Grandparents Plus at 18 Victoria Park Square, London E2 9PF.

 Michael Young (Lord Young of Dartington) was the originator of the Open University and the Consumers Association. Jean Stogdon is a former court-appointed guardian. They are co-chairs of Grandparents Plus.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: CGNU reports record sales
fields.body:
CGNU reports record sales

CGNU, Britain's largest insurer, yesterday reported record life, pensions and investment sales in Britain and worldwide in the final quarter of last year.

Issuing its long-term savings new business figures for 2000, CGNU said full-year worldwide sales rose 24% to £13.5bn. British sales were up 21% to £7.5bn against the background of an anticipated "flat" market.

But Philip Scott, UK life group executive director, said that while the Equitable Life crisis could offer the company business opportunities since Equitable had closed its doors to new customers, he believed the debacle could damage confidence in the life and pensions industry. He said he thought the matter was being handled "messily".

The company said stakeholder pensions - the new schemes which go on sale in April, aimed at workers without access to a company pension scheme - were "a top priority" for this year.

CNN cuts 400 jobs

CNN, the 24-hour cable news channel which rose to prominence during the Gulf War, is to cut 400 jobs, nearly 10% of its work force. The top executive of its business news department, Shelby Coffey III, had resigned, CNN said.

The network, founded by Ted Turner in 1980 and owned by the newly merged AOL Time Warner, plans to roll the operations of its news web sites into the television channels, a strategy used by other media companies recently to cut costs.

One-third of the CNN's job cuts will come from its interactive unit, including CNN.com. Another third will come from the programming division, and the remainder from other parts of the company. After the cuts, the company will have 3,900 employees.

Shares of AOL Time Warner rose $2.16 to $48.86 in afternoon trading.

Vardy splits top posts

Vehicle distributor Reg Vardy said it was splitting the role of chairman and chief executive, and that its finance director, Gerard Murray, would become chief executive officer from May 1. Peter Vardy will continue as chairman.

Reg Vardy reported first-half results including a 38% fall in pre-tax profit to £9m on turnover down 2% to £656m.

The group, which warned last month that full-year profits would fall short of expectations, said the "unprecedented fall in vehicle values made 2000 one of the most difficult for the motor industry in the last three decades".

Used car prices fell sharply last year as manufacturers cut the price of new cars to bring them more into line with the rest Europe following government intervention.

Boeing profit fails to please

Boeing said its fourth-quarter profits rose 36%, beating Wall Street forecasts, as it squeezed more cash out of its aerospace businesses despite shrinking revenues.

Shares in the world's largest aircraft maker fell 4% after three big airlines reported weaker quarterly earnings, adding to concerns about future commercial jet orders. The commercial jet unit was responsible for the revenue decline, as deliveries fell to 489 aircraft in 2000 from a record 620 in 1999.
