webTitle: TV and Radio: The price is right

fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst: Which of these US TV shows will first be on in the UK?
fields.trailText: Which US TV shows will first be on in the UK?
fields.body:
The Gilmore Girls 4-6
Gideon's Crossing 3-1
Boston Public 4-1
TV Funhouse 6-1
Deadline 20-1

Is more US product going to appear on British TV? "Channel 4 buys the most US programmes. Channel 5 hasn't the budget, and neither ITV nor the BBC are particularly interested", says Andy Clifton, Ladbrokes' entertainment odds compiler. "The market for American product is therefore small. Does the programme suit the channel? is the question that should guide your betting," he adds.

The Gilmore Girls (pictured) is about a bohemian single mum forced to go cap-in-hand to previously rejected parents. Written by Veronica's Closet scribe Amy Sherman-Palladin, Andy says "It's won the viewers' and critics' acclaim."

Hospital drama Gideon's Crossing excels in emotive gore, and has secured the services of Rhona Mitra, the original live-action model for Tomb Raider. But is anyone in the mood for another hospital fizzing with frustration and tension? "Channel 4 is the most likely home for this programme, but they already have ER," notes Andy.

Boston Public also takes an essentially boring institution - this time, high school - and jazzes it up with teacher- teacher sex, student-student sex, and teacher-student sex. Unsurprisingly, David E Kelley of Ally McBeal fame is responsible. "I don't think Hollyoaks would sell to America, and, for the same reason, American high school is perhaps too unique an experience to appeal to us," says Andy.

The same applies to the topical comedy of TV Funhouse, the creation of veteran comic writer Robert Smigel. With randy superheroes and the show's "anipals", a collection of foul-mouthed and carnal puppets, this is one of the filthiest shows on TV. "The nature of the content probably rules out the BBC," says Andy.

Unfortunately, the deadline has passed for Deadline, which was axed by NBC before its sixth episode. "Perhaps if they sell it off cheap, and pitch it for the Columbo slot." Well, it worked for Knot's Landing.

fields.headline: Frank Capra: The Bitter Tea of General Yen
fields.standfirst: No 100
fields.trailText:
Capra's more affectionately remembered
                                                                  films look niave and sentimental now...
                                                                  but he did make one extraordinary film, an
                                                                  exotic fable that showed him capable of
                                                                  making what producer Harry Cohn called
                                                                  "the sort of arty junk that wins Oscars"
fields.body:
'Buddha, Joan of Arc and the spirit of all who believe in God live in the White House," Spencer Tracy was made to say in State of the Union, a dreadful film made by Frank Capra in 1948. It was the logical conclusion to the Sicilian immigrant's admiration for America, which admittedly produced much better movies, such as It Happened One Night and Mr Deeds Goes to Town.

But even these affectionately remembered films look naive and sentimental now, despite the evident skill of their making. The former won Capra the Oscars he craved. He called them "my holy grail". Shrewd and talented as he was, Capra's espousal of the virtues of the little man reek of whimsy and wishful thinking and, though we were once taken in by their sheer entertainment value, they remain among American cinema's most cosily absurd fables.

Not long after he made State of the Union, this somewhat unpleasing man was convinced that the America he once loved, and who had once loved his work, had been taken over by gays, druggies and draft dodgers. Unfortunately, he funked making a movie about that.

But, much earlier in his pretty long career, he did make one extraordinary film. It was called The Bitter Tea of General Yen, an exotic fable that showed him capable of what producer Harry Cohn called "the sort of arty junk that wins Oscars". It was neither arty nor junk, but a very skilful adaptation of a novel about a prim New England girl (Barbara Stanwyck) who arrives in Shanghai to marry a tight-arsed missionary as civil war breaks out. Attempting to save some children, she gets knocked flat and wakes up in the train of a notorious Chinese warlord (Nils Asther).

Taken to his summer palace, and held by the fascinated infidel, she starts trying to convert him. But she also begins to dress in Chinese gowns and to fall in love with a surprisingly wise and courtly man. Alas, however, the the war turns against him and he poisons himself.

It is a tale made both credible and erotic by Capra's cameraman Joe Walker, screenwriter Edward Paramore and Stanwyck, an actress it was always difficult to look away from (she seldom seemed so innocently beautiful as here). And we have to credit Capra too for seeing in it a kind of Jamesian intelligence, and playing that up together with the sexual connotations.

The film looks marvellous, almost in the Sternberg mould, with black and white lighting culled from special portrait lenses and the sort of richly textured decor that only MGM could contemplate at the time.

The dream sequence is particularly striking. The American girl sees a couple courting before retiring to bed. Her bedroom door is broken open by a threatening Chinese man, but she is saved by a masked man in western clothes. When he takes off his mask, we see that it is General Yen. They sink back on to the bed and she wakes from her dream to find the general standing above her.

It was only later that Capra began his patriotic Americana. Before that, he seemed capable of superbly crafted movies - an eclectic talent who turned into a careerist. We should perhaps not mock films like It Happened One Night. They were made in an era when Capra wasn't the only one fooled by the American dream. But we should certainly regret that such a good film-maker ended up thinking that Buddha was likely to be comfortable in the White House.

The book: Derek Malcolm's Personal Best: A Century of Films, is published by ID Tauris at £9.95. To order a copy for £7.99, freephone CultureShop on 0800 3166 102.

The quiz: Test your knowledge of Derek Malcolm's top 100 films with our quiz at Film Unlimited.

Have your say: Derek Malcolm will be online at Film Unlimited to discuss his choices at 5.30pm today.

See the films: A selection of the films will be shown at the Screen on the Hill, London NW3 (020-7435 3366), starting with Godard's Breathless on January 23.

webTitle: Opec curb Cartel agrees 5% output reduction

fields.headline: Opec curb Cartel agrees 5% output reduction
fields.trailText: One Petroleum Exchange trader in London was left open-mouthed when Opec yesterday agreed an aggressive cut in oil supplies of 1.5m barrels per day despite warnings from Europe and America that sharply lower produc tion levels could harm the fragile global economy.
fields.body:
One Petroleum Exchange trader in London was left open-mouthed when Opec yesterday agreed an aggressive cut in oil supplies of 1.5m barrels per day despite warnings from Europe and America that sharply lower produc tion levels could harm the fragile global economy.

After a two-hour meeting in Vienna, the cartel said the 5% production curb would take effect from the beginning of next month.

Oil prices, which had been climbing before the meeting, fell sharply after the announcement, which was in line with market expectations.

London benchmark blend lost 66 cents to $24.86 but remained within Opec's target band of $22-$28 a barrel for its basket of seven crudes.

Opec's members fear a slowdown in world demand and a seasonal build-up in stocks during the second quarter could see prices fall sharply.

"Stocks are increasing and in the second quarter we saw a sharp fall in pricing coming," said Opec's secretary general, Ali Rodriguez.

The cartel, anxious to avoid a repeat of 1998's price slump to below $10 a barrel, agreed to meet again in March. "If there is a price fall below the target band there will be an automatic increase and we agreed that we could decide to cut up to one million barrels per day more in March if necessary."

The cartel's move came as a slap in the face to the United States and European Union which had urged producers to make only a modest reduction.

Oil hit a high of more than $35 a barrel last autumn, triggering protests about the cost of petrol.

webTitle: TV and Radio: ER best TV medical drama

fields.headline: Back to the suture
fields.standfirst: It may have too many characters and over-complicated plots. But we love it anyway.  Matthew Baylis on why ER is still the best medical drama on TV
fields.trailText: It may have too many characters and over-complicated plots. But we love it anyway. Matthew Baylis on why ER is still the best medical drama on TV.
fields.body:
'I assume you're cheating on the whore with another whore?" No not a courtroom epithet from Ally McBeal, but a speech from the first episode of ER's seventh series, airing tonight on E4. One of the few lines, in fact, not uttered in the presence of arterial spray and 14-inch needles.

On results alone, it's no surprise that ER is on its seventh series: the winner of 14 Emmys, nominated for seven Golden Globes, and watched all across the globe. Reading the CV of creator Michael Crichton goes some way towards explaining this success. A Harvard Medical School graduate, Crichton went on to lecture in anthropology at Cambridge, before writing 11 novels and six movies, including Jurassic Park. It seems as if award-winning TV is just his hobby.

What's more perplexing is that a show so formulaic can continually capture high ratings. A glance at any random episode proves the point. There's always a scene or two involving one cast member breaking the worst news to a grieving relative. Another in which a nervous neophyte has to do something grisly with a tube or needle, then either funks it or saves the day. Plus, hopping from background to foreground, some macabre mass accident, involving a dozen blood-drenched casualties, dressed as Vikings, Pilgrim Fathers or Santa Claus.

Many new viewers feel nauseous after an ER encounter. This is only partially due to the litres of blood lapping around the set. Put bluntly, ER is a confusing experience. An episode can feature up to seven storylines, which compared to the sedate three or four of British soaps, is like exposing GCSE maths students to quantum physics. These storylines are played out in nouvelle cuisine -sized chunks - lines shouted out against a backdrop of bleeping machinery and death rattles. It's hard to keep up, particularly when the quieter, more emotional stories end up sidelined, just a few scenes at the start and finish.

This chaotic structure can creep, like a deadly virus, into the characterisation. There are acres of web-space devoted to explaining who's who in ER, a thorny issue for those of us unfamiliar with the jargon. We know that Kerry Weaver's important, because she tells people off and carries a stick. But the precise nature of the hospital hierarchy is a mystery to most, as are - in a busy episode - the differences between the characters.

The core cast is unwieldy - some 12 doctors and nurses, plus eight support staff. Writers who can keep all these people in our consciousness, and tell several stories in 40 minutes, are rarer than state-registered alchemists. There's also the additional problem that, in a high-action emergency situation, there's a limited range of ways in which a character can act. They have to get on with their jobs, after all, or they wouldn't be there.

Of course there are well-drawn characters in ER. The wealthy recovering drug addict Dr Carter. The gruff but kindhearted Dr Benton, intent on self-advancement but ever pricked by his conscience. But this isn't soap. There might be an occasional visit to the diner across the road, but for the greater part, ER is "precinct drama" - the action limited to the workplace and seldom visiting characters' outside lives. Who even knows why Dr Weaver has a walking-stick?

In fact, ER's success occurs because, rather than in spite of, these problems. Soaps can overload us with details about a person's life. But in precinct drama, glimpses of character become treats, made precious by being rarer.

Remember the interest sparked when Dr Weaver's African lover, Mlungisi, came to visit. Or when we discovered Dr Carter's gilded background. It's axiomatic that, as drama viewers, we're more interested in the feelings of the characters than in seeing the familiar routine with the defibrillator. But guesswork, and occasional rewards, can be more satisfying than knowing what everyone looks like in their pyjamas.

Tethered to the workplace, the stories have to intersect with how the characters are feeling. A story about a miscarriage becomes relevant only when a nurse or doctor is pregnant, or in some related situation. This principle is at the core of every ER episode. People are brought into conflict with issues bigger than but entirely relevant to themselves - science, medical ethics, protocol, economics. So a doctor who's studied hard to escape the ghetto has to turn away poor patients. Another, recently bereaved, deals with the implications of a DNR order (Do Not Resuscitate).

And aside from the odd schmaltzy moment where the resident heart-throb cradles a baby, ER tells these stories in a bold manner. In a cautious TV-world, it's never afraid to tackle issues like AIDS, racism and homophobia head-on. This courage ensures that, whatever the formula, viewers are continually challenged. It's mirrored in the producers' readiness to experiment with the form - the live episode, Tarantino's guest-directed piece.

So viewers of tonight's episode might feel that the tale of a certain doctor's divorce becomes engulfed by the usual tidal wave of saline fluid and fresh cadavers. But they should remember that this is how the makers of ER have always won results. And, as some famous surgeon once said, if it ain't broke, don't fix it.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The Material World | Analysis
fields.body:
Car buyers behave increasingly as if they were shopping for a jumbo jet. They want their vehicles to be ever lighter, more fuel efficient and, of course, cheaper. As Quentin Cooper discovers from his guests on The Material World (4.30pm, Radio 4), it raises tricky issues for the industry's research scientists. Dr Ken Kendall of Aston Martin thinks his people may have found an answer, a mixture of carbon fibre, aluminium, and bonded composites.

Alexander Woollcott complained three generations ago that everything he liked was either illegal, immoral, or fattening. He should be living at this hour. Doom and gloom pour constantly from the mass media. From their perspective it's understandable - that's how they attract an audience. But in a nation experiencing unprecedented wealth and wellbeing, it irritates Felipe Fernandez-Armesto as much as the rest of us. In Analysis (8.30pm, Radio 4) he examines modern Britain's strange need to believe the worst.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Last night's TV

fields.headline: The devil you know
fields.trailText: The Vice | Dark Angel | Confidence Lab
fields.body:
Inspector Pat Chappel should avoid pristine corridors. Like a catwalk model for an Oxfam shop, he looks scruffier, more rumpled against institutional white walls than he does normally. And normally, he looks pretty rough, a controlled explosion at a jumble sale.

Looking rough goes with the job, of course. If, like Pat in The Vice (ITV), you traipsed through the worst sexual excesses of humanity every day, dealing with the damaged and the devious, you too would soon abandon any grooming routine you have in the knowledge that grubbiness comes from within.

In this, the first of a series of feature-length, allegedly self-contained efforts, Pat was forced to confront a demon of his own. Frank Vickers may well have had a name like a cryptic crossword clue, but he was much more trouble, causing mayhem in Pat's personal life and sewing seeds of mistrust among the careworn Chappel's colleagues.

As stories go, The Vice was very Prime Suspect, with prostitutes being horribly tortured in basements, seemingly untouchable baddies (Tim Pigott Smith looking like a constipated turkey) and a complicated love interest (the bolshy one from Hearts And Bones) thrown in there for good measure.

As self-contained stories go, it was thoroughly unsatisfying, with Vickers' only punishment for horrifically torturing prostitutes seeming to be his inability to sell the brothel he owned to an advertising agency. That'll teach him. Or not.

Even with the disappointing pedigree of the story, The Vice was uncomfortable but gripping drama. Ken Stott's Pat Chappel is the most complex, interesting detective on television. With the look of a man on whom his responsibilities and emotions weigh heavy, he navigates in and out of the shadows, not a wholesome superman but a deeply flawed human being. With first-class support from Caroline Catz, David Harewood and the promising Rosie Marcel as new recruit Kirsty, Stott is magnetic - both as a hero and as a warning.

It's nice to know that in the future of Dark Angel (Sky One), some things won't change. Black men will still speak in funny voices, black women will continue to be sassy Miss Things and heroines will still be pneumatic, gymnastic vixens after whom all men will fruitlessly lust.

The year is 2020 and America is broke and broken after an electro-pulse bomb wiped out all things computerised - from infrastructure and satellites to money and dental records. "The zeros and ones became zeros", Max, the eponymous angel, helpfully points out in her semi-witty, teenage way.

Genetically engineered - by someone with a Lara Croft fixation - as a superior soldier by some shadowy government organisation, Max has been hiding in Seattle since her childhood escape from a gulag-ish research facility. She splits her time between being a cycle courier and a burglar, while also finding time to sit atop tall buildings and, in a ponderous voiceover, muse on the fate of her fellow escapees. (It's good to know that even the master race has angst.)

Then she meets a cyberjournalist with whom she reluctantly teams up to bring Justice to this lawless yet authoritarian time. Luckily, her lantern-jawed, oddly-named compatriot is put into a wheelchair by the end of the pilot episodes, so Max can backflip and kick butt while Logan Cale - which sounds like an Irish cabbage to me - finds her corruption to confront and Good Deeds to do.

So there we have it: Batman meets Buffy and La Femme Nikita with a hint of the X-Men and The X-Files in a not-too-distant Paul Verhoeven-esque future.

Director James Cameron's first venture into TV, which reputedly cost some $10m for the pilot alone, is derivative but extremely watchable, if you like that kind of thing. And with that kind of thing being sci-fi-teen-action hybrids with voluptuous jailbait heroines, you are most likely from a teenage male, internet-using demographic with a Gillian Anderson fixation.

Dark Angel is tosh - but good tosh.

You can see why Dawn French was chosen to narrate Confidence Lab (BBC2). If you, like Emily or Paul, are at a bit of low ebb in life, I can't think of anything better than a big, warm cuddle from French. Once you had buried your face in her bosom, all would seem right with the world. Or at least it would for me.

webTitle: G2: Pass notes on Vanessa Feltz

fields.headline: No: 1803
fields.standfirst: Vanessa Feltz
fields.trailText: Vanessa Feltz
fields.body:
As in the chat-show queen, darling of daytime TV? Well yes but...

Feltz the super slimmer, the inspiration for the downtrodden female? Yes but...

The woman who turned her life around when her husband walked out on her? If you'd let me get a word in...

Ah yes, the women who inspired thousands by picking herself up and bagging a £2.5m deal with the BBC? You missed out the fitness instructor boyfriend. Yes, it was all going so well for Miss Feltz, but now it seems she has fallen from grace. She's been dropped after BBC bosses decided her appeal had become "extremely limited".

You mean no more of The Vanessa Show? Actually it had already been scrapped after the Mirror revealed that it had been using fake guests.

So what about all her other TV outings? You mean Talking Television and Quotation Marks? I'm afraid those were savaged by the critics. She has made very few appearances on high-profile TV shows lately - although she's still picking up £20,000 a week.

So it's all gone a bit pear-shaped? Very funny. Vanessa will still be competing for BBC work with other independent presenters. She's already made an episode of Danger: Celebrity at Work.

A docusoap of her life? Don't be rude. It's something about weddings in Las Vegas.

So why doesn't she just go back to ITV? It seems she burned her bridges there when she walked out after seeking a salary rise from £1m to £2.75m. A senior executive says, "There's no job for her here. It's no secret that she upset a lot of people with the way she quit. And frankly you reap what you sow."

So what does she do now? Well, her lawyer says there are some "great ideas for new shows under development". She is also working for OK! magazine and has a fitness video.

Do say: " It will all work out." (Get it? Fitness video.)

Don't say: "Being dumped by the BBC and not having all that pressure must be another great weight off your shoulders."

webTitle: 1,300 jobs go as S&N sells off smaller pubs

fields.headline: 1,300 jobs go as S&N sells off smaller pubs
fields.trailText: Britain's shrinking brewing industry suffered a fresh blow yesterday with the announcement of 1,300 job losses at Scottish & Newcastle, which is streamlining its beer distribution network and selling hundreds of its smaller pubs.
fields.body:
Britain's shrinking brewing industry suffered a fresh blow yesterday with the announcement of 1,300 job losses at Scottish & Newcastle, which is streamlining its beer distribution network and selling hundreds of its smaller pubs.

In a large-scale restructuring, the Edinburgh-based firm is aiming to save £46m a year to compete with multinationals such as Belgium's Interbrew.

Furthermore, Scottish & Newcastle has bowed to pressure from the City to reduce its managed pub estate, by selling 740 houses and switching a further 180 to leased operations. The company intends to concentrate on branded chains such as Chef & Brewer.

Chairman Brian Stewart said: "We've got to react to, and anticipate, changes in the industry." The changes mean the workforce of Scottish Courage, the group's brewing arm, will fall from 6,500 to 5,200 over four years, with redundancies concentrated in warehousing and administration.

The Transport & General Workers' Union described the cuts as a "bitter blow".

Scottish & Newcastle is replacing 40 local beer warehouses with three regional hubs - in Scotland, Yorkshire and southern England. The company is the biggest British-owned brewer - its beers include Kronenbourg 1664 and Newcastle Brown Ale, and it produces Foster's and Beck's under licence for the brands' overseas owners.

The firm is likely to get about £500m for its up-for-sale outlets, although thousands of Whitbread and Bass pubs are already on the market.

Scottish & Newcastle will concentrate on developing suburban, traditional-style pub concepts such as Chief & Brewer, T&J Bernard and Barras. It will scale back investment in its city-centre brands, such as Rat & Parrot, as the market is too crowded.

The proposals got a lukewarm reception in the City. Scottish & Newcastle's shares fell 9p to 456p. Analysts want the firm to withdraw from pubs entirely, arguing that it should concentrate on building international beer brands.

Mark Reed of stockbroker Teather & Greenwood said: "If you want to be an international brewer, why do you need a UK retail estate? You don't see Anheuser-Busch or Carlsberg running pubs."

Another analyst said: "Scottish & Newcastle have set themselves ambitious earnings targets here but there's no reason yet why we should believe they can deliver."

fields.standfirst: So Barbara Castle loves men and has no time for women who hate them. But what does she expect, says  Julie Burchill. Men are doing hateful things to us every day
fields.trailText: So Barbara Castle loves men and has no time for women who hate them. But what does she expect, says Julie Burchill. Men are doing hateful things to us every day.
fields.body:
There are some words and phrases that are so quaint, so outdated that they make me literally shiver with glee. "Living in sin" is one; "liberty bodice" is another. And this week Barbara Castle, one of the greatest women of our age, came out with one I thought was surely lost and gone for ever: "man-haters".

Oh, glory! The giggly, girly reality of modern me-too feminism recedes and once more we are faced with a monstrous regiment of dungareed sirens, charred bras borne proudly aloft, underarms unshaven, copies of the Scum Manifesto to the ready, chalking boldly on bare walls that A WOMAN NEEDS A MAN LIKE A FISH NEEDS A BIKE.

Trouble is, they became extinct 30 years ago. That doesn't stop Barbara from wading in and having a bash, as is her wont. "One of the biggest dangers women face today are men-haters," she said earlier this week. "I love men. If there's a great deal of love you can get a great many things done. You don't have to be a man-hater to be a successful woman. In fact, all it can do is impede your progress."

This statement may seem preposterous on first, second or even third reading, but dash it, she's right, you know. Look at that first sentence and just think about it for a moment. When it's two in the morning and you can't get a taxi and you're walking home and you hear footsteps behind you, you do instinctively think, "Oh my god, it's one of those Men-Haters! Everyone knows they're one of the biggest dangers women face today. Any minute now she's going to run up to me and spin me round and rub my lipstick off AND STICK A FALSE MOUSTACHE ON ME! Quick - I'd better find a MAN!"

And dig that third sentence. She's a wise old bird, is Babs. You can tell she's thinking about the suffragettes and how they got us the vote. They didn't do anything unpleasant like smashing windows, setting postboxes on fire, slashing nude paintings and yelling "VOTES FOR WOMEN AND CHASTITY FOR MEN!", did they? Course not!

They got in there, old Emmeline, Christabel and Sylvia, and gave Lloyd George and his cabinet a whole lot of neck rubs, foot massages and savoury snacks because, like Barbara, they knew that a) the way to a man's heart is through his stomach and b) if there's a great deal of love you can get many things done. Sensible, those Pankhursts; knew the importance of Pussy Power every time.

But it's the second sentence that's the real giveaway: I LOVE MEN. Only one sort of woman ever has the brass neck to say this; and it's a woman in her 80s or 90s like Castle or her fellow Barbara, Cartland, who spent her entire life kicking men into touch, breaking their balls and generally making their lives a misery, as Castle has rightly done in the pursuit of her radical vision and as Cartland did in order to achieve the lifestyle she felt she was born for. Between them, they have probably bossed more men into early graves than the entire Lesbian Nation.

But then, as they get older, they want to be seen as all soft and cuddly and feminine, which is a bit difficult when you can't wring out a drop of oestrogen to save your life. So they resort to these sad, man-pleasing tactics; belittling other, younger women in order to bolster their own sense of femininity.

It's sad that 40 years ago Barbara Castle would have happily agreed with Rebecca West's definitive statement about feminism: "I only know that people call me a feminist whenever I express sentiments that differentiate me from a doormat or a prostitute." For feminist, substitute man-hater.

Shamefully, when women attempt to finger other woman (oo-er!) as man-haters, the implication also is that they are lesbians, and therefore not "qualified" to speak out on the mysterious, wondrous beauty of, say, men beating women to within an inch of their lives.

Just last week Carol Sarler said as much about the magnificent Julie Bindel of Justice For Women in the Express. But this is as dumb as saying that a gay man can't be a gynaecologist because he has no practical experience of female genitalia. I know it's a bit of a cliche, but when women make such a to-do about man-haters and dykes, you really have to wonder how many of their own feelings they've repressed, and if they don't fancy a bit of dyke action themselves. It's like: "Aaagh! Big hairy lesbians - PLEASE!"

Besides, the number of professional feminists who are gay is minuscule; you'll find a higher proportion of gay models, nuns or housewives. And as for real man-haters, they are - curiously - largely to be found in the man-pleasing sector of society. You'll never meet a lap dancer, phone sex worker or prostitute who doesn't despise men, while those ultra-feminine women who write manuals on how to successfully "catch" a man seem to see them as nothing more than walking wallets.

Oh dear (snigger), surely that can't be right - that the more sexual contact women have with men, the more they hate them? Quick - the smelling salts for Baroness Castle!

When the six o'clock news is a litany of men being oppressed, murdered and raped by women; when a female Taliban confines Afghan men to their homes; when African women emasculate boy children and call it "tradition"; when two men a week are routinely killed by their female partners; when boys are monthly molested, strangled and left to die in a ditch by female assailants; when the female equivalent of Eminem becomes the world's fastest selling popular singer with her songs about killing and mutilating men - come to me then, Barbara, and complain about man-haters.

Until that day, concern yourself with the reality: that every day, in every way, in every country and in every culture, men are hating women to death. And getting away with it.

webTitle: Huntingdon Life: facing collapse in 36 hours

fields.headline: Huntingdon Life: facing collapse in 36 hours
fields.standfirst: Bank may pull plug on £22m loan to animal testing firm
fields.trailText: Bank may pull plug on £22m loan to animal testing firm.
fields.byline: Jill Treanor, Steven Morris  and Andrew Clark
fields.body:
The Royal Bank of Scotland was last night looking for ways to extricate itself from the uncomfortable position as banker to Huntingdon Life Sciences as it emerged that one of America's largest banks had severed its ties with the controversial animal-testing laboratory.

The Edinburgh-based bank, which refused to comment last night, citing client confidentiality, is one of three banks which have provided a £22m loan to the laboratory that is due for repayment on Friday. Huntingdon will have to close if the Royal Bank of Scotland insists on recalling the debt before it can complete alternative financing. The bank is facing pressure from the government to maintain its support.

The funding crisis at the drug-testing laboratory is causing a tug of war in the City where the Royal Bank of Scotland faces the prospect of continuing to support a loss-making company, which admits it is losing business as pharmaceutical companies take their testing elsewhere, or being accused of surrendering to intimidation tactics.

The threats employed by the Shac, the Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty campaign, since animal cruelty was uncovered in 1997, have led to many investors, bankers and brokers removing their backing for the firm, even though the management has been changed.

Yesterday, Citibank, an arm of one of America's biggest banks, Citigroup, admitted that it had cut its financial ties to the firm, following in the footsteps of almost every other instantly recognisable financial firm. It did not own shares directly but held them in nominee accounts for big pension funds.

This leaves the Royal Bank of Scotland as the highest profile bank with links to Huntingdon and it faces the difficult prospect of being accused of surrendering to the protesters who have targeted its directors, branches, employees, customers and vandalised its cash machines.

Pharmaceutical companies are threatening to withdraw their business if the Royal Bank of Scotland removes its finance for Huntingdon while government ministers are increasing the pressure on Royal Bank to maintain its support.

Well-placed industry sources said yesterday that they would be "shocked and amazed" if the loan was withdrawn. There is a feeling within the industry that pharmaceutical companies who contract work out to Huntingdon may be tempted to retaliate by stopping doing business with the Royal Bank of Scotland if it bows to the activists' pressure.

Antisoma, a London-based biotech company is a client of the bank's subsidiary, NatWest, and its chief executive Glyn Edwards has written to the bank urging it to continue supporting the controversial firm.

Mr Edwards said he would withdraw his personal account from NatWest and Antisoma's board of directors would consider taking the company's money elsewhere, if Huntingdon were allowed to close.

The Royal Bank of Scotland, one of three banks owed a total of £22m by Huntingdon, is thought to be owed half that amount. The identities of the other two banks, understood to be American, are unknown but it is understood that Huntingdon Life Sciences believes it will be able to clinch a financing agreement with them. This will allow the Royal Bank of Scotland, whose connection to the laboratory is the result of its takeover of NatWest, to end its financial support for the laboratory.

The Edinburgh-based bank has been trying to withdraw its financial support to Huntingdon since August when the £22m two-year financing facility was due to be repaid. It has, however, been throwing the loss-making laboratory a lifeline every month - the equivalent of extending its overdraft - while the company completes a refinancing.

Brian Cass, managing director of the Cambridgeshire laboratory, insisted last night that he was confident that the company would survive beyond Friday night, when the debt becomes due again.

"My confidence remains," Mr Cass said. "This is the fifth time we've been through this and every time it runs to the wire".

He said it was "impossible" to say which banks would remain as backers. "We're in discussions with the Royal Bank of Scotland and the others," he said. An announcement was unlikely before Monday.

He admitted that the business had suffered because of the uncertainty about whether the laboratories had enough financing to finish projects which can take three years to complete. But, he insisted: "You've got to look at the turnaround - the increase in order level of around 40% over the last two years. We are approaching consistent profitability".

webTitle: Salvadorean anger at post-quake aid delays

fields.headline: Salvadorean anger at post-quake aid delays
fields.standfirst: Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: More than 45,000 people have been left homeless by El Salvador's massive earthquake, the government admitted yesterday, as criticism of the delays in ensuring food and medicines reach displaced families increased.
fields.body:
More than 45,000 people have been left homeless by El Salvador's massive earthquake, the government admitted yesterday, as criticism of the delays in ensuring food and medicines reach displaced families increased.

The death in hospital of the last survivor to be pulled from a giant mudslide, whose 33-hour ordeal trapped beneath rubble and 10ft of mud captured international attention, added to the grieving country's woes.

Sergio Moreno, a 22-year-old musician, died of a heart failure, two days after being dragged from his home on the Las Colinas estate.

Of the 675 people killed in the disaster, he has perhaps caused the most widespread sadness. Doctors amputated his left leg, which had been severely damaged, in a desperate attempt to save his life.

After his rescue national television stations broadcast regular bulletins reporting on his progress. They interrupted their scheduled programmes to break the news of his death.

"He had become a symbol of life and energy for all of us, and especially for those who lost their loved ones in this tragedy," said Douglas Angel, a close friend.

Local government officials in Santa Tecla, the scene of the worst quake damage, complained that the central government's emergency committee (COEN) was sending survivors to the municipal-run evacuation camp without offering any assistance.

"We don't know what COEN is doing, whether it's out of negligence or incapacity, but the need here is immense and they have been sending neither food nor medicines," a local authority spokesman, David Hernandez, said. "All the aid we are giving out here is from direct donations."

Earlier Santa Tecla's mayor, Oscar Ortiz, complained on national television that the central government was not co-ordinating rescue efforts on Las Colinas housing estate, where more than 400 people died under a giant mudslide.

The tent city installed on municipal land now houses more than 7,000 survivors who lost their homes and belongings in the earthquake.

"We are all squashed in here like sardines, waiting to see what happens next," said Areceli Perez Carpio.

Her family of eight shares a small plastic cover with three other families. They have been there since early Sunday morning.

A clown entertains the small children, while Mexican army medics administer vaccines against possible epidemics.

The camp's organisers say that they badly need non-perishable foods and more bedding.

There are only 18 portable latrines in the camp, one for every 388 people.

A spokesman for President Francisco Flores denied favouritism in aid distribution and said that the mayor's office was "politicising" the emergency response.

Local radio stations have joined in the slanging match over aid. One commentator on Radio Corporation Salvadorena accused government emergency officials of "not wanting to get their shoes muddy".

Observers have privately expressed concern that there may be a repeat of the political bickering that followed the last big national crisis, when Hurricane Mitch hit El Salvador in November 1998.

Santa Tecla town hall is controlled by the former guerrilla group FMLN, which is the main political opposition to President Francisco Flores' rightwing government.

According to official figures, the earthquake, which measured 7.6 on the richter scale, has left 45,842 people homeless and wrecked more than 67,000 homes. In some villages in the east almost 95% of the housing was ruined.

fields.headline: Sarah Raphael
fields.standfirst: Gifted painter who rejected a career as a society portraitist after discovering a new artistic landscape on a trip to the outback
fields.trailText: Gifted painter who rejected a career as a society portraitist after discovering a new artistic landscape on a trip to the outback.
fields.body:
Sarah Raphael, who has died aged 40, was perfectly poised to establish herself as a brilliant society portraitist, like Emma Sargent, with an assured, highly lucrative career. She did not want this. She wanted to make her own way as a painter, on her own terms, rejecting the silver spoon she had been handed from her wealthy and cultivated family background.

As with many artists, drawing and making paintings was a crucial part of her life from earliest childhood. As a little girl aged seven, she was dazzled by the beauty of the Greek island Ios, where she lived with her family. She started painting it then and there with her little box of paints, and she would return to the motif later in adult life. Her father, the Oscar-winning writer Frederic Raphael, recognised his daughter's early precocity and always encouraged it.

Later, at Bedales, art continued to be central to her life, so much so that, unusually, at 16 she left to study at Camberwell School of Art, instantly recognised as a student of unusual gifts. She told me, when we were talking of art school days, how frustrating she often found the somewhat dilatory approach of many fellow students.

At Camberwell her terrible headaches were first diagnosed as migraine, a complaint that dogged her life as an artist, causing her such pain that she had to give up work for a couple of years both then, and later with the birth of her third daughter, Rebecca. Giving up work was an especial trial for her. The painkillers she was prescribed led to an addiction, which in turn had to be treated. The intensity of her focus on her work and the turpentine and oils she used were both thought to exacerbate her condition. She died from complications following pneumonia.

Sarah's first major solo exhibition was at Agnew's, her first dealers, in 1989. At this point her portraits showed the marked influence of Lucian Freud. The combination of immaculate technique and psychological penetration in portrait studies such as Daisy and Simon demonstrated Sarah's extraordinary natural facility. Later she would rebel against her ability to paint in a more traditional, figurative style.

She first came into the public eye in 1992, when an early portrait was shown at the National Portrait Gallery's Imperial Tobacco Award (now the BP Award). The gallery's director, Charles Saumarez Smith, who has a high regard for her work, especially admired her later commissioned portrait of the Samaritan founder Chad Varah, which he describes as: "One of the collection's finest small scale contemporary portraits".

After being awarded one of her many glittering prizes, the Villiers David Prize in 1994, Sarah made an important trip to "the baked bush of Australia", as she called it. She was there for six weeks, making a breakthrough in her career with a series of majestic, arid landscapes of the bush. Leaving her husband, the publisher Nick McDowell, with their two small daughters, she was briefly alone to explore an entirely new aspect of her artistic persona.

"For many years I had a yearning to visit the Australian outback," she later said. "To inhabit an unknown landscape, devoid of familiar forms, foliage of artistic iconography; to be shocked into reseeing the world as a stranger might, through innocent eyes. I had the opportunity to do things which can only be done when there is no one but oneself to be concerned with." She showed this work in her exhibition, Desert Paintings, at Agnew's and the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge in 1995.

I first met Sarah seven years ago at the National Portrait Gallery, when her portrait of the Guardian women writers had just been unveiled. I was instantly struck by her charm and her dark, dramatic beauty. We spoke of her commission, and how much she had enjoyed getting to know the writers, whom she much admired.

It was clear how deeply and passionately she cared about two things; her art and her daughters, Natasha, Anna, and Rebecca. We talked about having daughters as opposed to sons (both our experience) and her future plans for her work. I was particularly aware of how someone with every obvious advantage should not be content to rely on this alone.

The art world is often prone to pigeonhole artists and loathe to accept an established artist changing direction. But Raphael's last exhibition at Marlborough Fine Art, who became her dealers in 1998, showed more forcibly than ever her desire to continue to explore and experiment. Strip, in the summer of 1998, was a complete departure into a world of abstraction, using a collage-like assemblage of lusciously coloured shapes and invented objects.

I am certain that Strip was only the beginning of Sarah's journey away from what came perhaps too easily, towards something more challenging. Like any artist of real worth, she would have gone on pushing the boundaries and reinventing herself. Her death came far too soon.

She is survived by her husband, from whom she was separated, and her daughters.

 Sarah Natasha Raphael, painter, born August 10 1960; died January 10 2001

She did not want this. She wanted to make her own way as a painter, on her own terms, rejecting the silver spoon she had been handed from her wealthy and cultivated family background. As with many artists, drawing and making paintings was a crucial part of her life from earliest childhood. As a little girl aged seven, she was dazzled by the beauty of the Greek island Ios, where she lived with her family. She started painting it then and there with her little box of paints, and she would return to the motif later in adult life. Her father, the Oscar-winning writer Frederic Raphael, recognised his daughter's early precocity and always encouraged it. Later, at Bedales, art continued to be central to her life, so much so that, unusually, at 16 she left to study at Camberwell School of Art, instantly recognised as a student of unusual gifts. She told me, when we were talking of art school days, how frustrating she often found the somewhat dilatory approach of many fellow students. At Camberwell her terrible headaches were first diagnosed as migraine, a complaint that dogged her life as an artist, causing her such pain that she had to give up work for a couple of years both then, and later with the birth of her third daughter, Rebecca. Giving up work was an especial trial for her. The painkillers she was prescribed led to an addiction, which in turn had to be treated. The intensity of her focus on her work and the turpentine and oils she used were both thought to exacerbate her condition. She died from complications following pneumonia. Sarah's first major solo exhibition was at Agnew's, her first dealers, in 1989. At this point her portraits showed the marked influence of Lucian Freud. The combination of immaculate technique and psychological penetration in portrait studies such as Daisy and Simon demonstrated Sarah's extraordinary natural facility. Later she would rebel against her ability to paint in a more traditional, figurative style. She first came into the public eye in 1992, when an early portrait was shown at the National Portrait Gallery's Imperial Tobacco Award (now the BP Award). The gallery's director, Charles Saumarez Smith, who has a high regard for her work, especially admired her later commissioned portrait of the Samaritan founder Chad Varah, which he describes as: "One of the collection's finest small scale contemporary portraits". After being awarded one of her many glittering prizes, the Villiers David Prize in 1994, Sarah made an important trip to "the baked bush of Australia", as she called it. She was there for six weeks, making a breakthrough in her career with a series of majestic, arid landscapes of the bush. Leaving her husband, the publisher Nick McDowell, with their two small daughters, she was briefly alone to explore an entirely new aspect of her artistic persona. "For many years I had a yearning to visit the Australian outback," she later said. "To inhabit an unknown landscape, devoid of familiar forms, foliage of artistic iconography; to be shocked into reseeing the world as a stranger might, through innocent eyes. I had the opportunity to do things which can only be done when there is no one but oneself to be concerned with." She showed this work in her exhibition, Desert Paintings, at Agnew's and the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge in 1995. I first met Sarah seven years ago at the National Portrait Gallery, when her portrait of the Guardian women writers had just been unveiled. I was instantly struck by her charm and her dark, dramatic beauty. We spoke of her commission, and how much she had enjoyed getting to know the writers, whom she much admired. It was clear how deeply and passionately she cared about two things; her art and her daughters, Natasha, Anna, and Rebecca. We talked about having daughters as opposed to sons (both our experience) and her future plans for her work. I was particularly aware of how someone with every obvious advantage should not be content to rely on this alone. The art world is often prone to pigeonhole artists and loathe to accept an established artist changing direction. But Raphael's last exhibition at Marlborough Fine Art, who became her dealers in 1998, showed more forcibly than ever her desire to continue to explore and experiment. Strip, in the summer of 1998, was a complete departure into a world of abstraction, using a collage-like assemblage of lusciously coloured shapes and invented objects. I am certain that Strip was only the beginning of Sarah's journey away from what came perhaps too easily, towards something more challenging. Like any artist of real worth, she would have gone on pushing the boundaries and reinventing herself. Her death came far too soon. She is survived by her husband, from whom she was separated, and her daughters.  Sarah Natasha Raphael, painter, born August 10 1960; died January 10 2001

fields.headline: Kabila 'is lying in Zimbabwe morgue'
fields.trailText: The government of the Democratic Republic of Congo continued to claim that President Laurent Kabila was alive, if not well, last night even though one of his closest allies said his corpse was lying in a foreign morgue.
fields.body:
The government of the Democratic Republic of Congo continued to claim that President Laurent Kabila was alive, if not well, last night even though one of his closest allies said his corpse was lying in a foreign morgue.

But while almost everyone but Congo's government has come to believe Kabila is dead, there was uncertainty over the fate of his son, Joseph. Some reports said he had been killed with his father but others said he had succeeded him.

In Kinshasa the information minister, Dominique Sakombi, told state radio: "The government of public salvation met in a special session ... and decided to entrust the running of the government and military command to Major General Joseph Kabila."

The authorities were still insisting that Laurent Kabila survived being shot several times by one of his army officers on Tuesday. Mr Sakombi claimed he was being treated in Zimbabwe.

But Moven Mahachi, the defence minister of Zimbabwe and Kabila's close ally in Congo's war, yesterday said that Kabila died on the flight to Harare as his poorly equipped doctors fought to save him. Britain has joined other countries in saying it believes Kabila was killed.

Some western and African diplomats said they believed Joseph Kabila was assassinated but a British diplomatic source yesterday said he had been seen in Kinshasa.

An account circulating among Francophone diplomats in Kinshasa has it that Kabila's brutish ways finally backfired when he ordered the arrest of his former deputy defence minister, Colonel Dieudonne Kayembe.

Kabila has had a number of army officers shot for cowardice for failing to obey orders they thought misguided or irresponsible during the war against Rwandan and Ugandan-backed rebels. Some had simply been unwilling to throw away their men's lives.

Kabila's army commanders have little respect for him. The publicly cultivated image of him as the great liberator of Congo from the clutches of the late Mobutu Sese Seko does not wash in a country where almost everyone believes he was merely a front man for the Rwandan army when it invaded what was then Zaire in pursuit of Hutu extremists who led the 1994 genocide.

So when Kabila turned to his son, who is the head of the army, and ordered Joseph to arrest Col Kayembe, the soldier would have had good reason to fear for his life. According to one account, the colonel pulled his gun on the two Kabilas. The president took at least three bullets. His son was hit several times. Other senior officers and bodyguards drew their weapons and the shooting continued in and around the palace even after Laurent Kabila was bundled on to a helicopter.

Both Kabilas were taken by helicopter to hospital in Kinshasa. But with outdated equipment there was not much the doctors could do. So Laurent Kabila followed the path of so many privileged Congolese in need of medical treatment and was flown out of the country.

If Zimbabwe's defence minister is right, Kabila was dead before the 747 touched down in Harare. Mr Mahachi says the body is now lying in a Harare morgue.

Much of his close family was with him on the 747 in a flight reminiscent of the escape of Kabila's predecessor, the dying Mobutu, four years ago. Only Joseph Kabila was left behind.

Belgium sent 10 commandos to Gabon in central Africa yesterday in preparation for a possible evacuation of its nationals from Congo, a former colony.

webTitle: Dome sale talks falter over government profits clause

fields.headline: Dome sale talks falter over government profits clause
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The Irish backers of the Legacy consortium seeking to buy the Millennium Dome yesterday admitted the negotiations had run into problems, casting renewed doubts over the £125m deal.
fields.body:
The Irish backers of the Legacy consortium seeking to buy the Millennium Dome yesterday admitted the negotiations had run into problems, casting renewed doubts over the £125m deal.

Dublin-based Treasury Holdings accused the government of attempting to change the terms of the sale during recent negotiations.

Richard Barrett, Treasury's co-owner who will sit on the Legacy board, walked out of a meeting at the end of last week after a row over clauses guaranteeing Whitehall a share of any profits in the first 10 years and a slice of the money made if it is later sold.

The Irish backers, who would own 80% of the dome, are believed to feel the government is attempting to tighten the clauses to avoid later charges that it sold the complex too cheaply.

Legacy was made the "preferred bidder" last November when Japanese bank Nomura dropped out. The Irish deal is due to be signed next month. Treasury Holdings appear to be taking a tougher line than Robert Bourne, the British property developer who is Legacy's frontman and holds a 15% stake.

As Treasury played up the problems, a source close to Mr Bourne said: "There isn't anything that's going to be a deal breaker and we are confident that the deal will go ahead."

Waiting in the wings if the deal does collapse are Frenchman Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, who would keep it as an entertainment centre, property group Stanhope, and engineering outift Pell Frischmann.

These last two would develop the dome as a business complex.

Dome minister Lord Falconer's office last night appeared unconcerned by the threatening noises from the Dublin camp.

In difficult negotiations of this kind, ministers routinely expect the other side to complain of unfair treatment.

But the Tories, who are determined to make the dome a symbol of Labour waste and incompetence at the coming election, seized on media reports that there was to be an investigation of the Greenwich project.

Andrew Lansley, the shadow Cabinet Office spokesman, wrote to Sir John Bourn, the comptroller and auditor general who runs the national audit office.

In the light of Mr Bourne's admission that, while Legacy was emerging as preferred bidder, he gave Labour £30,000, part of a £100,000 gift to party funds, Mr Lansley asked Sir John "to ensure that the scope of your inquiry is concerned not only with the value for money aspects of the [dome] sale, but also the financial propriety of the process for making decisions on the sale which have involved ministers".

fields.headline: French attack Railtrack
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The French cried "foul" on the British yesterday and attacked Railtrack's threat to pull out of the second stage of the Channel tunnel rail link.
fields.body:
The French cried "foul" on the British yesterday and attacked Railtrack's threat to pull out of the second stage of the Channel tunnel rail link.

The criticism came from Guillaume Pepy, director of passenger services for SNCF, the French state-owned railway, in a put-down of Britain's dilapidated railway system. Mr Pepy said: "I am shocked. It's nonsense. It's incredible."

Mr Pepy, whose company has a big stake in Eurostar, said that the 72-mile journey from Folkestone to London on Eurostar was "sometimes a nightmare". He was speaking at the opening of the latest section of fast track that will join Paris and Marseilles via the TGV services. The journey time for the 466-mile journey will be two hours, 59 minutes.

Mr Pepy said the French were amazed that the British were still quibbling on finding the money to finance the second stage of the £2.5bn Channel tunnel link from Ebbsfleet in Kent to central London. The sum of money is exactly the cost of the final, 155-mile section of the TGV link between Paris and Marseilles. When the link is opened to the public in June, passengers from the UK will be able to go from London to Marseilles in seven hours, changing trains at Lille.

Jean Francois Bernard, director general of RFF, a publicly owned company but otherwise the equivalent of Railtrack, said: "Because the British system is private, it is bad, and it is bad for safety."

The problem with Britain's railways was insufficient investment over the years, added Mr Pepy.

SNCF receives £2.1bn from the French government to run its services compared with the £1.3bn which the 25 train operating companies get in Britain. RRF gets £1bn a year from the French government to maintain the railways.

webTitle: Byers casts doubt on air traffic bid

fields.headline: Byers casts doubt on air traffic bid
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: A government minister last night cast doubt over one of the three bids to run the air traffic control system when it is privatised, fuelling the controversy over the sale.
fields.body:
A government minister last night cast doubt over one of the three bids to run the air traffic control system when it is privatised, fuelling the controversy over the sale.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, sought assurances from one of the shortlisted consortiums over fears it would have a monopoly over the training of staff.

Serco, part of the the Nimbus bid, already provides services at a number of smaller airports including Biggin Hill, Sheffield and the Shetland Isles. "If the acquisition went ahead, the new company would have an effective monopoly in the training of UK air traffic controllers," said Mr Byers.

Serco indicated it would issue guarantees in an attempt to stay in the race for a 46% slice of the country's air traffic control network. A further 5% is earmarked for existing staff, with the government retaining a minority 49% stake.

The other two bidders are the Airline Group, a collection of eight airlines including British Airways and Virgin who would run it on a not-for-profit basis, and Novares, a consortium led by Lockheed Martin of the US.

The government is expected to make a decision within the next few weeks with the hand over timetabled for April.

MPs on the Commons transport committee yesterday urged the government to postpone the sale until the long-delayed new air traffic control centre at Swanwick in Hampshire is opened next year.

webTitle: Apple and IBM results show different views of US economy

fields.headline: Apple and IBM results show different views of US economy
fields.trailText: Two US computer manufacturers provided a mixed view of the economic slowdown last night when Apple Computer reported its first quarterly loss in more than three years, while IBM beat Wall Street estimates.
fields.body:
Two US computer manufacturers provided a mixed view of the economic slowdown last night when Apple Computer reported its first quarterly loss in more than three years, while IBM beat Wall Street estimates.

Apple's first-quarter results revealed the extent of the company's trading woes as consumers tired of the colourful iMac computers. In the three months to the end of December, Apple lost a net $247m (£168m) - or 73 cents per share - compared with a net profit of $183m a year ago. Analysts had been expecting the company to lose 65 cents per share this quarter, although last night's results were clouded by an accounting change and one-off investment gains. Sales more than halved from $2.3bn a year ago to $1bn in the period.

Apple sought to cheer investors when it said that it expected to return to profitability in the current quarter.

Shares in the company rose slightly in after-hours trading after losing about 70% of their value since September.

Steve Jobs, Apple's chief executive who returned to the company in 1997 and who took credit for the earlier turn around said the company was dealing with its stock surplus. "We took our medicine last quarter."

He added that the company had a strong pipeline for the coming year. However, Apple also reduced its sales expectations for 2001 for the second time in just over a month.

International Business Machines results provided a sharp contrast to those of Apple as Big Blue reported a 28% increase in quarterly earnings to $2.7bn, or $1.48, a share.

The company's better than expected earnings came on top of a 6% increase in sales to $25.6bn.

webTitle: Comment: Hugo Young on why Dubya will eventually be doomed

fields.headline: A surreal sleepwalker with little right to wield power
fields.standfirst:
George W Bush uncompromisingly seizes the prize as US president

Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: George W Bush uncompromisingly seizes the prize as US president.
fields.body:
The American political system is entirely different from the European, Anglos included. There's no possibility of anything resembling coalition government. The president is the chief executive and appoints his board of management, otherwise known as cabinet, which bears little resemblance to the British version. Government, as Bill Clinton has shown for eight years, needs to be a continuous process of negotiation with Congress. Deals on laws have to be struck within and across parties. But the president is the president, and there can be only one of him.

It should therefore not be surprising that George W Bush's run-up to his inauguration on Saturday has been executively efficient. Only one minister, the would-be labour secretary, proved dead before arrival. The Republican party network didn't go cold in eight years' absence from the White House. Reaching back to Bush I and Gerald Ford, Bush II could draw on a large cohort of departmental chiefs with a track record in the politico-business complex, and create a cabinet in his own image, which is to say, even in American terms, decidedly rightwing.

That's what the system permits, apparently requires. The newly elected president strides undeviating into office. And yet it is extraordinary. It knocks your eyes out. It may be what presidency needs, but its very smoothness is an amnesiac affront to what happened last November. It proceeds as if that election - at best inconclusive, at worst stolen - had nothing unusual about it, nothing that demanded a new kind of response. The transition has passed as if normality prevailed. This is a necessary consequence of the system, but it's one that surely won't stop there: a sleepwalk into pretence, from which Americans will one day wake up. The question is: when?

Mr Bush's reliance on tranquillity was always striking. Even before he could know the outcome would be very close, he pledged himself to a new kind of politics. It was an insistent part of his campaign. He promised an end to acrimony and division, a purging of the Washington he ridiculed. When the outcome proved unclear, you might have expected these promises to be redoubled. Instead, he reneged on them at every turn. The tighter the result, it seemed, the less not more consensus had to be sought.

First, his new agenda itself pays no regard to compromise. Bush thinks he was elected to do what he said he would do, irrespective of his failure to get a plurality of voters to back him. Thus, for example, he will now withdraw support from any aid organisation that promotes abortions abroad: a strident victory for anti-abortion colonisers. He will go ahead with energy prospecting in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, regardless of opposition. He announces a priority for reversing all Clinton's recent executive actions, especially in the environmental field. None of this has a unifying purpose.

Second, his appointment of John Ashcroft as attorney-general is not a gift to the nation but a gesture to the hard right. Ashcroft is not just an anti-liberal but a throwback to days one naively thought had gone for good from respectable federal politics: a racist, a gun-lobby man, anti-choice and anti-gay, as well as a senator prepared, according to the distinguished columnist Anthony Lewis, to lie to block the nomination of a judge he didn't like. A president humbled by the narrowness of his victory would have found an attorney-general who enjoyed bipartisan respect. Instead Bush puts in charge of the justice system a politician whom few people trust, and the Christian right does not want, to administer laws he disagrees with.

Third, Bush foreshadows a foreign policy which again moves far from the centre ground. He wants to rethink Russia, challenge China and build a national missile defence system. This may prove to be the policy zone where radical change is hardest to implement. We should wait and see what actually happens about NMD, under the hand of a sceptical secretary of state, Colin Powell. But the chorus demanding it, in Republican circles, deepens. All subtleties are swept aside by a state of mind that could hardly be further from the voice of a divided country. Before any of the technical or diplomatic arguments are heard, let alone concluded, comes the assertive claim to a power that brooks no interference. Hearing the voices of Republicanism triumphant, as I did at a recent American Enterprise Institute seminar, one can easily forget, as they do, that Bush got half a million fewer votes than Gore.

Such forceful nonchalance may not seem as startling to Americans as to a European. Maybe America agrees that it must have, above all, a government. Perhaps it doesn't mind much what kind. Maybe it will stand by and watch a rightwing government behaving in a rightwing way. The distance of most voters from Washington makes that easier. The absence of a truly national conversation helps. The closer reality of state governments can make federal anomalies irrelevant in many people's minds. This is a vast country. Besides, George W seems a regular guy, inoffensive, all-American, one of us.

Indifference to what's going on could run still deeper. Maybe the country, while evenly split as to voting, is not deeply divided as to the outcome. It is not, after all, an intensely ideological place. Visceral disagreements are confined to social/moral issues, pre-eminently guns and abortion. This is not a time for large statements, especially about the wider world. There being no Soviet menace, perhaps the identity of the national leader is no longer of vast importance. Such, at any rate, must be Bush's hope, as he reflects on the astounding fact that chance and chad have made him president.

I don't believe it will be justified. The system may not allow for coalitions, but the divisions of the electorate call for a coalitionist mentality to handle them. However confidently he moves to take the oath of office, Bush must offer something more subtle than the simple assertion of his power. To that extent, his confident behaviour now is a kind of sham. For the divisions are in truth very deep, geographically and racially if not so much in old-fashioned ideology: between cities and the country, between south-and-west and north-centre-and-east, between black (90-9 the respective Gore-Bush percentages) and white, above all between those who think Bush won and those who know he didn't.

Where these will cause explosions we cannot tell. But they will come. The serenity in which this surreal presidency begins is deceptive. Every mistake Bush makes will excite the same questions: who exactly is this man, and by what right is he there? The rituals of succession can take him to the White House, but provide no bulwark against the doubts that surround his locus, which he refuses, so far, to do anything to appease. The media, the Congress, many of the people, all conspire to make him seem as real as Ike or Reagan. But this can't last. Unless he finds a way to recognise the uniquely narrow limits of his victory, his presidency will unravel and Dubya will eventually be doomed.
