webTitle: DU admission stokes Gulf war health row

fields.headline: DU admission stokes Gulf war health row
fields.standfirst: Special report: depleted uranium
fields.trailText: Depleted uranium shells fired by Britain in the Gulf war and the US in Kosovo contained traces of plutonium and other highly radioactive particles, the Ministry of Defence and the US department of energy admitted yesterday.
fields.byline: Paul Brown, John Hooper  in Berlin, Ian Black  in Brussels,  and  Peter Capella  in Geneva
fields.body:
Depleted uranium shells fired by Britain in the Gulf war and the US in Kosovo contained traces of plutonium and other highly radioactive particles, the Ministry of Defence and the US department of energy admitted yesterday.

The fact that DU rounds used by British and US forces contain far more radioactive isotopes than uranium, which are more likely to cause cancer, is bound to fuel the controversy over Gulf war syndrome.

But the additional risk to British and US servicemen was minimal because the amounts of contaminants were so small, a MoD spokeswoman in London said yesterday, echoing a Nato statement issued in Brussels.

The International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna was not so sure that the dangers of uranium containing even traces of plutonium were small, saying there was no data on what happened to contaminated depleted uranium when released into the atmosphere.

David Kyd, spokesman for the agency, said: "The science simply can't provide the answers in terms of the long-term consequences. It is definitely worth investigating further, not only in the Balkans but also in Iraq."

In Germany, the defence minister, Rudolf Scharping, yesterday summoned the US charge d'affaires in Berlin to brief him on the issue.

The Ministry of Defence said the increase in radiation dose to British servicemen handling the shells and operating in tanks with DU shielding because of the contaminates was only 0.8%, so small as to be minimal.

However, other experts disagreed. John Large, of Large Associates, said: "Once this has been fired in anger and is lying about in dust, there is a huge difference in the dangers. A speck of plutonium is hundreds of times more dangerous than uranium."

Mr Large said the only way that products of nuclear fission known as transuranics - neptunium, plutonium, and americium - could get into depleted uranium was through reprocessing. "I am amazed they have done this."

Both the US and UK defence organisations denied the uranium had been reprocessed. The uranium had been supplied from the same civil source in the US and had accidently been contaminated because it had been placed in the same containers as reprocessed material.

Mr Kyd emphasised that the research so far on the effects of DU was derived from monitoring miners dealing with natural uranium or the consequences of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster.

Over the past 10 years of controversy about the impact of particles released when DU shells hit their target, there had been no civilian research on the battlefield until Nato told the UN where to find sites it examined in Kosovo last year.

The IAEA, which is taking part in the UN investigation, was offered some information about the effects of DU munitions by military sources, but Mr Kyd said it was "still sketchy on what happens after vaporisation".

Mr Scharping also ordered a German laboratory, testing samples from Kosovo, to look specifically for traces of plutonium. The University of Bristol is also testing Kosovo samples of depleted uranium.

Mr Scharping made the move after it became known that a German television programme to be transmitted tonight by the publicly-owned ARD channel will turn the spotlight on documents from the US Department of Defence which noted the possibility of plutonium traces in its weapons.

A spokesman for the US embassy in Berlin said the documents were openly available on US government websites.

webTitle: Straw acts to curb animal extremists

fields.headline: Straw acts to curb animal extremists
fields.standfirst: Move to end intimidation
fields.trailText: The government last night signalled its intent to drive through legislation, perhaps as soon as tomorrow, aimed at preventing animal activists violently intimidating staff at research laboratories.
fields.byline: Michael White, Steven Morris and Jill Treanor
fields.body:
The government last night signalled its intent to drive through legislation, perhaps as soon as tomorrow, aimed at preventing animal activists violently intimidating staff at research laboratories.

In another clear indication that the government is putting its weight behind the beleaguered research firm, Huntingdon Life Sciences (HLS), the home secretary, Jack Straw, also revealed that a one-off payment of £1m would go to help Cambridgeshire police's battle against extremists.

The announcements demonstrate the government's growing concern about the future of HLS, which could be forced to close tomorrow if the Royal Bank of Scotland bows to pressure from anti-vivisection campaigners and calls in a £22m loan which it has been extending since August.

Both Tony Blair and the science minister, Lord Sainsbury, have spoken out this week against the protesters. There is fear that jobs and millions pounds of business could be lost if laboratories like HLS are driven out of business.

Police confirmed for the first time yesterday that a series of nail bomb attacks sent through the mail to addresses in Cheshire, East Yorkshire, North Wales, West Midlands and North Yorkshire were the work of animal extremists.

webTitle: UK invests £2bn in new US fighter

fields.headline: UK invests £2bn in new US fighter
fields.standfirst: Britain seeks to secure 5,000 jobs in biggest military project
fields.trailText: Britain seeks to secure 5,000 jobs in biggest military project.
fields.body:
The government yesterday committed nearly £2bn to an American project to develop a new generation of fighter aircraft billed by Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, as the world's biggest ever military procurement programme.

Within 70 British companies, 5,000 jobs will be created or sustained, after the agreement signed in Washington yesterday setting out a new stage in the development of the US Joint Strike Fighter project, which could be worth up to $400bn (£272bn).

The JSF, which will replace Royal Navy and RAF Harrier jump jets, could ultimately cost the UK £10bn and create or guarantee a further 7,000 jobs. The supersonic fighters will serve on two new aircraft carriers due to enter service in 2012 at a cost of £2.7bn.

Doubts were raised about whether the George W Bush administration or US congress would sanction the JSF programme though the incoming president pledged to raise defence spending by $60bn a year. Donald Rumsfeld, Bush's defence secretary, has put all big projects under review. But Mr Hoon said yesterday he was confident it would go ahead.

The sheer scale of the project into which the government has locked itself raises profound financial and military issues for Britain's relationship with both the US, its traditional ally, and with the emerging European joint defence force.

Britain so far plans to buy only 150 JSFs, while the USAF, its navy and marines intend buying 3,000 of the fighters, which, according to Sir Robert Walmsley, chief of defence procurement, should cost $30m-40m each. Export orders could boost the programme to 5,000 aircraft involving both conventional and short take-off and vertical landing models.

Mr Hoon said the JSF would play a "crucial part in continuing our transatlantic partnership, maintaining Nato interoperability and improving European military capability".

Britain has one of four votes on key decisions of the project such as choice of prime contractor. Boeing and Lockheed Martin, America's two biggest defence contractors, are head to head bidders to win the lucrative contract. Industry sources said yesterday the Pentagon should choose its prime contractor in September, and production would begin in 2004, with the first planes in service in the US in 2008.

British firms have won at least 15% of the work on the project, a share that may seem disproportionate to the US. The UK's share of the cost of the engineering, manufacturing and design phase meanwhile is just 10% (£1.3bn), with a further £600m for UK communications equipment, weapons systems and missiles.

Phil Lader, outgoing US ambassador, said the success of British firms in winning a substantial work share reflected "transatlantic linkage" which had seen British firms, such as BAE Systems, taking over American defence firms.

Menzies Campbell, Liberal Democrat defence spokesman, said of the project: "The government is between a rock and a hard place. Unless we participate, employment and technology opportunities will be lost. But if the [project] founders... it's by no means certain we'd get value for money."

webTitle: £74,000 for son man did not live to see

fields.headline: £74,000 for son man did not live to see
fields.trailText: A four-year-old boy has won almost £74,000 in compensation for the loss of his father who was killed before he was born.
fields.body:
A four-year-old boy has won almost £74,000 in compensation for the loss of his father who was killed before he was born.

The mother of Liam MacIntosh brought the civil action on behalf of her son over the death of his father, Matthew Jackson, killed in a road accident in 1995 at the age of 19.

Lynsey MacIntosh, 23, from Monifieth, near Dundee, had been unaware that she was pregnant at the time of her fiance's death but told the court of session in Edinburgh that Matthew Jackson would have made a wonderful father.

She said Liam, born almost eight months after Mr Jackson's death, had been deprived of his father's guidance, company and financial support and would grieve when he was old enough to appreciate the circumstances of his father's death.

The court heard that Liam had been told about his father, and had photos and a video of him.

Mr Jackson was a passenger in a car being driven by his friend, Stuart Findlay, 19, which crossed on to the opposite carriageway near Arbroath on September 5, 1995, and collided with a lorry. Both men were killed and Liam's damages claim was brought against Mr Findlay's parents, Alex and Ann Findlay, of Arbroath, as his next-of-kin and insurers. There was no dispute that Stuart Findlay was to blame for the accident.

Miss MacIntosh had sought £150,000 on behalf her son, £50,000 for loss of society and £100,000 for loss of support. At the time of his death, Mr Jackson, who had spent time in the merchant navy, was working as a labourer.

Yesterday the judge, Lord Kingarth, told the jury that it was very difficult to put a monetary value on the loss of a parent's love, guidance and financial support. After deliberating for two hours, the jury unanimously awarded Liam £73,900, £37,500 for loss of society, and £36,400 for loss of support.

In her evidence, Miss MacIntosh told the jury she believed she and her fiance would have gone on to get married and that Mr Jackson would have been a proud and enthusiastic father.

Her counsel, Andrew Smith, told the court the claim was Liam's "only chance" to obtain damages for loss of his father.

Colin MacAulay QC, counsel for Mr and Mrs Findlay, asked the jury to take into account what might have happened had the crash not occurred. "What you have to decide is what might have happened had Matthew not died."

Liam's paternal grandfather, Nick Jackson, of Letham, Angus, told the court: "I was very proud of Matthew. He loved children. He was an extremely sensitive and generous guy."

webTitle: Letsbuyit is one day from collapse

fields.headline: Letsbuyit is one day from collapse
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Online retailer Letsbuyit.com moved a step closer to collapse yesterday after its administrators announced they were filing for bankruptcy.
fields.body:
Online retailer Letsbuyit.com moved a step closer to collapse yesterday after its administrators announced they were filing for bankruptcy.

Three weeks of rescue talks with administrators appear to have failed and it is not known whether creditors will recover the money they are owed.

Administrators for the Amsterdam-based company, which arranges for consumers to pool their buying and bargaining power for goods, said the application for bankruptcy would go before the Amsterdam district court tomorrow. This leaves the company with little over a day to put together a rescue package.

A source close to Letsbuyit said the company was still optimistic about finding further funding.

The website last night gave no indication of bankruptcy, saying only: "Unfortunately, we are currently unable to take any orders. We apologise for this inconvenience but hope to resume normal service soon."

Shares in the group, whose holding company is Dutch but whose website is based in London, were yesterday suspended at €0.46(29p), a fraction of their July 21 peak of€6.45 posted on their stock market debut.

Letsbuyit, best known for its advertising campaign featuring ants showing strength in numbers, won protection from creditors chasing debt repayments at the end of last year.

The company's financial history has been difficult. Its flotation was postponed twice and raised just half the money it had expected. Its shares were eventually placed at €3.50 each. It now needs an extra £50m of funding.

Heidi Fitzpatrick, an internet analyst at Lehman Brothers, said she would be surprised if the company found a buyer.

The company has been linked to possible rescue packages by French-based Dealpartners.com and Norwegian CoShopper.

fields.headline: Workers living in fear
fields.trailText: As far as the workers at Huntingdon Life Sciences are concerned, the Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty (Shac) campaigners are not just demonstrators. They are terrorists.
fields.body:
As far as the workers at Huntingdon Life Sciences are concerned, the Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty (Shac) campaigners are not just demonstrators. They are terrorists.

For more than a year employees - not just scientists but administrators, clerks and cleaners - have been subjected to daily abuse as they arrive at and leave work. If they can get away with it, demonstrators hurl stones at their cars. Workers often need a police escort.

Throughout the day, at their desks and in their laboratories, workers can hear activists outside yelling slogans through loud hailers and setting off horns. The company has offered counselling to employees.

Shac's tactic of publishing names, addresses and telephone numbers of workers on the internet and in its magazine, then encouraging volunteers to - in its own words - "Go get 'em", has turned Huntingdon Life Sciences (HLS) into a place of real fear.

Since March last year five employees have had their cars torched. Firebombs have been found under another five cars. Some employees have received threatening mail at home and crowds of protesters have gathered outside their houses.

In the most serious incident a senior manager returned home just before Christmas to find two men in balaclavas. They sprayed chemicals in his eyes and punched him. The beating was "just for starters" - they would be back if he continued to work for HLS.

Jim, a 32-year-old administrator, said the mood at the company was one of fear and determination. His address has been published and he has had to stop his partner's children from opening mail.

Christmas and birthdays are a worry. "Every time the post arrives we have to check what has arrived. Every time the phone rings late at nigh there is concern. Whenever someone knocks on the door you wonder who it could be."

But still workers do not believe they should give in. Jim said that last year a protester had an asthma attack. A police officer used an inhaler to treat her. Jim said: "A security guard looked at the make and it turned out to be one that we helped develop. We know that our job is necessary."

webTitle: Rapper Puff Daddy says his fame puts fair trial in doubt

fields.headline: Rapper Puff Daddy says his fame puts fair trial in doubt
fields.trailText: Sean "Puffy" Combs looked just like any other multimillionaire when he appeared in a Manhattan courtroom yesterday in a navy pin-stripe suit, dove-grey tie and matching handkerchief.
fields.body:
Sean "Puffy" Combs looked just like any other multimillionaire when he appeared in a Manhattan courtroom yesterday in a navy pin-stripe suit, dove-grey tie and matching handkerchief.

But the fame of the 31-year-old rapper and record producer better known as Puff Daddy is such that his lawyers warned the judge trying him for gun possession and bribery that it might be impossible to find a single unbiased juror.

In some ways it was his fame and wealth that landed him in court in the first place. During a nightclub fracas on December 27 1999 an unidentified man - apparently incensed by the star's gold jewellery, mink coat and enormous diamond ring - is understood to have thrown thousands of dollars into his face.

Jamal Barrow, aka "Shyne", Mr Comb's 19-year-old protege, is alleged to have taken such offence at this that he opened fire into the crowd, injuring three innocent clubgoers.

Mr Combs allegedly then rushed out of the club with his girlfriend, the film star Jennifer Lopez, and his bodyguard, Anthony "Wolf" Jones, and began a car ride which took them across several pavements and through 11 red lights.

The police officers who stopped them found a loaded gun under the passenger seat, moments after another had been tossed out of the window, according to court documents.

Mr Combs is charged with offering his driver, Wardel Fenderson, $50,000 to say that the gun was his. It is claimed that he offered his $40,000 diamond ring - a gift from Ms Lopez - as collateral.

Mr Barrow is charged with attempted murder, Mr Combs and Mr Jones with illegal gun possession. If found guilty Mr Combs can be jailed for 15 years.

The defence lawyers say they have 30 witnesses ready to testify that Mr Combs had no gun.

The rapper is using some of his estimated $400m fortune on the services of two of America's best known defence lawyers.

In court yesterday he sat be tween Johnnie Cochran, who led the so-called "dream team" hired to defend OJ Simpson, and Ben Brafman, whose past clients include the mobster Sammy "The Bull" Gravano.

Mr Brafman asked for a week's delay, citing what he called negative media reports about the rapper's past run-ins with the law.

He said: "A lot of what I read in the papers has been totally inaccurate and sometimes so patently false that it doesn't even warrant a response."

The assistant district attorney, Matthew Bogdanos, has already asked for a gagging order after taking exception to some positive newspaper articles.

In several interviews since being arrested, Mr Combs has spoken of the pain he was causing his two sons, Justin, six, and Quincy, eight, and his fear on the night of the fight.

"I was definitely scared to death," he told the New York Daily News.

"I was especially scared because I had Jennifer with me. I'm an innocent man and I want everyone to know."

The prosecution is also afraid that the respect many rap fans feel for Puff Daddy could make it harder to select a jury. Each potential juror will face a 30-minute grilling by the defence team.

Judge Charles Solomon said he was satisfied that sufficient precautions had been taken to ensure a fair trial when he denied a defence request for more time yesterday.

The selection of a jury is likely to take at least a week. The trial is expected to last five weeks.

fields.headline: Brewery's half measures down at the pub
fields.standfirst: S&N must prove its policy
fields.trailText: Anyone dropping into their local for a quick pint tonight should find time for a sympathetic word with the bar staff. There is a one in 10 chance that the building is up for sale and that the employees are worried about their future.
fields.body:
Anyone dropping into their local for a quick pint tonight should find time for a sympathetic word with the bar staff. There is a one in 10 chance that the building is up for sale and that the employees are worried about their future.

Scottish & Newcastle joined the stampede to the estate agent yesterday, with plans to sell 740 outlets. Large estates are already up for grabs at Whitbread, Bass and Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries, which means more than 10% of the country's 60,000-odd pubs are looking for an owner. S&N chairman Brian Stewart blamed regulations for the industry's sudden indifference towards boozers. He pointed out that even the smallest pub now needs a hi-tech air extraction system, and the minimum wage has reduced sinking profits.

Static beer prices have handicapped the industry in recent years, as has a change in habits - young people tend to travel out of their neighbourhoods to drink, preferring "destination" bars.

However, Mr Stewart's solution goes only half way. A fifth of S&N's remaining 1,400 managed pubs have unexceptional takings of less than £8,000 a week and there are question marks about its brands. Chef & Brewer is a success, but interestingly, the company is reining back its plans for Rat & Parrot.

There is no longer much fundamental logic in a brewer owning pubs. Beer brands have become international, relying on multi-million pound advertising campaigns to attract customers, rather than a local following in "tied" estates.

Mr Stewart points out that pubs are a good "window" for trials, and launches of products, but the remaining estate -1,400 managed, and a further 1,200 pubs on leases - seems a little excessive for that purpose alone.

S&N has had a rough time recently - the sale of Center Parcs dragged on for months and the firm was accused of overpaying for Kronenbourg. Mr Stewart faces a critical year in which he must prove pubs are sufficiently attractive to warrant a place in the company.

Flawed analysis

Performance league tables: the City is as hooked on the things as every other sector of society. So when an annual survey appears, such as the Reuters/Tempest European larger company research listings published yesterday, investment banks just race to the results. The rankings spell serious money. Stuart Birdt and his newly established team monitoring the telecoms sector for Deutsche Bank, for example, have probably already lodged a fresh turbo-charged pay claim.

According to votes from the telecoms industry, the German bank is the best authority in London on the subject, having been nowhere a year ago. Meanwhile, Birdt's oppo at Goldman Sachs, the seasoned James Golob, looks to have gone ex-growth. His ranking has fallen from first to third according to the companies' vote, which has more than halved. Golob's only consolation is that he held second place in the sector according to votes from fund managers, who reckon James Ratzer and his bloated team at UBS Warburg provide the best research coverage.

For what it is worth, Deutsche and Goldman shared the overall Tempest honours this year, with fund managers favouring the Germans across all sectors and companies themselves plumping for the Americans.

But Tempest has also come to some startling conclusions in the wake of this survey. There is said to be a growing disenchantment with the role of some analysts in corporate transactions - acting as part-time corporate financiers and potentially obscuring their investment judgment in the process. The evidence is reckoned to be in the sharp differences of opinion between fund managers and quoted companies over who are the best analysts within each sector. Tempest also points to a noticeable shift in the pattern of commission payments made by fund managers to investment banks, moving away from sector-focused stock research towards general strategy research.

Now, some in the City might quibble over the depth of Tempest's research. Others might point out that there is serious competition to publish the "benchmark" analysts' league table (Extel has a more established award series for analysts), and perhaps accuse Tempest of going for sensationalised news to drum up publicity.

It coincides with developments elsewhere. In the US, regulators are looking at the relationship between commission payments paid to investment banks for research and the allocation of stock in popular flotations, while in Britain there have been suggestions that the Treasury-commissioned institutional investment review being conducted by Paul Myners, chairman of Gartmore (and of the Guardian Media Group), might be broadened to investigate the independence of analysts' research.

A thorough debate on this subject is long overdue.

webTitle: Affinity transports Lakeside mall experience to cyberspace

fields.headline: Affinity transports Lakeside mall experience to cyberspace
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Affinity Internet, provider of branded online services to companies such as Egg and Powergen, yesterday announced it is developing cyberspace shopping malls.
fields.body:
Affinity Internet, provider of branded online services to companies such as Egg and Powergen, yesterday announced it is developing cyberspace shopping malls.

Affinity saw its shares rise 17.5p to 467.5p after announcing a link-up with South African-controlled Liberty, the investor and developer which owns malls such as Lakeside in Thurrock and MetroCentre, Gateshead. Affinity and Liberty have each bought a one-third share in Mall-UK, which is to open a virtual shopping centre based on Lakeside.

Customers will be able to choose goods from several shops bearing established brands and pay just once by credit card at the end of their shopping trip.

Wayne Lochner, Affinity's chief executive officer, said: "It will enable the customer to continue being loyal to their shopping centre without having to go there. They will be able to enjoy the same shopping experience from the comfort of their armchair."

Affinity is supplying services rather than cash for its stake, worth around £2.5m, in the venture. Terry Plummer, chairman of Affinity, said: "The combination of Affinity technology platforms, the ideas and implementation of the Mall-UK management and access to a large customer base provides a major commercial opportunity for the partners in this venture."

The online mall will open in June and the group plans to roll out by next Christmas a further nine in Britain, based on sites such as the Harlequin in Watford and Victoria Centre in Nottingham. The idea will then be taken overseas over the next 18 months.

Affinity will make money by charging shops rent for web space.

webTitle: Russia halts military cuts as hawks take over in US

fields.headline: Russia halts military cuts as hawks take over in US
fields.standfirst:
Missile defence plans strengthen the Kremlin hardman's arm

Special report: Russia
Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: Missile defence plans strengthen the Kremlin hardman's arm
fields.body:
The Kremlin has shelved plans to cut and restructure the Russian armed forces radically, a decision seen by Moscow analysts as its first concrete response to the incoming Bush administration's decision to press ahead with the "son of Star Wars" national missile defence system.

In November, after months of infighting between military commanders, President Vladimir Putin ordered them to put their house in order by reducing the 1.2m under arms by 360,000 in the next five years. He also ordered a shift in emphasis from the strategic nuclear missiles to conventional forces.

The reshaping was to have begun last month, but nothing will happen until March at the earliest. "The main reason for the delay is the first steps of the new US leadership," the respected military analyst Viktor Litovkin said.

Only time will tell whether Presidents Putin and Bush will strike up a friendly relationship, but the early signs are of increasing hostility between Moscow and Washington on security, arms control and economic and financial issues.

In the past few weeks Washington has accused Moscow of covertly deploying battlefield nuclear weapons in Kaliningrad, its westernmost enclave, and has been angered by Russian moves to invigorate arms sales to Iran.

Moscow, in turn, accused the US last week of breaching the Start-I nuclear arms reduction agreement by going ahead with the national missile defence system (NMD). Mr Putin described the Kaliningrad allegation as "total rubbish."

George W Bush indicated at the weekend that his administration would halt much financial aid to Russia.

Yesterday the chairman of the Russian parliament's budget committee, Alexander Zhukov, brusquely responded: "Russia does not need large loans from foreign countries at the moment."

Yuri Gladkevich, a military observer at Moscow's independent Military News Agency, said: "There are signs of a worsening in relations, and it looks as though things will get a lot worse yet."

Moscow analysts see the people Mr Bush has named for his key cabinet posts - Dick Cheney, Donald Rumsfeld, Colin Powell and Condoleezza Rice - as hawks from a bygone era.

"These are people who see themselves as the victors of the cold war," said Alexander Golts, military commentator on the news magazine Itogi.

"The Kremlin and the generals are flattered by that, because it reminds them of the days of the USSR when they were a great power. But the new American administration is making a very strong and negative impact on our military."

Moscow sent three warships on patrol in the Pacific on Monday, its most ambitious naval display since the Soviet Union collapsed a decade ago.

Mr Putin has been pushing for a radical overhaul of the armed forces since the Kursk submarine disaster August, and that has provoked a public brawl between the defence minister, Igor Sergeyev, and the chief of the general staff, Anatoly Kvashnin, who wants the currently separate strategic missile forces integrated with the army, navy and air branches and scarce resources redirected to building up conventional forces.

Gen Kvashnin was generally supposed to be getting the better of the struggle, but Marshal Sergeyev's hand may have been strengthened by the new US administration's robust militaristic signals and "new realism" in international relations.

"Sergeyev wants to maintain the strategic missile forces as a political-military instrument, as the main lever for pressure on the US and Nato," Mr Gladkevich said.

"The new US administration means Putin won't weaken the strategic missiles forces to the degree that Kvashnin wants."

In the past year the Kremlin has repeatedly stated that it wants major arms reductions, including cutting its stockpile of nuclear warheads to 1,500. But Alexei Arbatov, an influential moderate on the parliamentary defence committee, now argues that Russia needs 4,500 nuclear warheads to maintain parity with the US.

"The Kremlin sees NMD as as threat to Russia's national security which will ignite a new arms race it can't afford," Mr Gladkevich said.

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: The Burren, Ireland
fields.trailText: The Burren, Ireland
fields.body:
Cheese... It was nothing like cheese. The night following its eclipse, splendid here, it shone above Finnavara and our bay like a beautiful peach, one just plucked from the tree, with a delicate bloom, a perfect moon. It cast its light on hill and sea, warming their cold and icy look with its "sprinkled blush" (Marianne Moore).

So the first year of the millennium has ended, though for many it now begins with 2001. What has our small country done to celebrate this past year? Each baby born on January 1, 2000 received a silver salver, and silver tokens were given to those who turned 100. How, it might be asked, did the environment fare? - it got the biggest grant. In 14 forests 1,200,000 trees (oaks and other broad-leaved varieties) were planted, one for each household, with a certificate issued of the location and species.

To match this, people here paid 10 punt each to plant a belt of trees beside the new playing field. As the old Irish poem Cill Cais asks, "Cad a dheanfaimid feasta gan adhmaid?" (What will we do without wood?) Brigid was released on Cullenstown Strand, the 100th seal cared for and then freed from the National Sanctuary. Golden eagles, extinct here for years, will, it is hoped, fly over Donegal from their new breeding sites in Glenveagh National Park. Dublin's River Liffey was enhanced by a new pedestrian bridge and a short boardwalk.

Amy Sweeney, aged 11, wrote of her hopes for the new millennium. "That all the problems of the world - war, famine, poverty, pollution - will be solved. I also would like Sligo to win an all-Ireland football final." (Gaelic football)

fields.headline: Cardinal proclaims Estrada's guilt as Filipinos crowd the streets
fields.trailText: Tens of thousands of people returned to the the streets in the Philippines yesterday to press their demand for the resignation of President Joseph Estrada as the senate adjourned his impeachment trial indefinitely.
fields.body:
Tens of thousands of people returned to the the streets in the Philippines yesterday to press their demand for the resignation of President Joseph Estrada as the senate adjourned his impeachment trial indefinitely.

The trail in effect collapsed on Tuesday when the senator-judges voted by a majority of one not to investigate the president's bank accounts, and the prosecution resigned.

At yesterday's 30-minute session the senators adjourned the trial until new prosecutors are appointed. But the resignation of the old team means any new team will not be taken seriously.

Led by the Archbishop of Manila, Cardinal Jaime Sin, the former presidents Fidel Ramos and Corazon Aquino, and the current vice-president, Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo, yesterday's demonstrations took on a more militant tone than previous protests. There were calls for civil disobedience and strikes.

Cardinal Sin said in his sermon at a street mass in Manila: "Truth has become a victim of immoral people."

"With all the evidence already presented, only the foolish and the crazy will say that he is as innocent as a dove and pure as a baby."

The senators voted 11-10 on Tuesday not to admit potentially crucial prosecution evidence: sealed bank records which allegedly show a small proportion of the wealth amassed in office by Mr Estrada, who is accused of corruption, bribery and abuse of office.

Cardinal Sin said: "[the senators] did not vote to tell us the truth. They voted to hide it from us. How can you not be angry?"

He was speaking to a noisy but good-natured congregation, ranging from stockbrokers to nun. Protests were staged in several other cities. But practically none of the country's poor people were present, and the organisers admit that a repeat of the "people power" movement of 1986 which deposed Ferdinand Marcos was unlikely without their support.

If the protests grow, then Mr Estrada's grip on power may last only for days. But if they get no bigger he will probably survive, at least until after the congressional elections in May, according to Salacnib Baterina, one of the prosecutors.

"He cannot buy the elections," Mr Baterina said. "The people cannot be fooled all the time."

Until then the army will hold the key to the political future. "The economy has already collapsed, so for the sake of the country they could well be the protectors of the interests of the Filipinos," he said.

The chaos sent the stock market and peso tumbling.

Ms Macapagal-Arroyo believes that plots are already being hatched to form a civilian junta.

"[But] the people will certainly oppose this ... and you will bear the brunt of their collective indignation," she said in a statement.

Mr Estrada remained in his palace yesterday. He issued a statement calling for calm, strength and guidance.

webTitle: Trouble brews in land of Burma's boy rebels

fields.headline: Trouble brews in land of Burma's boy rebels
fields.standfirst: Rangoon and Bangkok put squeeze on ethnic Karen separatists
fields.trailText: Rangoon and Bangkok put squeeze on ethnic Karen separatists
fields.body:
The surrender to the Thai authorities on Tuesday of the twin boys who led a mystical band of Burmese rebels consigns one of the world's most romantic independence movements to the history books.

Ever since taking dozens of people hostage in a Thai hospital 12 months ago, Johnny and Luther Htoo's ragtag militia, God's Army, has captured the imagination of the west.

These ardent Christian child warriors - thought to be barely more than 13 years old - with allegedly supernatural powers were seen as bravely standing up to the Burmese and Thai armies in their quest for a homeland for the Karen people.

The deeper truth is that the boys were driven to their desperate acts by the unrelenting pressure of constant military bombardment by both the Thais and Burmese.

The struggle continues

The folly at the hospital in Ratchaburi, where all the hostage-takers were murdered by Thai commandos, was the last roll of the dice by a movement on the brink of elimination.

But the fall of Johnny, Luther and God's Army does not mean that the wider Karen struggle for an independent homeland along the Thai-Burmese border, which began 52 years ago, has come to an end.

The Karen, variously Buddhist, Buddhist-animist and Christian, fought alongside the British against the Japanese in the second world war but received no reward for their efforts.

Since Burmese independence they have never really lived in peace.

Although eclipsed in fame by the twins, the Karen National Union (KNU) and the Karen National Liberation Army (KNLA) are much larger organisations and still very much alive, if not that well.

Both have suffered extremely heavy losses in the past few years as the onslaught against them has intensified.

But some analysts believe that the defeats have actually transformed them, particularly the KNU, into much more effective fighting forces. Instead basing itself in big camps susceptible to attack, the Karen resistance now concentrates on hit-and-run raids.

A typical recent example was an attack at the end of last year on half a dozen illegal sawmills deep inside Burma.

Not only do they have to contend with the official armies, the Karen also constantly suffer at the hands of the myriad armed narcotics gangs taking their wares across the Burmese border into Thailand.

It is thought that one of these gangs was responsible for the murder of six Thai villagers on December 30, although the Burmese and the Thais have tried to blame the KNU.

The KNU responded immediately with a strong condemnation of the killing in a statement which also summarised the movement's goals. "Together with the Burmese democratic forces and the non-Burman ethnic nationalities," it said, "we, the KNU, are struggling for freedom and democracy, against the ruthless military dictatorship, in order to establish a peaceful and friendly Burma for all the neighbours of the country, and will always oppose tyranny, oppression and terrorism against the innocent people".

Refugee camps

The most visible legacy of all this oppression is the 150,000 Karens (out of an ethnic population of about 7m) living in appalling conditions in refugee camps in Thailand.

Recent research shows that tens of thousands of them have malaria, tuberculosis is rife and HIV and Aids are starting to take a grip.

Foreign aid does reach the camps on a periodic basis but there are no signs of a long-term solution anywhere in sight.

The same can be said for the main independence struggle. The Karen receive next to nothing by way of international support for their cause as they get squeezed into an ever smaller area.

Their plight could well deteriorate further once the new Thai prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, takes office and seeks to strengthen relations with Rangoon.

But despite their invisibility to most of the wider world, the Karen people show no signs of giving up their fight.

"Together with the Burmese democratic forces and the non-Burman ethnic nationalities," it said, "we, the KNU, are struggling for freedom and democracy, against the ruthless military dictatorship, in order to establish a peaceful and friendly Burma for all the neighbours of the country, and will always oppose tyranny, oppression and terrorism against the innocent people". Refugee camps The most visible legacy of all this oppression is the 150,000 Karens (out of an ethnic population of about 7m) living in appalling conditions in refugee camps in Thailand. Recent research shows that tens of thousands of them have malaria, tuberculosis is rife and HIV and Aids are starting to take a grip. Foreign aid does reach the camps on a periodic basis but there are no signs of a long-term solution anywhere in sight. The same can be said for the main independence struggle. The Karen receive next to nothing by way of international support for their cause as they get squeezed into an ever smaller area. Their plight could well deteriorate further once the new Thai prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, takes office and seeks to strengthen relations with Rangoon. But despite their invisibility to most of the wider world, the Karen people show no signs of giving up their fight.

webTitle: India greets Li with missile test

fields.headline: India greets Li with missile test
fields.standfirst: Special report: India and Pakistan
fields.trailText: India flexed its nuclear muscles yesterday, test-firing its latest long-range ballistic missile, the Agni II, amid signs of a growing consensus among Indian scientists that the country needs to carry out another round of nuclear tests.
fields.body:
India flexed its nuclear muscles yesterday, test-firing its latest long-range ballistic missile, the Agni II, amid signs of a growing consensus among Indian scientists that the country needs to carry out another round of nuclear tests.

The missile was fired from an island off the eastern state of Orissa yesterday morning, in what defence officials said was its "final operational configuration".

The Agni II has a range of 1,560 miles (2,500km), making it capable of delivering a nuclear warhead anywhere in Pakistan and, more importantly, into most of China.

The timing of the test surprised observers, coinciding with a state visit to India by China's second most powerful man, Li Peng, who planted a tree yesterday in the country's silicon valley, the southern city of Bangalore.

It also comes as India and Pakistan, the world's two newest nuclear powers, embark on tentative peace negotiations for the disputed territory of Kashmir.

A Pakistan foreign ministry official yesterday accused India of trying to destabilise the region. Local experts, however, saw the test more as a missive.

"We don't know how far in advance this test was decided upon. But there is no doubt it sends a message to China, a message to Pakistan, and a message to the US," Indian nuclear analyst Achin Vanaik said last night.

"Agni II is a crucial part of India's evolving nuclear programme," he said.

India's Hindu nationalist-led government will be keen to see what response, if any, its latest test provokes from the incoming administration in Washington. The new regime under George W Bush is thought likely to shelve demands that India become a signatory to the comprehensive test ban treaty - a long-standing demand during the Clinton era. It may also abolish sanctions imposed on India after its controversial nuclear tests at Pokharan in 1998.

Mr Bush's election victory has strengthened the hands of the hawkish members of India's nuclear establishment, who argue that data obtained from its tests two years ago is "inadequate". More tests are needed, they say, if India is to develop a credible nuclear capability.

"The international scientific community does not regard the 1998 tests as a success. They were something of a damp squib. With George W Bush in the White House, it is very much a possibility that India will carry out further nuclear tests...," one source said last night.

New Delhi has dismissed this prospect. "I've seen the data and its fine," one senior aide to India's prime minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee said recently.

It is, however, working on a longer-range intercontinental version of the missile, which could reach central China. That missile will be test-fired "sooner than expected", India's defence minister, George Fernandes, said recently.

webTitle: Rare Armenian manuscripts exhibited for first time

fields.headline: Rare relics
fields.standfirst: Treasures from first Christian state on show for first time
fields.trailText: Some of the oldest and rarest manuscripts from the world's first Christian state are to go on show later this year at one of the biggest exhibitions ever mounted at the British Library in London.
fields.body:
Some of the oldest and rarest manuscripts from the world's first Christian state are to go on show later this year at one of the biggest exhibitions ever mounted at the British Library in London.

The documents, including hand-illuminated sixth century gospels, bound in silver and ivory, come from Armenia, which became the first country in the world to adopt Christianity as its state religion, in 301, a decade before the Roman empire.

Some of the relics have never been taken out of the country, on the borders of Turkey and Georgia, before. They have survived a succession of foreign occupations, from the Persians to the Soviet Union.

Vrej Nersessian, the library's Armenian specialist, said: "We have been part of at least 30 empires - it is such a long history that time does not matter.

"The Soviets are no longer there but our culture remains. The church is a strong part of our identity."

He recalled grimly the Turks scoffing "Who now remembers the Armenians?" after they had perpetrated the first act of genocide of the 20th century, wiping out vast numbers of the Armenian population in 1915.

The exhibition - called Treasures from the Ark, in commemoration of the belief that Noah landed on Mount Ararat, Armenia's national symbol, after the flood - has been 10 years in the making. It will run from March 2 until May 28. Treasures on display will include an Armenian stone cross, strikingly similar to Celtic crosses dating from the same period in Ireland, reliquaries, a 17th century altar cloth from the Armenian patriarchate in Jerusalem, and even the 15th century doors from a monastery.

The organisers have cajoled exhibits from 20 countries, including the Hermitage at St Petersburg and collections in Venice and Vienna, both homes of the Armenian diaspora, though not from Georgia or Iran as relations remain too fraught.

The library itself already has one of the world's best collections of Armenian manuscripts, many of them donated by Lord Curzon in 1917 though it started collecting much earlier when the curators were impressed by an Armenian dictionary in 1836.

The Christian world is preparing to commemorate the 1,700th anniversary of Armenia's conversion by King Trdat I and St Gregory the Illuminator.

The Pope hopes to pay a visit later in the year and the Archbishop of Canterbury has spoken of the inspiration of the country's enduring faith.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Nothing so mundane as coincidence can explain the fact that the internet adoption story broke barely a week after "Britain's leading paranormalist" Uri Geller launched his online novel, Nobody's Child, which is about couples fighting each other for an unclaimed baby under the gaze of TV cameras.
fields.body:
 Nothing so mundane as coincidence can explain the fact that the internet adoption story broke barely a week after "Britain's leading paranormalist" Uri Geller launched his online novel, Nobody's Child, which is about couples fighting each other for an unclaimed baby under the gaze of TV cameras.

But when we call the spoonbender-in-chief to check our hunch that the adoption scandal is another of his paranormal pranks, he is evasive. "I don't like to call it a coincidence," Uri says enigmatically. "I prefer to talk of synchronicity. What happens happens for a reason." We are forced to abandon the call when the diary telephone receiver develops an unexpected kink, but we hope to continue via ESP at a later date.

 A worrying hint that the endlessly entertaining masterminds at Monsanto may be about to enter the human cloning business comes from Professor Janet Bainbridge, chair of the Advisory Committee on Novel Foods. Despatched to India to take part in Bright Sparks 2001, an Indo-British science festival, Janet, Monsanto's website reports with delight, has been busy arguing that GM foods "may one day be the only solution for a world supporting 100 bn people". Since even the gravest UN estimates put the highest future total at 12 bn, we must assume that Monsanto knows something we don't.

 Heartbeats are set racing with uncharacteristic speed at the European parliament, where the seemingly loyal New Labour MEP for south-west England, Glyn Ford, has been apparently outed as an undercover operative in the service of communism. The source is traced to a website of MEPs' interests set up by Channel 4's Mark Thomas programme, where it is revealed that Ford earns £500pa from "Communist Research Fortnight". Disappointingly, Ford is actually a columnist for Research Fortnight, a higher education publication which is, we regret to report, not very interesting at all.

 Yet another traumatic episode in the already stressful life of Chris Blackhurst, the Daily Express deputy editor of whom feisty new proprietor Richard Desmond is understood to be extremely eager to get rid. Chris's neighbours have spotted a mysterious figure sifting through the bins outside his Kingston home at 6.30am where he would have found, Chris reports, "the remains of two roast chickens and some Coco-Pops from breakfast".

Even though this apparent hunt for secrets couldn't possibly be anything to do with Desmond, we call his office for a comment, but the phone rings unanswered all day. This may, of course, be a technical fault with the diary phone, which has been malfunctioning ever since it fell victim to the powers of telepathic trickster Uri Geller (qv).

 Sad news for Charles Kennedy, as the BBC prepares for a trial run of election coverage this weekend. Though a Labour win and a hung parliament are the main rehearsal scenarios, fantastically unlikely events are also being planned for, including, a BBC source says, "Tony Blair being discovered shagging Peter Mandelson". A LibDem win, on the other hand, is considered too ridiculous to countenance.

 The hunt for ubiquitous UMIST quotemeister Cary Cooper comes to a long overdue end, with several readers reporting an appearance in a Radio 4 item on stress yesterday.

But we are appalled by the antics of occupational psychologists Nic Groombridge of London, Alan Lorman of Lewes and Norman Claringbull of Hampshire, who all choose to exploit nationwide trauma at Cooper's unexplained absence to nominate themselves for the post of diary headshrinker. This sort of craven self-publicising is not what we expect from the world of occupational psychology, and we trust it will cease forthwith.

fields.headline: Budgens' sales surge eclipses rivals
fields.trailText: Convenience grocers Budgens yesterday revealed a Christmas performance that put some of its larger rivals in the shade, writes Julia Finch .
fields.body:
Convenience grocers Budgens yesterday revealed a Christmas performance that put some of its larger rivals in the shade, writes Julia Finch .

Its like-for-like sales in the eight weeks to January 7 climbed 2.5% on 1999 levels and chief executive Martin Hyson pointed out that unlike leading rivals such as Tesco and Asda, all of the improvement has come from food sales rather than big ticket brown goods such as DVDs.

"We are pleased with our performance," he said. "And it is purely from food, not non-food items and fuel sales."

Budgens' Christmas figures were revealed as the group reported first-half profits up from to £8.6m from £8.5m - which included a one-off £700,000 profit from a property sale and leaseback. Excluding the effect of that, profits were up 10%.

The group said it had maintained its margins and believed it could continue to do so even if an other price war broke out. "We were all supposed to go into decline when Wal-Mart arrived, but we are all still here," he said.

Budgens was not the only retailer to report improvements in festive trade.

Mothercare - the only listed leftover from the once-vast Storehouse empire - said its like-for-like Christmas sales were 1% ahead of 1999 levels and that its recovery remained on track. The group said it had problems with its clothing range for three to five year olds, but was restructuring to do own brand basics and higher priced premium garments. The store expects to meet analysts' predictions of £10m profit this year and shares climbed 6p to 161p.

JD Sports also reported brisk trade, with like-for-like sales up 6.8% in the six weeks to January 6. Chairman John Wardle said the improved profit margin reported in November had been sustained and the shares advanced 2p to a 12-month high of 270.5p.

webTitle: Fat children at greater risk of asthma

fields.headline: Fat children at greater risk of asthma
fields.trailText: Fat children are at greater risk of asthma than others, according to a study of nearly 15,000 children published today.
fields.body:
Fat children are at greater risk of asthma than others, according to a study of nearly 15,000 children published today.

Researchers at King's College, London, also found that in English inner cities obese girls were more likely to suffer the condition than boys, a link not evident in other parts of the country or Scotland.

An overweight child is about 25% more likely to have asthma, a condition that affects about one in six children between the ages of four and 11, suggests a report in the specialist medical journal, Thorax.

Similar links were found in adults in the US, although the authors could find no obvious explanation as to why inner city girls were more prone to the problem.

American studies suggest that being overweight precedes asthma. But the latest study says it is also possible that asthma may induce obesity; many parents believe children with asthma should not exercise, so such youngsters may lead sedentary lives.

Sue Chinn, one of the researchers, said the link between fatness and asthma revealed in their work based on parents' questionnaires during 1993 and 1994, was a fairly recent phenomenon and had not been found in 1977 data. "This suggests it is not directly causal. It is more likely to do with changing diets."

The past 20 years have seen steep rises in both asthma and obesity; the latter now affects about one in 10 children.

webTitle: Ribena loses case over tooth decay

fields.headline: Ribena loses case over tooth decay
fields.trailText: The makers of Ribena, GlaxoSmithKline, were dealt a blow yesterday when a judge ruled that the company was wrong to claim that one of its drinks did not encourage tooth decay.
fields.body:
The makers of Ribena, GlaxoSmithKline, were dealt a blow yesterday when a judge ruled that the company was wrong to claim that one of its drinks did not encourage tooth decay.

Consumer groups have welcomed the judgment, but the British Dental Association is standing by its decision to endorse Ribena ToothKind as "a soft drink dentists can recommend with confidence" and has renewed its accreditation.

GlaxoSmithKline had challenged a ruling from the Advertising Standards Authority which said the claim was "misleading" and condemned posters which depicted bottles of the drink as bristles on a toothbrush.

Despite sifting through scientific papers backing GSK's assertions, Mr Justice Hunt, sitting at the high court in London, said that when taken as a whole, the evidence did not justify the "absolute nature of the claim".

He backed the ASA view that while there was evidence that Ribena ToothKind was less likely to encourage tooth decay, it was only when compared with other soft drinks.

He added that even "negligible risk" or "no substantial risk" were not "no risk". GlaxoSmithKline is considering an appeal.

A spokesman for the ASA said: "We felt their claims were misleading and we feel this judgment is a vindication of our organisation, our investigations and our procedures."

The Consumers' Association investigated the drink in Which? magazine. They found that while it has less fruit juice and less acid than other drinks and so causes fewer cavities, it was not "good" for teeth.

A spokesman for the association said: "We talked to dentists who were concerned about the way the drink was promoted.

"They were critical of a lot of evidence in relation to the claim that it was kind to teeth. Although it might be better than other fruit drinks it is not necessarily 'kind'. Adverts claiming that it was almost as kind as water were not completely accurate."

Yet despite the view of the Consumers' Association, the BDA has remained steadfast in its support for the drink.

Geoff Craig, chairman of the BDA's health and science committee, said: "We accredited Ribena ToothKind three years ago because oral health would improve if children drank this sort of product instead of conventional sugary drinks.

"Our view has not changed and our independent panel of four researchers recently gave the drink BDA accreditation for another three years.

"We still think the best drinks for children's oral health are milk and water. However, Ribena ToothKind is also a soft drink that dentists can recommend with confidence. Research shows the product does not encourage tooth decay and minimises erosion. We would like to see more companies developing products of this type."

GSK was disappointed by the decision and said its claims are backed by "more than 1,200 pages of scientific evidence". Graham Neale, head of nutritional health care at GSK, said: "We are very proud of Ribena ToothKind and will continue to defend it against unfounded criticism."

The case has sparked a debate about health claims made by companies about their products and European legislation on the issue is expected over the summer.

The joint health claims initiative, established at the end of last year, is made up of consumer organisations, enforcement authorities and manufacturers. It has devised a code of practice for companies who want to make health claims about their products.

"If claims are made we look at what the consumer perception of them would be, the marketing image and whether language used is misleading, suggesting by implication that products are better than they really are," said the spokesman from the Consumers' Association.

"We don't believe health claims should be made on products without prior approval.

"Companies are making these claims and no one is checking them or checking the evidence behind them."

webTitle: Discounters suffer as big chains bite back

fields.headline: Discounters suffer as big chains bite back
fields.standfirst: Cheap outlets issue prot warnings as 'victims' undercut their prices
fields.trailText: Cheap outlets issue prot warnings as 'victims' undercut their prices
fields.body:
Discount stores which inflicted so much pain on traditional high street rivals have been given a dose of their own price-cutting medicine.

Three "value" retailers - Peacocks, QS Group and Brown & Jackson, which operates Poundstretcher and What Everyone Wants - issued profit warnings yesterday as they were forced to admit to lacklustre Christmas trading and pressure on profit margins.

The damage has been done by companies the discounters have hurt in the past couple of years - including C&A, Bhs, Littlewoods and Arcadia.

C&A has been holding a clearance sale before pulling out of Britain, Bhs clearing the decks with big reductions before relaunching under new managment, and Littlewoods and Arcadia - which operates clothing chains including Dorothy Perkins and Miss Selfridge - have cut prices to compete with the value chains.

The discounters have been forced to trim prices further to hold on to market share - with serious impact on profit margins. The discount groups had been thriving as traditional retail names suffer. fields.headline: Canary Wharf's princely profit
fields.trailText: A Saudi prince who invested heavily in Canary Wharf five years ago has sold two-thirds of his stake for £124m, more than four times what he paid.
fields.body:
A Saudi prince who invested heavily in Canary Wharf five years ago has sold two-thirds of his stake for £124m, more than four times what he paid.

Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, nephew of Saudi king Fahd and one of the world's richest men, said he was capitalising on "a great opportunity... to realise tremendous gains" but would hang on to a 2% holding.

Shares in Canary Wharf Group hit a high last month after the company which built what some deemed a monument to Thatcherism produced its first profit since being rescued by creditors.

Canary Wharf, a development centred on Britain's tallest building, was built for £1.8bn by Olympia & York, a Canadian company that hit financial trouble in the early 1990s property slump.

Prince Alwaleed is a member of the consortium that bought Canary Wharf out of receivership for an estimated £800m in 1995 before floating a quarter of it on the stock market in 1999.

The prince, who enjoys making high-profile international investments, spent £45m acquiring 6% of Canary Wharf at 113p a share and sold at 467p.

Yesterday the shares, which had reached a 12-month high of 580p last month, ended at 472p, up 14p.

Rising rental income and the sale of completed properties around the main tower helped Canary Wharf to a £54.1m pre-tax annual profit, compared with a £42.8m loss last time.

Chief executive George Iacobescu said the company was three years ahead of its own business model as top City firms rent space.

fields.headline: Museum 'deceived over building stone'
fields.trailText: The British Museum was "deceived" by contractors working on its £100m Great Court development after they supplied stone from France rather than Dorset, a report has revealed.
fields.body:
The British Museum was "deceived" by contractors working on its £100m Great Court development after they supplied stone from France rather than Dorset, a report has revealed.

Pricewaterhouse Coopers was commissioned to investigate the error, and while clearing the management of a cover up its report said the museum had suffered "reputational damage" as a result.

The sum of £1.74m was spent on the south portico of the Great Court as part of a renovation programme funded by the Heritage Lottery Fund.

But the museum was "deceived" by Easton Masonry which supplied Anstude stone from France rather than Portland stone from Dorset, according to the report, published on the museum's website.

In 1998 one of the companies which expected to supply the stone queried why it had not received an order and the report added that it was unfortunate that this early indication was not followed up.

The problem was, in fact, first brought to light in March 1999, when the museum's project manager received a tip-off letter.

A period of testing was carried out which confirmed the wrong stone had been used. The museum has withheld £200,000 of the final bill, but has confirmed that, at the moment, it is not planning any legal action.

The report also criticised the museum for the lack of liaison between trustees and management and said: "The delays in determining the facts and engaging early the professional advisers, trustees and stakeholders has resulted, more significantly, in damage to the reputation of the mu seum and those involved in its management, which might have been avoidable."

Graham Greene, chairman of the British Museum, said: "The British Museum regrets that its project team was unable to prevent deception by a contractor and we accept responsibility for our part in any disappointment caused.

"We are pleased that the report confirms there was no attempt at a cover up and that decisions made were appropriate, but we are determined to learn lessons for the future."

The report is available at: The British museum website

fields.headline: Talking dirty
fields.trailText: "Though she [Kathy Botham] can't be happy about his exploits being all over the newspapers ... her real indignation should be focused on the harpie who turned him in." Peter McKay sticks up for Ian Botham, Daily Mail
fields.body:
"Though she [Kathy Botham] can't be happy about his exploits being all over the newspapers ... her real indignation should be focused on the harpie who turned him in. Mr Botham appears to have treated Miss Verrells, a waitress and single mother, with great kindness. He wined and dined her. He flew her and her daughter to Scotland, where they joined him on a fishing trip on the River Tay.

"Her disclosures about their sex life are intended to mark Mr Botham out as a pervert, but I doubt if he put a gun to her head. Now she sells him down the river to the News of the World, seeking to justify herself by saying she's woken up to his lies about leaving his wife. To say the least, it's bad manners. When men do this they're despised by members of their own sex. I wonder why women get away with it"
Peter McKay sticks up for Ian Botham, Daily Mail

"That's why women designers are not as good as men. Because with us, everything starts with the dream, like not everything I make I would wear but, for instance, when women design for women they design what they can wear themselves. It's genetic! It's instinct! Actually I think gay men are just better fantasists."
Stefano Gabbana of the fashion design duo Dolce & Gabbana, the Independent

"If you're taking the piss I'll give you a right-hander. One thing I ain't is a fucking teddy bear. Do I look like a teddy bear? I've worked hard all my life and I don't expect people to take the piss. That's complete bollocks. The men who write about that stuff probably go home and put dresses on. I can assure you that, in the near future, I will not be taking steps in that direction."
Vinne Jones on being asked whether he ever gets in touch with his feminine side, Stuff magazine

"I find it irritating that Cherie appears like his concubine. She's an intelligent woman doing an important job. I don't want to see her coming around being a wife."
Germaine Greer, LineOne

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
'Assault' by Gallagher
Damilola case on Crimewatch
Taggart actor dies
fields.body:
Attempted murder charge

A man appeared at the Old Bailey yesterday charged with attempted murder of an Orthodox Jew. Nabil Ouldeddine, 23, is alleged to have stabbed David Myers, 21, on a bus in Stamford Hill, north London, on October 16. The case was adjourned for 28 days.

'Assault' by Gallagher

Police are investigating a report that Oasis star Liam Gallagher, 28, indecently assaulted a 30-year-old female member of British Airways ground staff as he boarded a flight to Rio de Janeiro at Gatwick last Friday.

Damilola case on Crimewatch

The murder of 10-year-old Damilola Taylor will be featured on the BBC's Crimewatch UK programme next Wednesday.

Zero hour for one o'clock gun

Edinburgh Castle's one o'clock gun is being decommissioned after nearly half a century. The 25-pounder howitzer is becoming increasingly difficult to maintain, says the Royal Artillery, which is to replace it with a more modern 105mm light gun.

Short rations for romance

Unromantic Britons decline to take their partners breakfast in bed, a survey by the National Farmers' Union shows. Seven out of 10 respondents admitted they had not been treated to breakfast in bed a single time in the last year.

Apology by chocolate firm

Confectionery giant Thorntons has apologised to Rachel Harrison, 28, of Warboys, Cambridgeshire, after she was charged 26p at the firm's Huntingdon branch after requesting a piece of chocolate for her diabetic son Ross, four.

Taggart actor dies

The actor Robert Robertson, 70, best known for playing pathologist Stephen Andrews in the TV series Taggart, died in hospital yesterday after suffering a heart attack on stage at Perth, while he was reciting a Robert Burns poem.

Store gets the nod

Selfridges department store in Oxford Street, London, founded in 1909, has been granted a royal warrant by the Queen, it was announced yesterday.

webTitle: Arts: Tim Ashley on staircases in opera

fields.headline: Flights of fancy
fields.standfirst: In opera the staircase is more than a way of moving between floors: it is a gateway to other worlds.  Tim Ashley continues our series on strange fixations
fields.trailText: In opera the staircase is more than a way of moving between floors: it is a gateway to other worlds. Tim Ashley continues our series on strange fixations.
fields.body:
"Who is this angel descending from heaven?" sings Mandryka at the start of the second act of Richard Strauss's Arabella, as the heroine walks towards him down a colossal flight of stairs. It is a moment riddled with symbolic resonance. Mandryka is a baritone, a hunky, earthy type, a man of instinct tethered to his low voice as well as the floor of the stage. Arabella is a soprano, a creature whose voice flies above the world of mortals. Her descent of the staircase is, on one level, the progress of a seraph or goddess from the stratospheres towards earth.

What awaits Arabella at the bottom is no terrestrial paradise but the all too human ambivalence of reality. The steps bring her not only to Mandryka, whom she loves, but also to an awareness of the sexual, moral and emotional precariousness of existence.

The staircase is located in a Viennese ballroom, where a carnival is taking place. Amid the frenzy of couplings, the lovers lose their idealistic visions of each other. Mandryka comes to believe that his angel has descended to earth only to be transformed into a whore; Arabella has to face the fact that her dream man can be a cantankerous bully. The staircase that brought them together has also betrayed them, setting in motion events that may pull them apart.

Staircases, by their nature, are causes of confusion. None of us knows what lies in wait for us at the bottom or top, while with each step our perspective changes. In opera, steps are blown up to become emblems of disturbance, images of moral ricketiness or metaphysical convulsion, the Jacob's ladders of the human psyche. The presence of an operatic staircase is a portent of at best chaos, and at worst catastrophe.

Strauss, whose operas, more than those of any other composer, describe a universe reeling from Nietzsche's announcement of the "death of God", seems almost staircase-mad. The stage directions for Salome specify a staircase leading from Herod's palace down to the terrace where the action takes place. At the top is a world of repression, where desires are unspoken and emotions fester. At the bottom lurks a landscape of erotic savagery in which the neuroses heave their way to the surface.

At the top of the stairs, Salome is an innocent, technically a virgin. Her descent is a gradual submersion into her own sexuality, culminating in her necrophiliac orgasm over John the Baptist's head. Herod later tries to flee his monstrous stepdaughter by retreating up the stairs, but he cannot escape. All he can do is dither halfway.

With Elektra, Strauss pushes opera into Freudian extremism, and staircases proliferate, mirroring the opera's emphasis on the bifurcation between conscious action and subconscious thought. We see a flight of steps leading from the courtyard to the palace, but within the building, unseen by us, lurks a multiplicity of stairs that twist and turn like the psyche and lead to windows through which the characters peer in vain attempts to make sense of their lives. The guilt-ridden Klytemnestra pokes her head through one such aperture and decides that her demented daughter is calm for once.

But her view from the staircase is deceptive. She descends, only to be savagely taunted by Elektra. Klytemnestra retreats upstairs to an illusory safety. Her murderer, her son Orest, eventually ascends after her and, having slaughtered her, waits for his next victim. Elektra cannot follow her brother inside, but leads his next victim to him. "Watch the steps," she tells Aegistheus, before he too ascends to his death. Long before Hitchcock's Psycho, Strauss knew of the fear that in the dark at the top of the stairs someone with a blade is waiting to puncture your skull.

Strauss's staircases hint not only at psychic chaos but at social change and the blurring of class boundaries. The carnival confusion into which Arabella descends is a cabmen's ball, at which social roles are reversed and servants entertain their masters. In Der Rosenkavalier, the second act takes place in the house of the upwardly mobile arms dealer Faninal, in a salon from which staircases lead both up and down. The aristocratic Octavian ascends to this midpoint to present the bourgeois Faninal's daughter Sophie with a silver rose.

"It's heavenly, not earthly," Sophie sings as she sniffs the rose. Her words might refer to the room in which they are standing, though her rapture does not last long. The boorish Baron Ochs crashes up the lower staircase after Octavian, and the web of stairs becomes a social battleground as the tottering aristocracy is forced into conflict with the emergent bourgeoisie.

Strauss may have been the ultimate staircase composer - Arabella's stairs even have their own tune - but he was not alone. Deception and death lie in wait for Puccini's Tosca and her lover Cavaradossi on the steps of the Castel Sant'Angelo in Rome. His predatory Turandot tantalises men by despatching riddles and death from a stair-linked platform, only to be deflowered into submission when she descends.

Berg's Lulu, the sex goddess incarnate, descends a flight of stairs to entertain the males who desire her, only to find her divinity profaned and sullied. In Lohengrin, Wagner ascribed to Antwerp cathedral a flight of steps that it does not in reality possess, and used them as the setting for the climactic showdown between Elsa and Ortrud.

Elsa is defenceless when she moves from level ground. Ortrud can only undermine Elsa's faith in her nameless saviour when she is off the flat, and proceeds to do so, impeding her ascent. By the time Elsa gets to the top, her moral certainty is fatally undermined, and her climb has been a journey into psychological darkness.

The process is reversed in the comedy of Die Meistersinger. Walter sings his Prize Song, which brings life to jaded aesthetic tradition, from the top of a staircase. Walter, like God, is a creator. The song is addressed to "Eva in paradise", and below the heroine waits for him in a world restored to its prelapsarian state.

In John Adams's Nixon in China, steps hint at the fragility of diplomacy as political worlds collide. A rickety staircase is trundled into place beneath the presidential plane, down which the morally flawed leader of the capitalist world descends to confront the equally flawed strictures of communism. At the end of the opera, the process is reversed. Nixon climbs into his plane, the staircase is removed, and the two worlds come apart.

Operatic producers have similarly exploited the dramatic and symbolic potential of staircases. Franco Zefirelli's staging of Donizetti's Lucia di Lammermoor made musical history and turned Joan Sutherland into a star when it opened in 1959.

Sutherland, by her own admission, was no actress, though she had the extraordinary ability to move at speed while singing some of the trickiest music written. Zefirelli staged the famous mad scene on a colossal flight of stairs, up and down which Sutherland sprinted and fluttered like a wounded bird, conveying the tortuous twists of Lucia's damaged psyche.

More controversial was Graham Vick's use of a staircase in his 1999 Glyndebourne production of Debussy's Pelléas et Mélisande, where stairs form the entrance to an alluring, deceptive prison. Mélisande, the creature of light, descends into the oppressive gilded bell jar that forms the set, where her life, drop by drop, is slowly extinguished.

Opera illuminates the human condition by combining music and drama to probe our deepest emotions. In its strange, phantasmagoric world, the staircase is an icon of the confusion and uncertainty that govern our lives.
