Berg's Lulu, the sex goddess incarnate, descends a flight of stairs to entertain the males who desire her, only to find her divinity profaned and sullied. In Lohengrin, Wagner ascribed to Antwerp cathedral a flight of steps that it does not in reality possess, and used them as the setting for the climactic showdown between Elsa and Ortrud. Elsa is defenceless when she moves from level ground. Ortrud can only undermine Elsa's faith in her nameless saviour when she is off the flat, and proceeds to do so, impeding her ascent. By the time Elsa gets to the top, her moral certainty is fatally undermined, and her climb has been a journey into psychological darkness. The process is reversed in the comedy of Die Meistersinger. Walter sings his Prize Song, which brings life to jaded aesthetic tradition, from the top of a staircase. Walter, like God, is a creator. The song is addressed to "Eva in paradise", and below the heroine waits for him in a world restored to its prelapsarian state. In John Adams's Nixon in China, steps hint at the fragility of diplomacy as political worlds collide. A rickety staircase is trundled into place beneath the presidential plane, down which the morally flawed leader of the capitalist world descends to confront the equally flawed strictures of communism. At the end of the opera, the process is reversed. Nixon climbs into his plane, the staircase is removed, and the two worlds come apart. Operatic producers have similarly exploited the dramatic and symbolic potential of staircases. Franco Zefirelli's staging of Donizetti's Lucia di Lammermoor made musical history and turned Joan Sutherland into a star when it opened in 1959. Sutherland, by her own admission, was no actress, though she had the extraordinary ability to move at speed while singing some of the trickiest music written. Zefirelli staged the famous mad scene on a colossal flight of stairs, up and down which Sutherland sprinted and fluttered like a wounded bird, conveying the tortuous twists of Lucia's damaged psyche. More controversial was Graham Vick's use of a staircase in his 1999 Glyndebourne production of Debussy's Pelléas et Mélisande, where stairs form the entrance to an alluring, deceptive prison. Mélisande, the creature of light, descends into the oppressive gilded bell jar that forms the set, where her life, drop by drop, is slowly extinguished. Opera illuminates the human condition by combining music and drama to probe our deepest emotions. In its strange, phantasmagoric world, the staircase is an icon of the confusion and uncertainty that govern our lives.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Work in progress

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.standfirst: Matt Lucas, comedian
fields.trailText: Matt Lucas, comedian.
fields.body:
I wrote some months ago about Little Britain, the sketch show that Dave Walliams and I were working on for Radio 4. We finished the scripts shortly after Christmas, with a month to spare before recording starts. David has wisely gone on holiday.

I, meanwhile, linger at home with that cough, struggling intermittently with the temptation to tinker with the scripts in Dave's absence. I resist the urge, not just because we prefer to work together on such matters, but also because there's only one thing worse than underwriting, and that's overwriting. It's too easy to get so close to the material that you get bogged down in small details and forget what appealed in the first place.

While texture is important, simplicity is usually the key - if you want laughs. But it is hard, particularly when the material becomes overfamiliar, to stop yourself from feeling that somehow the joke or routine isn't quite finished.

For jobbing live comics, this is often compounded by the fact that different audiences laugh at different things, and often we on stage don't have a clue as to why. So we start misguidedly tampering with a gag that worked perfectly well in Ipswich but which failed in Cambridge purely because someone sneezed over the punchline.

In our radio show, however, we don't even have this dubious luxury. There are no previews, no long runs, no opportunities to mix in new material with trusty old one-liners. And yet in with the panic is a sense of liberation.

Faced with little alternative (other than the endless regurgitation of all our old jokes), I've become less afraid, certainly less apologetic of such public failure, accepting it as an inevitability, much like the footballer who scores 20 glorious goals in a season but misses at least twice as many. In fact it's the only real way to learn.

webTitle: Arts: London theatre takes on New York

fields.headline: 'The critics love it!'
fields.standfirst: Over the past month  Mike Bradwell  and his colleagues at London's Bush Theatre have done battle with rats, blizzards and bureaucrats in their attempt to take two of their shows to New York. This is his diary
fields.trailText: Over the past month Mike Bradwell and his colleagues at London's Bush Theatre have done battle with rats, blizzards and bureaucrats in their attempt to take two of their shows to New York. This is his diary.
fields.body:
Tuesday, December 19, 2000

Read-through of Resident Alien at New York Theatre Workshop. There are 43 people for the meet-and-greet, all called Randy or Larry. We have five kinds of doughnuts, four kinds of bagels, peanut butter and jelly sandwiches, muffins, bananas, apples, crunchy granola, muesli, six kinds of tea, cinnamon hazelnut decaf ... and Bette Bourne, who plays Quentin Crisp, has a cigarette. Everyone nervously looks at the sprinkler system but says nothing.

Wednesday, December 20

Costume fittings. There's a whole rail of new jackets, coats, shirts, scarves and pants. Bette doesn't like any of them, so they all go away for alterations. Tom Watson, wigmeister at the Met, fits Bette for a new wig. In London he looked like a badger in a shower cap.

Thursday, December 21

Tim Fountain, the Bush's literary manager, arrives and moves into his apartment. It's freezing. When he complains, his landlord gives him a coat. The set is almost finished; it looks terrific. Neil Patel, the designer, has taken the original Bush Theatre design, turned it 90 degrees, put a roof on it and stuck it on the Workshop's vast stage. It looks like the Tardis floating in space.

Friday, December 22

The visas for the cast of Howie the Rookie have not turned up. The US consulate is about to close for Christmas and in London the office is going mad. Happy holidays.

Christmas Day

Helen and Flora, my partner and daughter, have arrived for Christmas. We go to Central Park with Tim to watch the skaters. The wind-chill factor is minus 19. I try to cook Christmas dinner in my apartment. This sets off the smoke alarm. The handle falls off the lavatory door and I get locked in. The others can't hear my cries for help. They're listening to Christmas With Liberace.

Tuesday, December 26

In America they don't have Boxing Day. Our first day on set with Resident Alien. It turns out there are two prop departments: one for "props" and one for "hand props", the latter being props that get moved about. Quentin had a television set, which he kept on the box it came in. In the play, the television set moves but the box doesn't. So the dilemma is which department is responsible for purchasing a) the television and b) the box. I suggest props buy the TV and sell the box to hand props. They do not consider this suggestion to be satirical.

Wednesday, December 27

The Workshop is putting on new doors. They are magnificent neo-brutalist postmodern affairs, but unfortunately they don't have any handles, so they have to take them off again. The Howie visas still haven't arrived.

Friday, December 29

Still no visas. Tom Watson turns up with the new wig. It's fabulous. He fits it on Bette. "You will be here every night to do this, won't you darling?" says Bette. "I'm sorry," says Tom, "but I've got other work on." "Who could be more important than me?" jokes Bette. After a beautifully measured pause, Tom says, "Pavarotti." Bette is silent.

The Weather Channel says there is a snowstorm brewing, the biggest since 1996, with 8in to 10in of snow expected. Fiona Clark, executive producer at the Bush, is due to fly in from London. After five hours on the tarmac her plane is cancelled.

Saturday, December 30

Fiona and the snow blow in to New York - Fiona via Washington and several planes, trains and automobiles. The city closes down. Tim moves out of freezing apartment and into new pad. Disturbed in the middle of the night, he looks up through his skylight. A plague of rats looks back. He moves into a hotel.

New Year's Eve

Fourteen inches of snow. Flora and Helen having gone back, I spend the evening in a rock'n'roll bar watching a Frank Zappa tribute band with half of Circus Oz and a Vietnam vet called Charlie. I am really too old for this kind of thing, but then Fiona falls asleep before midnight, so who knows?

New Year's Day, 2001

Fiona is permanently on the phone to the Bush, the actors, the consulate and the state department. The Howie boys will not be leaving today. Their set has arrived at its venue, PS122, and Gareth, our technical director, and Steve, their technician, start practising their Irish accents.

Tuesday, January 2

At the Workshop we tech Resident Alien and in the evening we do the first stagger-through. Fiona has ascertained that the Howie visas were processed last week but are sitting in a mailbag in Grosvenor Square. The boys - Karl Shiels and Aidan Kelly - finally arrive in New York at midnight, to be met by Fiona and Mark Russell of PS122. They drink heavily.

Wednesday, January 3

We tech Howie in the morning, dress-rehearse Resident Alien in the afternoon, and preview Howie in the evening. The boys are magnificent. More drinking. Mark Ravenhill shows up for a wedding and joins the party.

Thursday, January 4

We attend a snow-machine training session at the Workshop but the motor fails to materialise. Production manager Larry Ash has to work it from up a ladder. Outside it snows. At 7pm we do the public dress of Resident Alien and are suddenly struck by the poignancy of doing this show just a block from where Quentin lived. At PS122 Fiona sees the opening night of Howie. Larry Eilenberg, artistic director of the Magic Theatre in San Francisco, turns up - Howie tours there next. There's an amazing buzz.

Friday, January 5

First preview of Resident Alien. Press in to see Howie. Ben Brantley from the New York Times sees Howie. I walk between the two theatres in the snow. This is mad.

Tuesday, January 9

6.30am: Fiona is at the airport. She's going to Chicago to meet producers interested in Howie. She buys the New York Times. The review is out - it's phenomenal. She calls me. She calls everyone. We are over the moon. Don't fully comprehend the significance of this until the phones start ringing, and ringing, and ringing. In Chicago, Fiona gets the same response. We try not to lose our heads, but indulge in a swift celebratory vodka martini.

Thursday, January 11

New York Theatre Workshop press-the-flesh-with-patrons evening. We network. Tim is nervous. Fiona, Tim and I stand outside the theatre with its artistic director, Jim Nicola. Jim tells us that a member of his board has told Ben Brantley to move his seat and he has had to clamber over two rows. Cheer up, Tim, I say. It's only theatre.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Indiscreet | Cinema Paradiso | The Bodyguard
fields.body:
Indiscreet
(Stanley Donen, 1958)
10am, 4pm, Sky Cinema

Norman Krasna's Broadway flop becomes a delightful, frothy comedy on screen, reuniting Hitchcock's Notorious stars Cary Grant and Ingrid Bergman. Grant, a Paris-based Nato official - and a confirmed bachelor - tells Bergman's actress at the outset of their affair that he is married (inverting the usual scheme of things). When the romance develops - he's zooming into Mayfair on weekend leave - she discovers the truth, and it looks like their fine romance is over. As if.

Cinema Paradiso
(Giuseppe Tornatore, 1988)
8pm, FilmFour

In a wartime Sicilian village, 10-year-old Salvatore, who's fascinated by the movies, wins the affection of Phillipe Noiret's grizzled old projectionist, Alfredo. The cinema is a hub of the small community, running into comic confrontation with the church when the priest bans kissing scenes, but the crowds keep coming, and when Alfredo is blinded in a fire, the boy steps in. It's all told in flashback - a moving, magnificent celebration of cinema.

The Bodyguard
(Mick Jackson, 1992)
8pm, Sky Cinema

Glossy, well-produced romantic thriller in which only the turgid theme song lingers - unwanted - in the mind. Kevin Costner plays a minder, ex-CIA, looking out for pop star Whitney Houston. A formulaic plot has the couple falling in love, and hiding out in a rural retreat where he can lay down honest country values. Watchable, undemanding stuff.

The Hard Way
(John Badham, 1991)
8pm, Sky MovieMax

Hard is what Michael J Fox's wimpish actor Nick Lang aspires to be in his cop-thriller movies, so he takes lessons in tough from James Woods' real-life cop, who's hunting a serial killer. An enjoyable pairing but the comedy flags before a predictable conclusion in which Lang has to act his way out of trouble.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Gunman takes his own life
fields.body:
Gunman takes his own life

A fugitive who killed four men in the south of France nine days ago took his own life yesterday as the police stormed his hideout in Beziers, 80 miles west of Marseille.

Albert Foulcher, 49, jumped bail in April before his trial for the murder of a former colleague. In January he shot dead two policemen and two men who had testified against him.
Jon Henley, Paris

Beijing hit by double threat

Beijing faced an unwelcome twin offensive from dissidents and the Falun Gong sect yesterday as it prepared to celebrate next week's lunar New Year.

More than 100 dissidents said in a letter that the future of Beijing's 2008 Olympic Games bid would depend on releasing political prisoners for the New Year holiday, while the US-based leader of the Falun Gong made a veiled threat to abandon its philosophy of non-violence.
John Gittings, Shanghai

Child law gets Paris hearing

A bill went before the French cabinet yesterday to amend a 50-year old law that has stopped thousands of children finding their parents.

It provides for a new council to record the identities of women who wish to exercise their right to surrender new-born children to the state anonymously. It will make it possible for mother and child to meet, but only with the consent of both.
Jon Henley, Paris

Czech rebels expand control

The rebel journalists occupying the newsroom of the public service television station in Prague took over the management of the network yesterday.
AP, Prague

webTitle: Leader:  social reform has been set back by 30 years

fields.headline: Back to the bad old ways
fields.standfirst: The fault in this case is Lord Irvine's
fields.trailText: The fault in this case is Lord Irvine's.
fields.body:
The lord chancellor set back social reform by 30 years this week. He has condemned unhappily married people to many more years of unnecessary acrimony, bitterness and pain. Worse still, he has sentenced thousands of children, caught between warring parents, to suffer serious psychological damage which many will have to carry through the rest of their lives. This was not quite how his department described the decision, but it would have been more honest if it had. Instead, it was billed as the abandonment of "no fault" divorce reforms, introduced by the 1996 Family Law Act.

Theoretically, fault was eliminated not in 1996 but in 1969, by a divorce reform which introduced the concept of "irretrievable breakdown". In reality, two-thirds of all couples continued to use fault (either adultery or intolerable behaviour) to obtain a quickie divorce in months, rather than the alternative route of waiting for a two-year separation to demonstrate their marital breakdown.

Reports in 1988 and 1990 from the law commission, which advises the government on law reform, and an even earlier report, Putting Asunder, from the Archbishop of Canterbury's committee over 30 years ago, called for the abolition of "fault" because of the way it increases hostility, bitterness and recriminations. Even uncontested petitions require detailed accusations. A series of research studies has shown that it is not the divorce itself, but the acrimony and bitterness involved, which causes most damage to children.

What the lord chancellor's predecessor set out to do in 1996 was to introduce the law commission's sensible proposals. Unhappily, the bill was hijacked by right-wing Tory MPs, concerned at being accused of introducing divorce on demand. They introduced various hoops and delays that petitioners would have to go through before they could get a divorce. Anyone seeking a divorce had to first attend an information meeting three months before filing. Instead of implementing this section, which would have abolished "fault", the government carried out pilot schemes involving 8,000 divorcing couples.

According to political reporters, briefed by the government, the pilots showed a nationwide scheme would cost £50m to introduce and would increase acrimony. Wrong on both counts. The research shows that it would cost £26m - and less than half that, if confined to the 150,000 couples who divorce, rather than widened to 400,000 who are considering it. There was no finding of increased acrimony. Just the reverse. Over 90% found the sessions useful and reassuring. It helped them end indecision and uncertainty, two conditions which create so much anxiety in children.

Some things were wrong. All sessions had to follow a rigid procedure, rather than responding to the needs of petitioners. Only the petitioner was required to attend, which was a fatal error, with only one side of the partnership getting the information. And people were required to attend three months before petitions were filed: researchers suggest that the two events should take place together, as happens successfully in Australia and Canada.

Parliament should insist on "no fault" being introduced - along with more support for marriage counselling and mediation schemes. What is needed is more realism and less ministerial moralising. Ministers cannot mend broken marriages, but they can ensure that all the emotional energy now expended in establishing fault is diverted into more productive channels.

webTitle: BBC plans 'brighter' news as rival's ratings rise

fields.headline: BBC plans 'brighter' news as rival's ratings rise
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
Memo to BBC staff
fields.trailText:
The BBC is planning an overhaul of the Ten O'Clock News amid fears of falling ratings and competition from ITV's revived 10pm bulletin, writes Matt Wells.
Memo to BBC staff
fields.body:
BBC executives are planning an overhaul of the Ten O'Clock News amid fears of falling ratings and increased competition from ITV's revived 10pm bulletin.

In a memo that has caused staff concern, BBC news chiefs said the programme would have a "broader agenda" and "more intelligent coverage". A former ITN editor takes over after the general election, and some fear he will import a populist agenda to the bulletin, which has concentrated on politics and foreign news. Some Ten O'Clock News journalists are reportedly upset at the slur about coverage not being intelligent enough.

But executives are understood to be concerned at the prospect of a head-to-head clash with ITV's News at Ten, which returns to screens on Monday. This week, the BBC Ten O'Clock News recorded its lowest ratings since being moved from the 9pm slot last year, scoring 3.4m viewers on Monday night.

The BBC director general, Greg Dyke, is thought to believe the old Nine O'Clock News too austere, and be keen to recreate a bulletin with the impact of ITV's old News at Ten. He supports the new editor, Mark Popescu, responsible for relaunching the BBC's Six O'Clock News.

One BBC producer said the "middle class intellectuals" behind the 10pm bulletin were worried: a staff member reportedly said Mr Popescu's agenda would be "more Madonna than Macedonia".

But executives said such reports were "twaddle". In a memo signed by the deputy director of news, Richard Sambrook, and the head of television news, Roger Mosey, staff were told the Ten O'Clock News would be more ambitious and make more use of specialist correspondents.

The comments raised eyebrows at the BBC. One journalist said: "The Ten O'Clock News people think they are the top brains in the BBC. You can imagine how that went down."

The BBC chairman, Sir Christopher Bland, had said that if audiences fell drastically the news would be moved back to 9pm, and he promised a review in a year's time. But that commitment is watered down; in yesterday's memo, Mr Sambrook and Mr Mosey said success would be judged over "a couple of years".

Some in the BBC believe Mr Popescu must ease out the programme's current presenters. Peter Sissons and Michael Buerk have been in the job for seven and 12 years respectively, and their regular stand-in, George Alagiah, is popular with viewers and regarded as heir apparent. But the pair would not go without a damaging public fight.

fields.headline: Ask Jack
fields.standfirst: Send your questions and comments to Jack.Schofield@guardian.co.uk. Published letters will be edited for brevity but please include full details with your original query
fields.trailText: Hold the FrontPage | Time's up
fields.body:
Hold the FrontPage
I have just started making my own web page and would like to use FrontPage Express. Currently, I use Internet Explorer 5, but when I tried to install FrontPage Express from an ISP's CD, it wouldn't because it has to install IE4 with it. I also tried downloading it from the Microsoft website but they have removed it. Is there anywhere else that I can download it? Chris Uglow
chris@uglow.swinternet.co.uk

Jack Schofield replies: FrontPage Express does seem to come and go. At the moment it is available, and free, for IE5. Use the Start button option to go to the Windows Update Centre and it should be offered as one of the programs available for downloading: the updated FrontPage Express 2.0 (1229K) is in the Internet Authoring section about half way down.

It should also be possible to get it by running IE. In IE4, click on the Help menu and select Product Updates; in IE 5, click on the Tools menu and select Windows Update. However, FrontPage Express has disappeared from the latest IE 5.5, and at the time of writing, Microsoft UK could not tell me why, or if it was going to be restored. It seems that IE 5.5 users who want to install FPE will have to try to uninstall it and go back to IE 5.01.

There are, of course, dozens of HTML editors to download besides FPE. I like SiteAid 2.1. The alternatives include Evrsoft's 1st Page 2000 and Arachnophilia.

As for downloading FrontPage Express from elsewhere, there are, as usual, hacked versions around, as a simple web search will reveal. I do not recommend this, as it can tend to lead to installation and update problems.

Just stick to the fax
I use Windows 98 at home and would like to have the facility to send and receive faxes. I understand it was part of Windows 95, but Microsoft took it off for Windows 98. I have tried to download it without much success. Can you help? Dave Callaghan
David.Callaghan@rbi.co.uk

JS: Although Microsoft Fax is not actually part of Windows 98, an installation utility is included in the Tools\Oldwin 95\Message\Intl folder on the CD, and Microsoft says it "will support running the version of Microsoft Fax located on the Windows 98 CD-ROM to the best of our ability".

MFax (for short) needs a MAPI (mail application) to be installed first, so it is probably a good idea to install Windows Messaging. Find the file called wms.exe on the CD in the Tools\OldWin95\ Messaging directory, double-click it and follow the prompts.

Now go back to where you were on the CD and double-click the fax program, awfax.exe, to install Microsoft Fax. For help, read the Wmsfax.txt file on your CD (or http://support.microsoft.com/support/windows/readme/98/w98wms-faxtxt.asp) and the Microsoft Knowledge Base article Q196624 at http://support.microsoft.com/support/kb/articles/Q241/2/84.asp

Outlook users (not Outlook Express users) may have problems. The solution seems to be to uninstall Outlook 97, 98 or 2000, install the fax software, then reinstall Outlook. See http://support.microsoft.com/support/kb/articles/Q241/2/84.asp.

Time's up
Is it possible to set a limit on the number of minutes/ hours that I can play Patience or Minesweeper on my computer, other than by using non-existent self-control? Also, a friend has FreeCell and I don't. Is there some way of sending a copy to my PC? Julian Dunn
eisendora@compuserve.com

JS: I was going to suggest Time's Up! by the Fresh Software Company, but it seems to have disappeared. However, one of the many parental control programs should do the job. They are all available in free trial versions.

The best option may be Cyberpatrol 4.01, which has now become part of Surf Control. It is available in Windows and Mac versions but it is expensive at $49.95 a year. An obvious alternative is Net Nanny 4 but you should read reviews of the others.

If you have problems with Minesweeper then it is not a good idea to install FreeCell, which is far more addictive and a vastly better game. However, if freecell.exe is not in your C:\Windows directory, it should be on your Windows CD. Go to Start|Settings|Control Panel and double-click the icon for Add/Remove programs. Click the Windows Setup tab, then double-click the entry for Accessories, and put a tick next to Games. This should install all the games, including FreeCell.

Interestingly, the FreeCell Links Page on Gusworld ) includes a link to download a copy of FreeCell from Microsoft.

Virus warning!
From time to time I receive warnings about new viruses from well meaning friends. Usually the email suggests that I forward the warning to everyone in my address book. I am reluctant to do this. What do you think? Alan Quilley
quilley@bigfoot.com

JS: You are right. Every one of these I have seen has been a hoax, but you can check them first at www.Vmyths.com

webTitle: Councils set to appoint 'mini' drugs tsars

fields.headline: Councils set to appoint 'mini' drugs tsars
fields.trailText: Local authorities are to take a lead role in tackling substance abuse by appointing their own anti-drugs coordinators, government drugs tsar Keith Hellawell will announce today. Simon Parker reports
fields.body:
Local authorities are to take a lead role in tackling substance abuse by appointing their own anti-drugs coordinators, government drugs tsar Keith Hellawell will announce today.

Elected councillors will be expected to take on the new "mini-tsar" posts. They will be appointed from April and head drug action teams responsible for fighting the problem in their areas.

The mini-tsar plan came as part of the government's bid to let local authorities take the lead in looking after social welfare.

The decision reflects the government's recent moves towards giving councils a new "community leadership" role, as all-purpose problem solvers for local people.

Until now, campaigns against drugs at a local level have been run by a mixture of police, health, educational and other agencies. The new teams will be just one step down the ladder from Mr Hellawell.

The drugs tsar was due to unveil the scheme at a seminar organised by the Association of London Government and the London Drug Policy Forum. He was expected to say that the new positions would be crucial in developing the role of local authorities in the government's 10-year anti-drug strategy.

"I am convinced that the commitment, cooperation and willingness to work together at a national and local level will help to create a healthier and safer society," he was to say.

Peter Rigby, chairman of the London Drug Policy Forum said: "We welcome the government's recognition of the crucial role of local authorities in delivering anti-drugs strategies."

He said the new plans would end the "mishmash" of agencies responsible for tackling drugs.

fields.headline: The best theft scene
fields.standfirst: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon
fields.trailText: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon
fields.body:
Night. A masked figure silently enters the study of Sir Te through the window. Once inside, they swiftly locate the ancient Green Destiny sword which has been left in Te's safekeeping.

As the figure leaves, they're interrupted by Bo (Li Fa Zeng), Te's head of security. Bo makes a clumsy attempt to grab the intruder, who simply drops from the window into the courtyard below, then leaps up to the roof.

"Someone help!" Bo yells. "Stop him! He's on the roof! The sword's been stolen! Stop thief!"

The thief skips down to a sidestreet and makes off, as Bo bangs a gong to alert his neighbours to the theft. Tsai (Wang Di Meng) and his daughter May (Li Li) join the pursuit.

"It's Jade Fox!" Tsai cries.

"We must avenge mother!" screams May.

The thief executes a gravity-defying flip, soaring over a wall and onto a second rooftop, where he or she immediately encounters Yu Shu Lien (Michelle Yeoh). Yu addresses the figure in calm, measured tones.

"Return the sword and I'll let you go."

The figure merely shifts their weight from foot to foot. Eventually, Yu attacks, but the thief dodges every blow. Yu peers hard at her adversary.

"You've been trained at Wudan?"

The figure answers by leaping gracefully onto another rooftop.

See also: Psycho, My Name Is Joe, The Thomas Crown Affair, To Catch A Thief

Don't see also: Blue Steel

Pointless trivia: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon director Ang Lee plans to helm both a sequel and prequel to Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon.

webTitle: Animal rights movement is a haphazard army

fields.headline: Haphazard army with the scent of victory
fields.standfirst: The extreme wing of the animal rights movement is little more than a loose, barely organised coalition
fields.trailText: The extreme wing of the animal rights movement is little more than a loose, barely organised coalition.
fields.body:
Should Huntingdon Life Sciences be forced out of business it would, in the words of one former activist with a record of violent action, "be the most significant victory in the history of the animal rights movement."

Neither side in the protracted battle over Britain's leading animal research laboratory would argue about the symbolic significance of HLS. The scientific community fears that, should the facility close, it would end Britain's reputation as a centre of excellence in science and research. "We'd become known as a world leader in the world of animal rights terrorism instead," says a spokesman for Harlan UK, the leading privately owned wholesaler of laboratory animals, and itself a target.

Such sentiments will be taken as a compliment at the more extreme end of the animal welfare movement, a diverse community that spans a broad spectrum. At one end are the mainstream lobbying groups such as the RSPCA and the International Fund for Animal Welfare (Ifaw), groups that draw on the Brits' soft spot for animals to fuel the letter writing campaigns and placard-waving demonstrations by which they lobby for change.

Away from the mainstream however lies a loose collection of activists, allied more by common purpose than action, who favour more extreme measures. The committed volunteers of the Hunt Saboteurs Association regularly rise at 4am throughout the winter in order to place themselves in between a hunt and its prey. But they rarely go further than obstruction and the occasional scrap.

Other individuals and groups are willing to harass employees of animal testing laboratories and hunts, smash windows at meatpacking factories, firebomb haulage firms involved in live animal transportation, plant incendiary devices under cars and even post parcels packed with homemade explosives, nails and ballbearings.

There has been a spate of such actions recently. Since September three members of the Old Surrey and Burstow hunt have had incendiary devices planted under their cars in attacks believed to be connected to serious injuries received by a saboteur, Steve Christmas, who was run down on a hunt in September. A man has been charged with GBH with intent.

Since December 15, six letter bombs have been received at addresses in the north of England, Wales and the West Midlands. A chip shop, pet shop and estate agency were among the targets. A girl was injured and a woman could lose the sight in an eye.

No one has claimed responsibility for the attacks but North Yorkshire police confirmed yesterday that they believe animal activists are to blame. So seriously are the attacks being taken that, for only the third time in police history, a formal "linked investigation" headed by North Yorkshire and involving more than 50 officers is being undertaken.

The Animal Liberation Front (ALF) is as close as this radical end of the movement gets to an organising force. Founded 25 years ago, the ALF has no membership and no designated leaders. "The ALF could be said only to exist for the period it takes to carry out an act of ALF policy," says Robin Webb, the front's veteran spokesman.

Extreme measures

"We aim to release and protect animals in danger, and support economic sabotage to the businesses and property of animal abusers, looking to put them out of business, but we do not support any action that puts any life, animal or human, in danger," he says. Broadly speaking, fire bombing an empty car is acceptable, sending a nail bomb is not.

Beyond the ALF are groups such as the Animal Rights Militia, the Hunt Retribution Squad and the Justice Department. These groups favour more extreme measures. "They see themselves as like the ANC in South Africa," says Mr Webb. "Their argument is that if you believe that life is of intrinsic value then it is justifiable to commit short-term violence in the interests of a longer peace."

Mr Webb claims the current spate of incidents does not mark the start of an organised militant campaign. Most acts are carried out by individuals or cells of two or three people with limited resources. "You get peaks and troughs of activity and we're in a peak right now. There is an awful lot of disillusionment and frustration around though, and if you are asking is it likely that animal abusers will be assassinated, I think it is probable."

Graham (not his real name) was an activist with an extreme group in the early 90s and admits to planting incendiary devices. He supports Mr Webb's analysis of the current spate of activity.

"The movement is only as organised as people can be botherd to be. We used to plant devices and then read in the papers about being a major terrorist threat - it used to make us laugh," he says. "You can make a firebomb for £1.50, buying all the bits in Woolworths, and cause £500,000 of damage.

"Recruitment is really haphazard and ad hoc. You might be involved in some naughty stuff yourself and spot someone who is quite militant who lives in, say, Middlesbrough. You might pass them a leaflet or a video in the hope of setting up another cell.

"I was recruited like that. Someone sent me a video anonymously with a note that said 'You might be interested in this'. It showed someone making devices.

"These things go in waves. People are part of the same social scene, maybe doing a bit of [hunt] sabbing on the weekend, a bit of grafitti and it grows from there. There's this understanding that people find their level. It might be smashing windows, it might be a nail bomb. Someone has a success so someone else has a go. It lasts for a while and then the police make a few arrests and things go quiet."

But since the early 90s there has been a shift away from isolated incidents towards targeted campaigns of direct action and harassment. Under the umbrella of the Animal Rights Coalition, a loose grouping of activists who share information via a website and newsletter, tactics and methods have been refined to great effect.

Several small animal farms have been closed by these tactics and HLS, targeted by the sophisticated and dogged group Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty (Shac), would be the greatest scalp yet.

Led by Gregg Avery, who was jailed last year for four months after threatening to kill an HLS executive, Shac has some 10,000 subscribers to its mailing list. Around 1,000 people visit the website every day.

HLS has always claimed that its work is crucial in the development of medicines but demonstrators point out that products such as weedkiller, fertiliser and domestic cleaning products are tested on animals there. A Channel 4 documentary screened in 1997 showed beagle puppies being abused by staff, and undercover investigations have produced evidence of maltreatment of monkeys, mice and rats.

According to the Research Defence Association, which represents medical researchers in the debate over animal research, Shac is the Animal Liberation Front by another name. They believe there are a dozen hardcore campaigners nationwide who they will continue to have success in closing down small animal suppliers and breeders unless legislation banning demonstrations is introduced.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday indicated that he would consider new measures. Under the new Terrorism Act, which broadens the definition of terrorism to include "the use or threat, for the purpose of advancing a political, religious or ideological cause, of action which involves serious violence against any person or property", MI5 may have an increased role.

Counter-terrorism and protecting Britain's economic wellbeing are central functions of the service. Should the financial interests of British science be threatened, Shac, the ALF and others may find themselves facing formidable opposition.

Hunger strikes, threats and anger in the world of the activists

Barry Horne

Horne's prison hunger strikes have made him one of the animal rights movement's most famous names. To hardcore activists, he is a prisoner of conscience.

Horne was jailed for 18 years following an Animal Liberation Front firebomb attack on the Isle of Wight, which caused £3m of damage. He has been on hunger strike three times. During one strike, supporters drew up a hit list of 10 scientists and breeders who they said would be assassinated if he died.

During his most famous hunger strike in the autumn of 1998, his supporters claimed he was close to death. But his campaign was undermined by claims that he had drunk orange juice and sugary tea and was not as ill as had been made out. Horne, 48, is in the high-security Belmarsh prison in south-east London and remains a category A inmate.

Robin Webb

Webb has never made any secret of his role as an animal rights activist. As a self-styled spokesman for the Animal Liberation Front, the 56-year-old has long been the public face of a movement with no formal membership.

Believed to be a leading player in the loose network of animal welfare extremists, he says he is the target of MI5 surveillance and warns reporters that his phone calls are monitored.

Webb only concedes ALF responsibility for actions that do not injure or kill, laying more extreme action at the door of anonymous groups such as the Hunt Retribution Squad. He says that in 25 years no-one has been injured or killed as a result of an ALF action.

He claims not to know who is responsible for nail bomb attacks in the north of England: "The ALF would not condemn or condone such actions but we would understand the anger and frustration that would lead people to action of this kind," he said.

Webb was remanded in custody in 1995 for seven months on a public order charge linked to a food-contamination hoax, but was acquitted at trial.

webTitle: Kabila was to blame, Congo rebels insist

fields.headline: Kabila was to blame, Congo rebels insist
fields.trailText: The war in the Democratic Republic of Congo was always personal for Laurent Kabila's enemies. So they were quick to say yesterday that his death at the hands of one of his own soldiers presented a chance to end a conflict that has claimed more than 1m lives.
fields.body:
The war in the Democratic Republic of Congo was always personal for Laurent Kabila's enemies. So they were quick to say yesterday that his death at the hands of one of his own soldiers presented a chance to end a conflict that has claimed more than 1m lives.

Rwanda and Uganda, which back the rebel groups fighting Kabila's forces, swiftly rejected claims from the government in Kinshasa that they were behind the assassination.

Moreover, they said, Kabila had blocked the implementation of the peace accords signed in Lusaka, by refusing to allow the deployment of United Nations peacekeepers, and demanding the withdrawal of foreign troops supporting the rebels.

James Wapakabulo, chairman of the Ugandan government's committee dealing with the war, said Kabila's death had removed a major obstacle to peace.

"The death of Kabila will have drastic implications. His demise could make it easier for the Lusaka peace process to go ahead, as he was its principle opponent. Kabila wasn't letting the UN deploy and he was against the mediator in the inter-Congolese dialogue," he said.

The rebels who control more than half of Congo's territory also spoke of an opportunity for peace now. "Kabila was the barrier to the Lusaka peace process and the resolution of the Congo crisis through peaceful means," Claver Pashi, spokesman for one faction of the Congolese Rally for Democracy, said.

"So it could be a blessing for Congolese people if political engagement and military disengagement takes place," he said. "Hopefully this event, as awful as it may be, could mark the beginning of a new era."

Kabila's allies - Zimbabwe, Angola and Namibia - were more circumspect.

The Zimbabwean president, Robert Mugabe, hurriedly left the Franco-African summit in Cameroon for Harare, where the body of his ally lies in a morgue.

"The allied countries will soon meet before meeting other belligerents to chart the new way forward," Zimbabwe's state radio quoted him as saying.

Most Zimbabweans want their troops brought home from this very unpopular war, and Kabila's death may give Harare a way out. But Didymus Mutasa, the ruling Zanu-PF's foreign secretary, said Zimbabwe will not withdraw its soldiers.

"This gives us all the more reason to stay in Congo, in order to stop further instability," he said. "We went there to promote peace and security - clearly there is not peace and security. We should become more deeply committed."

Much will depend on who succeeds Kabila. If it is his son, Joseph, or an equally belligerent leader, the rebels may see it as their best opportunity yet to try to seize power. Congo's army is demoralised and poorly led and, despite Mr Mutasa's bluster, Zimbabwe's troops do not want to fight.

Botswana's former president, Sir Ketumile Masire, who endured Kabila's ire as chairman of the committee taxed with getting all the parties to talk peace, appealed yesterday for an end to the killing.

"Whatever the nature of the new regime in Kinshasa, whatever has gone before," he said, "I would like to appeal to the Congolese who signed the Lusaka agreement and to the [eight] neighbouring countries who have troops in the Congo to abandon the illusion that warfare or murder can offer any long-term solution."

fields.headline: Kabila's son may have died in shooting
fields.trailText: The government of the Democratic Republic of Congo continued to claim that President Laurent Kabila was alive, if not well, last night even though one of his closest allies said his corpse was lying in a foreign morgue.
fields.body:
The government of the Democratic Republic of Congo continued to claim that President Laurent Kabila was alive, if not well, last night even though one of his closest allies said his corpse was lying in a foreign morgue.

But while almost everyone but Congo's government has come to believe Kabila is dead, there was uncertainty over the fate of his son, Joseph, who may have been killed with his father or may have succeeded him.

The authorities in the capital, Kinshasa, are insisting that Laurent Kabila survived being shot several times by one of his army officers on Tuesday. The information minister, Dominique Sakombi, told state radio that Kabila is being treated in Zimbabwe. In the meantime, he said, Kabila's son is running the country. "The government of public salvation met in special session and decided to entrust the running of the government and the military command to Major General Joseph Kabila," said Mr Sakombi.

But Moven Mahachi, the defence minister of Zimbabwe and Kabila's close ally in Congo's war, yesterday said that Kabila died on the flight to Harare as his poorly equipped doctors fought to save him. Britain has joined other countries in saying it believes Kabila was killed.

Some western and African diplomats said they believed Joseph Kabila was assassinated but a British diplomatic source yesterday said he had been seen in Kinshasa.

An account circulating among Francophone diplomats in Kinshasa has it that Kabila's brutish ways finally backfired when he ordered the arrest of his former deputy defence minister, Colonel Dieudonne Kayembe.

Kabila has had a number of army officers shot for cowardice for failing to obey orders they thought misguided or irresponsible during the war against Rwandan and Ugandan-backed rebels. Some had simply been unwilling to throw away their men's lives.

The publicly cultivated image of him as the great liberator of Congo from the clutches of the late Mobutu Sese Seko does not wash in a country where almost everyone believes he was merely a front man for the Rwandan army when it invaded what was then Zaire in pursuit of Hutu extremists who led the 1994 genocide.

fields.headline: Ombudsman runs out of space
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: An unexpected 30% surge in complaints has left the financial services industry's new ombudsman scheme facing a multi-million pound dilemma: it has outgrown its offices.
fields.body:
An unexpected 30% surge in complaints has left the financial services industry's new ombudsman scheme facing a multi-million pound dilemma: it has outgrown its offices.

Dozens more people are being recruited to tackle a tide of gripes about mortgage endowments, Tessa savings accounts and other investments.

In a candid assessment of its predicament yesterday, the government-established Financial Ombudsman Service said it has squeezed extra staff into its east London HQ but will "run out of space" by April.

The service is requesting a sizeable increase in funding, renting an extra floor at its Docklands offices and plans home working for some staff.

Four floors big enough for 400 staff were taken at South Quay Plaza last May. The unforeseen jump in complaints meant that by December 414 were being squeezed in. Now the total is to reach 470.

fields.headline: Terrorvision's anonymous appeal
fields.standfirst:
Terrorvision
Electric Ballroom
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Terrorvision
Electric Ballroom
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
Expecting Terrorvision to live up to their name by being either terrifying or visual would be asking too much of a band whose primary selling point is a boozy bonhomie best embodied by 1999's fluke number-two single, Tequila. The only British group to parlay similar qualities into an A-list career were the Faces, who had the advantage of Rod Stewart as vocalist in the days when he was sexy.

Terrorvision have neither a Stewart nor a particularly distinctive sound, so even their brush with the top of the charts didn't stop EMI Records from handing them their P45s when their next single collapsed outside the top 40.

They have since signed with a smaller company, where Cliff Richard is a labelmate. They boast that they are the evil to Cliff's good, which, if this tour-closing date is a barometer, is pure fantasy. Leopard-shirted singer Tony Wright and his ramshackle Bradfordians caper on to an old salsa tune and proclaim themselves delighted, grateful, etc, until the evil tally stands at Cliff 1, Terrorvision 0. Still, bearing in mind that everyone in London who can name any of their 14 other singles is here tonight and there's still room to mosh, the foursome put on a plucky show of bravado.

The reason Terrorvision have always been the bridesmaids of UK pop-metal is illustrated right in front of us: despite the accessibility of their chorus-heavy songs, they could be anyone from Aerosmith to the pub band next door. Even their crack at Eminem-style misanthropy, Sometimes I'd Like To Kill Her, is neutered by the predictability of histrionic verse-chorus-middle-eight. Tequila, played without benefit of studio mariachi effects, slips into anonymity, only the refrain "Tequila makes me happy, gives me a high" distinguishing it from a cover of Five's Keep on Movin'.

Terrorvision do, it must be said, have a passionate following who already know the words to the single D'Ya Wanna Go Faster just two days after release, and raise their hands as one when Wright hits the rumbling crescendo of Oblivion. One girl's response is more visceral - she simply screams. As long as they can provoke such rather bewildering emotion, Terrorvision will be with us for a while yet.

webTitle: Bid for Abbey or pull out, Lloyds told

fields.headline: Bid for Abbey or pull out, Lloyds told
fields.standfirst:
Takeover panel demands that £20bn offer be formalised

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The takeover panel is pressing Lloyds TSB to make a £20bn bid for Abbey National or walk away, according to widespread industry speculation.
fields.body:
The takeover panel is pressing Lloyds TSB to make a £20bn bid for Abbey National or walk away, according to widespread industry speculation.

Lloyds has been stalking Abbey for two months, since the target company admitted it was trying to complete a merger with Bank of Scotland. But, while Lloyds has confirmed the terms of the offer it made privately to the Abbey management, it has yet to make a formal bid for the bank.

The takeover panel, which polices mergers and acquisitions, is now rumoured to be considering setting Lloyds TSB a deadline to bid for Abbey, even though the competition authorities have not given the all-clear to that proposed combination.

Such a ruling by the panel would effectively end the three-way stand-off which shows little sign of easing before Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, decides whether the deal should be referred for a full-scale competition investigation. This decision is not expected until the middle of next month.

As Robert Peston of CSQuest.com, a research service for fund managers, pointed out yesterday, Lloyds TSB would make its formal offer conditional on receiving clearance from the competition authorities. Any deal would be expected at least to match the terms of the offer made privately to Abbey, which would allow its investors to receive 260p cash and 1.5 Lloyds TSB shares for each of their shares.

Abbey's plans to merge with Bank of Scotland are rumoured to offer less monetary lure for its investors, many of whom are private individuals rather than big institutional investors. City sources believe this structure of Abbey's shareholder base is causing a dilemma for Lloyds, which would need to canvass support from the 2m individuals who own Abbey shares as a result of its conversion from a building society to a bank more than 10 years ago. This, sources speculate, would make it harder for Lloyds TSB to launch a hostile bid for Abbey National.

Leading institutional investors, however, are said to be trying to encourage Abbey National to enter takeover talks with Lloyds TSB and therefore avoid the need for Lloyds to make a hostile bid.

Abbey National has told the City that it has rejected the offer by Lloyds TSB on three grounds, including regulatory risks. This refers to the possibility that the competition commission would be asked to investigate any competition concerns raised by the combined market shares of close to 30% of current accounts and just under 25% of mortgages.

fields.headline: Emanuel Ax
fields.standfirst:
Wigmore Hall
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Wigmore Hall
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Emanuel Ax is an immensely likable pianist. With his unfussy platform manner and intensely musical playing goes an inquiring mind - his repertoire now stretches from Bach to Birtwistle. He covered one end of that spectrum in his appearance as part of the Wigmore Hall's centenary celebrations. A Bach partita, the First in B flat, was sandwiched between the two books of Debussy's Images, with Schubert's B flat Piano Sonata D960 to make up the second half.

It was a very accomplished recital - but it was not a genuinely memorable one. No single performance really demanded to be heard or cast fresh illumination on familiar musical territory. The idea of separating the two Debussy cycles by Bach was no doubt to provide something cool and rigorous between the highly coloured and perfumed impressions of the images. But Ax's way with Debussy isn't particularly sensuous, any more than his Bach is particularly astringent.

The partita was sometimes perfunctory. And rather than luxuriate in the textures and washes of Reflets dans l'Eau (which opens book one of the Images) or the layered sonorities of Cloches à travers les Feuilles in book two, he concentrated on clarity and line; he built Reflets to a turbulent climax, and made sure the melodic line of Hommage à Rameau was perfectly sculpted, while the perpetual motion of Mouvement was always evenly weighted. The result was monochrome. This was Debussy playing lacking in suggestion and allusiveness, as if this unique musical world had been compressed and simplified for unspecified reasons.

The Schubert, in its way, was lacking a dimension too. Ax seemed intent on showing that the B flat Sonata was not a great innovative work laid out on an unprecedentedly expansive scale, but something that could be related quite directly to the classical sonata. He gave the first movement no chance to develop at its own pace, but hustled the music along, omitting the exposition repeat in the process; he observed the slow movement's andante marking to the letter, and turned the scherzo into a Mendelssohnian scampering. The sonata's timeless meditative power, and its celebration of melody, were definitely out of favour.

fields.headline: Twist's puppetry lacks life
fields.standfirst:
Symphonie Fantastique
ICA
London
Rating: *
fields.trailText:
Symphonie Fantastique
ICA
London
Rating: *
fields.body:
It was the painter Vasili Kandinsky who pushed the visual arts away from being mere representations of reality and into the abstract, and it is clear from his programme notes that the American puppeteer Basil Twist, appearing at the ICA as part of the London international mime festival, aims to do the same for puppetry.

That's fine by me. But this 60-minute underwater fantasia, during which Twist and his colleagues manipulate pieces of cloth and feathers in a large tank of water to the accompaniment of Berlioz's 1830 Symphony, is about as interesting as spending the evening at home watching your lava lamp while listening to a CD. Pretty - but also pretty dull.

On Kandinsky's canvases, the splodges skid across the empty spaces, the colours do the jitterbug or the quickstep and erupt into tangos and tarantellas. Seeing, hearing and moving become one experience. But in Twist's hands the manipulation of inanimate objects becomes merely illustrative. When Berlioz's music is rousing, his feathers or silver balls are duly roused; when it is busy, they jiggle up and down excitedly; and when it is soft the fabrics drift about dreamily.

About halfway through I suddenly realised that the experience had much in common with toddlers' music time at my local church hall, when the under-fives are asked to physically mirror the mood of the music.

For one who is attempting to be abstract, Twist is remarkably literal in his approach. The performance takes place in a tank of water, so what does he give us? Fish. Feathered fish, wispy fish, eel-like fish. But nonetheless fish. Once you've seen him create one or two fish, you know he can certainly do fish. But the fish keep on coming. It is like being at an aquarium, not a theatre.

Actually, it is more like being at the cinema. The major problem with this live performance is that it is inert. It doesn't just lack drama or theatricality, it lacks all signs of life. If it were not for the odd thump and bang from behind the screen, the fact that, if you are sitting close up, you can see some of the strings, or that the puppeteers appear at the end to take their bow looking slightly water-logged, you could be forgiven for thinking that the whole thing was simply a piece of film.

To have achieved this is something of a technical triumph, but what puzzles me is why anyone would want to take this experiment out of the workshop and into the theatre.

After all, it is pretty hard to make out a case for the artistic merit of synchronised swimming, and this is just synchronised swimming for inanimate objects.

I never thought I'd find myself saying this, but this is 60 minutes that starts making you think of Pinocchio with considerably more affection.

 Until Sunday. Box office: 020-7930 3647.

webTitle: Why managing the wealthy is big business

fields.headline: Why managing the wealthy is big business
fields.trailText: Britain's growing number of 'mass affluent' people now not only have to ponder how to spend their money, they also have to decide between a plethora of new banks and advisers, all of whom want to look after it.
fields.body:
Britain's growing number of 'mass affluent' people now not only have to ponder how to spend their money, they also have to decide between a plethora of new banks and advisers, all of whom want to look after it.

The provision of wealth management services has become a major new industry in the UK, but some independent advisers are questioning whether some services provided by banks offer sufficient choice for investments.

Abbey National's Inscape venture and NatWest private banking are among the high street names targeting the mass affluent - or in Abbey National' words, "the privileged many."

Others include Alliance & Leicester, which has also launched a web-based wealth management service and Credit Suisse recently set up a web portal aimed at those with £30,000 or more to invest. This will offer online share dealing in 15 stock market and a supermarket of 175 investment funds.

Halifax is shortly due to launch its offering, a private bank using its subsidiary, St James's Place Capital.

The mass affluent are those with between £25,000 to £250,000 to invest. Many have acquired the money through events that are far from out of the ordinary, such as owning a property in an area where prices have risen steeply.

It is estimated around 11 million people now fall into this category, with around four million people having at least £50,000 in liquid assets.

Abbey National believes this group will grow by 9% a year and that the potential market is worth £600 billion. Two thirds of those who fall into the mass affluent category are male and aged 45 to 64.

But some independent financial advisers are critical of what's on offer. Craig Wetton, marketing manager for Bath-based Chartwell Investment Management says: "Many IFAs are able to offer a virtually the same service to these banks and in some cases it is a lot better. Some banks expect clients to buy their own investment products, which is some cases have performed appallingly. It is not good for anyone to be with a bank that skews its products towards one provider."

NatWest, which launched its private banking arm for those with more than £75,000 to invest has no up front charges, but it does required that at least £75,00 is invested within the NatWest group.

The newcomers have also placed pressure on existing providers of wealth management services.

Martin Smith, managing director of Close Wealth Management, which is part of the private bank, Close Brothers, says he believes many of these new providers will not do enough to educate clients.

"It is vital that clients understand the concept of risk and return and in particular the benefits of investing directly and avoiding hidden charges."

Smith says so-called stealth charges are a serious problem. "We don't invest any of our clients' money in unit trusts, for example. These are not transparent and equally insurance with-profit bonds tend to have lots of charges and be awful investments."

He explains that Close instead uses five model portfolios based on blue chip shares, gilts and investment trusts.

Despite the growth of wealth management services, those at the top of the market say they are not threatened by the new providers. Coutts, for example seeks clients with at least £500,000 in liquid assets.

But Coutts does face a challenge from Rothschilds, which is launching a pan-European venture aimed at the super rich.

fields.headline: Haunting images at the Impressions Gallery
fields.standfirst:
Annie Halliday
Impressions Gallery
York
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Annie Halliday
Impressions Gallery
York
Rating: ****
fields.body:
The photogram was a strange byproduct of the birth of photography: a technique without lens or camera, in which a negative silhouette was cast directly on to light-sensitive paper. Essentially no more complex than making bum-prints on a photocopier, the photogram nonetheless has the potential to transfigure our perception by twisting shadows inside out.

The Dadaists latched on to the artistic potential of the technique first, when Christian Schad produced small "Schadographs" documenting the contents of his wastepaper basket. Man Ray's "Rayographs" pushed the process further by linking these "unconscious happenings in the darkroom" to Surrealism. But it was the Constructivist artist Laszlo Moholy-Nagy who made the connection between the rapid transmission of these images and telecommunications and coined the word "photogram". Former scientist Annie Halliday has resisted the temptation to christen her technique Halligraphy, but she retains the distinction of being the only artist engaged in a modern investigation of the method. The surprise is that the best of her work succeeds because it seems to have derived from ancient and mysterious sources.

The majority of photograms are abstract impressions of inanimate objects. Halliday is adept at drawing streaky, ectoplasmic swirls from careful arrangements of glass objects, like Morandi still lifes in soluble form - but by far the most striking aspect of her work involves the clammy press of wet human flesh.

The standout item, a three-sided installation entitled In the Dark, captures the spectral impression of a woman's body held in suspension like a secular Turin Shroud. It's a haunting anti-impression of a human being, a sarcophagus for someone who is no longer there. The petrified form, distorted like a child's nose against a sweetshop window, could be a fossil, an ancient relief, or the shadow left on the pavement by an atomic explosion. Much as Rachel Whiteread reveals the poetry of anti-matter, Halliday captures the poignancy of our own negative space.

It's a shame Halliday hasn't extended this theme. A room full of these ghosts would have been truly profound; a less inspired sequence of wet feet padding from the shower seems insipid by comparison. In the Dark leaves you hankering to see more of Halliday's soul. Instead we must content ourselves with a glimpse of her bathmat.

 Until March 3. Details: 01904 654724.

fields.headline: FSA explains how it will police listing rules
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The financial services authority, which will be given the power this year to levy fines for breaches of stock market listing rules, yesterday issued guidelines explaining how new sanctions will work.
fields.body:
The financial services authority, which will be given the power this year to levy fines for breaches of stock market listing rules, yesterday issued guidelines explaining how new sanctions will work.

The City watchdog also issued proposals designed to make it easier for young companies to gain access to capital through the stock market.

According to Paul Geradine, the FSA's director of listing, the power to impose fines - which will be granted under the Financial Services and Markets Act when it comes into force in the summer - will be " an important addition" to the FSA's armoury.

"In those instances where the listing rules have been breached, financial penalties will be a very effective way of emphasising our view of the seriousness of these breaches both to those directly involved and to the market generally."

The paper details factors to be taken in account in deciding whether to levy fines and the level of penalty imposed, including seriousness of the offence and whether the action was deliberate or reckless.

An FSA spokesman said the regulator was not drawing up a tariff for offences: "We aren't saying if rule 1:2 has been broken the tariff will be £x. It will be flexible." The FSA would not use fines to make companies insolvent, for example.

The FSA plans to change the listing rules to allow strategic investment companies, which invest and help manage young companies, to list without a three-year trading record. It also proposes more of a disclosure-based approach which will make it easier for science-based companies to list.

Separately, the Forum of European Securities Commissions published proposals to make it easier for companies to make cross-border share offerings.

A "European passport" would allow companies to draw up a single prospectus rather than issuing a separate set of documents in each country where shares were offered.

"The proposals would deliver the objective of home country control of the prospectus for cross-border offerings, while maintaining appropriate protection for investors," said Georg Wittich, Fesco's chairman.

fields.headline: Online shopping 'safe' say Goldfish
fields.trailText: Shoppers who have bought faulty or unsuitable goods from the Internet need have no fears about their rights, provided they have followed basic guidelines, says consumer information provider, Goldfish Guide.
fields.body:
Shoppers who have bought faulty or unsuitable goods from the Internet need have no fears about their rights, provided they have followed basic guidelines, says consumer information provider, Goldfish Guide.

Its "don't panic" message follows the announcements that bulk buying discount company letsbuyit.com and eToys continue to face liquidation threats.

And many people are still too scared to part with their credit card number online. "Our research shows that 85% of people who have not bought online are put off because they would not know what to do if something goes wrong," said Goldfish Guide director, Peter Neden.

But he added shoppers on the internet had exactly the same rights as those who bought in the high street and in some cases were better protected.

This is because those who buy online or from mail order are now covered by the new Consumer Protection (Distance Selling) Regulations 2000.

This means consumers have the right to clear information about goods and services before they buy and e-tailers are required to supply more information if it is requested.

In addition, the new laws give a seven day cooling off period, during which the consumer can cancel the contract.

Delivery dates have also been speeded up and e-tailers must now supply goods within 30 days of the purchase. There is also further protection for those who buy using a credit card.

It is recommended that these are always used when buying online and consumers are entitled to a refund of any money that is taken fraudulently.

All online shoppers are advised to follow basic precautions to make sure they are buying from reputable e-tailers. These are:

 Make a note of any online orders including date, product, price and terms and conditions. Save any emails sent confirming these details.

 Make sure a full postal address and telephone number of the e-tailer is on the site.

 Check the delivery costs and times and ask for the ocmapny policy on refunds and exchanges

 Tick boxes state you do not want your details supplied to third parties.

 Double check with your credit card company to see what its policy is on online shopping

 Only buy from sites with secure servers. Look out for the padlock image at the bottom or the browser. The address in the browser window should also start with https and not http.

 Look out for sites approved by the Consumers Association under the which? brand.

 It is also worth checking out IsItSafe.com, which is a directory of approved retailers.
